webTitle: Still a long way to go before equality is a reality

fields.headline: Still a long way to go before equality is a reality
fields.trailText: Only when every child with a disability has the right to attend a mainstream school will real progress have been made in education, says Rachel Hurst, project director at Disability Awareness in Action.
fields.body:
Only when every child with a disability has the right to attend a mainstream school will real progress have been made in education, says Rachel Hurst, project director at Disability Awareness in Action.

The special educational needs and disability rights in education bill, announced in the autumn, aims to bring this goal closer. The bill sets out to eliminate discrimination and increase young people's access to mainstream education at all levels.

Under the new measures, local education authorities will have a duty to set up a parent partnership service to help solve disputes between schools and parents, strengthen the right to a mainstream school place and make changes to the appeal procedures of special educational needs tribunals.

In addition, "the bill envisages a new age, in which disabled students will be able to choose their university on the basis of the education provided rather than just the facilities that it has to accommodate disabled people," said Bert Massie, chairman of the Disability Rights Commission, welcoming the bill's announcement. The organisation has been charged with producing a code of practice to accompany the implementation of the legislation, early in 2002.

Children with special educational needs, including disabilities, have never had such a high profile within government. But there is still a yawning gulf between the opportunities made available to this group and those on offer to the majority of children.

For years, the education system has failed disabled people, who, whatever their age, are twice as likely as non-disabled people to have no qualifications.

It will take more than the placement of children with disabilities in mainstream schools to close the gap in opportunity, the Disability Rights Task Force pointed out in From Exclusion to Inclusion, published in December last year.

Inclusion is not just about attending a mainstream school, the report said - an inclusive curriculum is an equally important part of the mix.

A survey carried out by the Royal National Institute for the Blind last month highlighted the Task Force's concerns. Researchers found that many blind and partially sighted children in mainstream education were struggling to get the help they needed.

The respondents revealed they were often given educational materials, such as course books, in a format they couldn't read, rather than in large print, on tape or in Braille. More than 30% received test papers in an inaccessible form, and nearly half said their sight affected GCSE subjects they chose.

The Task Force report was taken on board by the government, and many of its recommendations are included in the bill. Schools, local education authorities, and further and higher education institutions will have new duties under the legislation, including taking reasonable steps to change policies, procedures and practices that discriminate against disabled children. They will also need to plan systematically to increase accessibility of schools for disabled children.

Meanwhile, there is mounting concern over the government's plans for revising the code of practice that guides local authorities and schools on meeting special educational needs.

Earlier in the year, ministers promised the new guidance would speed up statementing - the process where children's education needs are identified and assessed - by cutting unnecessary paperwork and simplifying review procedures. But the draft guidance has run into problems. Charities, including the Down's Syndrome Association (DSA), have accused ministers of watering down the guidelines by ending the requirement to specify in the statement how much extra help children with special needs should receive.

DSA chief executive Carol Boys said: "These rights are meant to be protected in law. But if the guidance explaining the law is not in place, parents cannot exercise their rights".

The government says the guidance is still under development and that it aims to strengthen, not dilute, the support available.

webTitle: Disability rights apply to voluntary organisations

fields.headline: Disability rights apply to voluntary organisations
fields.standfirst: Voluntary sector organisations, which were among the foremost supporters of the Disability Discrimination Act, must now implement it in the workplace, writes Bert Massie
fields.trailText: Voluntary sector organisations, which were among the foremost supporters of the Disability Discrimination Act, must now implement it in the workplace, writes Bert Massie
fields.body:
Voluntary organisations were at the forefront of the campaign for the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), and it could be argued that without their efforts the legislation would not have arrived. They also fought to strengthen the Act and to have the Disability Rights Commission (DRC) established. Well done, everybody.

There remains much to do to further strengthen the Act, and the government's indication that it will introduce legislation to bring education within its remit is welcome. Again, voluntary sector advocacy will doubtless help win the arguments ahead. Yet, since the DDA was introduced, some in the voluntary sector seem to have forgotten that the legislation also applies to voluntary organisations.

Voluntary organisations are employers and service providers. If you are a voluntary organisation with more than 15 employees, the Act covers you. You should have reviewed your recruitment practices and you should be making reasonable adjustments at interviews, on internal training courses and when members of staff become disabled.

I wonder how many organisations are confident that they will respond appropriately to requests for application packs in different formats, or sign interpreters at interviews? Do you know what you should be doing, or are you just hoping that you can muddle through? If so, is that wise?

Most voluntary organisations are small, with few or no employees. Eventually even the smallest employers will be covered by the Act. The DRC will be making recommendations next year on how, and when, the threshold should be reduced. A new European directive means it must be removed no later than 2006. The DRC will be seeking speedier action.

If you provide services to the public you're covered by the DDA, because it applies to all suppliers of goods and services, with some exceptions. You may offer advice. How do I get through to your information service if I have a hearing impairment? Is the information you send out accessible to visually impaired people? Is your website accessible? Can I attend your AGM as a wheelchair user? The Act expects you to provide auxiliary aids and services, and to review your practices and procedures so that you can give disabled people the same quality of service as you provide to non-disabled people.

The DRC wants to see the sector take its responsibilities seriously. Meeting the requirements of the DDA is non-negotiable, but how you get there is another matter. This all takes planning, and the time to start is now.

We will work to support and help you. Our website is a good starting point. We also have an advice line and a practice development team who can offer support.

In the final analysis, those who championed the Act now need to show they have embraced its requirements. Any alternative approach will be a failure for disabled people and a failure for the voluntary sector.

 Bert Massie is chairman of the Disability Rights Commission

fields.headline: New name - same old problems
fields.trailText: Today the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals meets under its new name of Universities UK to discuss an old problem: money.
fields.body:
Today the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals meets under its new name of Universities UK to discuss an old problem: money.

Members of the august body founded in....which doubled in size in 1992 when the former polytechnics became universities and were received into the fold, will be discussing a review of funding options.

This work on fees, loans and levels of private and public funding for higher education will, they hope influence the next government after the coming general election. Appropriately the group are also commissioning research on student attitudes to debt. "Universities UK is determined to take centre stage in all the crucial debates which affect higher education," said Diana Warwick the chief executive.

fields.headline: Albertz right floors Germans
fields.standfirst: Albertz 88
fields.trailText: Jorg Albertz ended a frustrating night for Rangers in the 88th minute to give Dick Advocaat's team a fighting chance of progression when they travel to Germany.
fields.body:
Jorg Albertz finally ended a night of frustration for Rangers with a lashing drive from his less favoured and normally incompetent right boot in the 88th minute to give Dick Advocaat's side a fighting chance when they go to Germany next week for the second leg of this Uefa Cup third-round tie.

The game swung from either penalty box at a frenetic pace, and brewed inside an Ibrox atmosphere where yet another 50,000 crowd gathered to beseech Rangers to do something in Europe.

Beyond question Rangers are missing the presence of Giovanni van Bronckhorst, a midfield player surely bound for the Premiership or the continent, whose injury in the mean time is lingering painfully for player and club. Rangers again last night moved with plenty of passion but Van Bronckhorst's incisive passing brings danger to their play.

Advocaat certainly felt the pressure of having to take something from this first leg. For all the Dutchman's talk of German menace, the fact is that Kaiserslautern have been a shambles in the Bundesliga, toiling from one defeat to the next as their new coach, Andy Brehme, has toiled where the ejected Otto Rehhagel also failed. Last night Youri Djorkaeff was skill personified, but the rest of his team-mates did not look so mesmerising.

In the opening half, to Advocaat's frustration, Rangers bludgeoned a whole sequence of efforts wide. Albertz, Arthur Numan and Kenny Miller were the main culprits, although how George Koch in Kaiser slautern's goal was allowed to block Barry Ferguson's drilled shot from six yards on the half-hour was anyone's guess.

The Germans exhibited doggedness as only they can but the nearest they came to stealing the lead in the opening period was when Djorkaeff's firm but poorly angled strike was fisted clear by Stefan Klos.

The Germans did not just frustrate Rangers but had a habit of going down in the traditional mode of being hit by sniper-fire whenever the opportunity arose. A remarkable exponent of this time-wasting was Jorgen Pettersson, who was on the grass so often with so many apparent ailments that it was a wonder he could still walk let alone gambol around Ibrox.

The referee, the famously fussy and pendantic Frenchman, Gilles Veissière, could only endure this for so long before flashing Pettersson with a yellow card. Yet it was a symptom of Rangers' pique that they allowed Kaiserslautern to claw more and more into this match. Only a searching tackle from Lorenzo Amoruso on the edge of his own box prevented Slobodan Komljenovic from barging through on Klos.

Rangers replied with a couple of blasting free-kicks from Albertz and Amoruso but this was an evening of time-honoured frustration for the Scottish champions.

The fact that Pettersson finally paid for his antics with a second yellow card and an ordering-off following a foul on Neil McCann was little consolation to Rangers.

Rangers: (3-5-2): Klos; Amoruso, Konterman, Wilson; Reyna, Ferguson, De Boer, Albertz, Numan; Miller, Mols.

Kaiserslautern (3-5-2): G Koch; H Koch, Yakin, Ramzy; Buck, Pettersson, Komljenovic, Hristov, Grammozis; Djorkaeff, Lokvenc.

Referee: G Veissiere (France).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Uefa to take hard line with Lazio

fields.headline: Uefa to take hard line with Lazio
fields.trailText: Leeds United's Champions League game at Lazio next Tuesday will be carefully monitored by Uefa amid fears of a repeat of the racism which marred Arsenal's visit to Rome in the first group stage.
fields.body:
Leeds United's Champions League game at Lazio next Tuesday will be carefully monitored by Uefa amid fears of a repeat of the racism which marred Arsenal's visit to Rome in the first group stage.

The assurance follows a meeting in Geneva yesterday between the Football Association and senior Uefa officials, who stressed their determination to come down heavily on clubs whose players or fans are guilty of racist abuse.

Lazio could be forced to play Champions League games away from the Olympic Stadium if there is a repeat of the incidents seen in October when Arsenal's black players were booed and Sinisa Mihajlovic was given a two-match ban for racially abused Patrick Vieira.

Those incidents were among several which prompted the FA, led by its executive director David Davies, to raise its concerns with European football's governing body. Emile Heskey was racially abused in Turin last month playing for England and faced similar problems during an Under-21 game against Yugoslavia in March.

"I'm satisfied that the leadership of Uefa are taking these matters very seriously," Davies said after a one-hour meeting during which an anti-racism congress was mooted. "They are monitoring matches in Europe very closely, and this meeting is recognition of a need to be much more pro-active in this area."

Meanwhile, Mihajlovic, who publicly apologised for abusing Vieira and urged Lazio fans to stop booing black players, said this week that Vieira had "used" him to win public support and that his apology had been largely written by the club.

In any event it did not stop a right-wing element booing Bologna's black players last month. Sven-Goran Eriksson named a black player in a squad for only the second time in Lazio's history this week when he called up the 18-year-old Ghanaian defender Daniel Ola. The only other black player to have played for Lazio was the Dutchman Aron Winter, who left in 1996.

fields.headline: Jump off the disability bandwagon
fields.standfirst: Society may been keen to flaunt its accomplishments in giving the disabled access, but all too often the actual people with disabilities get left behind
fields.trailText: Comment: Society may been keen to flaunt its accomplishments in giving the disabled access, but all too often the actual people with disabilities get left behind, writes Polly Eyre
fields.body:
Disability is big news these days. Every time I turn on the radio or open a newspaper, it seems, society's movers and shakers are keen to let us know how disability provision is top of the agenda. Everyone's at it, carving out ramps, installing giant toilet cubicles, laying out Braille signs. Everyone wants a seat aboard the corporate disability bandwagon. So they should, I hear you cry. We live in an enlightened world, after all.

I hesitate to mention it, but it seems there's scarcely any room aboard for disabled individuals. They're left waving their hankies and smiling as the shiny bandwagon tours the district, broadcasting news of enormous achievements in accessibility options, spreading the word that the disabled have never had it so good. Powerful men in suits clutch disability mission statements, proclaiming to the press the progress that has been made, beaming down on cheering crowds. Woe betide you, cripple, if you get in the way of the disability bandwagon!

A few weeks ago, a senior manager at the college of further education, where I teach two evening classes, told me I had a naïve view of disability and the issues it involved. Reeling with shock, I said nothing. He was right - I am naïve. But I felt that what he said was unforgivable - because I am disabled.

I have multiple sclerosis. I have 2 sticks, a zimmer frame and a wheelchair. For the moment I use what I need on any particular day, but I am currently facing up to the prospect of the wheelchair becoming a permanent feature of my life.

I have lived with MS for many years, but it's only in the last year or two that it has started to impinge on my life, slowly draining away my energy, taking the bounce out of my stride. My family and friends have got used to my wooden gait, first with one stick, then with two. It must be hard to know how much help to offer me. Those who know me well put a lot of thought into helping me preserve my dignity.

Disability is a humbling thing. One is ever aware of those who have a worse time of it. I'm profoundly grateful to have had 40 years of walking, swimming, cycling. I'm so very lucky to have three wonderful sons, a supportive husband, enough money to be able to buy aids to make life easier. I'm glad that I am becoming disabled in an age when a wheelchair does not bar me from taking part in life. I have my black days of course, but in the main, life is good to me.

There again, there is no alternative but to accept what life throws at you. You get used to people's sympathetic looks, to people looking away. People helpfully remind you that you still have your brain. Now that really is strange. When your legs don't work, your brain is a little apt to give up trying. The battle that I wage, shoring up my mind against the ravages of a disease that slowly eats away my strength, demands energy, which is in short supply. Writing, not just about MS, is proving to be an unexpected help: my brain and fingers still manage to get it together for a fling every now and then.

Some weeks ago I had an article published in an educational supplement. It was a piece about the personal adjustments I need to make to live and work with MS. I compared my feeling of loneliness at coping with MS with the self-sufficiency needed by evening class lecturers, who are in effect sub-contractors to a college of further education, paid at an hourly rate.

I approached a senior manager at the college to seek permission for a photo on college property to go with the article. Although I was under no obligation to, I gave him a copy, as a matter of courtesy, and in an effort to reassure him. Unfortunately, this culminated in his assertion that I was too naïve to understand about disability.

Before this incident, I'd thought that this particular college was exemplary in its treatment of students with all kinds of disability. How naïve I must be, to presume that I have the right to carry on living without bowing and scraping, without asking permission to write about my disability.

People who know nothing about disability are usually harmless. Those who think they know more about it than the disabled are anything but harmless.

webTitle: Ron Atkinson runs the rule over Arsenal

fields.headline: Gunners fade away with blunt arrows of desire
fields.trailText: Unflagging competitive pride and a healthy dose of blood and thunder - that's what Arsenal need if they are to regain a grip on their season.
fields.body:
It may seem a strange thing to say of a team with one of the country's worst disciplinary records but as Arsenal lurch from defeat to defeat I wonder whether they are showing enough desire and passion to win matches, particularly away from home.

In terms of talent Arsène Wenger's side are equipped to run Manchester United very close but as they sit eight points adrift there is clearly a deficiency and the ability may not be matched by competitive pride.

There is no shortage of determination among the players who worked under George Graham, and that has rubbed off on certain others such as Patrick Vieira. But whereas Lee Dixon shows huge desire, has Oleg Luzhny got the same burning drive when the going gets tough?

Over the years I often thought Arsenal were more of a threat away, particularly when it was backs against the wall. But when I look at their heavy defeats at Shakhtar Donetsk and, in particular, Spartak Moscow I have to question whether they have gone a bit soft.

I'm not sure they have anybody up front prepared to go in and get an eye cut in the cause. Are Dennis Bergkamp, Nwankwo Kanu, Sylvain Wiltord and Thierry Henry willing to throw themselves among the boots where it really hurts?

I see beautiful creative moves and incisive balls played between people for good goals but maybe they need to start scrambling a few. Don't forget they only got away in that Champions League game at home to Shakhtar Donetsk because of Martin Keown's tenacity. When it comes to those red and yellow cards I wonder how many are down to petulance rather than aggression.

There's something wrong when you can't trust such a talented team to win away. It's a surprise when United are beaten but not an eye-opener when Arsenal lose outside Highbury. There may be a need for more blood and thunder but how do you ingrain that in players from different cultures?

A lot of the United lads have grown up together, become used to winning since the youth team and been ingrained with a desperate hatred of failure. That group, which includes Paul Scholes, the Nevilles, Nicky Butt and David Beckham, also have a fierce allegiance to Manchester United.

When it comes to mental strength United seem to have the upper hand, although it helps that they can afford to be more relaxed than Arsenal. Whereas Wenger needs to get more silverware to justify his reputation, United have been there and done that.

They assume it will come to them and feel they will win most of their games anyway. They've lost once in the league and I can't see them losing more than five. It's too early to say the title is decided but Arsenal need to find a higher level and cannot afford to slip up.

Wenger has suggested teams roll over against United because they believe they have no chance. That may have been a wind-up to get the likes of Derby going but the fact is that the teams making life easy for Sir Alex Ferguson are those who should be competing, such as Arsenal, Chelsea and Liverpool. Rather than asking other teams to do them a favour Wenger should be looking at his own side.

Since winning the Double in 1998 Arsenal have not picked up a major trophy and they underachieved last season when they finished Premiership runners-up and lost in the final of the Uefa Cup after dropping out of the Champions League.

Not that they are the only underachieversmaking United's life easier. Chelsea had a great chance to challenge but have made a mess of their season and should never have got rid of Gianluca Vialli. No doubt Claudio Ranieri is a good coach but he needs to get his big players performing for him. The bread and butter of our league sometimes seems a bit mundane for one or two of Chelsea's stars. I exclude Gianfranco Zola but Marcel Desailly, who is the barometer of that side, does not always look as immense as he needs to be.

Nor should Gérard Houllier be saying Liverpool are not ready to win the title. After the time he's been there and the money he's spent they should be running United close. By saying they're not ready he gives his squad a cop-out when he should be making greater demands of them. How Ferguson must be laughing as everyone slips up.

fields.headline: Chelsea part with Niedzwiecki
fields.trailText: Chelsea's goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki has become the third member of the former manager Gianluca Vialli's backroom staff to leave the club this week.
fields.body:
Eddie Niedzwiecki, the Chelsea goalkeeping coach, has become the third member of the former manager Gianluca Vialli's backroom staff to leave the Premiership club this week.

The coaches Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix will have the six months left on their contracts paid off after Claudio Ranieri decided they were no longer needed because he had brought in his own staff.

Amid consultations with the club's captain Dennis Wise, Ranieri offered Niedzwiecki and the fitness coach Antonio Pintus the choice of staying on in "redefined" roles or leaving with a pay-off.

Niedzwiecki has since decided to leave Stamford Bridge, even though Wise paid him a fulsome tribute when asked about his past work at the club by Ranieri.

Pintus, about whom Wise was also complimentary, is expected to give a final decision about his future in the next day or so, the managing director Colin Hutchinson revealed.

He was responding to reports which claimed that a player revolt, led by Wise, had led to Niedzwiecki and Pintus being reinstated by Ranieri after the Italian had initially decided to dispense with their services.

Hutchinson attempted to put the record straight after a week which, even in Chelsea's terms, has been fraught with difficulty amid the pressure of a run of five games without a win.

"Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix left on Tuesday, and their contracts are going to be paid in full," Hutchinson said. "There is no truth in the rumour that there was a player revolt to have them reinstated.

"Eddie Niedzwiecki and Antonio Pintus were given the option of staying on in slightly redefined roles. Eddie has opted to go, while Antonio is still debating and will make his decision in the next 24 hours."

Aston Villa have offered a new 3º-year contract to the England goalkeeper David James, which would keep him at the club until 2004.

Villa's manager John Gregory wants to reward James for his outstanding form since he moved to the club from Liverpool in the summer of 1999.

webTitle: Stockport consider move to Maine Road

fields.headline: Stockport look for the Maine chance
fields.trailText: Stockport are considering a move from Edgeley Park to Maine Road when Man City move out in 2003, and a consequent name change to Man-Stock County.
fields.body:
Stockport could celebrate 120 years of existence by changing their name and moving to Manchester after the club revealed yesterday that they are holding talks over swapping Edgeley Park for Maine Road.

County have discussed the possibility of taking over Manchester City's ground when City move to the 48,000-seat Commonwealth Games stadium in 2003 but face competition from Sale rugby union club. Stockport have proposed that they could change their name to Man-Stock County.

Manchester city council will become Maine Road's new owners when City leave. County's chairman Brendan Elwood said that the club had held talks with its chief executive Howard Bernstein over the proposed six-mile move.

"It's an attractive idea because, to be honest, with the crowds and ground we have at Stockport we've been overachieving for the past few years. We have the smallest crowds in the First Division when you take into account the fact we give away 1,500 tickets for each game," Elwood said. "For those who see Edgeley Park as a sacred ground, I would reply there simply aren't enough pilgrims there.

"Name changes are possible and when we were founded in 1883 we were Heaton Norris Rovers. But I would want to keep some reference to Stockport in the name - Man-Stock County, for instance."

Elwood is willing to ground-share with Sale although the Sharks are favourites as they have the support of City. City councillors will meet on Monday to decide the ground's fate.

Gary Megson has been named the First Division's manager of the month after three wins and a draw lifted West Brom into fourth place. Wigan's Bruce Rioch and Cardiff's Alan Cork won the Second and Third Division awards.

webTitle: Leeds in big push to bring in Robbie Keane

fields.headline: Leeds in big push to bring in Keane
fields.trailText: Leeds underlined their plans for the future yesterday when they opened talks with Internazionale about tempting Robbie Keane back to England.
fields.body:
Leeds United's attempts to chip away at Manchester United's dominance of the English game gathered pace last night when they instigated talks with Internazionale about tempting Robbie Keane back to England.

After concluded a British-record £18m transfer for West Ham's Rio Ferdinand at the weekend, Leeds hope to negotiate a deal over the next few days that would see Keane spend the rest of the season on loan at Elland Road.

The Yorkshire club made their first official approach to the player's representatives and both parties are quietly optimistic about arranging a deal that could lead to a permanent move next summer.

Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman, is now waiting to hear from Inter, although his enthusiasm was tempered by the news from Italy yesterday that eight other clubs - Reggina are known to be one - have also lodged an interest in the 20-year-old Republic of Ireland forward.

Keane has gone on record this week as saying he wants to stay in Milan despite a turbulent time since his £13m summer move from Coventry. But Leeds understand from his advisers that, contrary to his public utterances, he would relish returning to the Premiership when the Italian transfer window opens in January.

After an impressive start to his career with the nerazzurri, "Baby Irish" has quickly fallen out of favour at the San Siro since the coach Marcello Lippi was sacked and replaced by Marco Tardelli.

He was omitted from the squad for the 6-1 humiliation at Parma on Tuesday with what was described as a back problem, although this was widely seen as Tardelli merely resting the Dubliner rather than risk injury when many potential buyers are vying for him.

Even so, Tardelli is extremely unlikely to give Keane a first-team run. "I got everything wrong for the Parma game," said the coach, who rested Christian Vieri and Hakan Suker. "I will play my best team from now on."

Leeds are taking a cautious view over the comebacks of another forward, Harry Kewell, who came through a 45-minute performance in the reserves on Monday, and the midfielder David Batty, who has been out for more than a year.

Batty, 32 tomorrow, has been pencilled in for the reserve match against Sheffield Wednesday on December 14.

The former England player has been training with his team-mates for the last seven days and his agent Hayden Evans confirmed that the player's recovery was well ahead of schedule. "The original date was always February. But we are very reluctant to consider a target for David's comeback to the first team."

The Leeds defender Robert Molenaar's £400,000 move to Bradford City will be completed today after he passed a medical at Valley Parade.

The England coach-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson, whose Lazio side entertain Leeds on Tuesday, expects his playmaker Juan Veron to miss the Champions League tie with injury.

Despite the growing pressure on Eriksson in Rome - which saw his club's president Sergio Cragnotti leave Wednesday's Italian Cup tie with Udinese early in disgust - the coach remains upbeat about his team, even if a poor display against Leeds could well signal the end of his Lazio career.

Eriksson's side could only beat a nine-man Udinese with two goals in the last five minutes. But the Swede countered: "Lazio is a bomb that is going to explode soon - just wait and see."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Physical abuse is a worldwide problem

fields.headline: Physical abuse is a worldwide problem
fields.standfirst: The group Disability Awareness in Action is working to highlight human rights abuses against people with disabilities
fields.trailText: Evidence of discrimination against people with disabilities could fill a courtroom. To mark European Day of Disabled People on December 3, campaigning group Disability Awareness in Action (DAA) has condensed the stories of discrimination into a powerful dossier of human misery. The DAA will present United Nations officials with a report containing information about some of the worst human rights abuses suffered by people with disabilities around the world.
fields.body:
Evidence of discrimination against people with disabilities could fill a courtroom. To mark European Day of Disabled People on December 3, campaigning group Disability Awareness in Action (DAA) has condensed the stories of discrimination into a powerful dossier of human misery. The DAA will present United Nations officials with a report containing information about some of the worst human rights abuses suffered by people with disabilities around the world.

In Thailand, Goy lives in an institution and is tied up every day to prevent him wandering out of the gates into the road outside. "I don't like being tied up, as I get no exercise and it is very boring. I cannot go to visit my friends, or help myself to visit the toilet or get water," he says in the report.

Another boy, Vichien, is bound by his left arm and right leg to a metal bedstead and is forced to lie in a pool of his own urine on a hard tile floor. "Sometimes the staff tie the cloth too tight and my hands become blue and swollen. It is unsafe and uncomfortable," he explains. Fellow resident Jeeab has been trained by staff to remain in the same place, where she also sits soaked in her own urine.

The report was produced in response to the UN Human Rights Commission's Resolution on the Human Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which called for campaigners to keep commissioners informed about discrimination.

Human rights abuses are not confined to the developing economies. In the Netherlands, a 34-year-old woman tells how she had to go to court to fight for an interpreter to help her study at the University of Utrecht.

Initially, the government refused to pay. "They told me, 'you can work in a factory, so why should you study at university?'."

In Australia, a 53-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis, who cannot write or use her hands, was denied the opportunity of a postal vote in a local council election. She asked if her husband, who has power of attorney, could sign and date the voting form on her behalf. The request was denied.

The officials suggested that her husband "place the pen in my mouth, so I can make a mark on the ballot paper and he can then attest to the fact that this is my mark," she said. "I take exception to being asked to make my 'mark' like an illiterate person. I am an educated person and feel this treatment is very degrading."

A 60-year-old woman in hospital in the UK was denied the use of a textphone to call her family after she developed a potentially fatal condition. She asked a nurse to phone on her behalf and request an urgent visit, but the family was not contacted.

Over the past couple of years, the DAA has been putting together an international database of human rights abuses. The organisation has used the Universal Declaration on Human Rights (1948) and the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities (1993) as yardsticks for measuring the treatment of people with disabilities. The database currently contains more than 1,200 reports concerning 2m disabled people.

According to Richard Light, DAA's research director, one of the most depressing findings to emerge from the project is the fact that human rights abuses are 1.5 times more likely to stop because of the death of the victim than as a result of a legal intervention.

DAA project director Rachel Hurst says full implementation of the Disability Rights Task Force's recommendation in the UK would make a huge difference. The Human Rights Act is another tool that could benefit people with disabilities, she says.

The Act has brought new opportunities for people who have suffered at the hands of organisations to seek redress. The Disability Rights Commission, which has the power to take cases up under the Disability Discrimination Act, has asked the government to extend its remit to allow it to use human rights legislation to the benefit of people with disabilities.

fields.headline: Top companies highlight need for equal rights
fields.standfirst: The Disability Rights Commission is calling on bosses and community leaders to champion the fight for equal rights
fields.trailText: The Disability Rights Commission (DRC) will kick off the festive season with its first major campaign in the UK since its creation in April this year. Actions Speak Louder Than Words is an attempt to beef up disability rights in the workplace and the wider community. On December 11 the DRC will ask business leaders and high-profile individuals in the worlds of media, sport and entertainment to make a practical commitment to improve the lives of disabled people - over and above the minimum standards enshrined in legislation.
fields.body:
The Disability Rights Commission (DRC) will kick off the festive season with its first major campaign in the UK since its creation in April this year. Actions Speak Louder Than Words is an attempt to beef up disability rights in the workplace and the wider community. On December 11 the DRC will ask business leaders and high-profile individuals in the worlds of media, sport and entertainment to make a practical commitment to improve the lives of disabled people - over and above the minimum standards enshrined in legislation.

So far, the DRC has signed up Microsoft, Lloyds TSB, the transport company Arriva and the Trades Union Congress. The DRC is asking the top people in organisations to make an imaginative gesture to raise the profile of the fight for equal rights and hoping that this will have a trickle down effect from the boardroom to the shop floor.

Microsoft supremo Bill Gates is one of the celebrities endorsing the campaign. The Royal National Institute for the Blind is joining forces with the Sunderland-based Arriva to create a model bus route in Wakefield, Yorkshire, that is fully accessible to people with disabilities.

The two organisations are looking at bus design, the route, and the ways in which passengers receive information before or during a journey - including audible announcements on buses, and at stops. The aim is to create new standards in service provision that will eventually become the norm for all routes. The DRC says there is a strong business case for maximising the participation of people with disabilities in society. The group has more than just bus fares to pay out - as consumers they spend £40bn a year.

As part of the Actions Speak Louder Than Words campaign, the DRC is launching a new film, Talk, to raise awareness of discrimination. Talk tells the story of the problems faced by an able-bodied man when he wakes up and finds himself a minority in a disability-friendly world. The lead is played by Jonathan Kerrigan, who appeared as nurse Sam in BBC1's Casualty and currently stars in ITV's Catherine Cookson adaptation Dinner of Herbs. The film will also be available as a training tool.

Following the implementation of the Disability Discrimination Act (1995), the DRC was set up to promote the rights of people with disabilities and to lobby for their full participation in society. The Royal National Institute for Deaf People, together with a range of partners including Scope and Mencap, is running the Actions Speak Louder Than Words campaign on behalf of the DRC.

The campaign is one of the first things on the agenda for the DRC's Scottish office, which opens for business this week. A separate base in Scotland will enable the DRC to pursue an equality agenda, while taking into account the different rules that apply in the country - such as Scotland's own Education Act.

A landmark in the battle for equal rights, the employment section of the Disability Discrimination Act celebrates its fourth birthday this month.

There are more than 6.6m disabled people of working age in Great Britain. They account for nearly a fifth of the working age population, according to official figures. People with disabilities are nearly seven times more likely than their non-disabled peers to be out of work and claiming benefits.

Part 11 of the Act makes it unlawful to discriminate against disabled people in recruitment, with terms and conditions of employment, in training, pensions, or dismissal. At first, the provisions applied to companies with 20 or more employees, a threshold that was later lowered to 15 or more. The DRC is consulting on lowering the threshold further.

The DRC's mission is to ensure that as many disabled people who want to work, can work. Recent cases taken up by the DRC include that of Mrs P, whose employer decided that she would not enjoy the job she'd applied for and took an "employer knows best" attitude to her recruitment. A full picture of the progress of the DDA emerges on the DRC's website, which provides details of cases as they emerge.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Ros
fields.trailText: When you go to Vancouver, take a couple of days on Vancouver Island. The ferry trip is quite cheap and you can book a bus all the way to Tofino. Don't underestimate the amount of time you can spend on a Pacific beach without getting bored.
fields.body:
Hi Milly, when you go to Vancouver, take a couple of days on Vancouver Island. The ferry trip is quite cheap and you can book a bus all the way to Tofino. I took this route in the winter of 1999 and travelled through four-metre drifts of snow and rainforest; when I finally reached Tofino, a friend and I spent an afternoon perched on two enormous boulders on the beach writing and talking. The Pacific rolled in to the beach and we both got sunburnt.

Ask the locals where and when to find the whales and sea-otters. The latter tend to play in rocky inlets and will float on their backs and dissect sea-urchins on their stomachs with their paws; I spotted one next to the Wickanninish Inn. Buy a really good cagoule. It rains a hell of a lot out there. Don't underestimate the amount of time you can spend on a Pacific beach without getting bored.

fields.standfirst: From  Peter
fields.trailText: The local news here in Seattle reports that orca whales were spotted yesterday heading this way; you're likely to see bald eagles too, if you take a ferry trip around the B.C. or Washington islands. Enjoy!
fields.body: It seems ironic that you've just travelled nine hours to arrive in... another cold, rainy northern city. But never mind! At least Vancouver has a ski mountain right above it. And Whistler and Mount Baker are not far off. The local news here in Seattle reports that orca whales were spotted yesterday heading this way; you're likely to see bald eagles too, if you take a ferry trip around the B.C. or Washington islands. Enjoy!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Daniel Beeden
fields.trailText: Take a trip across to Victoria; it is a beautiful place, especially around the harbour. There are six Travellers Inns around doing brilliant rates; the downtown Traveller's Inn is on the corner of Chatham and Douglas, I think. Bargain. Also, have coffee and cake at Grabba Jabba.
fields.body:
hey Milly, I read about your trip today and as I went to Vancouver in February, I have a few ideas of where to go.
1) Take a trip across to Victoria, it is a beautiful place, especially around the harbour. There are 6 Travellers Inns around doing brilliant rates, downtown Travellers Inn is on the corner of Chatham and Douglas I think. Bargain. Also have coffee and cake at Grabba Jabba.
2) Take a couple of days out to look around Seattle, I took the Quick Shuttle bus that picks up where you want pretty much in central Vancouver and takes about 6 hours to get to Seattle. Return was just over $52 US. Call 604 940 4428 for bookings. Go to Pike Place Market on the waterfront for all the great market stands.
3) Take a bus across to North Vancouver and Horseshoe Bay (it was No 250 when I went) and get dropped off at Lighthouse Park. It is forest-covered peninsula with loads of trails that come out on gorgeous rocky outcrops looking into Horsehoe bay and on to Vancouver Island. Nicest thing was that I spent the afternoon there and almost had it to myself, weird really as Vancouver is just around the corner. Beautiful place where you can sit and take it all in.
4) Don't even think of missing one of the crepe cafe's on Robson street, excellent food, loads of fillings and great people. Go for Banana and Chocolate.
5) Walk all the way around Stanley Park, just because it's really nice.
6) If you get a nice day (when the mountains behind North Vancouver are clear of cloud) and take a bus up to Capilano Canyon. From there take the cablecar up to Grouse Mountain. The cloud for me, however did not budge so I saw nothing. Hopefully you'll get lucky and will be able to see all over Vancouver.
7) Get hold of Lonely Planet guides-even if you forget everything else.
8) Check with locals and various drivers on what rate you should pay for a cab before committing yourself, or you may get stung. Hope that you have a fantastic time and take pictures of everything and buy loads of souvenirs if you've got room to carry them.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Doug Mercer
fields.trailText: Hey Milly, I just got an email from my sister in London. She gave me your URL so I figured I'd suggest a few tips for your trip to Vancover. I lived there for over a decade. Don't worry about it being too cold. It's essentially about the same winter as in England.
fields.body:
hey milly, I just got an email from my sister in London. She gave me your URL so I figured I'd suggest a few tips for your trip to Vancover. I lived there for over a decade. Don't worry about it being too cold. It's essentially about the same temperature as winter in England, so expect some solid rain and darkness. (It's technically a rainforest climate. Neat bit of trivia, eh?) Things for you to check out:
1. Jump on a bus and head to Whistler. The drive on the sea-sky highway's gorgeous, and whistler's a cool place (although getting a bit too commercial).
2. Go to a restaurant at The Eatery (on Broadway Ave), in kitsilano, and order a sushi combo plate. yes, sushi! trust me, it's awesome.
3. If you want to buy cds, go to A & B Sound on Seymour st, downtown van, where you'll find the cheapest cds in the world.
4. Check out the Capilano suspension bridge. A bit touristy, but gorgeous nonetheless.
5. Check out the Museum of Anthropology at the University of B.C. some really cool artefacts and it'll give you a good sense of the lay of the land and its peoples before we whiteys found our way out there.
6. Catch a flick at the IMAX cinema at Canada place.
7. Catch the bus on the corner of Granville and Broadway that'll take you to the ferry terminal where you'll then jump on the ferry to schwartz bay and bus it to Victoria. Nice place.
OK, that should keep you pretty busy. Have a great time tumbleweeding around, enjoy the city.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Mark and Charlotte Birkett
fields.trailText: Vancouver will be miserable. Get to Whistler YHA via Greyhound (if you can get a place - must book beforehand). It's a beautiful YHA on the edge of a lake with a cosy log fire. Laugh at all the Aussies who've never seen snow before!
fields.body:
We went on a very similar route this time last year. If you're feeling at all disorientated and homesick at all, don't be, it'll be the best six months of your life! Vancouver will be miserable. Get to Whistler YHA via Greyhound (if you can get a place - must book beforehand). It's a beautiful YHA on the edge of a lake with a cosy log fire. Laugh at all the Aussies who've never seen snow before! Tofino YHA on Vancouver Island was more like a hotel, but beware of the gruelling bus journey on winding roads. Worth having a visit to Victoria on Vancouver Island as it's more British than Britain. In Vancouver we stayed at the YHA Downtown too but even if you don't, you have to see if Erik is doing his tours- he's a legend and you'll get to see Vancouver in a different light.

We went to Hawaii from Vancouver - if you can get a cheap flight, get to Kauai, the most beautiful place on our whole trip (Jurassic Park and Indiana Jones were filmed there). The very best tips we were given:
The Great Eagle boat for cruising the Whitsundays leaving Airlie Beach. Loads of dodgy stories from other travellers going on the hundreds of other boats - you'll be guaranteed a good time on the Great Eagle.
Mama's Place on Pulau Besar, the Perhentian Islands, NE Malaysia. How Thailand was 20 years ago, before all us backpackers ruined it!
Hostels change very quickly in Australia - so beware of descriptions in the Lonely Planet etc, go with other travellers' suggestions.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: Mike Campbell (1 Dec)
fields.trailText: Dear Milly, Good luck in your 'netjetting'. My younger daughter lives in Hawaii, where we went for a holiday a few years ago. Make sure you see one of the smaller islands, and I recommend Kauai, where she lives - it's laid back, relaxing and very friendly!
fields.body:
Dear Milly, Good luck in your 'netjetting'. My younger daughter lives in Hawaii, where we went for a holiday a few years ago. Make sure you see one of the smaller islands, and I recommend Kauai, where she lives - it's laid back, relaxing and very friendly! It is the oldest and most beautiful - the "Garden Island" - paradise, indeed. If you ever saw the film 'South Pacific' - your parents did, I bet - then you must visit the beach where she "washed that man right of my hair" - Lumahai Beach. Or see the now empty hotel where Elvis Presley's 'Blue Hawaii' was filmed. And a must see is the Waimea Canyon, otherwise known as the "Grand Canyon of the Pacific" There's so much you can visit on the island, and I recommend the Hawaii Handbook, by JD Bidsignani as an excellent travel companion.

For somewhere alternative to stay, a big recommendation - and cheap too - is the Keapana Centre. A secluded garden cottage , B&B, overlooking lush hillsides, near Kapaa where you get a tropical fruit breakfast and can sit in a solar jacuzzi looking up to the stars, where you can relax, meditate, be at peace, etc! There's no where else in Hawaii like it (001 800 822-7968). You get to Kauai by flying an hour's flight to Lihui.

fields.headline: Chilean lawyers confirm Pinochet trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet is to go on trial in connection with the disappearance of 19 prisoners during the first months of his 17-year dictatorship that ended in 1990, lawyers on both sides have said.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet is to go on trial in connection with the disappearance of 19 prisoners during the first months of his 17-year dictatorship that ended in 1990, lawyers on both sides have said.

The general, who celebrated his 85th birthday last Saturday, has been under court supervision in Chile since last month, while he is being investigated over 177 criminal offences during his dictatorial rule between 1973 and 1990.

Last month, Gen Pinochet made a hesitant admission of responsibility for atrocities the military committed during his rule, saying in a taped birthday message that he accepts "all the facts."

He said: "As a former president of the republic, I accept all the facts that they say the army and the armed forces did." However, he also added that some of the accusations against his government are just propaganda.

According to a report by the civilian government that succeeded General Pinochet, 3,197 people disappeared or were killed while he was in power.

However, any efforts to put General Pinochet on trial are likely to proceed only after neurological and psychological medical tests. The ex-dictator has been recovering from acute pneumonia. The home secretary, Jack Straw, permitted General Pinochet to leave Britain in March this year, arguing his failing health meant he could not go on trial or be extradited to Spain where he faces charges of atrocities.

There have also been extradition requests by Argentina for General Pinochet after an ongoing investigation in Buenos Aires named him as the main suspect in the planning of a car bombing in 1974 in the city. The bomb killed Carlos Prats, a Chilean army general and a leading opponent of the dictator.

Since his return to Chile earlier this year, General Pinochet has been free to travel both in Chile and abroad - although numerous international warrants for his arrest have limited his options.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Carla Mercer
fields.trailText: I lived in Vancouver for a few years and think it's one of the nicest cities in the world. The scenery and the people are fantastic, with some of the best (and really affordable) restaurants in the world.
fields.body: From: Carla Mercer (1 Dec) Hi Milly, I'm a 30-year-old Canadian living in London. Your trip sounds fantastic! You asked for advice about Vancouver. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Kevin Rush
fields.trailText: Vancouver Island (and the boat trip there) is AMAZING. If you can't make it this time, come back another day. Go up to Tofino on the west coast. The most heavenly place to eat is the Wickeninnish Inn overlooking Long Beach, even if it's just for a sandwich.
fields.body:
Dear Milly, I'm dead envious of you in Vancouver. We had our best ever holiday there three years ago. I still look at the weather there every day (my wife thinks I'm sad) so I know you won't be too cold - just a bit damp like at home! Maybe it's a bit cold up Grouse Mountain, but you ought to go up there for the view. Similarly, go and try the suspension bridge at Capilano! Can you do roller-blades? You could skate round Stanley Park like all the other cool dudes. There are so many fabulous eateries it's hard to know where to start, but my two favourites were Isadora's on Granville Island (kind of West Coast-ish) and, for posh, Il Giardino 1382 Hornby Street. Go on - treat yourself on your last night and imagine you're in Tuscany! Better still, find someone else to treat YOU!

I don't know if you're staying in the area for any time, but Vancouver Island (and the boat trip there) is AMAZING. If you can't make it this time, come back another day. Go up to Tofino on the west coast. The most heavenly place to eat is the Wickeninnish Inn overlooking Long Beach, even if it's just a sandwich. They knocked up a veggie creation for us specially and we sat by the panoramic window looking out on the Pacific breakers. It was unbelievable. Anyhow, hope you have a good time. Please excuse my ramblings. By the way, if you're an X-Files fan, don't forget that it was filmed in Vancouver. Check out the seedy back alleys in Gastown for the places Sculley goes unarmed into pitch-black corners looking for crazed, blood-sucking psychopaths!

webTitle: Freedom of Information Act will mean more work for councils

fields.headline: Freedom of Information Act will mean more work for councils
fields.trailText: In two years' time, when the Freedom of Information Act 2000 comes into force for local government, councils face the prospect of a flood of requests for information from local residents. People will under law have the right to information that was previously denied them - and individual departments could bear the burden of the extra paperwork. Though local government is already subject to a powerful openness regime, and will be well on the way to implementing further change when the act comes into force after November 2002, the changes may well add to the administrative burden individual officers already face.
fields.body:
In two years' time, when the Freedom of Information Act 2000 comes into force for local government, councils face the prospect of a flood of requests for information from local residents. People will under law have the right to information that was previously denied them - and individual departments could bear the burden of the extra paperwork. Though local government is already subject to a powerful openness regime, and will be well on the way to implementing further change when the act comes into force after November 2002, the changes may well add to the administrative burden individual officers already face.

Until now openness has always been based on releasing information related to public discussions in committee or full council meetings.

According to Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, the new freedom of information rights mean local people will be allowed access to a far wider range of documents.

He said: "The Freedom of Information Act will create a free standing right of access to documents. The previous rights related to forthcoming meetings. The problem with that is if a subject's not about to be discussed, there's no right of access."

The main points of the act which affect local councils are:

 The act will effectively give local people the right to access the wide range of council information that does not often come up in meetings.

 The legislation will require councils, along with other public bodies, to produce schedules detailing what types of information will be available.

There will, however, be exceptions to the rule:

 A range of information could still be kept under wraps due to exemptions in the act covering, among other areas, commercial interests and privacy.

 Public interest can override some of these exemptions, and councils will take the first decision over what this covers, although decisions could then be referred to a new information commissioner with powers to enforce the new information rights. The current data protection commissioner, Elizabeth France, will fill the role.

Although the act will mean extra work for councils, it will not necessary mean a culture change. Jo Dungey, Local Government Information Unit policy officer, believes councils are better placed to deal with the act than other organisations which are similarly affected. She said: "I hope it will be easier for local authorities to implement these reforms than other areas of the public sector which haven't had a freedom of information regime before."

The government's approach to freedom of information in local government has been somewhat confused. The Local Government Act 2000, running alongside the Freedom of Information Bill in this year's legislative schedules, was intended to allow council executives to meet in private, a move that would have promoted at the very least the appearance of secrecy. Only a government climbdown brought decision-making by council cabinets back into the open, and then only for certain "key decisions" that ministers have yet to define.

This access regime and the new freedom of information measures should complement each other to help ensure the openness and accountability ministers have always said they want from local government. "The act should help ensure the new structures are open," said Ms Dungey.

The government has also exempted Whitehall from the act's tougher regulations by maintaining a veto on releasing information. This will allow cabinet ministers to ignore the decisions of the information commissioner. In reality, the veto will probably not be as powerful as it sounds. Ministers will want to avoid both waging public battles against their own information commissioner, and explaining to parliament why they have blocked information.

This exemption is, however, one of the reasons that the Campaign for Freedom of Information has offered the act only a guarded welcome. Mr Frankel emphasises, however, that this does not mean the legislation is worthless: "This isn't the kind of strong act we had hoped for. But it could still make a difference."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Emily May
fields.trailText: I was in Vancouver this time last year. I stayed in three different hostels (it's good to try different places), one on Jericho beach (sort of nice but quite formal with curfews and a long way from the centre), the Cambie hostel, which was the cheapest and quite central, but not really the height of luxury, and the globetrotters hostel on Granville St (I think that's what it's called) which was really good.
fields.body:
Hi! I was in Vancouver this time last year and as far as I remember it was pouring with rain the whole time (sorry!) I had a great time though. I stayed in three different hostels (its good to try different places), one on jericho beach (sort of nice but quite formal with curfews and a long way from the centre), the cambie hostel, which was the cheapest and quite central, but not really the height of luxury, and the Globetrotters Hostel on Granville Street (I think that's what it's called) which was really good. Brightly coloured rooms, friendly people, no curfew, and staff that organised evening outings (to bars mostly) for guests! The prices were regular for Vancouver (I think about $25 a night or maybe less).

The aquarium in Stanley Park (vast expanse of clean forest surrounded by water) is good if you like fishy things. I'm not sure how correct it is to have a killer whale paddling about in a swimming pool but it is nice to look at. Vancouver people seemed to be obsessed with healthiness and they're all madly exercising every weekend. If you like parties there is a massive underground warehouse party thing going on in Vancouver. (which we found out about from a barman in a cafe). You just go into any record shop (sort of scary looking ones with lots of blokes in) and look for a cheap photocopied flier. They usually involve going to a secret location and being picked up in a white van and taken a hundred yards down the road. You should probably go to something like this with someone else as they make you wait around in some not so nice places.. . Anyway, I thought Vancouver was great, the air was really clean (probably because of all the rain) and although you have to dig a little bit to find it, there is a lot to do there.

I sympathise with you being a young lady all alone in a big city (I landed in LA on my own last summer), but it's so brilliant being away from everyone you know to just be yourself and do what you like I know that after the first week or so (maybe now) it will be fantastic.

fields.headline: Blow by Blow
fields.standfirst: She's famed for fabulous coats but there's more to Selina Blow than that, finds  Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: She's famed for fabulous coats but there's more to Selina Blow than that, finds Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.body:
Selina Blow is usually referred to as a "society" designer, which drives her mad. "The thing is, I've got a posh voice. But I'm not a society person, I'm a textiles person. And I hate elitism because it's just so stupid ." The society label belies the fact that her designs are simple and classic - not at all the sort of frou-frou creations that scream Hunt Ball. Her name is most often seen "in the county kind of papers, walking the dogs, Cotswolds kind of papers. They are very, very nice and they do marvellous things for us but it is good to have a bit of a change, isn't it! Stir the stew, flick the fat out!"

She emphasises her point with vigorous stirring gestures. The one customer in the shop - the kind of well-preserved beauty one finds in expensive clothes shops on weekday mornings, with swept-up hair the colour of Dom Perignon - shoots her an alarmed glance. "Hello!" Blow booms gaily as the champagne blonde makes a rapid exit.

Even though her name is above the door, Blow seems slightly at odds with her genteel Belgravia boutique. Before she arrives, all is calm and quiet. Then in she whirls, carrying six bags, including a leather satchel that spills its contents as she drops it, unfastened, on the floor. She is wearing one of her own coats, in green cord with a tan leather trim, only it is two sizes too big for her, missing a button and covered in white fluff. Her thick black hair is cut into a dramatic bowl shape, like an elegant Blackadder. She is terribly eccentric and terrifically nice. Like a Lewis Carroll character, she talks dizzyingly fast but makes a huge amount of sense.

"What I do is all about tailoring and fabric. I like timeless pieces, clean shapes you can wear with anything." Blow usually teams her own tailored pieces with jeans and men's shirts. And for evening? "Smarter jeans." Her beautifully cut coats, single-breasted, bright and dapper, achieve that rare state of being classic but not boring. They are not cheap, but the price is reflected in the quality of the fabric: the £650 coat is in exquisite red or mustard Harris tweed with leather trim. "It's a strong look but it's simple and sharp, so it appeals to people from 25 to 75," Blow says.

She attributes her passion for fabric to her Sri Lankan mother. On the paternal side, her grandfather was the architect Detmar Blow, her father a historian. Selina's brother is married to the famously eccentric fashion editor Isabella Blow. Selina had no formal fashion training, but produced her first collection in 1992 while living in New York. Her early work sold there to Henri Bendel, as well as to Liberty and Harvey Nichols; she returned to London and in 1995 opened her shop. Now 34, she is married to Dr Charles Levinson, has a young son, Gus, and has recently expanded the business to include menswear and childrenswear.

Her career as a designer didn't get off to a smooth start. The frock coats for which she is best known were rejected the first time she took them to Bergdorf Goodman, the powerful New York store. "They said: 'Honey, we don't dress cardinals,' and sent me home." Now that they are accepted as a classic, the success of the frock coats is beginning to cramp Blow's style. "People always say: 'Oh yes, you do frock coats.' Bloody frock coats. I don't just do frock coats!" She stops and grins. "The frock coat label is part of the society thing. It's just a bit annoying."

Nonetheless the appeal of her style lies in its slightly grand, artistic, ceremonial air. Clients range from Anjelica Huston to Ffion Hague, who wore a blue crushed velvet frock coat at the most recent Conservative party conference. "That was funny about Ffion Hague, she'd just come in and bought it and left. None of that fussing and haggling," Blow says approvingly. "I didn't even know she'd been in."

Blow knows full well that in the fashion whirlwind, having an identifiable, consistent style might not win the front pages but can save your business. "Fashion is just so enormous now. If you get absorbed in trends and seasons, you get in a spin, so I've always tried to stick to a formula. But every season we change the shape of the coats. It's a fine balance - a period accent, but not too much, otherwise you hit panto land."

 Selina Blow's shop is at 42 Elizabeth St, London SW1, 020-7730 2449.

webTitle: US economy worries cause global tech stock rout

fields.headline: US economy worries cause global tech stock rout
fields.trailText: Technology shares fell sharply around the globe yesterday as profit warnings from hi-tech companies and fears of a hard landing for the US economy combined to send investors fleeing from stock markets.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York Larry Elliott  and John Cassy
fields.body:
Technology shares fell sharply around the globe yesterday as profit warnings from hi-tech companies and fears of a hard landing for the US economy combined to send investors fleeing from stock markets.

In a day of frenzied selling the dollar came under sustained pressure on the foreign exchanges amid signs that the euro might have ended its two-year period of decline.

The European single currency rose 1.5 cents against the dollar after a new bout of selling on Wall Street, where Gateway, the personal computer seller, and Altera, the speciality chip manufacturer, warned that sales in the current quarter would be far worse than expected.

Figures showing a rapid slowing of the American economy, with the number of jobless up and personal spending down, added to the jittery mood. The Nasdaq composite index, a benchmark for hi-tech companies, fell more than 4% within minutes of opening yesterday to a 16-month low of 2,592 points.

After a decline of almost 50% from its March high, the index is on course for the worst annual performance in its 29-year history. Yesterday's drop was its ninth decline in 10 trading days.

Blue chips were also hurt by fears that US consumers and companies had stopped spending. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell almost 1% yesterday morning. Technology shares in London and on other European markets were also under pressure.

The Techmark index in London closed down 2.77% at 2,467.75, having fallen every day since November 5.

Several well known and widely held stocks were among the biggest losers.

Microchip designer Arm Holdings lost 5.4%, Irish e-security expert Baltimore Technologies slipped 8.8% and online auctioneer QXL.com continued its miserable run by slumping 30%.

Optical networking specialist Bookham Technologies slipped further under its issue price with a 10% fall, while punters' favourite Durlacher lost 12% to close at 27.5p.

Some stocks managed to reverse the trend: CMG added 32p to close at 880p, Marconi put on 24p to close at 670p and Energis edged up 14p to end at 449.5p.

Oil prices hardened after Iraq threatened to halt exports of crude from last night unless the United Nations agreed to a new price formula.

On the foreign exchange markets, the euro was underpinned by comments from the European Central Bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, who said the single currency was under-valued.

"We can therefore expect a correction - the euro has a strong margin for appreciation," he said.

webTitle: Interpublic set to buy out Deutsch

fields.headline: Interpublic set to buy out Deutsch
fields.trailText: 8am: Communications giant Interpublic Group is set to acquire advertising agency Deutsch for £200m, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Deutsch, one of the last big independent US advertising agencies, is about to be swallowed up in a £200m-plus takeover.

The Interpublic Group, the world's third largest communications giant after Omnicom and WPP, is expected to announce the completion of the deal by the end of the week.

The Deutsch boss, 43-year-old Donny Deutsch, owns roughly 87% of the £1bn agency, with the remaining equity shared among five partners - Linda Sawyer, general manager; Val DiFebo, director of account management; Peter Drakoulias, director of new business development; Cheryl Greene, chief strategy officer; and Kathy Delaney, executive creative director.

Deutsch, which counts Mitsubishi, Pfizer and Domino's Pizza among its clients, has long been considered a plum acquisition target and has been approached by a number of holding companies over the years.

The Interpublic deal will allow the company to expand globally.

Interpublic boss Phil Geier has been courting the agency since an initial meeting early last year.

IPG owns two other agency networks - Lowe Lintas & Partners and McCann-Erickson.

Under the terms of the deal, it is understood that Deutsch will remain a standalone agency alongside the two existing companies.

Deutsch, which counts Mitsubishi, Pfizer and Domino's Pizza among its clients, has long been considered a plum acquisition target and has been approached by a number of holding companies over the years. The Interpublic deal will allow the company to expand globally. Interpublic boss Phil Geier has been courting the agency since an initial meeting early last year. IPG owns two other agency networks - Lowe Lintas & Partners and McCann-Erickson. Under the terms of the deal, it is understood that Deutsch will remain a standalone agency alongside the two existing companies.

fields.headline: Ill-fitting fashion firm restyled
fields.standfirst: City smitten by celebrity label
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores yesterday confirmed that it wants to cash in on the Burberry brand, which has been so swiftly turned from home counties to high fashion. The credit for the reversal of fortunes goes to Rose-Marie Bravo, the New York fashion retail guru who has engineered the about turn - and to former GUS chairman Lord Wolfson, who hired her.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores yesterday confirmed that it wants to cash in on the Burberry brand, which has been so swiftly turned from home counties to high fashion. The credit for the reversal of fortunes goes to Rose-Marie Bravo, the New York fashion retail guru who has engineered the about turn - and to former GUS chairman Lord Wolfson, who hired her.

Burberry is now a status brand with rapidly growing profits. The City is as smitten as the label's big celebrity following and believes it could be valued at £2bn - or 200p of GUS's current 528p share price.

Some analysts reckon that is still cheap - certainly compared to Gucci and LVMH - but they are more mature businesses and they have more than one brand in their portfolios.

So it is not exactly clear why GUS chief executive John Peace wants to wait another 18 months to cash in or why he has decided to sell only 25% of the business.

Burberry is certainly not a great fit with GUS's bread and butter businesses of catalogue shopping and credit information. And 18 months is a very long time in the here today gone tomorrow fashion business. It is all very well for Mr Peace to insist he wants his shareholders to share in the upside potential of the brand, but he cannot be certain it will ever materialise.

Yesterday Ms Bravo, described as a "dynamo" of a woman, was in full-on overdrive. Her plans now know no bounds. She envisages babies bundled up in Burberry beige, and Burberry home furnishings.

She rattled off a lengthy list of the world's smartest cities where she wants flagship stores before drawing breath to say that she had not mentioned Mexico, South America, and so on.

Such grand plans will require equally large scale investment.

Yesterday GUS insisted it would not countenance a trade sale of the business unless a bidder opened its wallet extremely wide. Investors should be hoping someone will come up with the required mountain of cash.

On the block

The online auctioneer QXL.com yesterday attempted to end months of uncertainty about its future by announcing a £30m fundraising that should see it through to profitability.

The market responded by slashing a further 30% off its already bruised and battered share price. The shares now stand at 17p, or 98% off the one time high of 800p. And still stockbrokers are advising clients to bail out.

Jim Rose, QXL.com's relentlessly upbeat chief executive, passionately believes that the sell-off has been overdone. He says that some analysts have misread the latest set of quarterly results which show losses spiralling ever wider.

He still even talks enthusiastically about European domination. He is ready to hit the road and tell investors, analysts and traders exactly why.

He needs to hurry up. If you are a pension fund manager it just does not do to have a shattered dot.com among your picks of the market.

Mr Rose is going to have to come up with something pretty special to get the City back on board.

Bite back

The financial services authority yesterday took a bite out of insurer Royal Scottish Assurance just weeks after being accused of being toothless in its handling of the endowments scandal.

Royal Scottish, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland group, was handed a record £2m fine, will have to pay £50m compensation and has been ordered to overhaul the business.

The regulator said the action demonstrates its commitment to securing a fair deal for mortgage endowment holders who have lost out and now face a shortfall in paying off their home loan. Many thousands of people with underperforming endowment policies bought from other firms will doubtless be cheered by yesterday's announcement, and may well assume it means they are a big step closer to receiving justice themselves. It is an impression the FSA will probably not want to dispel.

But this is not a test case. It is a one-off and is not actually anything to do with mis-selling. Among an extensive list of failings, RSA staff made horrendous miscalculations in the premiums policyholders had to pay - they were set much too low. Then the company was economical with the truth when it wrote to some of the policyholders to suggest that they had better pay some more money in sharpish if they want to hit the target sum.

The errors stretched over an astonishingly long period of time - more than four years. And full details only emerged yesterday, more than a decade after the first mistakes were made.

Where were the regulators when all this was going on?
