fields.headline: Burberry's £2bn return
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores has announced plans to cash in on its Burberry luxury clothing brand with a partial flotation that could value the famous label at up to £2bn.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores has announced plans to cash in on its Burberry luxury clothing brand with a partial flotation that could value the famous label at up to £2bn.

GUS, whose other business interests range from home shopping catalogues to credit information, yesterday confirmed plans to sell up to 25% of the Burberry business within 18 months.

The huge price tag put on the label represents a complete turnaround in the fortunes of the Burberry business. Only three years ago it was viewed as a bombed-out brand of trench coat favoured by aging businessmen. Now it is one of the hottest fashion labels in the market.

The trademark plaid adorns everything from bandanas to spike-heeled boots, and is a must-have in the wardrobes of rock stars and royalty. Prince William, Madonna, Claudia Schiffer and Posh Spice are all fans of the Burberry beige.

The transformation has been engineered by Rose-Marie Bravo, an American fashion retail expert imported to GUS in 1997. Yesterday she said that Burberry had "only scratched the surface" of its potential and that she had plans to open stores worldwide, extend the brand into new sectors such as babywear and home wares and build the label into a luxury icon like Louis Vuitton and Tiffany.

"Wealth creation and the demand for luxury brands is not going to go away", she said. "Status is one of the things that people look for, whether it is a Mercedes, a diamond ring or a Burberry handbag."

Burberry's sales have soared 38% in the past six months and its profits have climbed from £4.3m to £26.6m, although some £8m of that was result of buying back Burberry's franchised business in Spain.

Only a year ago some City analysts had valued the Burberry business at just £200m, but yesterday there were estimates that it could be valued at anything between £1bn and £2bn. GUS chief executive John Peace said the group had not yet decided how it would use the £250m to £500m it could rake in from the float.

John Baillie of SG Securities described Burberry as the "hottest luxury goods brand around" and said his £2bn valuation was conservative.

Burberry trades from 70 stores around the world, with 25 in major cities. It recently opened a new flagship London store on Bond Street, will open in the Ginza district of Tokyo later this month and has plans to double the size of its store in New York.

But Ms Bravo wants much more. "Retail is the engine for luxury brands", she said, and outlined ambitious plans for outlets in Milan, Miami, Los Angeles, Rome and Madrid. "The sky is the limit," she said.

Some analysts criticised GUS's decision to delay the float for up to 18 months, believing the company should cash in while the going is good.

But John Peace said: "We are being prudent. We don't want to rush or do anything that might spoil the momentum of the business." He added that GUS was only selling a minority stake because he believed the brand had "very significant up side potential".

He said he had not received approaches from luxury combines such as LVMH for an outright sale of the business, and had no plans to build his own stable of luxury brands.

The Burberry float was announced as GUS revealed half-year profits up from £176m to a better than expected £181m.

The group's credit data business Experian recorded profits up 5% and its new Reality offshoot, which offers everything from website design to delivery, is "making good progress".

Label came in from the cold

 Thomas Burberry founded the business 134 years ago when he opened an outfitter's shop in Basingstoke, Hants

Burberry became a limited company and floated on the London Stock Exchange in 1920

Its trench coat was the peak of fashion in the 1940s and 1950s, as worn by Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman in the film Casablanca

The company was bought by GUS in 1955

Burberry went into food in 1987, selling preserves, mustards, teas and biscuits in a strategy of "expansion with discretion"

By the mid-1990s the brand had become tired and GUS hired Rose Marie Bravo , who had spent five years at the helm of New York's Saks Fifth Avenue department store, to revitalise the label

In 1997 Burberry's profits slumped from £62m to £25m.

Burberry recently introduced a unisex perfume called Burberry Touch

 Roberto Menichetti is responsible for Burberry's designer collections

webTitle: Fleet Street is stuck in the past

fields.headline: Fleet Street is stuck in the past
fields.standfirst:
The Race in the Media Awards are a worthy cause, writes Martin Bright, but newspapers still have a long way to go.
Special report: race in Britain
fields.trailText: The Race in the Media Awards are a worthy cause, writes Martin Bright, but newspapers still have a long way to go.
fields.body:
The season of media awards has begun. From now until the spring, journalists will pat each other on the back at lavish dinners at posh hotels and no one but them will really care.

Journalists are sensitive, insecure creatures who need constant reassurance. But some of these awards are less incestuous and self-serving than others: already this week I have attended the Drugscope awards (newspaper of the year, the Guardian), which promote responsible reporting of drug issues. There could hardly be a more worthy goal.

The Commission for Racial Equality's Race in the Media Awards are a similarly honourable exception. In a sign of the awards' growing importance, a promotional reception was held at 11 Downing Street last night, hosted by Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown.

Stars from East Enders, Brookside and Coronation Street were there to publicise a new award for soaps. This in turn promoted an appearance from Cherie Blair and her children, who were keen to meet the only people in the country as famous as they are. London mayor Ken Livingstone and nightclub owner Peter Stringfellow stood and watched the new CRE video in which computer technology turns them Asian and black respectively.

But despite this parade of politicians and personalities, it was noticeable that apart from Independent columnist Yasmin Alibhai-Brown, there was not a single prominent national newspaper journalist present at the Downing Street reception.

As far as race is concerned, media institutions, and newspapers in particular, remain some of the least enlightened corners of society. This is true of the Daily Mail's campaign against asylum seekers, but it also finds its expression in more subtle ways, such as the employment practices of most newsrooms in the country, where it is still unusual to see a black or Asian face.

There is still a long way to go before editors can claim they have really got to grips with the institutional racism at the heart of Fleet Street.

webTitle: Celebrities take on new look in anti-racism adverts

fields.headline: Celebrities take on new look in anti-racism adverts
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: They had to sit still in a dentist-style chair for more than 30 minutes but it was enough for the special effects wizards to transform Spice Girl Mel B, into a white woman with blonde hair and Chris Evans into a black man as part of a TV campaign against racism.
fields.body:
They had to sit still in a dentist-style chair for more than 30 minutes but it was enough for the special effects wizards to transform Spice Girl Mel B, into a white woman with blonde hair and Chris Evans into a black man as part of a TV campaign against racism.

The advertisements, which "morph" the racial characteristics of British celebrities, were conceived by the commission for racial equality, whose campaigns have a reputation for using shock tactics.

The campaign, which is broadcast from tonight, will also show a white Lennox Lewis, a blonde-quiffed, blue-eyed Prince Naseem Hamed, a black, naked Peter Stringfellow and an Asian Ken Livingstone. A digitally altered Chris Evans asks if people would still find him annoying if he was bald and black.

More than a year was spent trying to find body doubles of different races who had the same facial dimensions as the celebrities. The stars' facial features were filmed and transferred to the body doubles.

The director, Laurence Dunmore, said: "Certain people were difficult to change - we shot three doubles for Chris Evans."

David Seaman, who was transformed into a rasta with dreadlocks, said he had been tempted to keep the make-up on and get some petrol on the way home.

fields.headline: Emap pulls plug on indie bible Select
fields.trailText: 5pm: Britpop champion Select magazine is to close just seven months after a high-profile redesign, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Indie bible Select has hit the rocks just seven months after a high-profile redesign to boost sales.

Staff have been told that Emap is pulling the plug on the magazine that came to symbolise the Britpop movement.

The publisher has promised to relocate journalists on other music titles such as Mixmag, Q or Kerrang or special projects due to launch next year.

It is understood that Select's editor, former Mixmag deputy Alexis Petridis, has been approached by TV production companies about a presenting job.

Emap managing director for rock, Dave Henderson, issued a statement this afternoon saying: "Market conditions mean that the indie sector, which Select emphatically championed, has been completely absorbed into the mainstream, illustrated by the huge success of the magazine's core bands - Oasis, Blur and Radiohead."

Select, which was launched in the mid-90s when bands such as Blur and Oasis were hugely popular, saw its sales decline by 21% at the last ABCs.

Mr Petridis was brought in in March to oversee a relaunch designed to reverse the sales decline. He attempted to make the magazine more responsive to the growing numbers of music fans using the internet and introduced MP3 and online sections.

But according to insiders, research carried out by Emap demonstrated that Select had lost its brand value.

The magazine's closure is being seen as symbolic of the fragmentation of both the music and the magazine industries.

Interviewed earlier this year about Select, former Q editor Andy Pemberton said: "In 1995 and 1996 we had this incredible moment when we all agreed about everything. Most people voted Labour. Everybody liked Oasis.

"There was Britpop, and Brit Art, and Chris Evans. So it was an incredible time - a sort of spasm of excitement. In comparison, you could say that now is a bit boring, frankly."

webTitle: The Big Match,  Heart Of The Matter, and  Eurotrash

fields.headline: The Big Match,  Heart Of The Matter, and  Eurotrash
fields.trailText: DON'T COCK A SNOOK AT OUR COCKY COCKNEY SCOOP
fields.body:
DON'T COCK A SNOOK AT OUR COCKY COCKNEY SCOOP

The Fiver isn't the sort of smart-arsed publication which says "we told you so". That's because we usually cock everything up well true and proper. But even on the odd occasion like yesterday when we call it right - and who else could possibly have guessed that talks between north-eastern football club Middlesbrough and professional cockney Terry Venables would have broken down? - we're not the sort of folk who like to go on and on and on about it.

So we're not going to make a big thing about Venables choosing his role as resident ITV bore over the as-good-as-vacant manager's job at Middlesbrough. We're not going to puff out our chests proudly as we quote clearly exasperated Boro chief executive Keith Lamb explaining how the Teesiders "have concluded that Terry's present and future television commitments are incompatible with the role we were offering him".

We're saying nothing as Tel's crony Ted Buxton explains how the Boro job would have been "massive ... but obviously there are things there that weren't right for him, and he didn't feel it was the right time to go. I think he would have liked to have been able to do the two jobs, but obviously that wouldn't have been right for Middlesbrough or Terry." And we certainly won't be taking any cheap shots at lame-duck manager Bryan Robson during the rest of Boro's relegation season.

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Click here for December 1

THEY PLAY IN BLUE, YOU SEE

After losing the only coach to win them a trophy in the past four decades, you could be forgiven for accusing Heart of Midlothian of lacking ambition. But you'd be wrong. Because today the Edinburgh "giants" shook the world of football by appointing the manager of Brazil as their new boss! What's that? Look, we're trying to write a tea-time take on the world of football here. What? Oh.

Er ... in fact, they've appointed the manager of Blue Brazil. Sorry about that. Yes, the Jambos have chosen Cowdenbeath boss Craig Levein to be their new head coach. Levein, who made 401 appearances in the Hearts defence, has been rewarded with his dream job after guiding the club with the most "ironic" and "amusing" nickname in football to the top of the Scottish Third Division.

"I wish him all the best," said his predecessor Jim Jefferies, now at Bradford. "He will find a big difference in divisions from Cowdenbeath to Hearts - it is a big jump up - but I am sure he will do well. He will make his own decisions in his new job and I am sure he will be a success." We're sure he'll do well too. In fact, the only problem we can envisage is an inability to come up with a suitably daft wee monicker for his new charges. Maroon Argentina? Post-modern France?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We've put Dickov in for a 50,000-mile service. He's run that far for us this year. He's been running for two at times. Credit to the little fella, he's been magnificent and he's just having a rest for a couple of games" - Joe Royle knows that if you're going to drop someone for Shaun Goater, make sure you've got a damn fine excuse to hand.

GIN'S TONIC

Earlier this week, the Fiver received a call from a man with a heavy Gallic accent who described himself only as a "friend of the enigmatic one". For a brief moment, we were excited. "What does Antoine de Caunes want with us?" we asked, as an appearance on Eurotrash beckoned. Alas, it was not to be. Because the heavily accented man wasn't talking about M de Caunes but David Ginola - Aston Villa's overpaid, underplayed and over-the-hill winger!

Judging from the comments of Appy Arry's Ammers manager Arry Redknapp - who claimed this morning that "Ginola was offered to us by one of his mates" - we weren't the only ones he was being touted to. But it's amazing what the promise of a place in the starting line-up can do for you, because after stropping around like a large camel all week, Ginola was today all smiles. "I'm very happy at Aston Villa - and don't want to leave," he said, flicking his hair in a teasing manner. "There is absolutely no truth in the stories whatsoever. I'm very happy at Villa and I'm looking forward to playing in tomorrow's game with Newcastle."

But David wasn't finished there. Suddenly his voice changed, and the UN minesweeper patter took over. "Whenever a famous player isn't in a team, people make up stories and create situations that don't really exist. In this case it has been pushed to the limit - and I am very angry about it," he whined. "For me, everything about the club is tremendous and I don't want to leave Aston Villa," he purred. "All I want is to see is Villa being successful - with me a part of it," he concluded before loading up Championship Manager 3.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Another day, another Ronaldo rumour. This time it's Chelsea who are "planning an audacious raid" to bring the Brazilian striker on loan from Internazionale, according to reports.

More likely is the news that Claudio Ranieri is interested in bringing Robbie Keane on loan to Stamford Bridge. Chief executive Colin Hutchinson admitted: "We are currently looking at various playing options. We are monitoring the situation regarding Robbie Keane and have been in touch with Inter about him."

Leicester have denied reports that they have agreed a £5.5m with Celtic for Neil Lennon, although Teamtalk claims the Northern Ireland international is in Glasgow for talks.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ipswich manager George Burley and Leeds goalkeeper Paul Robinson have picked up the Carling Manager and Player of the Month awards for November respectively.

Coventry have completed the £2m signing of Blackburn midfielder Lee Carsley.

Robert Molenaar has joined Bradford from Leeds in a £500,000 deal.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is hoping to sign Chinese international defender Sun Jihai, who has been on trial at St James' Park. "Jihai would be a real asset," said Robson. "We were only allowed to look at him for a maximum ten days but he was fine and we liked what we saw. He's dynamic, enthusiastic, quick, strong and the only area where he needs quite a bit of work is in the air."

Walsall have signed former Barcelona, Southampton and Toulouse midfielder Ronnie Ekelund on a short-term contract.

Blackburn winger Keith Gillespie has joined Wigan on a month's loan.

Charlton striker Kevin Lisbie has joined QPR on a month's loan.

Keith Burkinshaw has resigned as Aberdeen's director of football.

fields.headline: BBC apologises over Millionaire
fields.standfirst: Nov 21: Liddiment hits back
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: The BBC has apologised to ITV over suggestions that Who Wants to be a Millionaire? was rigged, reports Jason Deans.

Nov 21: Liddiment hits back
fields.body:
The BBC has formally apologised to ITV over suggestions that the game show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? was rigged to get the first millionaire winner.

The apology relates to comments attributed to BBC sources about last Monday's edition of the blockbuster ITV game show, in which Judith Keppel became the first contestant to win £1m.

The show was scheduled against the last ever episode of BBC1 comedy One Foot in the Grave.

In a humiliating public U-turn, the BBC said it "does not believe there was any 'manipulation' or 'fixing' involved in Millionaire?".

It added: "Can we make it absolutely clear that any such suggestion did not represent the official view of the BBC.

"We can only apologise to all involved for the subsequent press coverage and any harm it has done."

The original comments were attributed by the BBC to an "overzealous press briefing", which suggested Millionaire's previous big winners had coincided with high-profile BBC programmes, "inviting some journalists to draw the inference that this might be more than a coincidence".

"This was wrong. We have already taken steps to ensure that this kind of incident is not repeated," the BBC said.

The corporation said that it "should simply have acknowledged - as a point of fact - that the first £1m winner on Millionaire coincided with the final episode of One Foot in the Grave.

"We should also have given more emphasis to the fact that Monday's schedule on both channels was a fantastic night for viewers - ITV had its flagship quiz show and BBC1 had distinctive comedy."

David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, last week described the BBC comments as "very childish" and "petty".

The BBC's apology follows a complaint last week from ITV chairman Leslie Hill, who wrote to Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the corporation.

An ITV spokeswoman said: "We said at the time these suggestions were completely unfounded and so are grateful to the BBC for setting the record straight."

A BBC spokeswoman said that the corporation was still investigating what happened as part of a thorough review.

fields.headline: Asian Ken and black Evans star in race ads
fields.standfirst:
Useful link: CRE website
Special report: Race in the media
fields.trailText:
8.15amGail Porter, Mel B and Chris Evans change the colour of their skin in a commercial for the Commission for Racial Equality, reports Claire Cozens.
Useful link:
Useful link: CRE website
Special report: Race in the media
fields.body:
Celebrities including Gail Porter, Mel B and Chris Evans are to change the colour of their skin in a high-tech commercial for the Commission for Racial Equality.

The ad, which airs for the first time tonight on Channel 4, is designed to force viewers to question their preconceptions about race.

It brings together stars as diverse as Chris Evans, Ken Livingstone, Peter Stringfellow and David Seaman.

Viewers will see a white Lennox Lewis, a Chinese Gail Porter, an Asian Ken Livingstone and a black Chris Evans. A white Prince Naseem appears with blue eyes and a blonde quiff and Spice Girl Mel B becomes a white woman with long blonde hair.

A naked black Peter Stringfellow will ask viewers whether they find him "more irresistible" in his new guise.

CRE chairman Gurbux Singh said: "In the past few weeks we have seen a number of national opinion surveys, which revealed the continuing high levels of prejudice in Britain and the harmful nature of those ideas."

The CRE ran into trouble two years ago when it ran a poster campaign that used deliberately racist images.

The police were forced to intervene after they received a barrage of complaints. The posters were replaced the following day with new ads that questioned people's responses to the original images.

webTitle: Cambridge Two won't have to make prison return

fields.headline: Cambridge Two won't have to make prison return
fields.standfirst: More about the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: Charity managers Ruth Wyner and John Brock, jailed for allowing drugs to be peddled at a Cambridge hostel for the homeless, were today told by the court of appeal that they would not have to return to prison.
fields.body:
Charity managers Ruth Wyner and John Brock, jailed for allowing drugs to be peddled at a Cambridge hostel for the homeless, were today told by the court of appeal that they would not have to return to prison.

Although three judges in London reserved their decision on the appeals against conviction brought by the pair - who were released on bail in July pending today's hearing - they made the dramatic announcement that the sentences imposed on Ms Wyner and Mr Brock, both 50, were "far too long".

William Clegg QC, prosecuting, told the judges that, if they were to quash the convictions, the Crown would not apply for a retrial.

Lord Justice Rose, sitting with two other judges, said the court was going to take time to consider its judgement on the appeal against conviction, but said, "we are not minded... to send the appellants back to prison".

The so-called Cambridge Two, Ms Wyner and Mr Brock were freed on bail in July by the court of appeal. However, they were warned that they might have to return to prison if they failed in their challenge to convictions of knowingly permitting the supply of heroin at the Winter Comfort Centre.

Ms Wyner, director of the centre, was jailed for five years last December. Mr Brock, a manager, was sentenced to four years.

They were present in court today for the hearing before Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Longmore and Mr Justice Ouseley.

In July the pair were granted leave to appeal on the grounds that the presiding judge at their King's Lynn crown court trial wrongly barred the jury from considering subjectively a major plank of the defence case.

The charity had operated a policy of confidentiality under which information about the homeless and vulnerable people who attended the centre would not generally be passed on to outside agencies, including the police.

Michael Mansfield QC, for the pair, argued that Judge Jonathan Haworth erred in not allowing the jurors to consider whether, in the light of that widely-accepted policy, Ms Wyner and Mr Brock acted reasonably in not telling the police what they knew about drug dealing.

The jailing of Ms Wyner and Mr Brock has been a cause of concern for workers at hostels and day centres across the country.

Some charities began turning away drug addicts and suffered staff shortages because people were unwilling to run the risk of imprisonment for failing to inform on those seeking shelter.

Earlier today, as she entered the royal courts of Justice in London to cries of "good luck" from supporters, Ms Wyner said: "I am fairly optimistic we will get justice here."

She said that the ruling which appeal judges Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Longmore and Mr Justice Ouseley made could have a major impact on those working with the homeless.

She also warned that, following her experience, homeless workers could now be worried about openly liaising with the police about drug problems among their clients.

She said: "The case has very wide implications for homeless centres as a whole, so I feel nervous about that as well as my own personal situation.

"Basically, John and I were never accused of any involvement in the drug dealing or drug use.

"If you work with drug addicts, there is implicit knowledge that some (drug) exchanges will take place. Is that 'knowingly allowing'?

"If it is, it would mean homeless agencies cannot work with people using drugs without breaking the law themselves.

"At Winter Comfort, we thought we had a good liaison set up with the police. We talked openly about our problems and concerns about drug use among our clientele.

"It seems they used that against us. Staff working with the homeless are now likely to be very worried about being open with the police - I certainly would be after my experience."

A new petition has been launched calling for Section 8 of the 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act - the section under which Ms Wyner and Mr Brock were convicted - to be rewritten.

The Cambridge Two Campaign, which launched the petition, said that it had been backed by trade union Unison, national drugs helpline Release, Cambridge MP Anne Campbell, Worthing West MP Peter Bottomley, and The Big Issue magazine.

Alexander Masters, the chairman of the campaign, said: "This is an extremely important issue, as the convictions of Ruth and John showed.

"Section 8 is dangerous law which creates tension between the police and charity workers. Until Section 8 is rewritten, it will be impossible for charities working with the homeless or with drug users ever to feel safe."

fields.headline: Venables talks break down
fields.trailText: Terry Venables will not be returning to management with Middlesbrough after talks broke down today.
fields.body:
Terry Venables will not be returning to management with Middlesbrough after talks broke down today.

The former England manager has been lined up to take over from Bryan Robson. But Boro chief executive Keith Lamb admitted that talks had foundered over Venables's commitments to television, and that he would not be joining the club.

Lamb said: "We have concluded that Terry's present and future television commitments are incompatible with the role we were offering him here at Middlesbrough. We have now brought our discussions to a close. We wish him well in his role as a television football pundit.

"We can assure our supporters that everyone at Middlesbrough will now continue to focus on the Premier League challenge that lies ahead."

It now appears that Robson will continue in charge into next year. Before the announcement, Robson had said: "If he [Venables] doesn't take a position here I would be in charge until the end of the season."

webTitle: Stand-up comic tipped for hearty Big Breakfast

fields.headline: Stand-up comic tipped for hearty Big Breakfast
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is pinning hopes for its ailing morning show, the Big Breakfast, on a virtually unknown stand-up comedian who has little experience of live television.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is pinning hopes for its ailing morning show, the Big Breakfast, on a virtually unknown stand-up comedian who has little experience of live television.

Paul Tonkinson is close to signing a deal to replace the anarchic Johnny Vaughan, who leaves the show at the end of the year.

Tonkinson, 26, fronts the Channel 4 quiz show Dicing with Debt, which gives away big prizes to students who gamble their loans and overdrafts.

It is hoped that Tonkinson's zany style will be a successful replacement for Vaughan. A female co-host has not yet been identified, but he has already hosted a late night Channel 4 music show with Donna Air, who has had a number of stints on the Big Breakfast.

Tonkinson is a familiar face on the stand-up circuit, but is less well known on TV. The Guardian's television critic, Gareth McLean, recently described him as possessing a "boyish charm" that did not save Dicing with Debt from being "mildly irritating, mediocre tosh".

An announcement about Tonkinson's role in the Big Breakfast is due within the next few weeks, and a Channel 4 spokeswoman confirmed that he is a serious contender. It is understood that terms for his contract are being finalised.

The eight-year-old show has been criticised for being tired and forced and ratings have plummeted. Few believe it has recreated the sense of groundbreaking television that was the norm under earlier presenters such as Paula Yates, Chris Evans and Gaby Roslin.

Even the return of Denise Van Outen to host the show with Vaughan - the pair were seen as the "dream team" when they first fronted it together - has failed to boost falling viewer numbers.

It struggles to draw more than half a million, and was beaten earlier this year by Bear in the Big Blue House, the Channel 5 series by the creators of the Muppets, the Jim Henson Company.

Executives at Channel 4 have spent months wringing their hands about the future of the Big Breakfast. At one stage they considered axing the programme, but are constrained by a strict contract with its makers, Planet 24.

The Carlton-owned production company, set up by Lord Alli and his partner Charlie Parsons, is understood to require a year's notice before the show can be dropped. Even then, it is thought that Planet 24 must be given first refusal on any replacement.

Instead, the Big Breakfast will undergo a relaunch in the new year with the new presenters. The two-hour programme will still come from a house in east London, but the look and format will be reworked. The flying chicken titles sequence will be altered, and a number of features added. A new executive producer has been drafted to oversee the changes.

A female co-host has not yet been identified, but he has already hosted a late night Channel 4 music show with Donna Air, who has had a number of stints on the Big Breakfast. Tonkinson is a familiar face on the stand-up circuit, but is less well known on TV. The Guardian's television critic, Gareth McLean, recently described him as possessing a "boyish charm" that did not save Dicing with Debt from being "mildly irritating, mediocre tosh". An announcement about Tonkinson's role in the Big Breakfast is due within the next few weeks, and a Channel 4 spokeswoman confirmed that he is a serious contender. It is understood that terms for his contract are being finalised. The eight-year-old show has been criticised for being tired and forced and ratings have plummeted. Few believe it has recreated the sense of groundbreaking television that was the norm under earlier presenters such as Paula Yates, Chris Evans and Gaby Roslin. Even the return of Denise Van Outen to host the show with Vaughan - the pair were seen as the "dream team" when they first fronted it together - has failed to boost falling viewer numbers. It struggles to draw more than half a million, and was beaten earlier this year by Bear in the Big Blue House, the Channel 5 series by the creators of the Muppets, the Jim Henson Company. Executives at Channel 4 have spent months wringing their hands about the future of the Big Breakfast. At one stage they considered axing the programme, but are constrained by a strict contract with its makers, Planet 24. The Carlton-owned production company, set up by Lord Alli and his partner Charlie Parsons, is understood to require a year's notice before the show can be dropped. Even then, it is thought that Planet 24 must be given first refusal on any replacement. Instead, the Big Breakfast will undergo a relaunch in the new year with the new presenters. The two-hour programme will still come from a house in east London, but the look and format will be reworked. The flying chicken titles sequence will be altered, and a number of features added. A new executive producer has been drafted to oversee the changes.

webTitle: US election: Supreme court on a date with destiny

fields.headline: Supreme court on date with destiny
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: The US supreme court became the scene today for a hoped-for breakthrough in the saga between George W Bush and Al Gore, as both sought a legal victory to win the upper hand in Florida's contested presidential election.
fields.body:
The US supreme court became the scene today for a hoped-for breakthrough in the saga between George W Bush and Al Gore, as both sought a legal victory to win the upper hand in Florida's contested presidential election.

Mr Bush's lawyers asked the justices to throw out the hand-counted tally that narrowed his lead over the vice president, Mr Gore. Mr Bush's lawyers claimed that Florida's highest court "plainly rewrote the election laws".

The Republican team hoped to convince the nation's highest court that the late-counted votes were unlawfully added to the pivotal Florida totals, while Mr Gore's lawyers were urging the justices to let those votes stand.

Ninety minutes of oral arguments in the extraordinary case were scheduled for this morning and access to the public gallery has become the hottest ticket in Washington for those hoping for a glimpse of history.

Not since the Watergate scandal of the 1970s have the nine members of the US supreme court been so firmly in a presidential minefield.

It was not known how soon the justices might rule, although in a few cases where the timing was urgent they have taken as little as one day.

However, the justices' decision will not dictate who becomes the next president. A ruling for Mr Gore would hold Mr Bush's lead at 537 votes and let the vice president pursue more votes in a state-court contest that could put him over the top.

A ruling for Mr Bush probably would push the Republican candidate's lead back to the 930-vote margin he had before the hand recounts were added to the Florida totals.

Mr Gore still could gain votes if state courts ordered more recounts, but a supreme court loss could create heavy pressure on him to give up the race.

Even as the legal battle focused on the supreme court, Mr Bush and Mr Gore developed their transition strategies and continued to skirmish in the courts in Florida.

Around 600,000 ballots from Miami-Dade County were loaded into a rental van before dawn today and put on the road to a Tallahassee courthouse - in case another recount is ordered. This follows the arrival of around 500,000 ballots there yesterday from Palm Beach County in a banana-yellow rental truck.

More ballots may be fetched. Mr Bush's lawyers last night asked circuit judge N Sanders Sauls to order an additional 1.2m ballots to be brought in from Volusia, Broward and Pinellas counties. The judge has not yet considered the request.

Mr Bush's spokesman Scott McClellan said: "We believe there were a number of illegal votes for Gore in those counties."

Mr Gore's legal team, which is contesting the Florida election that gave Bush a 537-vote lead, filed an urgent plea with the Florida supreme court asking that hand-counting of the ballots begin while Mr Sauls, who will hold a hearing tomorrow, decides whether these counts could be added to Mr Gore's totals.

"There is no reason to delay counting ballots even one day," the brief read.

Mr Bush's legal team, however, in a motion with Mr Sauls yesterday, cited more than a dozen reasons why the judge should toss out Mr Gore's contest.

In the Republicans' first formal response to the Democrats' lawsuit, they claimed Mr Gore's challenge was baseless because the real election wasn't between the Texas governor and the vice president, but between the separate groups of 25 Florida electors.

The motion also says Mr Gore's lawyers filed their challenge after the 10-day deadline required by state law and that manually counting only part of the ballots is illegal. The filing also claims that the judicial recounts the Gore camp is seeking are "illegal, inappropriate, and manifestly unfair".

At the supreme court in Washington, crowds waited through the night outside the white marble building in hopes of joining lawyers, news media and court staff in the packed courtroom today.

John Fucetola, 20, a political science major at George Washington university, who was first in line to get a ticket for the hearing, said: "Money can't buy this. Money can't buy history. This is something we'll be telling our grandchildren."

fields.headline: Breastfeeding may guard against HIV
fields.trailText: Breastfeeding may be the best way for mothers who are HIV positive to safeguard their babies from the infection, especially in the developing world, according to scientists whose work suggests that the conventional wisdom is badly flawed.
fields.body:
Breastfeeding may be the best way for mothers who are HIV positive to safeguard their babies from the infection, especially in the developing world, according to scientists whose work suggests that the conventional wisdom is badly flawed.

Virtually all women in the west who are HIV positive give their babies bottled formula milk, which experts have maintained is the best way to protect them from becoming infected with the virus.

But this advice, backed by the World Health Organisation, has been hard to follow for women in developing countries, who may not be able to afford formula milk and who risk revealing their HIV status to the entire community if they do not breastfeed. Most worryingly, the shortage of clean water in many areas means that bottles can give babies other serious infections.

Pilot studies by a well-respected South African paediatrician, Jerry Coovadia, and his colleague, Anna Coutsoudis, show that women who exclusively breastfeed their babies run little or no risk of transmitting HIV to them. Their work, in a rural area of KwaZulu Natal, two hours from Durban, where only 5% have clean water and where cholera outbreaks are common, shows that exclusive breastfeeding is as safe as exclusive bottle feeding in terms of HIV transmission, and that considered in the context of the general health of the babies, it is better for them.

A three-year project involving 2,000 women is likely to be launched next year, funded by the Wellcome Trust, to settle a fraught issue that is vital for the future of HIV/Aids management in the developing world.

"If more extensive research proves that exclusive breastfeeding is no more risky than formula feeding, this has profound implications for preventing the spread of HIV in Africa and the developing world," said Prof Coovadia.

"As well as the many advantages of exclusive breastfeeding - its cultural appropriateness, simplicity and well-documented health benefits - another major plus is that breast milk is free."

His work has shown that the least safe method of feeding is the one most often practised in Africa - mixed breast and formula feeding. The scientists believe that contaminated water in the bottles may damage the baby's gut, allowing any HIV virus in the milk, which might pass through harmlessly, to enter the infant's system.

The scientists published an early report of their findings in the Lancet last year. Their as yet unpublished follow-up of the children at 15 months old shows that the exclusively breastfed babies continue to thrive and are HIV free.

"It is a unique observation by Coovadia and Coutsoudis that if you exclusively breastfeed, with no additional feeds including water, you have minimal or no risk of transmitting HIV," said Michael Bennish, director of the Wellcome Trust's Africa centre, where the study is based. "Not everyone accepts that."

If breastfeeding is found to be the safest option for the developing world, one of the last objections to the use of drugs like nevirapine to prevent mothers transmitting the HIV virus to their babies during childbirth will have been removed. It has been argued that there is no point giving women and their infants the tablets, which are cheap and in some places have been donated free, because the babies will inevitably be infected through their mothers' milk unless an expensive programme to provide formula and clean water can be put in place as well.

fields.headline: Aids - a global crisis
fields.standfirst:
Westerners have become complacent about the dangers of Aids, say campaigners on World Aids Day

Special report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: Westerners have become complacent about the dangers of Aids, say campaigners on World Aids Day.
fields.body:
The world is in the grip of a global Aids crisis which affects 43m people - but in the west people have become complacent to the dangers. This is the message being pushed today, on World Aids Day, and campaigners have some chilling evidence for those who think the disease has nothing to do with them. Mark Oliver explains the threat.

How many people have Aids?
The Aids epidemic has so far left 50m people infected with HIV worldwide, of whom 16m have died. That leaves 34m people who are living with the infection. Africa has been the worst hit - 5,500 people die from Aids related illnesses there every day. There are new fears that Asia may eclipse Africa in severity of infection levels. However, the steepest rise in infections in the world during 1998 was in the former Soviet Union and eastern Europe. There are 1.4m children with Aids worldwide.

But Britain does not have such a bad problem, does it?
As many as 10,000 people in the UK have HIV but are unaware of their condition according to a report published by the Department of Health. At the beginning of this year there were 20,800 people living with HIV - 40% up from four years ago. And the number of people diagnosed as HIV positive in England and Wales is set to rise by another 40% in the next three years. The public health laboratory service has warned that there will be 29,000 people who know they are HIV positive by the end of 2003. Last year saw record numbers of HIV diagnoses, with more than 3,000 new cases identified in England and Wales. Of around 30,000 people who are expected to be infected, about 16,000 will have been through homosexual sex, 11,500 through heterosexual sex and about 1,500 through drug abuse. It is estimated that a third of gay and bisexual men who are HIV positive do not know they have the infection and more than half of heterosexual men in London who are infected are unaware.

Are people being ignorant?
Campaigners say people who are too young to remember the massive Aids campaigns of the 80s are becoming complacent about the risks of the disease. A Mori poll of more than 2,000 people in the UK for the National Aids Trust found that despite multi-million pound awareness campaigns, many people are still ignorant about the risks of becoming infected with HIV. One in 10 people wrongly believe there is a cure for Aids and a further one in 10 are not sure. Only a third of people aged 15-24 say that knowledge of HIV has made them change their lifestyle in some way - an 11% drop on the year before. A spokesman for the National Aids Trust said: "The fight against Aids is now a fight against complacency."

Is there a cure yet?
No. The new and effective drugs have been responsible for fewer people developing full-blown Aids and increasing the numbers of HIV positive cases. But there is no cure.

What are the government doing to attack the problem?
The health minister, Yvette Cooper, has announced an extra £41m for health authorities in England to treat and care for people with Aids. Last year the government announced that all pregnant women would be offered an HIV test after research on HIV-positive pregnant women in London found that 60% did not know they were infected before they conceived. Campaign posters, leaflets and an innovative website are being used in a "make a difference" campaign by the National Aids Trust to encourage people to join the fight against the disease.

webTitle: NatMags extends Cosmo brand to new cafes

fields.headline: NatMags extends Cosmo brand to new cafes
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: National Magazines is to launch Cosmopolitan-branded cafes in major UK cities next year, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
National Magazines has become the latest company to move into the catering business with the launch of a range of Cosmopolitan-branded cafes.

Opening your own cafe has become the latest marketing tool, with brands from Cadbury to Kenco planning branded high street outlets.

But women's magazine Cosmopolitan is the first non-food brand to adopt the trend.

"It's an obvious extension for Cosmopolitan. With cafes springing up all over the place, we thought a Cosmo cafe would be a fun place for young readers to hang out," said a National Magazines spokeswoman.

"They will be very Cosmo, with lots of pink and red, and we'll have lots of fun things like horoscope readings and pampering areas."

The cafes, to be called Cosmopolitan Life, will open in several major cities around Britain, starting with Manchester in the middle of next year.

Cosmopolitan has already expanded well beyond the magazine market through a series of licensing deals.

Fans of Cosmo's particular brand of girly glamour can now buy Cosmopolitan home furnishings, clothes, juices and yoghurts as well as the monthly magazine.

The cafes will be aimed at 18 to 25-year-old women and will probably be run as franchises. They will serve coffee and fresh fruit juices and some are likely to be licensed to serve alcohol.

For National Magazines, the move is a relatively cheap way of gaining exposure for the Cosmopolitan brand.

fields.headline: Spreading the blood of Kosovo
fields.standfirst: As tension flares once more, Derek Brown examines the reasons for the latest violence in former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: As tension flares once more, Derek Brown examines the reasons for the latest violence in former Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Once again, Serbs and Kosovars are in deadly confrontation in the Balkans.

They have never stopped killing each other, of course, but the latest round of bloodletting is different: it's taking place not in Kosovo, but in Serbia itself.

A small band of ethnic Albanian rebels has seized control of hilltop positions along part of Serbia's sinuous border with Kosovo. They have been active in the area for much of the year, but, in the past few days, they have stepped up their attacks, killing four Serb policemen.

The area is home to much of Serbia's sizeable ethnic Albanian minority. Many of them live in the five-kilometer demilitarised zone that was set up on Nato's insistence at the end of last year's war.

The Yugoslav army is barred from the demilitarised zone, which is patrolled by lightly armed Serb police, horribly vulnerable to guerrilla ambush.

The rebels call themselves - with the pomp and bravado so dearly loved by such men - the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac.

Those are the main Albanian population centres in southern Serbia.

Almost certainly, however, the guerrillas are not based in Serbia, but are cadres of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which fought a desultory war against the Yugoslav army before Nato's polyglot army, Kfor, took over the province.

Since the arrival of the Nato forces, the KLA has atrophied and splintered.

Denied a primary role in the emerging government or in the fledgling police force of Kosovo, it has also been outflanked politically by the leading political moderate, Ibrahim Rugova.

Now, it seems, militant KLA members have decided to revive their irredentist war and carry it to the Serbian enemy.

The implications for Nato are chilling. If the guerrillas provoke the Yugoslav military establishment into returning to the border buffer zone, their soldiers will be eyeball to eyeball with Kfor troops.

The Nato soldiers apparently have neither the stomach nor the means to prevent KLA men crossing the border, but they will be obliged to prevent any Serb military incursion into the buffer zone.

Had Slobodan Milosevic remained in power, the danger would be more imminent.

As it is, the new leader in Belgrade, Vojislav Kostunica, has talked reassuringly of restoring calm and seeking a political solution.

But Kostunica is also insisting that Kfor take control of its side of the border and stop the guerrilla incursions.

He knows that the Serbs, after their abject rout by Nato last year, are in no mood to be further humiliated by a ragbag bunch of mountain fighters in their own country.

webTitle: Nato steps up presence on Kosovo-Serbia border

fields.headline: Nato steps up presence on Kosovo-Serbia border
fields.standfirst:
More peacekeeping troops have been deployed at the buffer zone on Kosovo's border with Serbia following fresh attacks by rebel forces

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: More peacekeeping troops have been deployed at the buffer zone on Kosovo's border with Serbia following fresh attacks by rebel forces.
fields.body:
Nato has sent more peacekeepers into the border between Serbia and Kosovo, following a recent upsurge of violence and ethnic Albanian rebel incursions into the area.

A small band of ethnic Albanian rebels have seized control of hilltop positions along part of the border.

In the past few days the rebels have stepped up their attacks, killing four Serb policemen.

The area is home to much of Serbia's ethnic Albanian minority, many of whom live in the demilitarised zone set up at Nato's insistence at the end of last year's war.

The Yugoslav army is barred from the demilitarised zone, which is patrolled by lightly armed Serb police, vulnerable to guerrilla ambush.

The rebels call themselves the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac: the main Albanian population centres in southern Serbia.

They are likely to be cadres of the Kosovo Liberation Army which fought the Yugoslav army before Nato's army took over the province.

Since the arrival of the Nato forces the KLA has splintered. Denied a primary role in the government or in Kosovo's fledgling police force, it has also been outflanked by the leading political moderate, Ibrahim Rugova.

If the guerrillas provoke the Yugoslav military into returning to the buffer zone, their soldiers will come face to face with Nato troops, who are obliged to prevent any Serb military incursion into the buffer zone.

The new leader in Belgrade, Vojislav Kostunica, has asked for calm and a political solution to the violence.

However, he is insisting that Nato take control of its side of the border and stop the guerrilla incursions.

fields.headline: Worn down by election weariness
fields.standfirst: The US election saga rattles on, but the papers are still finding plenty to comment on, as Derek Brown finds out
fields.trailText: The US election saga rattles on, but the papers are still finding plenty to comment on, as Derek Brown finds out.
fields.body:
Two courts and a state legislature are now addressing the question that was put to the American people on November 7: who should be president?

The Miami Herald takes the Florida state lawmakers to task as they prepare to name a slate of (Republican) voters in the presidential electoral college.

The state senators and representatives are entitled to do so, the paper concedes, but their move is premature and potentially divisive: "For the legislature to meet to declare the Texas governor the victor, before the result of those challenges is clear, would be to cloak the result in partisanship.

"The nightmarish outcome for the nation would be for the legislature's Republican majority to name its slate of electors committed to Mr Bush, only to see a court-ordered recount produce a popular-vote victory for Mr Gore."

The tabloid New York Daily News somewhat breathlessly anticipates the day's legal manoeverings:

"Lawyers for both would-be presidents will come before a historic session of the nation's highest court today to argue over whether the State of Florida can nix the results of manual recounts.

"It will be the first time the supreme court has tackled a case that could decide the presidency. If the high court rules for Bush, it could return Bush to his previous 930-vote lead instead of his current 537-vote margin. At that point, Gore would have to concede."

The most original idea of the day comes in a reader's letter to the Los Angeles Times.

Richard Blue suggests that Al Gore should concede the presidency - on condition that George W Bush give a firm commitment to serve only one term.

"The precedent was set in the 1876 presidential election when Republican nominee Rutherford B Hayes knew the election had been stolen for him (not by him).

"Now, there was a man who showed character and integrity, not merely talked about it.

"Bush claims he trusts the American people. Time for him to show the American people can trust him."

The Houston Chronicle focuses on the bizarre televised motorcade which bore disputed votes from Palm Beach County to the Florida state capital, Tallahassee, in advance of yet another court hearing.

The paper asks rehetorically: "Who could blame Americans for being car sick? Many claim the wheels have come off our democracy in this case.

"It's been a long, exhausting and strange ride, but we're still a very long way from going off the cliff of constitutional crisis. And maybe, just maybe, the beginning of the end of this odyssey is now in sight."

The Chicago Sun Times looks ahead to the economic problems awaiting the next president, whoever that might be.

The paper bleakly warns that many analysts are predicting a downturn in the US economy: "This economic wildcard has led to the wry observation that the eventual loser in this presidential election may very well be the winner:

"Whoever misses out on the White House won't have to wrestle with the economy. With reduced tax revenues, tax cut pledges made by both campaigns may have to be revisited or spending plans altered.

"A new president trying to guide the nation under new economic rules also may be hamstrung by a warring Congress unwilling to cooperate.

"But an economic downturn will force Congress and the White House to find a way to work together."

The Boston Globe earnestly hopes that the supreme court will bring "finality and legitimacy" to the epic contest.

"This hope has grown steadily in the week since the justices agreed to hear the case, as each succeeding day has seen the parties become more polarised.

"The nation needs this campaign to be elevated above self-interested partisanship.

"Since no group has been able to achieve that, the supreme court may indeed offer not only the best hope, but - with 11 days left until presidential electors are to be named - quite likely the last."

webTitle: Failing London school to be closed

fields.headline: A lesson in failure
fields.trailText: Some schools' GCSE results are poor; results at Telegraph Hill, a south London comprehensive which will close shortly, are atrocious.
fields.body:
Some schools' GCSE results are poor; results at Telegraph Hill, a south London comprehensive which will close shortly, are atrocious.

Nationally, just under half of all pupils manage to secure five A-C grades. At Telegraph Hill, only 3% do, although the head told Ofsted inspectors earlier this year that he hoped 28% of his pupils would make the grade.

All the more surprising, then, that Telegraph Hill only opened fifteen months ago - albeit in the same buildings and with the same pupils as Hatcham Wood. Closed down and reopened under the government's Fresh Start scheme with a new headmaster, staff and uniform, Telegraph Hill revamped its curriculum to be 'excitingly different'. Lessons were lengthened to an hour and forty minutes to allow pupils more time to get to grips with a subject; subjects such as 'world studies' were introduced.

Much to the disgust of the Lambeth branch of the National Union of Teachers, existing teachers were 'pushed out' and replaced by a new team, but the school now depended heavily on supply staff and newly-qualified teachers. And the school's intake was just as disadvantaged as before.

Around 60% of pupils come from a home where English is the second language; 55% of them qualify for free school meals, a telling indicator of social deprivation; and, according to the most recent Ofsted inspection, a third of the 11-year-olds have a reading age of less than nine. Most local parents did all they could to ensure their child had a place at the neighbouring Haberdashers' Askes city technology college.

The inspectors returned in June this year to find that the school had failed to improve and placed it under special measures. The following month the new head, Mike Davies - described as 'very weak' by Ofsted - resigned.

The June report listed dozens of criticisms of Telegraph Hill. The new lessons were too long and children lost interest and concentration. Senior teachers could not plan effectively because they were constantly dealing with crises. Sometimes only half the pupils would turn up to a class, and when they did the tasks assigned to them were, according to Ofsted, unstimulating.

The teachers were "too tolerant of mediocre work and unsatisfactory behaviour". None of this was helped by the fact that computers and pupils' work had been 'mislaid' during the building work before the Fresh Start reopening.

You can read the June Ofsted report here.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 1.
fields.trailText: December 1: New PHD is close to landing the centralised £17m Weetabix media planning and buying account.
fields.body:
New PHD is close to landing the centralised £17m Weetabix media planning and buying account. The decision is down to a two-way shoot out between New PHD and OMD UK.

Carat Group UK is to pool trading activities for its three main agencies in a move that will effectively create the UK's largest buying point.

Ulster Television has expanded into radio with the acquisition of a leading radio group, County Media, in the Republic of Ireland.

The commercial team at the Express faces an uncertain future as Northern & Shell's joint managing directors, Stan Myerson and Martin Ellice, are set to split the running of the group between them.

CIA received a major boost this week by securing the £70m European planning and buying brief for luxury goods company Richemont.

The Racecourse Association has advised its members to enter exclusive negotiations with Go Racing with a view to conclude the sale of their terrestrial and interactive rights.

Fox Kids Europe has teamed up with online sports network Sportal.com to develop the largest children's online sports service in the world.

Granada Media revealed a strong performance in its first year as an independently listed company, with advertising revenue up by almost 8%.

Reed Elsevier has appointed Gerard van de Aast, a senior executive from computer manufacturer Compaq, to head its global business-to-business operations.

BBC Radio 5 Live has fought off competition from TalkSport to win a new, exclusive three-year deal to cover Premier League football.

fields.headline: LibertySurf relaunches as 'caring sharing ISP'
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: LibertySurf is to announce its comeback with a major ad campaign branding it the caring, sharing ISP, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
LibertySurf is to announce its comeback with a major advertising campaign that brands it as the caring, sharing internet service provider.

The campaign breaks after a turbulent time for LibertySurf, which was forced to pull its original launch advertising campaign in May after only a day on air.

The company took the radical decision to stop advertising and suspend sales after it was besieged by technical problems.

Now, six months later, the company claims it has sorted out its difficulties and the campaign is returning to our screens.

The ads, which were created by WCRS, will run from today until the middle of January and feature children innocently demonstrating the meaning of "unmetered net access".

The service is intended to appeal to first-time users and families in particular.

LibertySurf said that excess demand had been the cause of its launch difficulties. But the company faces an uphill struggle to overturn the negative PR surrounding its failed launch.

Users of LibertySurf pay a one-off monthly payment of £10 and receive four hours of internet access, available anytime of the day.

Any further usage is charged at 1p a minute. For an extra £4 a month, customers can buy an additional eight hours and 20 minutes online each month with no call charges.

webTitle: Bullies add costs to balance sheets

fields.headline: Bullies add costs to balance sheets
fields.standfirst: Workplace bullying is expensive, causing additional recruitment, training and sickness costs which can be quantified, writes voluntary sector consultant Jo Clifton
fields.trailText: Workplace bullying is expensive, causing additional recruitment, training and sickness costs which can be quantified, writes voluntary sector consultant Jo Clifton
fields.body:
If you were sent 42 memos in one day detailing your supposed faults and failures, would you feel managed or bullied? This is what happened to Alan, a senior manager, whose boss used this tactic to control, threaten, and ultimately destroy his workers. Unfortunately, some managers feel that this is the only way to get people to work effectively, but research shows that the opposite usually happens. The targets of this behaviour, through fear, can start to underperform, which often leads to increasing sickness leave.

In addition, other staff will be doing just enough work so as not to draw attention to themselves, reducing the amount of effective and creative work they carry out. The bully, meanwhile, is pursuing private agendas, not organisational objectives; and staff, time and resources are not being managed effectively. If each of Alan's memos took approximately 15 minutes to write, send and read, that's three and a half hours out of the working day!

Recent research has found that the majority of people experience bullying in their workplace; either as the target, or as a witness to the bullying behaviour. The National Workplace Bullying Advice Line reports that 20% of its callers are from education, 12% from the health services and 10% from social work, while the fastest growing number of callers in 1998 were from the voluntary sector.

Research also suggests that certain environmental conditions and organisational structures actually encourage bullying behaviour and a bullying culture. These include frequent organisational change and uncertainty, an authoritarian style of supervision, and no clear codes of acceptable conduct. This last issue is a major factor in the perpetuation of bullying. How can you complain if you don't know what is allowed and what isn't?

Without the bottom line of reduced profits and performance, how can non-profit organisations assess the cost? One telling factor is the expense of recruitment and training - reckoned to be approximately £5,000 for each new member of staff. The average cost of sickness absence is also £485 annually. These sums are a significant drain on the limited amounts of money available to finance the project or organisation.

The hidden financial aspects can be quantified by monitoring factors such as absence records and staff turnover. If you assess the amount of work left undone as a result, then you can see that there will be a lack of innovative and development work actually happening.

The cost of not dealing with bullying can be substantial. The Health and Safety Executive now includes bullying and harassment as a significant source of stress in the workplace. If employers know that employees are being put under undue, and inappropriate stress, and do nothing to address the cause, they are failing in their duty of care, implicit in employment law, and may be liable to action under health and safety law. In the case of Ballantyne vs South Lanarkshire council, a social worker who was forced into early retirement because of the "outspoken" and "abusive" behaviour of her boss won £66,000 in an out-of-court settlement.

In journals and conferences, the issue of workplace bullying is gaining greater visibility. Targets are starting to recognise what is happening to them and employers are acknowledging that the problem exists. But, until there is some formal recognition through legislation, we may only be able to tackle the problem on a piecemeal basis and not as a strategic and integrated change of culture.

 Jo Clifton is an independent consultant based in central Scotland, working primarily in non-profit sectors. She is the co-author of Bully Off! Recognising and Tackling Workplace Bullying (Russell House Publishing Ltd)

webTitle: Solar panels and Christmas gifts for space station crew

fields.headline: Solar panels and Christmas gifts for space station crew
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Endeavour is on its way to the international space station, carrying five astronauts and giant solar panels.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Endeavour is on its way to the international space station, carrying five astronauts and giant solar panels.

The shuttle rose promptly from its seaside pad at 03.06 GMT this morning in a brilliant blaze of light that turned night into day for miles around. It resembled a bright star as it soared through a clear sky into orbit.

"This is a beautiful night to fly," launch director Mike Leinbach told the astronauts just before liftoff. "So we wish you luck. Have fun and give our best to Shep, Sergei and Yuri," the space station's three residents - one American and two Russians.

The space station, Alpha, was 230 miles (370 kilometers) above the Indian Ocean at liftoff, its residents supposedly asleep. Endeavour will catch up with the station on Saturday.

Governor Jeb Bush, who witnessed his first space shuttle flight, couldn't help but mention the state's election turmoil while congratulating launch controllers.

"I don't know if you've noticed. You all have been very busy. But there's a lot of attention on Florida over the last couple of weeks," Bush said, drawing a big laugh. "But I want to tell you that the best of Florida is right here, not what is being depicted on television, but what just happened right now."

Endeavour's cargo bay is filled with the world's largest, most powerful set of spacecraft solar 'wings'. The shuttle astronauts will attach $ 600 million wings to the space station on Sunday in Nasa's most complicated construction mission to date.

Once unfurled, the wings will stretch 240 feet from tip to tip, and 38 feet across, constituting the largest structure ever deployed in space. It is one of the heaviest shuttle payloads ever, 35,000 pounds of panels and associated batteries and radiators.

The electricity-producing solar wings will provide the power necessary to open up the entire station and to run the US-made laboratory section when it arrives in January. Alpha's three occupants have been confined to two of the station's three rooms because of insufficient power for heating.

The shuttle flight almost got off to a late start. Nasa delayed fuelling Endeavour by two hours so technicians could remove a bracket that was dangling from the launch pad. Shuttle managers feared the metal bracket could break off and strike Endeavour's wing at liftoff.

The bracket was seen dangling during a routine inspection. It's supposed to hold up a water pipe on the outside of the walkway room used by astronauts to board the shuttle. Another loose bracket nearby was replaced. Then a small grass fire broke out near the pad, but was quickly extinguished.

During the last shuttle countdown, in October, a 4-inch pin was left on Discovery's external fuel tank and delayed the flight by one day. To avoid another embarrassing last-minute discovery this time, Nasa had technicians check the pad more thoroughly for tools and other stray objects.

Launch director Leinbach said that he was disappointed the bracket was not found sooner and that steps would be taken to improve shuttle inspections before Atlantis carries up the space station lab in January.

Space station commander Bill Shepherd and his Russian crew have been living on Alpha for one month. The Endeavour astronauts will be their first visitors; they won't see each other until December 8, after the shuttle crew conducts three spacewalks to hook up the new solar wings. Only then will the hatches between the spacecraft be opened.

The shuttle astronauts are taking up Christmas presents for Shepherd, Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev from their families, as well as fresh fruit and hot sauce.

Shepherd and his crew are not due back on Earth until February. The shuttle astronauts will be away 11 days.

This was Nasa's third shuttle launch in as many months, the busiest stretch in three years. The space agency must keep up a hectic pace if it hopes to finish building the station in 2006.

You all have been very busy. But there's a lot of attention on Florida over the last couple of weeks," Bush said, drawing a big laugh. "But I want to tell you that the best of Florida is right here, not what is being depicted on television, but what just happened right now." Endeavour's cargo bay is filled with the world's largest, most powerful set of spacecraft solar 'wings'. The shuttle astronauts will attach $ 600 million wings to the space station on Sunday in Nasa's most complicated construction mission to date. Once unfurled, the wings will stretch 240 feet from tip to tip, and 38 feet across, constituting the largest structure ever deployed in space. It is one of the heaviest shuttle payloads ever, 35,000 pounds of panels and associated batteries and radiators. The electricity-producing solar wings will provide the power necessary to open up the entire station and to run the US-made laboratory section when it arrives in January. Alpha's three occupants have been confined to two of the station's three rooms because of insufficient power for heating. The shuttle flight almost got off to a late start. Nasa delayed fuelling Endeavour by two hours so technicians could remove a bracket that was dangling from the launch pad. Shuttle managers feared the metal bracket could break off and strike Endeavour's wing at liftoff. The bracket was seen dangling during a routine inspection. It's supposed to hold up a water pipe on the outside of the walkway room used by astronauts to board the shuttle. Another loose bracket nearby was replaced. Then a small grass fire broke out near the pad, but was quickly extinguished. During the last shuttle countdown, in October, a 4-inch pin was left on Discovery's external fuel tank and delayed the flight by one day. To avoid another embarrassing last-minute discovery this time, Nasa had technicians check the pad more thoroughly for tools and other stray objects. Launch director Leinbach said that he was disappointed the bracket was not found sooner and that steps would be taken to improve shuttle inspections before Atlantis carries up the space station lab in January. Space station commander Bill Shepherd and his Russian crew have been living on Alpha for one month. The Endeavour astronauts will be their first visitors; they won't see each other until December 8, after the shuttle crew conducts three spacewalks to hook up the new solar wings. Only then will the hatches between the spacecraft be opened. The shuttle astronauts are taking up Christmas presents for Shepherd, Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev from their families, as well as fresh fruit and hot sauce. Shepherd and his crew are not due back on Earth until February. The shuttle astronauts will be away 11 days. This was Nasa's third shuttle launch in as many months, the busiest stretch in three years. The space agency must keep up a hectic pace if it hopes to finish building the station in 2006.

webTitle: You bet your life: week sixteen

fields.headline: You bet your life: week sixteen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Here they go again
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.08, Sean Ingle = £100.52, Football Unlimited punters collective = £55.00, Paul MacInnes = £51.34
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.08, Sean Ingle = £100.52, Football Unlimited punters collective = £55.00, Paul MacInnes = £51.34

Scott Murray: Ipswich v Derby - Derby to win. £10 @ 4/1

Ipswich are a pretty good side - you'll get no argument from me about that. But everyone seems to be ignoring that they've been blatantly riding their luck for a while now: they managed to be more tedious than struggling Coventry but still won, and they nicked off with all the points from Maine Road despite nearly matching their infamous hosts in the foot-shooting stakes.

Derby aren't as inept as they once were, either. They've turned things round at the back with the arrival of Colin Todd, and if their strikers hadn't been auditioning for a circus troupe, they would have won recent matches at Fulham and Arsenal, no less.

Great runs like Ipswich's always end unexpectedly, too.

OK, so they don't, but go with me on this one.

Sean Ingle: One 50p accumulator and 4x £1.50 trebles: Crystal Palace to win at Grimsby @ 7/4, Bayer Leverkusen to win at Bayern Munich @ 10/3, Oviedo to win at home to Malaga @ 4/5, Milan to win at Udinese @ 7/4.

With Christmas fast approaching, I've decided to go free 'n' festive with my bets. And so goodbye to oh-so-sensible singles and a lusty "hello there" to young Lady Accumulator, with her seductive promises of big-money pay-outs.

But don't worry, Blue Square's Patrick Murray, this time I'm taking precautions. All of my bets are sheathed in value, particularly Crystal Palace to beat Grimsby. Palace are unbeaten in their last seven, while Grimsby have lost four on the trot. The only reason why Palace are 7/4 is because they lost to the Mariners back in October - but since Alan Smith's boot up the backside they have been a different side, and I strongly fancy them to beat Grimsby.

Elsewhere, Real Oviedo look a safe bet to beat Malaga. Despite their shocking away record (no wins, no goals) they are unstoppable at home. For me 4/5 to beat a middling Malaga team is value.

My other two bets look riskier, but there is some logic behind them. Milan have struggled this season, while Udinese have soared. But Milan are undefeated in their last four and, crucially, have beaten Udinese away in each of the past two seasons.

Finally, I'm not convinced that Bayer Leverkusen will beat Bayern. But while Leverkusen are top of the table, and have the best away record and form in the Bundesliga, Bayern have been struggling ever since news of Franz Beckenbauer's love child came out. They've lost two of their past three games, including a humiliating defeat at home to Eintracht Frankfurt, and I think the 10/3 price on Bayer is much, much too high.

Paul MacInnes: Strasbourg to beat Monaco. £5 @ 5/1

Just like Ronnie Biggs, who was forced to flee Britain for Brazil when he forgot his mum's birthday [could somebody please check this?], I have decided to abandon my embarrassing betting past this week and head for pastures new. Not only that, but I'm heading for pastures that stink of socialism and flaming sheep carcasses. That's right - je suis having un punt on La Une.

Strasbourg are crap. They are second from bottom in the French first division and playing about as well as a team full of Mikael Silvestres (a Frenchman, you see, it's related). But the hidden secret to this bet is that Monaco, despite having recently been in the Champions League, are only just above them in the league and are in even worse form, having lost five of their past six games. When you combine those facts with juicy odds of 5/1, you will see why I have chosen to throw my money away in this fashion.

Bon nuit mes petites artichokes!

Jonathan Eggleton of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Trebles from 4 (Four lines @ £1.50): Rangers to win at Hearts @ 8/15, Hibernian to win at Motherwell @ 5/4, Fulham to win at Preston @ 10/11, Birmingham to win at Gillingham @ 6/5

My selections are based on form and the fact these four teams usually win every week. Birmingham will be high after their win in midweek against Newcastle. Rangers need to win to keep the title chase alive while Hibs seem unstoppable. Fulham I am unsure of as Preston are good at home but if Saha is on form it should be okay.

I have gone for aways as the odds are better and also trebles from 4 as always are at the best of times hard to predict. This method of betting means a good chance of breaking even if the majority of your bets come in while still netting a healthy profit if you get all your predictions correct.
