webTitle: Universities will lobby for £1bn boost in funding

fields.headline: Universities will lobby for £1bn boost in funding
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Future doctors, vets and lawyers would pay higher university fees than students on sociology or English courses under plans published by university heads today. Wealthy families might have to find as much as £14,500 a year for a medical degree.
fields.body:
Future doctors, vets and lawyers would pay higher university fees than students on sociology or English courses under plans published by university heads today. Wealthy families might have to find as much as £14,500 a year for a medical degree.

Universities UK, formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, is preparing to lobby in the run-up to the general election to boost funding by £1bn a year; the amount they say is needed to maintain the quality of teaching and reach the government's target of 50% of young people entering higher education.

They have set out options to raise this extra money. These range from increasing the means-tested fee to letting universities set their own rates (top-up fees). The vice-chancellors also want to consider education vouchers and the kind of graduate contributions introduced in Scotland after the Cubie report.

Doubling the present £1,000 tuition fee for subjects with lower expected lifetime earnings and tripling it for medicine, dentistry, veterinary science, computer science, engineering, law and business administration would raise more than £1bn for universities in England, calculated consultants London Economics in a study for the vice-chancellors. But, as only half of all students pay fees because of the means test, more than half of that money would have to come from the government.

Charging wealthy families the average cost of fees (£4,000) would bring in an extra £259m, equivalent to an increase of £264 a student in English universities and colleges. But vice-chancellors have not ruled out the option of allowing universities to set their own fees as they do for overseas students, ranging from £5,000 for an arts course to £14,500 a year for a medical degree.

Sir Howard Newby, president of Universities UK, predicted higher education would get only brief mentions in the party election manifestoes and admitted increased tuition fees were politically dangerous."One of the choices the government has to face is whether it wants to see a well-resourced sector able to maintain quality and compete globally and provide resources for teaching and research," he said. "If it is not prepared to fund them from the taxpayer, over a period of time it should introduce some form of contribution from students and their parents."

David Blunkett, the education secretary, made plain his continued opposition to top-up fees in his instructions to the higher education funding council for England published today.

Vote on the fees plan you prefer, in our special report.

webTitle: The BBC's gift to the eurosceptics

fields.headline: The BBC's gift to the eurosceptics
fields.standfirst: Ian Black explains why Radio 4's 'scoop' about a new EU constitution made him choke on his croissant
fields.trailText: Ian Black in Brussels explains why Radio 4's 'scoop' about a new EU constitution made him choke on his croissant.
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged, at least by old British EU hands, that Brussels is a suburb of Westminster. Occasionally, there are sharp reminders of that old saw, especially when the political debate about Europe is raging back home.

Last Wednesday was a classic example. Like most other Brits, certainly journalists, I was beginning my day with half an ear on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, easily heard in a town that is physically closer to London than Manchester.

But halfway through my croissant I almost choked when the sonorous tones of the BBC newscaster announced, at the very top of the bulletin, that a "new constitution for Europe" was under discussion by the European commission, an exclusive story from the programme's diplomatic correspondent, Andrew Gilligan.

It was a fantastic tale, and enough to make any Euro hack green with envy. What a scoop! And what timing too - in the feverish countdown to next week's Nice summit, with every newsdesk in the land desperate for a new angle. And all the more amazing in that this intrepid reporter was not even based here.

Clearly it took an independent-minded outsider, free of the pernicious influence of sinister commission spin-doctors, long lunches, and complicity with a federalist agenda, to uncover this astonishing fact.

The "new European constitution" made a good story. There was only one problem: it wasn't true.

The document referred to was published last July and does not involve drafting a constitution. The idea is to divide the EU's four rambling treaties, with 700 articles, into two easy-to-read parts with just 100 articles.

It still wouldn't be the Beano, but it would hopefully be a comprehensible to ordinary people, and not just rocket-scientist Eurocrats with doctorates in law and economics.

Why the BBC ran the story is something of a mystery, especially to its own embarrassed correspondents in Brussels. Jonathan Faull, the commission spokesman, called it "confusing, mischievous and outrageous". And those were his printable comments.

Chris Patten, the British external relations commissioner complained of "shoddy journalism". Patten was especially dismayed at being quoted out of context in the report in a sort of agitprop cut-and-paste style more worthy of the Lubyanka than Broadcasting House. The former Conservative party chairman put forward a serious argument about the need to define where the EU is ultimately heading, "so people can't go on pretending that we are on a journey to some ghastly superstate".

This story was a particularly clear example of bad journalism in the service of a clear political agenda, as shown by the way Tory central office leaped on it. "This document," thundered the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, "takes us further and further down the relentless one-way conveyor belt towards a European superstate."

For the eurosceptics the timing could not have been better. In the run-up to Nice the BBC "scoop" became another element in the miasma of misrepresentation, mendacity and sheer hysteria that passes for the European debate in Britain.

Hang on! Doesn't the government do the same? Of course it spins: Alastair Campbell caught the Eurostar to Brussels to do just that on the prime minister's preparations for the summit earlier in the week.

But that is putting a gloss on an essentially truthful case about Britain and the EU. The Tories and their media supporters - usually the Telegraph, the Mail and Sun, rather than public-service Auntie- are wildly out of control.

So I was amused, then, when one veteran colleague used a familiar lesson from the world of journalism to explain what the story of the EU's "new constitution" was actually all about.

"This business about simplifying the treaties," he said, sipping a cold Stella in the commission press bar as the air turned smoky blue. "You write 1,000 words, and the subs say, 'what's all this crap? No one can understand it.' So they cut it down to 500 words, and then it makes sense."

fields.headline: My unorthodox career
fields.standfirst: Brendan Gormley explains how he moved from social worker to monk to chief executive of the Disasters Emergency Committee
fields.trailText: Brendan Gormley explains how he moved from social worker to monk to chief executive of the Disasters Emergency Committee
fields.body:
The career profile of aid agency chief executives is changing as fast as the humanitarian world itself. New chief executives are increasingly likely to arrive from outside the humanitarian sector.

There are 14 member agencies of the Disasters Emergency Committee, an umbrella charity which launches and coordinates a national appeal in response to disasters overseas. Trustees are now placing strong emphasis on leadership, drive and effectiveness when searching for that person to take a charity forward. Shared values will outdo shared experience for the next generation of aid agency chiefs.

Before joining the humanitarian sector, and long before becoming the DEC's chief executive, my work experience was varied if not unorthodox: I was an "unattached" social worker with a Birmingham motorcycle gang, then joined the White Fathers Monastic Order.

Only then did I embark on a zigzag career path with Oxfam, which was to span 30 years. After nearly a decade working on Oxfam programmes in Africa and the Middle East, I returned to the Oxford headquarters as Africa director and then, most recently, as Asia and Latin America director.

The international response to the Sahel drought in the mid-70s was my first exposure to emergency programmes. Next came the so called "complex emergencies" in the Horn of Africa and central Africa, where internal conflict and weak, unaccountable governments played a major part in the misery of their nations. All these experiences confirmed my belief that any effective humanitarian intervention relies on informed political analysis as much as timely action.

The DEC brings together a unique alliance of aid, corporate, public and broadcasting services to rally compassion and ensure that funds raised go to member agencies best placed to bring effective and timely relief. My leadership challenge is to position the DEC as the "kite mark" in the public mind for effective fundraising and response when major crises erupt in the world. This will be done by building on member agencies such as the British Red Cross, Christian Aid, and Oxfam's commitment to effective collaboration both in the UK and at the point of delivery around the world. It will require further minimising of competition, increasing transparency and hopefully stimulating a climate of informed understanding and debate in the media.

While the British public still remains extremely generous and the DEC has raised more than £120m over the last two years, humanitarian values are challenged at every turn. The Kosovo war was waged as a "humanitarian" response; we are discouraged from aiding beggars in the street; and the media often caricatures the "aid business" as doing more harm than good.

Fortunately, the DEC can demonstrate that over the last few years its members have learned valuable lessons, and are striving to improve their accountability and effectiveness. Also, agencies have been robust in challenging politicians not to hide behind the fig leaf of humanitarian aid when dealing with the causes of suffering and loss of life across the world. As aid agencies take brave new steps to deal with a changing world, their personnel at all levels are becoming better trained, more professional, ever wiser. While humanitarian values remain the same, humanitarian practice - and the profile of those chosen to lead it - constantly evolves.

 The Disasters Emergency Committee member agencies are: ActionAid, British Red Cross, Cafod, Care International UK, Christian Children's Fund of Great Britain, Children's Aid Direct, Christian Aid, Concern, Help the Aged, Merlin, Oxfam, Save the Children, Tearfund, World Vision.

 DEC member agencies must be signatories to the code of conduct for the Red Cross and Red Crescent movement and non-governmental organisations, to help ensure ethical conduct in disaster relief operations.

webTitle: New hospital guidance puts end to 'prison culture' fears

fields.headline: New hospital guidance puts end to 'prison culture' fears
fields.trailText: New NHS guidance to improve security at Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor special hospitals has rejected the more "draconian" recommendations of a recent review in favour of "progressive" patient centred care, says the hospitals' former boss. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
New NHS guidance to improve security at Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor special hospitals has rejected the more "draconian" recommendations of a recent review in favour of "progressive" patient centred care, says the hospitals' former boss.

Ray Rowden, former director of the High Security Hospitals Commissioning Board, says the guidance published yesterday by health minister John Hutton represents a victory for clinicians over attempts to introduce a "prison culture" to the hospitals. "The more workable elements of the review have been kept, the more extreme rejected. This is good news for the more progressive staff, the people who reside in the hospitals and the security of the public," says Mr Rowden in an article published by societytheguardian.com today.

The guidance, which places tighter restrictions on visits to the hospitals and introduces random drugs testing, was introduced in the wake of concerns over persistent breaches of security by patients and staff.

A review of special hospitals' safety and security published by Sir Richard Tilt in June suggested a range of measures, many of which had a mixed reception form clinicians.

One particular recommendation, that the hospitals should consider locking the rooms of high-risk patients and patients on intensive care wards at night was criticised a because of fears that it would lead to an increase in suicide or self-harm among patients. The new guidance makes it clear that the decision to lock patients up at night will be taken by a clinical team based on a medical assessment of the individual patient. Health minister John Hutton said the guidelines would help high-security hospitals provide a safer environment for both patients and staff, and would be beneficial for the effective treatment and care of patients.

webTitle: NHS was right to reject recommendations

fields.headline: NHS was right to reject recommendations
fields.standfirst: The Tilt report sought to impose a prison culture in Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor hospitals, and it's a relief that the new NHS guidance has rejected some of its harshest recommendations, writes former special hospitals chief Ray Rowden
fields.trailText: Comment:The Tilt report sought to impose a prison culture in Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor hospitals, and it's a relief that the new NHS guidance has rejected some of its harshest recommendations, writes former special hospitals chief Ray Rowden.
fields.body:
New NHS guidance on security in Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor special hospitals has rejected the more draconian recommendations of the Tilt report. This is good news for patients and has prevented an exodus of 'progressive' staff.

In the fallout from the Fallon Inquiry into Ashworth Hospital, the government asked Sir Richard Tilt, former prisons director, to lead a review of security in all three high-secure hospitals. This was published in February and was as welcome as a bowl of cold vomit by most clinical professionals.

The great challenge in these services is setting a fine balance between the therapeutic environment and the security needs of a complex and vulnerable group of people.

We know from the catalogue of inquiries into these hospitals that failure to get the balance right has devastating effects. The problem that many had with the Tilt review was that it attempted to offer blanket solutions to a patient group that is anything but homogenous.

It did not recognise the needs of women, who rarely abscond, escape or seriously subvert security. The needs of patients from ethnic minority groups were largely ignored. The needs of mentally ill people, as opposed to those living with personality disorder, were not considered separately.

In short, the Tilt review sought to impose a prison culture to security in what are essentially NHS hospitals.

The government has responded to Tilt by issuing new security guidance to the hospitals. This offers a more pragmatic view of these issues. The new guidance allows the board of each hospital a greater degree of discretion as to how some of the more restrictive arrangements might be applied to individual patients.

The guidance also makes it clear that the patient's responsible medical officer and the hospital medical director will have a vital say in how the more restrictive elements of the guidance will or will not be applied.

This must be welcomed. If we are detaining citizens against their will in conditions of high security by reason of problems primarily related to their mental health, then it must be right that a clinician must have a lead role in security decisions as they apply to the individual.

These hospitals have operated a regime of 24-hour care in wards for many years. Prior to this, patients in the hospitals were "banged up" in their rooms through the night, much as prisoners are. Tilt recommended that "the feasibility of locking rooms at night of all patients on admission and intensive care wards, and all 'high-risk' patients, should be examined".

This reflects the wrong thinking behind the review. In effect, this was suggesting that at the very time people are at their most vulnerable, i.e., when newly admitted and full of anxiety and fear, or in need of intensive care, they be locked in their rooms overnight.

The implications such an approach might have had on increased rates of suicide and self-harm beggars belief. The new guidance thankfully rejects this approach and leaves such decisions to be applied by the clinical team on the basis of the needs of the individual patient.

New arrangements for the routine testing of patients for use of illicit substances are introduced, alongside a raft of policies to control the use of TV, videos, CDs or telephones.

Most are sensible, but again, allow the policies to be applied in a manner that need not compromise the clinical care of patients. However, it is regrettable there remains a risk that women will have these new arrangements applied to them in a discriminatory manner.

The guidance also brings in crucial new procedures for searching staff and visitors. Talking to many people living in these hospitals, it is clear that collusion from some corrupt and unethical staff and from visitors lies at the heart of some of the more serious breaches of security.

Just how can a mobile phone, electronic surveillance equipment, hard core pornography and heroin find their way in to such an environment? The answer is via someone outside the secure perimeter. As of now random searching of staff and visitors and the routine use of X-ray on their bags will become standard.

In short, the more workable elements of the Tilt Review have been kept, the more extreme rejected. How this came about is interesting. I spoke to many senior clinicians in all disciplines in the hospitals when the Tilt Review was published. Without exception they were deeply depressed with much of the review. One able psychiatrist assured me that implementation of Tilt in full would lead to a mass exodus of more enlightened practitioners from these services.

The chief executives of the hospitals had the unenviable task of conveying the serious nature of the views of good staff to ministers, who clearly wanted something done, and quickly.

I never believed I would say this, but thank God we had a czar. I understand that this thorny issue was handed over to Professor Louis Appleby, the new National Director for Mental Health by John Hutton, the minister responsible for high-security hospitals.

Professor Appleby worked with the hospitals to ensure that the systemic security improvements were put in place, but that good clinical care could continue.

While this is good news for the more progressive staff, the people who reside in these hospitals and might I say, the security of the public, the guidance does little to alter the totally dysfunctional nature of these places.

Tilt recommended the spending of some £25 million on new physical security for the hospitals, yet there has not been an escape since 1994.

We also know that government are intent on moving most women out of these hospitals and are likely to implement new arrangements for the care, support and containment of those with a more serious personality disorder next year.

These hospitals are therefore likely to become smaller, with a better focus and merged within mainstream NHS Trusts. The money currently being poured into physical security could be much better spent on a credible estates management plan, ensuring the hospitals are better suited to their future role.

My final note of caution lies in the fact that these troubled institutions remain on isolated sites, with deeply embedded cultures that the best security in the world will never overcome. It is still likely that, despite valiant efforts, and this largely sensible set of guidelines, that scandal will yet again erupt in one of them.

webTitle: Police say woman saw Damilola before killing

fields.headline: Police say woman saw Damilola before killing
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: A woman saw 10-year-old Damilola Taylor walking alone towards an alleyway just four minutes before he was found bleeding to his death on a stairwell after being stabbed, it emerged today.
fields.body:
A woman saw 10-year-old Damilola Taylor walking alone towards an alleyway just four minutes before he was found bleeding to his death on a stairwell after being stabbed, it emerged today.

News of the potentially crucial witness came as Damilola's father Richard was reunited with his family in London after flying in to London's Gatwick airport from Lagos, Nigeria.

It also emerged today that a child who was seen being marched along a road near the murder scene in Peckham, south-east London in a headlock on Monday afternoon was not Damilola.

Detectives will today speak to a boy and a girl who were filmed with Damilola on CCTV going into a library for an after-school computer class.

The two children, who are not suspects, have been identified by police, and officers will ask them what Damilola was saying in the hour before his brutal death. Police are also exploring the possibility that Damilola was followed from the library by his attackers.

Detective superintendent David Dillnutt, who is in charge of the inquiry, disclosed that a female witness spotted the boy walking past her home along Cronin Street in Peckham at about 4.45pm. At 4.49pm, a member of the public rang the emergency services to report a boy bleeding to death on a stairwell on the North Peckham estate.

Damilola left a 100-yard trail of blood as he tried to flee his attackers. He was bleeding heavily from a stab wound to his left leg.

Police are hunting three black youths who were wearing dark clothing and were seen running away from the murder scene.

Officers are also seeking information in relation to a reported bottle fight between youths outside the library where Damilola had gone to take his computer class at about 4pm. Police were called to the fight but found no evidence of a disturbance.

Yesterday, it was disclosed that a second knife was found about 200 metres from where Damilola lay bleeding to death.

That blade, along with another knife and a shard of glass, are still undergoing forensic tests. Detectives are also investigating a note found in Damilola's locker at Oliver Goldsmith primary school containing the name of one boy who may have been bullying the Nigerian-born youngster.

The dead boy's mother, Gloria, had voiced concerns to the school about bullying of her son the day before his death.

More than 40 detectives are working on the case - the biggest murder hunt in London since the Jill Dando investigation.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, made a direct appeal for help in tracking down those responsible for what he called the "evil" killing.

Mr Dillnutt said that children with information should not be frightened to come forward and if they were worried about speaking to police then they should talk to their parents, teachers or other community leaders, he said.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Perfect Storm | Stuart Little
fields.trailText: The Perfect Storm | Stuart Little
fields.body:
The Perfect Storm
Retail (£15.99/£16.99 widescreen), DVD (£19.99) Warner, Cert 12
***

If you feel like being swept away with special effects, The Perfect Storm will do the trick, with its 100ft waves and a visceral feeling of what it would be like to face them in a small fishing boat a very long way from home. The Perfect Storm turns your TV into a washing machine on the vibrating part of its spin cycle, but with people inside instead of Y-fronts. If you feel like being moved by a human drama of those at sea and those waiting to find out if they'll see them again, you might not be so impressed.

It's a shame because Warner Bros have done a lot of things right in this careful reconstruction of a 1991 tragedy when a hurricane collided with two hostile weather fronts to form the worst storm in recorded history. They bought Sebastian Junger's bestseller to base the film on. They hired Wolfgang Petersen, still best remembered for Das Boot, to bring an authentic atmosphere of claustrophobia at sea. They filmed the key scenes on land in Gloucester, Massachusetts, where the events actually took place. And they went for a cast of rough-at-the-edges actors who look like they could handle the hard living and the camaraderie of a dangerous trip on a swordfish boat, basing them around George Clooney and Mark Wahlberg, who struck sparks off each other so enjoyably in Three Kings. (Have you noticed how much easier it is to watch action films now that they star Clooney, Crowe or Cage rather than Schwarzenegger, Stallone and Willis, by the way?). Back home, they give us Diane Lane and Karen Allen, feisty women not weeping wives. And the eternally mean Michael Ironside, as the boat's owner, gives us a readymade villain at the dockside.

But sadly, they got a couple of things badly wrong: Bill Wittliff's doomy, overwrought script and James Horner's insistent sentimental strings are too eager to push you at the kingsize box of tissues instead of getting you involved in the film's characters and lives. Some of the mawkish father-and-son stuff doesn't fit this tough, tight community and everyone seems in the middle of their own personal crisis at the same time on the brief period between two fishing trips, like it was just any old disaster movie. With so little to engage the audience on the script front, it all seems to go on a bit too long.

The DVD has a welter of extras, including Petersen's commentary, interviews with actors and locals battered by the real storm and an explanation of how the film's makers tried to match it - an extra-hard task when even TV is awash with extreme weather programmes as it is.

Stuart Little
Rental, retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert U
***

The beginning, in which Hugh Laurie and Geena Davis pick a talking mouse from the adoption home, suggests unrelieved terminal whimsical cuteness, but once they get him home, things take a turn for the better. There's a talking housecat who is not best pleased and faces severe loss of face from his mates, the street cats, who see Stuart strictly as lunch. Some nicely shot adventures follow, like a chase through Central Park ("Da mouse is sleepin' wid da fishes," says street cat Smokey, hopefully). The lead character, being nervous, energetic and very small, is a natural for Michael J Fox and this odd tale from a 1945 story makes very passable fare for the smaller family members.

webTitle: Virgin Net to make 30 staff redundant

fields.headline: Virgin Net to make 30 staff redundant
fields.trailText: 12pm: Virgin Net is to make 30 staff redundant as part of its makeover from an ISP into an entertainment portal, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet service provider-turned-entertainment portal Virgin Net is making 30 staff redundant in what it is calling it "a consultative process".

A quarter of Virgin Net's 170 staff will be asked to leave before the new year.

All departments will be affected by the cull, in particular people working in technical, development and content roles. No senior jobs are said to be affected.

The company is making the cuts as part of the second phase of a restructure "to deliver growth and cost savings to reach profitability in 2002".

Alex Heath, managing director of Virgin Net, said: "Our decision to restructure in this way has been taken following an in-depth review of the way we operate.

"Every effort will be made to minimise the impact on those individuals that find themselves in redundant roles."

The move is being prompted by NTL, which owns 49% of Virgin Net, buying Virgin out and pooling the ISP subscribers into NTL World.

Virgin Net will now focus its efforts on positioning itself as an entertainment portal.

fields.headline: Tories forge social policy
fields.standfirst: Conservative proposals for local government and regeneration are the fruits of three years in opposition
fields.trailText: Conservative proposals for local government and regeneration are the fruits of three years in opposition, writes Simon Parker
fields.body:
The current Labour government had 18 years in the political wilderness to forge a new social policy, so maybe it shouldn't be surprising that the Conservative programme for the 1997 general election looked decidedly unoriginal by contrast.

Now that the Conservatives are in opposition, and potentially facing years out of government, they too have embarked on the long road to a new policy for the public sector.

The Tories have put a great deal of energy into the newly trendy area of regeneration, traditionally seen as Labour's home territory. Local government - another traditionally Labour policy area - has also received a great deal of attention from the Conservatives, partly because the party's new promise of more devolution for councils helps them portray ministers as overbearing and centralist.

Much of this work has been done in the last year, as a relatively fresh-faced team of shadow ministers started looking towards their future careers. This is what they have achieved so far on the key issues of local government and regeneration

So, what's the big idea for local government?
In a word, devolution. The Conservatives say they will give local government more freedom by ending council tax capping and giving more economic development powers to county councils. The best councils will also benefit from the Tory "free councils" policy, which will allow them greater freedom to borrow money, a lighter-touch inspection regime and a reduction in their administrative burden. Failing local authorities should be punished through the ballot box, the party says, not by government intervention.

Isn't this a u-turn for a party that made such enthusiastic use of capping in the 1980s?
Yes, but the new-found Conservative love of devolution does not necessarily translate into a love of local government as an institution. The Tories effectively want to abolish the council role in frontline education provision by handing many local education authority powers to school governors. While councils may be trusted to set their own domestic tax levels, the Conservatives are distinctly uncomfortable with current proposals to give local government powers to raise the business rate. The Tories would also transfer all council housing to the social sector within five years of taking power.

All this has led some to suggest the party is giving new freedoms with one hand, while stripping the power needed to use them with the other.

What about modernising local government?
The Conservatives have never really been reconciled to the idea of scrapping the committee system. The century-old system is currently on its way out, as the government replaces committees with council mayors and cabinets. The Tories plan to bring committees back, allowing councils greater choice over how their political management arrangements work. Councillors will have to hold a referendum to overturn a directly elected mayor and return to committees, but will be able to unilaterally throw out cabinets.

And best value?
The Tories are not opposed to the principle of best value. Indeed, shadow local government minister Nigel Waterson has claimed that best value would not have been possible without the previous - Conservative - compulsory competitive tendering regime, which introduced private service providers into local government on a large scale. But the Tories say best value is costly and heavy-handed, particularly for well-performing authorities. They promise to overhaul or abolish the system.

Labour has made regeneration a key plank of its policy programme. What are the Tories doing to fight this?
The Conservatives launched a big push on regeneration at their party conference this year, promising a "new social agenda". Under a Tory government, private-sector led regeneration companies would be set up to promote redevelopment in urban areas, while county councils would be given more power to tackle rural issues by gaining the funding currently put into regional development agencies (RDAs), which will be abolished.

The RDAs have only recently been established, so why do the Conservatives want to abolish them?
The party argues RDAs are cumbersome and expensive beasts that sprawl across the responsibilities of several departments, including Trade and Industry and Environment, Transport and the Regions. This, say the Tories, creates confusion and a lack of co-ordination.

The Conservatives also see the agencies as the first step towards elected English regional government. The party believes this could threaten its power base in county councils, which could be abolished to make way for the regional bodies.

Why the focus on urban regeneration? Aren't the Conservatives traditionally the party of the suburbs?
It's partly because of the controversy raging over housing pressures on the south-east. The Conservatives are set against what they have termed "concreting over the countryside" and believe that the way to relieve pressure on the south-east is to make northern cities better places to live.

The party is also aware that suburban voters care about the state of the inner city facilities and the plight of those affected by urban decay.

fields.headline: Hot Feet and Baby Bowen
fields.trailText:
Baby grounds Bowen
BBC chiefs have finally succeeded in persuading Jeremy Bowen to hang up his trenchcoat. Bowen has reportedly been weaned off running back to the middle east by the prospect of impending fatherhood and is even reported to be looking at houses in London. What did you do in the battle of the breakfast bulletins, Daddy?
fields.body:
Baby grounds Bowen
BBC chiefs have finally succeeded in persuading Jeremy Bowen to hang up his trenchcoat. Bowen has reportedly been weaned off running back to the middle east by the prospect of impending fatherhood and is even reported to be looking at houses in London. What did you do in the battle of the breakfast bulletins, Daddy?

Red hot feet
All TV executives know the value of the web for cross-branding. But just imagine the shock viewers felt when they logged on to coldfeet.com for a chat with actor Jimmy Nesbitt and found that the site had already been bagged by a bevy of lovely ladies with names like Dark Meat, Real Teens and Perfect Tits. The real site for ITV's Cold Feet drama is something far more obvious - coldfeetonline.co.uk

Bonus question
Who says it doesn't pay to take on your bosses? Express City hack David Hellier got a verbal pounding from Lord Hollick after writing a story earlier this year which revealed Carlton and United TV were in talks. The share price for United plummeted the day the story appeared and Carlton's Michael Green threatened to withdraw from talks, berating Hollick for not being able to "control his journalists". Hollick, who owned the Express and United TV at the time, was furious that his cover was blown and told Hellier in no uncertain terms. "You have just lost me £150m" he barked when he met the lowly journalist. Days later he was still on the warpath demanding a personal apology. But Hellier stood his ground and refused to say sorry. Obviously the right thing to do, because Hellier is one of the dozen staff who have just got a £40,000 bonus from the Lord.

Dirty dozen
Speaking of bonuses - rumour is that Express journalist Martin Samuel is one of the select dozen who benefited from Lord Hollick's largesse.

Hairy buttocks ban
Worldbeating jazzmag FHM has launched a drive to eliminate all but the merest whiff of testosterone from its pages - presumably its readers are so determinedly heterosexual that a glimpsed hairy buttock could put them off their Monkey Spanking. The January edition, encased in Madonna-style cellophane, carries an exclusive "S Club Frenzy" picture featuring... four women. We really should be told if the other three, male, members of the band have quit.

The right man for the job
A former Loaded mole recalls that plans to find an editor for the august organ were nearly resolved when Piers Hernu was offered the position. But the man described by James Brown as "a minor league star waiting to happen" so scared his prospective staff, that a special delegation was sent to advise the management of impending discontent if he was appointed. Meanwhile, Monkey understands that the favourite for the long-vacant editor's job could be that uber-laddette Rosie Boycott.

Burning secrets at Coca-Cola
Coca-Cola is notorious for its secrecy, but the drinks company is taking it too far this time. PR agency Jackie Cooper, which is handling the launch of Coke's new energy drink Burn, has been told not to talk to the press under any circumstances. Isn't PR life fun.

Who's that sitting in my desk?
Richard Desmond's clearout at the Express papers has moved from personnel to furniture, with the Express sports team finding their space taken by the OK! magazine editorial team. Political columnist Peter Oborne has also been re-located, though he can't be too unhappy. He can use some of the £40,000 he received as a goodbye from Lord Hollick to buy a new desk.

The Posh 'n' Becks Express
Desmond surprised staff at the Express and Star after arranging a late night regal tour of the building for the King and Queen of OK! magazine. But not everyone was horrified at the sight of Posh and Becks holding court in the offices of the right-on newspaper. One old duffer in the newsroom, who missed the point completely, was heard exclaiming: "That Desmond's personal assistant is a bit of a looker, isn't she?"

Fancy a curry?
Mr Desmond, meanwhile, had his own little treat prepared for the couple after their exciting trip round the building. The millionaire publisher knows how to impress his fellow millionaires, taking them to a slap up meal - at a nearby Indian restaurant.

Mama Mia Madonna
Altruistic Financial Times hacks auction their freebies for charity if no one wants them. However, they are so achingly hip or incredibly tight that yan unwanted ticket for the gig of the year raised a measly £70. Madonna tickets were fetching £2,000 on the internet.

Metro, you are the weakest link!
At a charity quiz last night contestants were shown headlines from that morning's Metro with one word blacked out. But fears that the contest had been rigged in favour of the Associated Newspapers title, which was sponsoring the event, soon disappeared when rival teams discovered the Metro team had scored nul points.

Tough man Stan doubles as nurse on call
Northern & Shell's deputy managing director Stan Myerson has a reputation as a bit of a tough guy. So he may not see the funny side when he finds out that his new phone line at the Express is still diverting to the voice mail message of its previous owner - company nurse Anne Norton. Somehow Monkey can't quite imagine Mr Myerson dressed in uniform administering TLC to poorly Express workers. "We'll get it changed soon but we're in a bit of a flap at the moment getting everyone's phones sorted out," said a harassed receptionist.

The news they were holding back
In typical Dunkirk spirit, staff at Express Digital Media (the website arm of Express Newspapers) have dug in and await their fate, following MediaGuardian.co.uk's report that all four websites are to be shut down. After Friday's announcement that Desmond et al were rethinking the future of the websites, staff found out their fate not from their new owner but via press reports. They await confirmation with bated breath.

Star sugar from Posh and Becks
Richard Desmond may not be everyone's cup of tea, but staff at the Star are finding his views fit the paper as snugly as a condom. He has promised them (a) more staff, (b) exclusives with the stars, and (c) access to the king and queen of showbiz and OK!'s best star-turns - Posh and Becks.

webTitle: Dec 1: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Constructive work with the housing team
fields.standfirst: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen finds positive steps are being taken as her team build up links with the housing department
fields.trailText: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen finds positive steps are being taken as her team build up links with the housing department
fields.body:
A positive week. It started with the coming together of housing's management team with mine. This is a regular event now and there is evidence that constructive work is happening between staff outside the meetings to try to solve problems that are (at last) being seen as common rather than the fault of the other party.

We'll know we've really made progress when social workers stop berating housing for being unable to provide clients with four-bedroom houses with gardens in Streatham and start advising clients about realistic options, thereby avoiding pointless wrangles which get played out in court to the displeasure of all concerned - except the lawyers of course.

We have had some joint sessions aimed at getting staff to feel like colleagues who work for one organisation, and will be doing more in future.

Reflected on these and other organisational peccadilloes when I met with the Improvement and Development Agency team who have been with us this week doing a "peer review". By the time they got to me it was near the end of their visit - so they had obviously begun to hone their thoughts and seemed to be highly perceptive about the state of the authority.

It was quite therapeutic to be talking to people who understand what it is like to be in the furnace and don't want to merely stand outside and turn up the heat. The report will be out in four weeks.

My mind is more on the forthcoming special council meeting at which the joint review report will finally be presented and to which the Barratt report and social services inspectorate inspection have been requisitioned for a further chewing over.

I shall be presenting the joint review action plan (no diary of mine can be complete without the mention of at least one action plan - as I am sure you are beginning to realise) and need to sharpen my PowerPoint skills. I found myself dreaming of flying bullet points whizzing impressively on to the screen - but the list was all about my daughter's fourth birthday party ...

webTitle: Hopes for a better life for care leavers

fields.headline: Hopes for a better life for care leavers
fields.standfirst: The coming Children (Leaving Care) Act could make a huge difference to young people leaving care, but there will be need for more resources and good practice guidelines. Radhika Holmstrom reports
fields.trailText: The coming Children (Leaving Care) Act could make a huge difference to young people leaving care, but there will be need for more resources and good practice guidelines. Radhika Holmstrom reports
fields.body:
"What you need is someone there that you can talk to and can help you. Not just when you know you're already in trouble but when you can see the difficulties coming - and you shouldn't have to go and ask, they should be there with you, ready for you, supporting you through it." This was the comment of a young care leaver, quoted in the Rough Sleepers Unit's audit and assessment of leaving care services in London, September 2000.

The Social Exclusion Unit recognises the crucial position of vulnerable young people and the need to join up services. The housing green paper acknowledges that care leavers are a vulnerable group in terms of housing priorities. Yet at least a quarter of the homeless young people in London have spent time in care. The RSU audit points to gaps in the housing provision in London and also to the alarming fact that many Quality Protects management action plans don't go into enough detail on after-care.

The Children (Leaving Care) Act aims to tackle these shortcomings when it is implemented in April 2001. Each young person will receive an assessment, a "pathway plan" and a young person's adviser, and contact and assistance (including money) from their local authority until they are at least 21. The pathway plan will include accommodation.

Agencies working with young people agree that the bill has the potential to make a huge difference. NCH Action for Children public policy officer Amanda Allard sumed up the concerns: "Nobody's arguing about what's in it. The difficulty is that we still don't know the additional financial support, the regulations, or limits on things like advisers' caseloads."

A National Foster Care Association (NFCA) survey in Wales also pointed out that some foster carers continue to supply considerable informal support after young people leave home. Rather than relinquish this completely to the personal adviser, the NFCA wants local authorities to recognise and build on it.

Regarding homelessness, authorities need to implement some decent models of good practice urgently. To this end, the RSU has appointed youth homelessness agency Centrepoint to advise authorities in London.

Although Centrepoint is not advocating one specific model at the moment, its leaving care co-ordinator John Short is clear that "what works and what doesn't is generally known - the key is building relationships with young people to develop the life skills they need".

Many of the problems young care leavers face are not just about accommodation but sustaining it. Mr Short's work, like similar projects by NCH and the Children's Society, aims to build up "independent living skills". He said: "You need a fairly low case load to be able to manage that. For instance, a young person needs a worker for the full day when they move into a flat. It's labour-intensive, but it's very important that any statement is translated into the nitty-gritty of how you actually make this work for individual young people." He added that young people also need social housing - which is in short supply.

Ena Fry, of the NFCA, agreed. "Safe, secure, affordable accommodation is becoming less of a reality," she said. "The different government departments really have to get their heads together in defining 'suitable accommodation' for care leavers. We need to assess and check private landlords. We also need to look at more specialist provision, like extending existing foster care placements until young people are ready to move on, or converting them into supported lodgings."

The final concern is for homeless young people who have not been in care. Other vulnerable young people are also passed between housing and social services departments, or find themselves in tenancies they cannot sustain. They will also continue to live on lower benefit levels which assume parental "help", while care leavers move out of the benefit system on to the new financial assistance.

If housing and support all become ring fenced for one undeniably high priority group, and no extra assistance goes towards the others, the rest of the young homeless population could lose out.

fields.headline: Miss World a winner for C5
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV Overnights: TV coverage of Miss World gave Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey some ratings cheer last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Newly crowned Miss World Priyanka Chopra was not the only one who left the Dome smiling last night, with TV coverage of the event also giving Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey some ratings cheer.

Miss World 2000, which was hosted by Jerry Springer, averaged 1.8m and an 8% share over two-and-a-half hours from 8pm last night, according to unofficial overnights.

10.45am: The latest high-profile journalist to leave the Express has accused Richard Desmond of treating readers like "imbeciles", writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 27: Catholic Kenny resigns
Nov 27: Express exodus begins
fields.body:
The latest high-profile journalist to leave the Express has launched a scathing attack on the paper's new owner, Richard Desmond, accusing him of treating readers like "imbeciles".

Express comment writer Stephen Pollard, who resigned yesterday to join the Times, has told MediaGuardian.co.uk that his departure from the paper was "entirely precipitated by the arrival of Richard Desmond".

Mr Pollard said: "I was very happy at the Express, but the new owners think our readers are imbeciles who want to live on a diet of pap."

He is to join the Times, where he will write a weekly column on health policy, opinion columns and leaders.

Mr Pollard added: "It's a fantastic job that I'm looking forward to doing," but said that before the takeover of the Express by Northern & Shell two weeks ago he was committed to "the Rosie experiment".

Mr Pollard is the latest in a string of journalists to leave the paper following its takeover by Mr Desmond.

Columnist Mary Kenny and political editor Anthony Bevins left at the start of the week.

Express journalists are said to be divided by the arrival of Mr Desmond and his Northern & Shell editorial staff, headed by former OK! editorial director Paul Ashford.

Some are relieved that the paper now has an owner who is prepared to invest in editorial.

One journalist said: "I know people don't like his soft porn and think he is vulgar and bad news. But you have to admire and have respect for a guy who is putting his own money into the paper.

"Hollick didn't put any money into it, so we have gone from nothing to something which has got to be good."

Others are disturbed by Mr Desmond's involvement in top-shelf titles and his celebrity-led editorial strategy.

fields.headline: Old economy to replace tech stocks in FTSE 100
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The quarterly FTSE 100 reshuffle is likely to see old economy stalwarts replacing technology stocks, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Old and new economy firms are set to swap places when the UK's flagship stock market index announces its quarterly clearout next week.

The FTSE 100 shake-out, to be revealed on Wednesday, is expected to dump a handful of technology stocks and bring in an assortment of brewers and retailers.

The list is made up of the largest companies by market capitalisation, calculated by the total value of their shares.

Favourites for the chop are internet security company Baltimore, computer services group Sema and chip-maker Bookham Technology.

They are set to be replaced by supermarket giant Safeway, the Scottish & Newcastle brewer and engine maker Rolls-Royce.

UK technology shares have been hammered by a series of profits warnings from US giants such as Dell and Lucent, with uncertainty over the US presidential election increasing market jitters.

However, fund managers expect a minor revival for put-upon tech stocks before the end of the year.

Colin McLean at Scottish Value Management said: "There will be a recovery, but it will be selective. People will focus on the larger stocks looking for bargains."

Mr McLean said the lack of new share issues, which tech companies use to get a quick cash boost, have allowed old economy companies to rise up the stock market listings on the back of organic growth.

Internet and technology upstarts have fallen due to mounting losses and panic-selling by investors.

The techMARK index in London has lost 43% of its value over the past three months, while the tech-rich Nasdaq listing in New York has shed nearly half its value since March.

11.15am: Up to 25 staff at the Daily Express and Daily Star have received Lord Hollick's notorious "goodbye-and-thank-you" bonuses, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Dec 1: Express plunged into chaos

fields.body:
Up to 25 staff at the Daily Express and Daily Star have received Lord Hollick's notorious "goodbye-and-thank-you" bonuses of up to £40,000 each.

Sources say that the Labour peer, who sold the newspaper group last week for £125m, has handed out cheques worth £1m to journalists on the two papers.

Up until now it was believed that just a dozen of Lord Hollick's favourite staff had received the cash.

The love-list is believed to include right-wing columnist Peter Hitchens and City editor Patrick Hosking, who has been at the paper for little over a year.

Sunday Express editor Michael Pilgrim and three senior staff on the Daily Star have also pocketed the surprise windfalls, including the paper's editor, Peter Hill and his deputy Hugh Whittow.

The bizarre bonus scheme is already creating bitter divisions among newsroom staff.

Other names on the list include Express number three Chris Williams, features editor John Price, comment writer David Robson and political editor Anthony Bevins, who quit the paper earlier this week in protest against the arrival of new owner Richard Desmond.

Star columnist Dawn Neeson is also believed to have received a cheque and, according to sources, Express diarist John McEntee's name was also on the list.

Both Mr McEntee and Chris Williams have denied they have received £40,000 however.

Express sports writers Martin Samuel and Rob Shepherd were singled out for the windfall, too, as was columnist Peter Oborne.

Up to now only five names on the list were known including Rosie Boycott, her deputy Chris Blackhurst and chief City correspondent David Hellier, who have all admitted they received the cheques.

The silence of the other beneficiaries, however, will shock staff, particularly those who have considered themselves loyal, hardworking and perhaps more deserving of bonuses.

"Some of the people on this list have only been here two seconds. Why Patrick Hosking is on the list is anyone's guess. Everyone who has seen the list has been scratching their heads to work out what the common link is," said one source.

"As far as we can tell the only reason they are on the list is because they are the only people Hollick met.

"He spoke to Hellier and Hosking because they wrote about business and the merger of United and Carlton TV.

"He loved talking football to the sports guys and gossiping about politics with Hitchins and Bevins and of course he knew Rosie and Chris."

Others on the list include Express board directors Andy Jonescu, managing director; Paul Rudd, production director; Paul Woolfenden; marketing director; John Stroud, information technology director; Jim Campbell, chief finance director at Xilerate; James Dymot, finance director; and advertising director Richard Bogie.

The identity of the 25th beneficiary is Lindsay Cook, managing editor of the Express, said one source.

However, an insider at United claims that personnel director Nicky Gray is the 25th name.

fields.body:
Express sports writer Charles Sale could be the next journalist to quit the paper since the arrival of new owner Richard Desmond.

He is being wooed by several newspapers, including The Times, which are keen to hire him for his insight into the sports business world.

His departure would be a certain blow to the Express.

Mr Sale, who was not at work today, has been one of the paper's best-kept secrets for years.

Although he has produced scoop after scoop, notably during times of negotiations between TV companies and football authorities, his column has remained buried on the inside back page.

Sources say that a deal with the Times is imminent.

fields.headline: Last hurrah for les rosbifs
fields.standfirst: Watching Britain's xenophobic bluster from across the channel, writes Jon Henley in Paris, is a grim and bemusing experience
fields.trailText: View from Paris: Watching Britain's xenophobic bluster from across the channel, writes Jon Henley, is a grim and bemusing experience
fields.body:
When exactly will we grow up? A French minister has the misfortune to preside over the failure of international talks on climate change in The Hague; she is denounced as an incompetent female at the head of a team of dastardly Frogs and other continentals out to scupper our brave deputy PM.

The British government, along with a few other reasonably large and not notably daft countries, commits some soldiers, should they be needed, to an EU rapid-reaction force; the move is variously interpreted as catastrophic, the end of Blighty as we know it, and Napoleon's revenge. One paper reveals that the father of the commander of the new "army" (which it isn't) fought for the Nazis.

The new British passports, reports another newspaper, will feature the European Union's 12 stars rather than the royal coat of arms. This further horrifying evidence of the ongoing construction of a European superstate is not, of course, true. But hell, that doesn't matter much.

Mad cow panic grips France after a crooked meat dealer is found to have sold potentially BSE-infected meat. The reaction across the channel - forgetting somehow that this is a disease that was 100% made in Britain and has been exported by us to the continent - could perhaps best be described as: "Ha, ha, now it's their turn."

Viewed from the continent, where I have now lived for nearly 15 years, this kind of stuff - once typified by the Up Yours Delors days of the pro-Thatcher Sun - used to be quaintly amusing. It isn't any more. It is, as Dominique Voynet, the French environment minister, might have said of John Prescott's comments on her shortcomings, plain sad.

This is not, I hasten to say, facile pro-Europeanism on my part. There is much that is bad about Europe; indeed some of it is so bad that inventing things which would - if they were true - make it worse really does not seem necessary.

But there is a kind of deliberately distorting, kneejerk anti-European, anti-French, anti-German, anti-everybody-who-isn't-damn-well-British mood in Britain these days that, from here at least, simply beggars belief.

The way almost all European issues are treated in Britain (a cooked-up scandal in the eurosceptic press followed by a defensive denial from the government and some publicity-grabbing scaremongering from the Right) means that it is now all but impossible for the average Briton to know what is actually going on.

It also makes Tony Blair's position invidious. On almost every European question he is forced to hesitate, temporise, digress or simply keep mum. Days before the Nice summit, this leaves him with no room for manoeuvre. Every item on the agenda is an unexploded bomb.

Regardless of the rights or wrongs of each issue, if he gives up Britain's veto on taxation, social security or border controls he will be accused of treachery and abandoning British sovereignty. If he signs up to the charter of fundamental rights the pages of the editorials will be dripping with venom over "the first step towards a European constitution".

France is far from perfect. French politicians and diplomats can appear, and often are, arrogant, meddling and pompous. This is not a country where it is advisable to cross a policeman, complain of bad service in a shop, omit to fill in all the boxes on the form, or step onto the metro wearing a short skirt.

But the average French citizen does not harbour this absurd Little Englander suspicion of all that is not British; this unreal belief that the forces of European evil are gathering around our island, intent on terminating Britain as we know it; this misconceived conviction that France (and Germany and Italy and Holland and all the rest) is somehow up to its neck in some fiendish plot to overturn the existing world order and Britain with it.

The average French citizen, too, is a lot better informed about what Europe means and where it is heading, and it doesn't seem, on the whole, to worry them very much. If the average British citizen knew what Europe actually meant and where it was really heading, I don't think they would be worried very much either - but if they were, they would at least be expressing well-founded concerns. At the moment, all they have to go on are wild, panic-fuelled fantasies.

1.45pm: The Express has been plunged into chaos after the publication of the names of 25 staff given £40,000 bonuses by Lord Hollick, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
12.45pm: Sports writer next to go?
11.15am: Hollick's handouts: who got what

fields.body:
The Express newspaper has been plunged into chaos after MediaGuardian.co.uk published the names of 25 staff singled out for £40,000 bonuses.

Journalists who have spent the past four years battling against swingeing cutbacks and lack of resources were incandescent with rage when they learned today that former owner Lord Hollick had handed over £1m in ex gracia payments to a select few.

"It is civil war here. People are rightly furious," said one journalist. "That is the money that we have been pleading for over the last few years.

"We could have had 25 extra reporters for that and given the paper the chance it needed."

Another said: "This is absolutely shocking. Why some of these people have got money when they can hardly string 40 words together is breathtaking.

"We are all just agog here. Lord Hollick is clearly the villain of the piece. He has just left this brilliant ticking timebomb that has sent the place into chaos.

"Instead of blaming him, we are now at each other's throats. What a brilliant device for causing divisions."

Many on the paper are outraged by Lord Hollick's decision to reward just a few journalists.

"It would have been better to have given everyone £1,000 or £2,000. That would have been fairer," said one.

Sunday Express editor Michael Pilgrim was confronted by the paper's political editor Jon Craig at this morning's conference about the payment.

"He just said he didn't want to talk about it," said one staff member present.

A spokesman for Lord Hollick refused to confirm or deny the list of recipients.

He said: "It was not Lord Hollick, but the company. A number of people have been given ex gracia payments in recognition of the significant contribution they have made to the group over the years."

The spokesman added that payments had been made to staff at every company disposed of this year, including United Broadcasting and Miller Freeman.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited

fields.trailText: Another day, another Ronaldo rumour. This time it's Chelsea who are "planning an audacious raid" to bring the Brazilian striker on loan, according to the Daily Star.
fields.body:
Another day, another Ronaldo rumour. This time it's Chelsea who are "planning an audacious raid" to bring the Brazilian striker on loan, according to the Daily Star.

And Chelsea have confirmed they are interested in bringing Robbie Keane on loan to Stamford Bridge. Chief executive Colin Hutchinson admitted: "We are currently looking at various playing options. We are monitoring the situation regarding Robbie Keane and have been in touch with Inter Milan about him."

Wimbledon's John Hartson could join Celtic on loan, according to the Daily Record.

Las Palmas will renew their interest in the transfer-listed Birmingham striker Dele Adebola when the Spanish transfer window reopens tomorrow, reports Planet Football.

Neil Lennon is on his way to Celtic after Leicester accepted an improved £5.5m offer, reports the Sun.

Spurs are lining up Swedish international Olof Mellberg to replace Sol Campbell, reports the Sun. The 23-year-old Racing Santander defender is under contract until 2003 but has a clause in his agreement that says he can leave for £7m.

West Ham have turned down the chance to sign David Ginola, claims the Express. "Ginola was offered to us by one of his mates," Harry Redknapp said. "I'm one of his biggest fans, but we'd need one ball for him, one ball for Paolo Di Canio and another for the rest of the team."

webTitle: Award season gets off to uninspiring start

fields.headline: Award season gets off to uninspiring start
fields.trailText: There are few suprises among the nominees for the People's Choice Awards which pay tribute to mainstream Hollywood blockbusters and ignore independent cinema
fields.body:
The Hollywood backslapping season has begun early, with the news today of the nominations for the People's Choice Awards. Nominees and winners are selected by a Gallup poll of over 213m Americans and it seems that what they want more than anything is crass patriotism, sentimentality and baseball.

The Best Picture nominations include The Patriot, The Green Mile and Denzel Washington's baseball drama, Remember the Titans.

Meet the Parents, Nutty Professor 2: The Clumps and Scary Movie will go head to head for the Best Comedy Picture prize, while Adam Sandler (pictured), Jim Carrey, Mel Gibson, Tom Hanks, Denzel Washington, Sandra Bullock, Julia Roberts and Meg Ryan are among the top stars who will be competing for the acting awards.

The gongs will be handed out on January 7, 2001. Let's hope that some of the numerous ceremonies to follow will have a few more surprises, with more nods to non-mainstream fare - this list does not auger well for an interesting award season.

Check out the full list of nominees on ABC News.

webTitle: Anti-stress tips must not replace broad mental health promotion

fields.headline: Anti-stress tips must not replace broad mental health promotion
fields.standfirst: Too many attempts to get rid of stress in the workplace concentrate on antidotes or coping strategies rather than working culture, writes Lynne Friedli
fields.trailText: Too many attempts to get rid of stress in the workplace concentrate on antidotes or coping strategies rather than working culture, writes Lynne Friedli
fields.body:
There is little doubt that stress is moving rapidly up the agenda. The "pull yourself together" brigade are retreating in the face of increasing evidence of the damaging impact of stress on health and productivity. Tackling stress is a growth industry, attracting many purveyors of snake oils and holy water, as well as more strategic remedies. An emphasis on the role of the employer has been driven by concerns about the risks of legal action, although public sector union Unison says that only a very small percentage of work related stress cases are successful.

This interest in stress has been widely welcomed and it is difficult to find dissenting voices. Indeed, "stress management" is rapidly displacing the broader concept of promoting mental health. So it is worth looking more critically at the implications of the stress agenda.

The problem is vulnerable to an overemphasis on individual solutions. From counselling to aromatherapy, massage to time management, seeking the "inner smile" to self-hypnosis, big companies are investing large sums in what might be called stress immunisation programmes. There are companies marketing "more effective thinking skills" as an antidote to stress, or offering employee assistance programmes to avoid litigation.

These and similar approaches aim to help people cope with pressure and improve their performance, rather than questioning the ethics of current working practices. Yet all the evidence seems to show that the only approaches that work are systemic - those which address and transform working practice and culture.

The Health and Safety Executive has identified the key causes of stress: poor management culture, excessive job demands, low job control, poor communications, role uncertainty and lack of training and support. These causes need to be at the forefront of stress solutions, particularly as the people who are most vulnerable to stress - the lowest paid - are least likely to be in a position to benefit from individual remedies.

A broader and more radical mental health agenda is one which addresses the mental health impact of policy and practice, and what is needed to create a mentally healthy society. Confining the discussion to stress allows us to remain within the safety zone of "lifestyle" and avoids difficult questions about discrimination and the exclusion of people with mental health problems.

These issues have a special relevance for public sector employees. In an assessment of the most stressful jobs carried out by University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology in 1997, which looked at 104 different jobs types, nine out of the 10 most stressful were found to be in the public sector. Four of these were in the NHS. With this kind of statistics, there is a danger that public sector workers and unions will lobby for stress solutions, rather than campaigning for mental health promotion policies.

There are three elements to an effective mental health promotion policy:
 the promotion of the mental health and well-being of all staff
 support for staff returning to work following absence because of mental health problems
 a positive approach to employing people with mental health problems.

Mental health promotion policies provide a framework for valuing and benefiting from diversity and fostering social inclusion. It would be a shame if this is lost in the current fervour about stress.

 Lynne Friedli is chief executive of mentality, a voluntary agency dedicated to mental health promotion

webTitle: Children on poor estates use crime to gain 'street cred'

fields.headline: Children on poor estates use crime to gain 'street cred'
fields.standfirst: Playground bullies as young as 10 are taking their menace to the streets
fields.trailText: Playground bullies as young as 10 are taking their menace to the streets. Nick Hopkins reports.
fields.body:
A new breed of young criminals, many as young as 10, are committing street robberies because they believe it will give them credibility and status in neighbourhoods they regard as "lawless", Scotland Yard said yesterday.

Sir John Stevens, commissioner of the Metropolitan police, said a recent rise in robberies around London reflected "a new phenomenon" - playground bullies taking their intimidation and menace outside school.

Many of the offenders targeted pupils they knew and put pressure on the victims not to come forward for fear of reprisals.

Although the Met recognises little research has been done in this field, it believes there is enough anecdotal evidence from officers on the beat, as well as worrying statistics from selected boroughs, to conclude a trend is emerging.

Sir John's remarks yesterday had particular resonance because the killers of Damilola Taylor, the 10-year-old who bled to death in a south London council estate stairwell on Monday, are thought to be from his age group.

Describing Damilola's death as "shocking and tragic", the commissioner said 40 officers were now working on the case full time and every back-up support was being offered.

Referring to recent figures from the west London borough of Hounslow, Sir John said 70% of street robberies were committed by youths under the age of 17. He said 72% of the victims were also under 17, and 40% of the offenders had never been in trouble with the police before, and were surprised they had been arrested.

Commander Tim Godwin said some of the teenagers spoke of earning £300 a week from street crime. They stole pocket money, mobile phones, credit cards and Pokemon cards, he said. In one case a boy told officers how he stole money to give to his parents.

But cash was not the sole or most important motive of those involved. Street crimes were often committed as a rite of passage by youths who were under pressure from their peers, Mr Godwin said.

Sir John said: "What we are witnessing is a new breed of criminal. What started off in the playground is now moving on into the streets."

It was, he said, a new phenomenon.

webTitle: Bravado and fear over death of a neighbour

fields.headline: Bravado and fear over death of a neighbour
fields.standfirst: Young people regularly carry knives and many will not go out alone - welcome to the estate that was home to Damilola Taylor
fields.trailText: Young people regularly carry knives and many will not go out alone - welcome to the estate that was home to Damilola Taylor. By Audrey Gillan and Raekha Prasad
fields.body:
It's hard growing up here," said 15-year-old Spencer Seed. "You don't know when people are going to come up behind you. Peckham's got so bad."

Spencer and his 13-year-old sister, Cheryl, had just been to see the stairwell in which Damilola Taylor died - a place that has become a shrine of flowers, cards and soft toys.

The pair lived "just over there", they said, pointing across concrete gallerys and landings, past the bulldozers that are tearing apart some of the old buildings. They did not like the new part of the estate much either and now the murder had made things worse.

Spencer was robbed in February by children his own age as he came out of a chip shop."I had just spent £10 and they stole all my food," he said. "There was three of them and I was on my own."

The pair said children regularly carried weapons in Peckham. Spencer said: "I've had a knife put on me three times here. I know lots of people round here who carry knives."

Cheryl felt scared unless she is with one of her brothers. Fingering a chunky gold necklace, she said: "If I went out on my own my jewellery would get nicked off of me and so would my mobile phone."

Spencer said it was easier for Cheryl because she had her brothers for protection. He did not have anybody and he was keen to stress that he did not carry a knife. "If they can't fight with their own hands they shouldn't carry weapons."

Like most other children on the estate, Cheryl and Spencer have been talking about the murder and picking up rumours. Spencer said: "I heard two boys talking about it and how they know the person who killed the boy."

In the window of the heavily-shuttered shop just one landing above where Damilola died, a sign reads: "Only two children/youths at a time."

The shopkeeper said he could not cope with more. "They are just nasty kids. They come and steal things and pinch things from the till and shoplift."

Damilola must have passed here in the seconds before his death, he must have turned the corners in this rat-run of almost 20 miles of deck landings. He would have run past the workers using heavy machinery to remove concrete amid clouds of dust, he may have glimpsed the piles of rubbish. He could have caught the strong smell of urine in these corridors.

Downstairs are yellow signs appealing for witnesses to the murder but in spite of all the talk very few people have anything to say. Sade Bikini passes the signs as she comes up the rank stairs that lead to the scene of the child's death. A 16-year-old pupil at Alwyn girls' school, she was sure that those of her friends fuelling the rumour mill knew nothing about what really happened.

She was also adamant that North Peckham estate was getting a bad press. She did not fear its dark corners, she said. The estate was not as bad as everyone made out.

"Some of this gang stuff people are coming out with is rubbish," she said. "The Peckham Boys don't hang around here. It's not that violent and I don't feel threatened."

Dressed in school uniform and in high spirits, six girls waited for a bus on Rye Lane. Latita, 16, said she did not like to go out alone. Her mother laughed at her when she asked to be accompanied from her home to the bus stop. "The only way to feel safe is to go out with my friends. We won't get touched if we stick together."

Further up the road, outside Warwick Park school two boys watched children pour out of the building. Both had been excluded from their Camberwell secondary schools. Rashshi, 14, said a project for pupils who had been in trouble at school, the Boyhood to Manhood Foundation, had helped him cope with his anger.

"It's racism that has made me angry, especially from the teachers. If a teacher sees me scuffling with a white kid, then I'm always the bad guy."

His 15-year-old friend said Damilola's murder had stirred up fears about gangs. "Black kids get accused of being in gangs, but often all we're doing is playing in a group. If it's black kids, we're a gang. If it's white kids, they're just playing football," he explains.

"Gangs have existed for a long time. But that's because groups of people from the same area hang out. There's no parks, no community centre to keep us off the streets."
