webTitle: View from the Middle East: Conflict over rules of engagement

fields.headline: Middle East conflict over rules of engagement
fields.standfirst: Not least of the disputes between the Israelis and Palestinians is whether they are actually at war, says Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Not least of the disputes between the Israelis and Palestinians is whether they are actually at war, says Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Are the Israelis and Palestinians at war? It may seem fatuous to ask. Whatever we call the conflict, people are getting killed. But the question is more important than it looks.

The precise status of the conflict determines the rules of engagement: the circumstances under which it is lawful to shoot and kill.

In peacetime the rules are strict. There are variations between countries but in general the authorities are expected to use the minimum force to maintain order, for example, to use non-lethal methods when quelling a riot.

They are allowed to shoot in self defence and sometimes in other legally specified situations.

In wartime, however, many of the normal restrictions disappear. Where military targets are concerned, you can shoot to kill.

So depending on how the Middle East conflict is regarded, killing can be either perfectly legal or murder. Most Palestinians seem content to regard it as a war (some describe it as a "war of liberation") though it's doubtful whether they have thought much about the implications.

The Israelis, on the other hand, have thought about it and have ended up in a muddle.

Colonel Daniel Reisner, the Israeli military's head of international law, pointed out recently in a briefing document: "International law actually only recognises two situations: peace and war. But life isn't as simple as that."

He continued: "The current situation...has brought us to the conclusion that we are no longer in the realm of peace. So where are we?

"While we are not at the end of the spectrum, which is war, because war is a conflict between two armies or two states, we are definitely in the area of armed conflict.

"We have reached the decision that the current situation has more of a semblance of war than of peace. As a result, we are also applying the principles applicable to warfare to the current situation."

Israelis apply these principles some of the time, and at other times the rules of peacetime policing apply.

For example, Palestinian stone throwers who are captured are not put into prisoner of war camps. A stone thrower who pleads guilty is usually jailed for two to four months.

Those who plead not guilty are normally refused bail (on very dubious grounds, according to Amnesty International) and detained for three to four months awaiting trial.

On the other hand, Israel calls upon the rules of war to justify the assassination of various Palestinian activists and militia leaders.

"You are allowed to target combatants," Colonel Reisner wrote. "In the current situation, people who attack us have been identified by us as combatants. As a result we view them as legitimate targets. That specific individual falls under that category, therefore he was attacked and killed."

The long conflict in Northern Ireland was never designated by the British government as a war. That meant that IRA gunmen, bombers and other combatants could not be targeted in the way that the Israelis target their Palestinian equivalent.

Although it is difficult to categorise the conflict, the Israelis appear to be picking and choosing the rules as it suits them.

If it is a war, then Reisner's arguments about targeting "combatants" also apply to the other side - in which case Palestinians should be legally entitled to kill Israeli soldiers and anyone else they regard as a combatant, such as armed settlers, and the Israelis should not complain.

This, Amnesty International warned, is a very dangerous route to take. The effect of treating it as a war is to place a lower value on human life.

One of the consequences, according to an Amnesty delegation who recently visited the area, is that neither side investigates killings properly. Many Palestinians are shot and buried without even an autopsy.

"Mechanisms for accountability in the use of force are lacking," they said. "There is a very strong need for an independent human rights monitoring presence."

Such a presence would bring several benefits. A thorough and public investigation of every death would help to clarify standards regarding the use of violence.

People would think twice before opening fire if they thought they would need to justify their actions to investigators. Credible investigations would also make it easier to discourage reprisal killings and gradually reduce the scale of the violence.

webTitle: How to keep warm without a pashmina

fields.headline: How to keep warm without a pashmina
fields.trailText: Ah, the golden age of 1997. Life was so much simpler then, wasn't it? You could be stylish and snug, cutting-edge and comfortable, all at the same time because that was the age when the pashmina was a highly desirable article.
fields.body:
Ah, the golden age of 1997. Life was so much simpler then, wasn't it? You could be stylish and snug, cutting-edge and comfortable, all at the same time because that was the age when the pashmina was a highly desirable article. But then high street outlets joined in and fashion magazines snootily deemed the poor shawl deader than the shahtoosh.

So what to do now to stay warm and look elegant? Manufacturers have plumped for the novel idea of promising us the same as before, yet fashionably different. The net result - any item draped around a model's neck is The New Pashmina.

So what is it? Well, first there were stripy scarves, which utilise the pashmina's winning formula of colour plus warmth. The best examples were last year's versions by The Gap and Jo Gordon. Now there are Prada's fur tippets (cheaper, faker versions are already available in high street outlets, such as Oasis), Miu Miu's furry collars, Luella's black and white wool scarves, Burberry's wraps, Paul Smith's long stripy numbers, Donna Karan's cashmere wraps... And don't forget summer's fashion leitmotif, the pretty crocheted vintage shawl - not much cop for warmth, lovely to look at, though.

And the pashmina itself is the new pashmina - if it's embroidered/multicoloured/bleached/beaded/ bereft of its tassels. A pashmina by any other name, it seems, is most definitely not a pashmina, but it's damn near as good as.

fields.headline: Batwings revisited
fields.standfirst: The 80s are back! And Hadley Freeman, for one, couldn't be happier
fields.trailText: The 80s are back! And Hadley Freeman, for one, couldn't be happier
fields.body:
It was the decade of legwarmers, puffball skirts and Debbie Gibson, but the fashion pack have been tripping over their gold chain belts to be the first to pronounce that The 80s Are Back. And I, for one, throw a charm bracelet-clad arm to the air and cheer. Roll a cynical eye if you must but who wouldn't rather have a dizzyingly colourful top, or a glamorous chunky bracelet, instead of the monochromatic 90s wardrobe? Beige and grey sportswear seemed subtly chic at first, until someone looked around and realised we all looked exactly the same.

The 80s may have been re-embraced by the style elite, but few take these glossy pronouncements literally - do so and you will look like an anachronistic fashion victim. Just as we've stuck with Madonna but long since ditched Milli Vanilli, you have to distil and extract the timeless style from the sea of unfortunate passing trends: sparkly dangling earrings and one-shoulder tops are sexy, but whacking gold hoops and batwing sleeves are downright impractical. We should have known better then, but at least we do now.

The trick is to take an 80s idea and give it a more contemporary touch. At the spring/summer 2001 shows in October, the trendiest of designers (London's David Wyatt, New York's Marc Jacobs and Paris's Nicholas Ghesquiere for Balenciaga) all took looks from the 80s and gave them a more stylish update, such as oversized belts slung low around the hips and trousers that are skinny-leg but don't, thank heavens, taper at the ankle. So think ruched boots instead of legwarmers; an off-the-shoulder jumper but in a muted, solid colour; a recognisably designer bag (a Burberry tote, Bottega Veneta's woven leather handbag) but not one emblazoned with gold initials. In other words, think Donatella rather than Gianni.

Sceptical eyebrows might be raised at the sound of fashion trumpeting the delights of leggings (now redubbed "footless tights") and quilted Chanel handbags, but what people tend to forget is that 80s fashion was fun, a shameless, full-bodied celebration of all that is frilly and frivolous. Forget about trends; we all want to look and feel glamorous, youthful and just a little bit fashion fabulous, whatever the year. So go on, let a little Ivana back into your life. I'll take glammed-up Gucci over limp linen trousers any day of the week, any decade of the century.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ... colourful camouflage
fields.trailText: ... colourful camouflage
fields.body:
What is this fashionable obsession with all things military? Long ago there was the craze for Dr Martens boots - once made for tramping over war-torn mainlands, then used by English teenagers to trudge to the shops. Then we had the seemingly endless trend for combat trousers. Gosh, weren't those army regulation pockets useful for carrying one's mobile, flat keys, car keys, change?

Now, with what one could almost call military precision, the newest army trend has arrived. Camouflage, once the pattern of choice for protesters, punks and students, has been rendered, well, fun, thanks to next season's Technicolor palette. Forget about green, white and brown; think baby blues, pastel pinks, sultry reds and stylish black.

Matthew Williamson's "Candy Girl" collection sweetened up camouflage no end by putting it on decidedly unfunctional garments (long sparkly dresses, hot pants), while Burberry has managed to wrench itself away from its signature check for part of this summer's collection, with a Burberry red, black and white camouflage swimsuit. And the usual high street suspects (New Look, Top Shop) are already breaking out the paintboxes to create their own versions of colourful camouflage.

Just as a pair of Donna Karan linen combat-style trousers would not have been much cop in Desert Storm, nor will a Matthew Williamson light blue camouflage jumpsuit provide you with much coverage in the jungle. But let's not get facetious here. There is something rather heartening in the way fashion can convert even the most functional of wear into something gloriously stylish. A triumph of the millinery over the military, perhaps? More like an appreciation of all things sartorial - functional and less so.

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ...Lady Victoria Hervey
fields.trailText: ...Lady Victoria Hervey
fields.body:
Poor Lady Victoria Hervey has twice been a successor to Tara Palmer-Tomkinson. In 1998, the half-sister of the Marquess of Bristol dated society figure Mogens Tholstrup (for people outside SW3, he owns a couple of restaurants). Now Lady Victoria has gone for sloppy seconds again, by taking up TP-T's old column in the Sunday Times Style section.

We had such high hopes for Hervey. With a recent role as muse to John Galliano at Dior, and the summer opening of her Knightsbridge boutique Akademi, she seemed to be the It Girl who had found something to do with her life. But her debut column at the weekend, which included the inevitable name-drop round-up, had the unfortunate effect of making the high life sound like suburban hell. "Sinitta was at the next table and she got us all singing Toyboy," she coos about a night at "Ronnie Wood's new place, the Harrington Club". How super, and what about the party for Ralph and Joseph Fiennes' sister-in-law's new fashion collection? "Alas, neither of the famous Fienneses were there." A crying shame. And she ends the week "with indigestion". Tragedy.

When TP-T first appeared on the scene, there was a naive charm to her perception of the OTT world of invites that she believed was everyday. But as her celebrity grew, this Capote-like irreverence was lost to knowing boasts and product placement. It is sad to think Hervey is heading for this realm of freebie launches, since the choice of designers in her store (Patrick Thompson, Tufi Duek, Jill Stuart) shows a mature fashion eye for a 24-year-old. Maybe she should stop trying to be a ligging clotheshorse and get back behind her well-appointed counter, since some hard graft might keep her out of the public eye for good.

webTitle: End in sight for infertility treatment lottery

fields.headline: End in sight for infertility treatment lottery
fields.standfirst: Hospitals warn cancer funding will suffer after minister's pledge
fields.trailText: The government pledged yesterday to end some of the unfairness surrounding access to fertility treatment, which for years has been available on the NHS to couples in some areas of the UK, but denied to those who live elsewhere.
fields.body:
The government pledged yesterday to end some of the unfairness surrounding access to fertility treatment, which for years has been available on the NHS to couples in some areas of the UK, but denied to those who live elsewhere.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, announced that he will issue guidelines to ensure equal access to the treatment for all who need it, regardless of where they live. His announcement, long awaited by doctors and pressure groups, met with delight, but there were warnings that it could inflate many times the NHS bill for infertility treatment at the expense of illnesses such as cancer and heart disease.

"Infertility causes distress to thousands of couples. Unfortunately NHS fertility services vary massively around the country. Some health authorities pay for it, some do not," said Mr Milburn. "That postcode lottery has to end now.

"It was right for the NHS to first target cancer, coronary heart disease and mental health in the modernisation programme. However, now the NHS has record funding secured - in the five years to 2004 it will rise by a third in real terms - it is time to tackle infertility."

Mr Milburn has asked the national institute for clinical excellence - set up to end inequities such as these, as well as to decide what drugs and treatments are cost-effective for the NHS - to review guidelines drawn up by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

A survey published yesterday revealed that some health authorities spent £500,000 a year on fertility treatments while others spend nothing. About 43,700 couples seek infertility treatment each year and 12,000 couples get it, either on the NHS or privately, where prices average at £3,000 an attempt. The chances of success are not high - around 14%-18% - and many couples get into financial difficulties in their desperate attempts to have a child. The success rate falls sharply as women get older and some NHS clinics exclude women over 35.

Rationalising fertility treatment around the country could cost the NHS tens of millions of pounds. Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, which represents hospital trusts and health authorities, said they had not paid for fertility treatment in the past because they could not afford it.

"It is not because they think it is bad treatment or doesn't work. It is because it is unaffordable," he told BBC radio. "If they are going to make it affordable, they are going to have to take some of the government's money which is being pumped into the NHS and spend it on infertility treatment, which of course means it won't be available for other pressing government priorities like coronary heart disease, cancer and mental health."

A spokesman for the health policy body the King's Fund agreed. "If health authorities are being asked to spend more than they are currently spending, other things are going to have to lose out."

The fertility expert Lord Winston said he thought there might be savings to offset the increased costs. "A great deal of money is lost and pain caused by inappropriate treatment being given and drugs being given in the wrong situations, and IVF not being offered to people who it should be offered to," he told the BBC.

Clare Brown, executive director of the infertility support network Child, said: "Patients have waited years for infertility treatment to be given the recognition it deserves as an illness, the treatment of which should be funded by the NHS."

A spokesman for Issue, the infertility support group, said: "This comes at a particularly good time. Christmas is devastating for infertile couples who desperately want a baby."

webTitle: The crippling cost of failed IVF attempts

fields.headline: The crippling cost of failed IVF attempts
fields.trailText: Beverley Verney could not imagine a life without children. She worked as the nanny of a little boy and had always wanted her own. For years, she had tried to get pregnant. Then in 1992 she found out that she would never be able to conceive naturally. Her fallopian tubes were blocked and the damage was too bad for an operation to clear them.
fields.body:
Beverley Verney could not imagine a life without children. She worked as the nanny of a little boy and had always wanted her own. For years, she had tried to get pregnant. Then in 1992 she found out that she would never be able to conceive naturally. Her fallopian tubes were blocked and the damage was too bad for an operation to clear them.

There was no choice for her or her partner Dean. They would have to undergo fertility treatment. But it was clear from the start that it was going to cost them a lot - and not just in emotional trauma. "The GP told us the waiting list for NHS treatment was phenomenal and probably not worth going on."

The couple, who live in Nottingham, were faced with finding about £2,500 for each IVF attempt at a private clinic. Few are successful first time. Beverley and Dean took out a loan and in June 1993, the treatment began. It was unsuccessful. "They told us you have a chance of about 24% or less, but I still convinced myself it would work," she said. "I was devastated when it didn't, but immediately began looking for a way to find more money."

The clinic advised a break before the next attempt. The couple arranged their wedding, even though the uncertainties over fertility treatment "took the shine off it". They borrowed money for the wedding - and a bit more for the second attempt.

The second attempt took place in August 1994. It failed. "You are informed by phone whether it has worked." said Beverley. "That is general. But when you are paying all that money, you at least expect someone to comfort you."

She and Dean were distressed and ever deeper in debt. It became too much, and they split up. "I pushed my husband away and went back to my mum's. But we realised we wanted children of our own and we would have to be strong. We took out money for a third attempt."

Beverley was unhappy with the clinic, so they changed to one recommended by a friend. She felt the new consultant was more positive. "He said: 'I'm going to get you pregnant.' Him being so positive made me feel much stronger."

The treatment began in September 1997 and was successful. Beverley was told she was carrying triplets, but at 20 weeks, one baby died in the womb. The couple were sad, but decided it was meant to be. She gave birth to twin girls, Tara and Rosie, nine weeks prematurely. The twins, now two and a half, are thriving.

Beverley and Dean were delighted, but had a huge debt, which she puts at £18,000. While she was still pregnant, they sold their home to pay it off and went to live with Dean's parents two months before the twins were born. Eventually the council housed the family in a two-bedroom flat. Two years later, with both working, they managed to buy another house, but she felt she was losing out through not seeing enough of her babies. Now Dean is doing two jobs so she can spend time with the children she desperately wanted.

Money is still tight. She understands that the NHS cannot pay for all fertility treatment, "but just one attempt would have helped".

webTitle: New Wembley in trouble as banks back off

fields.headline: New Wembley in trouble as banks back off
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams on the Wembley way to a fiasco
fields.trailText: The £660m redevelopment of Wembley Stadium has run into severe problems which are threatening the future of the entire project, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The £660m redevelopment of Wembley Stadium has run into severe problems which are threatening the future of the entire project, it emerged yesterday.

The world's most expensive stadium development needs to raise £410m from City banks, which are understood to be reluctant to put money into the project.

The redevelopment, which includes pulling down the landmark twin towers, is already behind schedule and problems over financing could delay the project by more than a year, meaning that it might not open until 2005, two years behind schedule.

When plans for the new stadium were unveiled last year, Wembley National Stadium Ltd (WNSL), the Football Association subsidiary company set up to oversee the project, proclaimed that the new stadium would be open in time for the 2003 FA cup final.

The date was then put back to early 2004, but with finance for the venture still not guaranteed even that looks unlikely with the bulldozers yet to move in.

The big banks are concerned about projections for revenues which could be generated at the redeveloped stadium.

Concerns that they will be saddled with negative publicity on the scale of the Millennium Dome are also said to be a deterrent. The terms under which the money is being raised may need to be altered to entice banks to back the plan.

The demolition of the existing stadium has been postponed twice already.

Under the original plans work was due to begin last month after England's defeat by Germany. But it was first rescheduled for December and is now unlikely to begin this year.

Chase Manhattan, a major US bank which specialises in raising money for large projects, has been hired by Wembley to find financial backers.

But one senior banker approached by Chase said: "They are finding it very, very difficult to get partners. There are very real concerns about the rough revenue projections for Wembley. It's pretty unlikely we will back it".

Another said: "Wembley just isn't like big stadiums in the US where they've got the home team turning up every week. They have only 16 or 20 sport ing events a year, limited to football and a bit of rugby, the wind and the rain and the whims of rock stars to go on tour."

Another major hurdle is the fact that the financing is being structured as an unsecured deal, according to the banker. If the company fails, the lenders will not have rights over the stadium in support of their loan.

According to the prospectus which Chase Manhattan has drawn up, much of the increased revenue for the new Wembley is expected to come from sales of the more expensive seats, many for corporate hospitality. The plans include 150 boxes, of which 30 are thought to have been reserved already.

Under the terms being touted by Chase Manhattan, the stadium could be prepared to pay almost 8% in interest starting from 2005, resulting in a likely annual interest payment of some £30m, although the amount of interest is linked to revenues generated by the ground. The loan is for 20 years.

A WNSL spokesman said that they hoped to have the £410m loan secured before Christmas and that demolition work on the old stadium would also have started by then.

It is believed WNSL wants to secure the backing of 10 banks who would each pay £41m.

The spokesman added: "We are not concerned if some banks are scared off by adverse publicity because there are still enough banks interested in the project.

"We have a number of agreements to stage events at the the new Wembley. The banks may come to us with one or two questions but we are confident that we will be able to address their concerns."

They have only 16 or 20 sport ing events a year, limited to football and a bit of rugby, the wind and the rain and the whims of rock stars to go on tour." Another major hurdle is the fact that the financing is being structured as an unsecured deal, according to the banker. If the company fails, the lenders will not have rights over the stadium in support of their loan. According to the prospectus which Chase Manhattan has drawn up, much of the increased revenue for the new Wembley is expected to come from sales of the more expensive seats, many for corporate hospitality. The plans include 150 boxes, of which 30 are thought to have been reserved already. Under the terms being touted by Chase Manhattan, the stadium could be prepared to pay almost 8% in interest starting from 2005, resulting in a likely annual interest payment of some £30m, although the amount of interest is linked to revenues generated by the ground. The loan is for 20 years. A WNSL spokesman said that they hoped to have the £410m loan secured before Christmas and that demolition work on the old stadium would also have started by then. It is believed WNSL wants to secure the backing of 10 banks who would each pay £41m. The spokesman added: "We are not concerned if some banks are scared off by adverse publicity because there are still enough banks interested in the project. "We have a number of agreements to stage events at the the new Wembley. The banks may come to us with one or two questions but we are confident that we will be able to address their concerns."

webTitle: Famke Jannsen to take on the Terminator

fields.headline: Famke Jannsen to take on the Terminator
fields.trailText: Already signed-up for an X-Men sequel, Dutch actress Famke Jannsen looks set to play a "sexy female villain" in Terminator 3
fields.body:
More news from Variety's columnist Michael Fleming about Terminator 3.

As we reported in last week's news, Arnold Schwarzenegger told reporters that there was to be a "sexy female villain" for him to grapple with in the much-hyped production. Fleming notes that Famke Janssen (pictured) has emerged as the frontrunner to play the female terminatrix who will be menacing poor old Arnie and his co-star Edward Furlong, who will also be reprising his T2 role.

The 35-year-old Dutch actress has more than amply proved that she can play it black. She first came to public prominence in 1995's GoldenEye as Xenia Zaragevna Onatopp, when she almost managed to derail James Bond with her killer thighs.

After the huge success of this summer's X-Men, Janssen has recently signed to play the telekenetic Jean Gray once again in a sequel that is currently in pre-production.

fields.headline: Potter's potions bought up
fields.trailText: Publishing rights on potion recipes and other book-based merchandising spin-offs from the Harry Potter series have been bought by author JK Rowling's publishers, Bloomsbury.
fields.body:
Publishing rights on potion recipes and other book-based merchandising spin-offs from the Harry Potter series have been bought by author JK Rowling's publishers, Bloomsbury.

The publishing house, which is already thought to make 20% to 30% of its revenue from Pottermania, will produce notebooks, diaries, calenders, journals, address books and writing paper to cater for the demand anticipated from next year's big budget film version of Harry Potter and The Philosopher's Stone.

The rights have been bought from Warner Bros - who are producing the film - for what is thought to be about £100,000.

"The merchandising will be launched in March 2001 and print run quantities will be restricted to initial demand," the publishing house said.

"But early piloting of the merchandise in the US indicates that there is a very strong market for the products."

Guy Bell, an analyst at Beeson Gregory, said Bloomsbury were wise not to anticipate too much from merchandising sales.

"It is taking a cautious view of how many they are going to print," he said. "They are more than aware of the Dorling Kindersley scenario."

British publisher Dorling Kindersley ran into trouble last year after hugely over-estimating the demand for merchandising spin-offs from the film Star Wars: Episode One.

fields.headline: Wilde gets revenge on wallpaper
fields.trailText: "My wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. One or the other of us has to go," said Oscar Wilde. A century later the celebrated writer has finally got his own back
fields.body:
"My wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. One or the other of us has to go," said Oscar Wilde in what may have been his last recorded witticism before dying, a penniless outcast, in a cheap Paris hotel.

A century later, as the city marked the 100th anniversary of his death yesterday with parties, plays and a memorial mass, the celebrated writer has finally got his own back: the dowdy floral wallcovering that so upset him has been well and truly buried in the past by resplendent red, blue, green and gold frescos based on designs by Wilde's contemporary Aubrey Beardsley.

The entire first-floor room of the Left Bank hotel where he passed away on November 30 1900, the victim of an ear infection that spread to the brain, has been redecorated in the style of his London home, complete with fin-de-siecle period furniture.

"Actually, the furniture can't be much like what was in the room when he died," confessed Fabienne Capelli, the manager of the renovated four-star L'Hotel. "At the time this was - how shall I put it - a poor people's hotel. It was rated 10th class."

webTitle: Railtrack announces easing of speed restrictions

fields.headline: Railtrack announces easing of speed restrictions
fields.trailText: Railtrack today announced an easing of speed restrictions on sections of the rail network.
fields.body:
Railtrack today announced an easing of speed restrictions on sections of the rail network.

Some of the 20mph limits will become 40mph ones, while some of the 40mph limits will go up to 60mph.

The changes, which are likely to be introduced next week, will offer beleaguered passengers the first glimmer of hope of better services since the Hatfield crash more than six weeks ago.

"We will be easing restrictions not so much on a region by region basis but on the basis of what engineers say is safe," said a Railtrack spokesman.

More details of the revised restrictions were given by Railtrack's new chief executive, Steve Marshall, at a news conference at the company's London headquarters.

Passengers have endured weeks of chaos on the railways due to the restrictions imposed after Hatfield, the track-checking work and the severe floods a month ago.

Meanwhile, the rail recovery action group set up by the government was meeting for the first time today to supervise efforts to restore normal train services.

The group, headed by transport minister Lord Macdonald, was set up as Downing Street let it be known that Tony Blair wants to see rail chaos ended by Christmas.

The meeting came a day after it was revealed that thousands of travellers were deserting rail to make domestic journeys by air.

"Passengers are becoming increasingly fed up at what they see as continuing and unnecessary delays in getting the rail network back up to speed," said John Prescott, the deputy prime minister.

"Railtrack, the train operators and government have got to work together to tackle this. That is why I have asked Gus Macdonald to head up a special rail action group to maintain regular contact with the industry and ensure they are totally focused on the issue, day to day."

The group will consist of senior representatives from Railtrack, the Association of Train Operating Companies, the Rail Passenger Council, the Health and Safety Executive, the Office of the Rail Regulator and the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority.

The key tasks of the group will be to:

Work closely with Railtrack and the train companies in resuming normal service as quickly as possible, while keeping risks as low as reasonably practicable;

To keep the public and ministers fully informed on progress of the recovery plan;

To help trouble-shoot any unresolved issues delaying full recovery.

Mr Prescott added: "I am pleased to say that our meeting with Railtrack today was very constructive. They are now in discussions with the HSE regarding the possibility of lifting a number of the current speed restrictions and the terms under which this might happen."

Airlines British Airways, Ryanair and British Midland have all reported huge increases in domestic travellers in recent weeks, with particularly high rises on services from London to the north of England and Scotland.

Lord Macdonald's appointment followed a Cabinet meeting yesterday morning at which the rail chaos was discussed.

"There was an acknowledgement that it is pretty grim out there for passengers and things have got to get better," a Downing Street spokesman said.

The cost to business of the crippled rail network has been "considerable", according to the Institute of Directors. A survey of 200 IoD members showed that the average small business has lost £14,500 since the Hatfield crash, while larger companies have lost £42,000 each.

Commuters still faced serious delays today after Tuesday's derailment at Northampton.

Just four trains in the area were able to run. A substitute coach service remains in place and a spokesman for train operator Silverlink, said that the company hoped to run more trains on Monday.

fields.headline: Painted into a corner
fields.standfirst: The Tories' hopeless response to the triumph of the new deal on jobs shows how dire their plight really is, writes Polly Toynbee
fields.trailText: The Tories' hopeless response to the triumph of the new deal on jobs shows how dire their plight really is, writes Polly Toynbee
fields.body:
Rhetorical trumpets sounded and drums beat inside Downing Street yesterday as the prime minister and his generals assembled to celebrate an important victory. The flagship manifesto promise - 250,000 long-term unemployed young people into jobs - has been more than met, under budget and ahead of time. "Rejoice!" David Blunkett said, denouncing the "nothing works" cynics.

In truth, it wasn't much of a news story. It has been obvious for well over a year that the new deal was working very well, a modest but solid success. Independent audits from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research showed that 164,000 young people who had been unemployed more than six months had all found jobs at least six months sooner than they would have done without help: the rest might have gone straight into jobs anyway. It cost an average £4,000 per job and at that price the scheme just about pays for itself in saved benefits.

At the height of the 1980s slump, half a million young people had no prospect of work - a lost generation, many of whom never recovered. Now there are only 37,000 long-term young unemployed left and the number is falling fast. Yesterday wasn't news - but imagine if the new deal had failed or if it had cost a great deal more per job. The dome would have paled into insignificance as an emblem of New Labour disaster. That's the trouble for governments - targets achieved, goals met, promises kept are dull. So yesterday ITN didn't mention the new deal result at all; the BBC gave it 10 seconds. Only failures are fun.

In human terms, the new deal has lifted up thousands of young people: to be out of work with nothing to do for six months is a long time for a drifting 18-year-old. The magic ingredient is the personal adviser, a job now hotly competed for, with its satisfying results. The weary, depleted, old Employment Service has sprung into new life. Ninety per cent of new deal clients talk in glowing terms about their personal advisers, who see them right through even when they are in work. Some telephone their advisers at night for help.

Most have never had an adult personally assigned to them before. One adviser swapped clothes with his client so he could send him off to an interview respectably dressed. He wore the boy's jeans and Man U T-shirt for the day; the boy got the job. If doubters want a taste of some real good this government has done, a session sitting in on new deal interviews is heart-warming stuff.

But then come the stark reality checks: a dead boy in north Peckham is a shocking reminder of the wastelands still to be rescued, how many people, how difficult it is to change places left to fester for the past 20 years. Government spending so far has only nibbled round the edges; there is more to come, but little yet.

The full force of what it really means to inherit a society where one in every three children is born poor is starting to sink in with Labour. Even the big increases in benefits for children don't fix all this quickly. Even if schools get better, many of these children will still end up at 18 with the new deal as their last resort. As years go by, these will increasingly be the hardest cases, for whom all else has failed. The later they are found, the larger the sums that need to be spent on treatment, counselling, intensive education, whatever it takes to get them on to their feet and into society.

The new deal was allocated £2.6bn over four years. It has spent only £1bn, so there is money that should now be spent on high-intensity programmes for the toughest cases, old and young. It is cheaper than waiting for them to end up in prisons or mental hospitals. A target of getting 70% of single parents into work will be hard to hit while there are still very few affordable nurseries. Above all, to reach full employment the chancellor has to abandon one great ideological barricade and spend money where he swore he never would - on job creation in the most blighted areas where no amount of training magics up non-existent work.

Nonetheless, hitting that new deal target is an important emblem of Labour success - and the starting pistol for the election campaign. It is also a stake through the heart of the Tory party. Yesterday they struggled to find anything coherent to say about it and their response is a revealing dry run for the plight they will find themselves in next May. Wherever they turn, they skewer themselves.

Yesterday they tossed out a fog of mendacious figures, all desperate stuff. They claimed the new deal cost £5.2bn instead of £1bn. They claimed Labour inherited only half the target number when it came to power - conveniently leaving out the 14,000 more coming on to the books every month. "The new deal is a spin operation. It claims credit for finding people jobs they would have found anyway." Why? Because the economy is so strong, but how can the Tories admit that?

They promise to scrap the programme, privatising it with bonuses for every job new contractors find. It will cost, they claim, £1,000 less per job. Where will that cut fall? On education and training - the high-value part of the new deal. Never mind that many of these young people are illiterate and innumerate, private employment agencies will bundle them into jobs anyway. "Employers don't want all this waste on training," said the Tory spokesperson. Nor workers who can read and write? No.

Michael Portillo is said to be tired of the game; he wants out. Maybe he's a sleeping crocodile but it wouldn't be surprising if he really has had enough. Who could blame him for not facing another arid four years of opposition? Trying to oppose the new deal epitomises their problem. It is virtually impossible to oppose most of Labour's major programmes for schools, the NHS or the poor except with lies and the odd ideological privatisation devised for the sake of it. Rarely can politics have seemed more pointless than inside the Tory party now. The sterile search for anything different to say must be deathly toil. Never mind what works, all that matters is contriving something plausible to say. Forget honesty, oppose everything. If Portillo wants to get a life instead, why not?

This is an easy government to criticise from the left - two no-spending years, no income-tax rises, too anxious to please middle England, too frit to lead, kissing the boots of the Tory press that kick it daily. But how do you attack from the right? Seeking clear blue water, Hague has landed the Tories on a desert island alone with their own ageing clan, tax-cutting, social-programme-slashing, 1950s-moralising, Europhobic, mad little Englanders. The harder Hague tries, the worse things get.

The only time Tories might indulge in delusions of victory is when they look across the floor of the House and see a government bench still so easily, needlessly frightened. There is only one interesting question about the next election - will the quiet success of most of what Labour has done so far nerve them to be braver? Is there a bolder plan to come?

fields.headline: Icebox axes half its staff
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Internet broadcaster Icebox has slashed its staff by half in a bid to move into the black by the end of next year, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet broadcaster Icebox has slashed its staff by half in a bid to move into the black by the end of next year.

The company's 100-strong workforce will be cut to 50, despite Icebox having just won a commission to make a web sitcom for US broadcaster Fox.

Fox has ordered a pilot for a live-action version of Zombie College, an animated series on Icebox.com about a man who attends school with the living dead.

The deal will give fresh hope to producers developing TV-style content for websites.

Any profits from the deal, assuming the pilot takes off, will be split 50-50 between Icebox and the series' producer.

fields.headline: Gay campaigners celebrate legal milestone
fields.standfirst: Government uses Parliament Act to push through sex at 16 legislation despite last-ditch protests
fields.trailText: Government uses Parliament Act to push through sex at 16 legislation despite last-ditch protests, writes Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Gay 16-year-olds will be able to have sex without fear of prosecution for the first time after controversial plans to lower the homosexual age of consent from 18 to 16 were finally pushed through Parliament yesterday.

Despite a last-ditch attack by religious leaders, family values campaigners and Tory MPs, the government used the rarely-invoked Parliament Act to put the sexual offences (amendment) bill on to the statute books after it was consistently rejected by the Lords.

The move - which will see the measures become law after being given royal assent before December 6 - was acclaimed by gay rights groups celebrating the 100th anniversary of the death of Oscar Wilde as "a great step towards equality.

"When the history books come to be written, I believe it will be seen as the moment when this country finally began to change, when lesbians and gay men started to take our place as equal members of society," said Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall.

"This is a welcome and historic milestone in the long struggle for gay human rights," said OutRage!'s Peter Tatchell. "My only regret is that it has taken 33 years, during which time hundreds of gay men have been unjustly jailed for victimless relationships."

Yesterday's decision to invoke the Parliament Act - only used twice in the last 10 years - means that men and women will legally be able to have anal sex at 16. Before, buggery between 16 and 18, even if consensual, could invoke a five-year prison sentence.

The Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act also creates a new offence of "abuse of trust", ensuring teachers and workers in children's homes, hospitals and care homes can be jailed for up to five years if they sexually abuse a child in their care, although critics have argued too few adults in positions of trust are covered.

The reduction of the age of consent - while voted through with three massive majorities in the Commons - provoked fierce opposition on moral and health grounds, with religious leaders yesterday writing a protest letter to the Daily Telegraph, and peers twice throwing it out of the Lords.

Yesterday the family values campaigner Lady Young, who has spearheaded the opposition, accused the government of treating Parliament in "a completely dictatorial manner" by ignoring the views of peers and denying MPs the chance to debate an amendment approved by peers to keep the law for anal sex for both men and women at 18 but lower the age for other sexual practices to 16. She added that it was "constitutionally quite wrong" to invoke the Parliament Act for a bill which had not completed all its stages in both houses, and which was not a central piece of government legislation but "a matter of conscience".

A spokesman for the staunchly Catholic Commons Speaker Michael Martin - who, as the servant of the house, has no discretion over whether to invoke the act - insisted: "Everything that has happened was absolutely in order."

The Parliament Act allows the government to present a bill for royal assent if it has been rejected in the Lords in one parliamentary session and has not been approved by peers by the end of the second session.

The decision to force through the act came as MPs ended their longest parliamentary session since the 1930s. Sessions typically end in mid to late November, with the Queen's speech on November 24 last year.

The reason for the late date of December 6 is the number of bills held up by defeats in the Lords.

Left on the shelf

Bills not in the Queen's speech:

 A consumers bill intended to outlaw the sale of insurance products linked to mortgages.

 A bill regulating mercenaries is likely to be offered only in the form of a green paper.

 A home office bill designed to crack down on psychopaths and paedophiles has also been shelved.

 The department of trade may publish in draft form a bill licencing the arms export industry.

 The Treasury is also not likely to go ahead with a bill cracking down on banks.

fields.headline: Brown aims at lone parents after hitting youth jobs target
fields.trailText: Labour has set itself a demanding target of putting 70% of lone parents into work by the end of the decade. Patrick Wintour reports.
fields.body:
Labour yesterday set itself a demanding target of putting 70% of lone parents into work by the end of the decade.

The new target and timetable was revealed by the chancellor at a Downing Street press conference called by the government to hail the achievement of hitting Labour's manifesto target to take 250,000 young people off the dole.

Overall the government will have spent £1bn of the £5.2bn raised from the windfall tax on the utilities on the new deal for 18-24 year olds between 1997-2001. Ironically, the single biggest spending item from the levy has been £1.5bn to improve school infrastructure, something for which it had never been intended.

The Treasury reckons the new lone parents target will bring 375,000 more lone parents into work and help take 600,000 children out of poverty. So far 100,000 lone parents have found work since May 1997, raising the proportion of lone parents in work from 44% to 50%. Nevertheless, Britain still has one of the highest levels of lone parents out of work in Europe.

Mr Brown hopes to improve the rate of progress by extending child care, child tax credits. and offering more generous benefits for those in part time work.

The shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, claimed the new deal for lone parents was stalled. The number of lone parents on income support fell by only 1,000 during the last quarter, taking the number to 909,000.

In an effort to reinvigorate the process, Mr Brown has decided all lone parents on income support with children aged over five will be required to meet a personal adviser to discuss the job opportunities available to them. From autumn next year the new deal for lone parents will be extended to the 150,000 unemployed lone parents not on income support.

Mr Blair said yesterday the new deal had "transformed" the lives of the 254,520 young people who had found a job. "Nobody talks about skivvy schemes anymore", he said.

The employment secretary, David Blunkett, claimed independent research showed 87% per cent who "touched" the new deal found work or a placement more quickly than otherwise would be the case.

The Conservatives countered that most of the young unemployed would have found work anyway, and claimed their own proposals for a private sector-led scheme would be cheaper, costing only £3,000 per job.

webTitle: In brief: Hopkins has to hold back as Hannibal

fields.headline: In brief: Hopkins has to hold back as Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Plus: Legendary French actor dies aged 73; Neve Campbell auctions dress to raise awareness of Tourette syndrome
fields.trailText: Plus: Legendary French actor dies aged 73; Neve Campbell auctions dress to raise awareness of Tourette syndrome
fields.body:
 MSNBC reports that cuts will be made to the forth-coming Hannibal for legal reasons. Any attempt on the part of Anthony Hopkins to repeat the mannerisms that he created for the character of Hannibal Lecter in the Silence of the Lambs, like the trademark "fava beans" slurping, will be excised because Orion Pictures is claiming the rights to those traits and will not allow MGM to use them in the new film.

 French actor Christian Marquand has died following a long illness, aged 73. The Marseilles-born star began his career as a stage comedian before making his screen debut in Jean Cocteau's Beauty and the Beast in 1945. He went on to appear in 50 films, including And God Created Women, opposite Brigitte Bardot, and in the 1960s he worked in English, appearing in The Flight of the Phoenix and Lord Jim. Marquand also ventured behind the camera to direct Les Grand Chemins in 1962 and Candy in 1968.

 Neve Campbell is offering up the wedding dress that she wore in the TV series Party of Five as part of a contest on her official website that she hopes will raise money for the Tourette Syndrome Foundation of Canada. The Scream star is keen to increase awareness of Tourette syndrome as her younger brother Damien suffers from the condition.

fields.headline: Market jitters threaten AltaVista float
fields.trailText: 8am: Internet search engine AltaVista has admitted that stock market turbulence may scupper plans to float next year, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet search engine AltaVista has admitted that stock market turbulence may scupper plans to float next year.

AltaVista is getting cold feet after a raft of profit warnings from US technology companies sent the tech-heavy Nasdaq list tumbling by 50% this year.

Vesey Crichton, general manager of AltaVisat Europe, said: "Looking at the Nasdaq, it's difficult to predict when the markets will recover.

"Resolving the US election will restore some stability, but it is impossible to use your crystal ball at the moment."

He added that a flotation "is not the be all and end all" for the company, and that AltaVista had the financing to fund its international expansion plans.

AltaVista expected to buck the sector trend and reach profitability by April 2001.

Mr Crichton said: "A company's flotation plans make for interesting headlines, but it is of minimal importance compared to extending our user base and improving the service, which is what takes up most of our time."

Aggressive expansion plans will see AltaVista search engines established in up to 40 countries by next April.

CMGI, the internet investment company that owns AltaVista, plans to float the company next year on Nasdaq in New York. This year it postponed similar plans due to volatile market conditions.

AltaVista has been through the wars recently, with the resignation of Andy Mitchell as boss of its UK operation following the collapse of a much-trumpeted unmetered access service.

Rod Schrock, chief executive of the whole group, handed in his notice last month, while 25% of AltaVista's workforce is being cut in a pre-flotation belt-tightening exercise.

Mr Crichton said the company had a shortlist for a new chief executive and that it had been impressed by the quality of applicants.

fields.headline: Pity the killers
fields.standfirst: Damilola's attackers were not born thugs. Children with mental health problems need help, writes Angela Neustatter
fields.trailText: Damilola's attackers were not born thugs. Children with mental health problems need help, writes Angela Neustatter
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor's dreadful, pointless death is the stuff of every parent's nightmare. A child killed with a knife and, it is assumed, by a child or young person, one of the boy's peers in what may well have been a final act of bullying that went too far.

In the face of Gloria Taylor's distress at having her beautiful child so mercilessly taken, at the knowledge that she had complained to his school that he was being bullied, there is public outrage, a desire to show we care, that we share her fury at whoever committed this bad, bad act.

The trouble is that this increasingly familiar way of making ourselves feel better, manifest in the oceans of media stories about hooligans and thugs, actually distances us from understanding that young people who commit such dreadful acts are not born thugs and hooligans. They become that way because their mental health needs are bypassed until they become a dangerous, dreadful, driving force.

The mental health problems of children in Britain are something we don't dwell on. Kids with hyperactivity, with emotional chaos bubbling inside, with a despair so deep they will do anything to keep it at bay, kids who act out their disturbance in ways that are at best unappealing at worst lethal don't capture the imagination.

We like mental health problems to come in the form of Shakespeare's fools or simple-minded lunatics amusing us with their harmless antics. This is blind folly for those kids whose problems may, to us, seem a private menace for their families or a failure of parenting, but who very often have mental health problems and need help early if they are not to turn mad and bad. When I sat on the Mental Health Foundation's steering committee into children's mental health, preparing the report Bright Futures, it was calculated that at any one time 20% of children and adolescents are experiencing psychological problems. It is very likely Damilola's killers are among them, as was the psychotic cellmate who killed Zahid Mubarek in Feltham.

When these children become thugs, commit dreadful acts and are vilified, we lock them up. We concluded in Bright Futures that "the demonisation enables troubled and troublesome children to be portrayed as the preserve of the mental health professionals or the criminal justice system not the concern of society as a whole".

This point was emphasised this week with the publication of a Prison Reform Trust report showing that out of a sample of 592 young people aged 16-20 in prison, 95% were assessed as having one or more mental disorders. Some had as many as five. Ten per cent had functional psychosis and up to 67% suffered from anxiety and depression. One-third of young women and 20% of young men had attempted suicide before being sent to prison.

These mental health problems are not a product of prison, although prison is the last place equipped to treat the psychological problems of our fragile and vulnerable young, as the statistics for suicide and self-harm bear witness.

We might well have felt sympathy for them if we'd heard their stories, so often ones of deprivation and poverty, before they committed their mad, bad acts, before they were driven to an urgent quest to escape the bad feelings inside themselves by acting them out on someone else.

The bullying that Damilola endured is one of the commonest and most urgent signs we should heed. In the past few years it has been identified as a serious problem - not just swaggering playground machismo but a merciless quest for power and control by those who all too often feel powerless. According to Young Voice, the charity set up to report the views and experiences of our young, 37% of teenage boys say they have been subjected to physical violence from bullies. Young Voice makes the important point that "bullying is a vital indicator of the health of the community".

Our prosperous capitalist society enables many of us to protect and nurture our children. But there is remarkably little interest in encouraging the government, which to its credit is doing more than its predecessors, to prioritise children's mental health problems in schools with special needs help and educational psychologists, or in funding some of the imaginative and constructive organisations offering practical help, psychological support, and early intervention for those children and young people who need it.

Our powerful media, with all the opportunities it has to help us take some moral responsibility for growing violence and criminality, revels in headlines that separate thugs from nice middle England. This is far more comfortable than accepting responsibility for children who are spiralling out of control, who we wouldn't much want sharing our kids' Playstations and teatime treats.

We should recognise our responsibility, albeit distanced, for Damilola's death. If we want to protect children like him, we need a comprehensive and dynamic range of initiatives to spot, intervene and help when children show signs of mental distress. Those of us fortunate enough to have the time and energy to battle for these things must do so.

Kids with hyperactivity, with emotional chaos bubbling inside, with a despair so deep they will do anything to keep it at bay, kids who act out their disturbance in ways that are at best unappealing at worst lethal don't capture the imagination. We like mental health problems to come in the form of Shakespeare's fools or simple-minded lunatics amusing us with their harmless antics. This is blind folly for those kids whose problems may, to us, seem a private menace for their families or a failure of parenting, but who very often have mental health problems and need help early if they are not to turn mad and bad. When I sat on the Mental Health Foundation's steering committee into children's mental health, preparing the report Bright Futures, it was calculated that at any one time 20% of children and adolescents are experiencing psychological problems. It is very likely Damilola's killers are among them, as was the psychotic cellmate who killed Zahid Mubarek in Feltham. When these children become thugs, commit dreadful acts and are vilified, we lock them up. We concluded in Bright Futures that "the demonisation enables troubled and troublesome children to be portrayed as the preserve of the mental health professionals or the criminal justice system not the concern of society as a whole". This point was emphasised this week with the publication of a Prison Reform Trust report showing that out of a sample of 592 young people aged 16-20 in prison, 95% were assessed as having one or more mental disorders. Some had as many as five. Ten per cent had functional psychosis and up to 67% suffered from anxiety and depression. One-third of young women and 20% of young men had attempted suicide before being sent to prison. These mental health problems are not a product of prison, although prison is the last place equipped to treat the psychological problems of our fragile and vulnerable young, as the statistics for suicide and self-harm bear witness. We might well have felt sympathy for them if we'd heard their stories, so often ones of deprivation and poverty, before they committed their mad, bad acts, before they were driven to an urgent quest to escape the bad feelings inside themselves by acting them out on someone else. The bullying that Damilola endured is one of the commonest and most urgent signs we should heed. In the past few years it has been identified as a serious problem - not just swaggering playground machismo but a merciless quest for power and control by those who all too often feel powerless. According to Young Voice, the charity set up to report the views and experiences of our young, 37% of teenage boys say they have been subjected to physical violence from bullies. Young Voice makes the important point that "bullying is a vital indicator of the health of the community". Our prosperous capitalist society enables many of us to protect and nurture our children. But there is remarkably little interest in encouraging the government, which to its credit is doing more than its predecessors, to prioritise children's mental health problems in schools with special needs help and educational psychologists, or in funding some of the imaginative and constructive organisations offering practical help, psychological support, and early intervention for those children and young people who need it. Our powerful media, with all the opportunities it has to help us take some moral responsibility for growing violence and criminality, revels in headlines that separate thugs from nice middle England. This is far more comfortable than accepting responsibility for children who are spiralling out of control, who we wouldn't much want sharing our kids' Playstations and teatime treats. We should recognise our responsibility, albeit distanced, for Damilola's death. If we want to protect children like him, we need a comprehensive and dynamic range of initiatives to spot, intervene and help when children show signs of mental distress. Those of us fortunate enough to have the time and energy to battle for these things must do so.

webTitle: Tolerance for mentally ill is not enough

fields.headline: Tolerance for mentally ill is not enough
fields.standfirst: Discrimination against people with mental health needs is a human rights issue and not just a case for awareness raising, writes Lynne Friedli
fields.trailText: Discrimination against people with mental health needs is a human rights issue and not just a case for awareness raising, writes Lynne Friedli
fields.body:
The discrimination experienced by people who use, or have used, mental health services is rightly gaining more attention.

The national service framework for mental health places a duty on health and social services to reduce stigma and discrimination, and the Department of Health has recently announced a £1m national campaign, Mind Out, that aims to challenge discrimination.

These developments have led to a renewed interest in public attitudes to mental health, media coverage of mental health issues, and interventions which seek to promote greater acceptance and understanding of people with mental health problems. This is a complex area, and needs to be treated with some caution, because there is a considerable discrepancy between public attitudes, as expressed in surveys, and the experiences of service users and those delivering services.

The most recent omnibus survey commissioned by the Department of Health, in June 2000, shows greater acceptance by the public of people with mental health problems. The vast majority of the public have a caring and sympathetic view, believing that virtually anyone can become mentally ill. Fewer than one in five people consider it frightening to think of people with mental health problems living in residential neighbourhoods, and nearly half disagree strongly with the statement "I would not want to live next door to someone who had been mentally ill". Although the public still express concern over how much responsibility can be given to people with mental health problems, they are becoming more tolerant. There is a growing belief that people with mental health problems should be integrated into the community, with support from community-based services.

Unfortunately, the view held by 71% of the public - that no one has the right to exclude people with mental health problems - is not borne out by the experiences of service users. Qualitative research from mental health organisations shows that the quality of life of people with mental health problems is diminished by stigmatising attitudes, negative and distorted media coverage, and discrimination. Discrimination is particularly powerful in the areas of employment, housing and access to mainstream services. Unemployment rates among those with long-term mental health problems are higher than in other groups of people with disabilities. Only 13% of people with long-term mental health problems are in employment, compared to over a third of people with disabilities generally. These factors contribute centrally to the experience of social exclusion, which is consistently reported by those who use, or have used, mental health services.

The question is, what can be done to address discrimination, and more broadly, to engage meaningfully with how people think and feel about both mental health and mental illness? There is some evidence that local measures to promote social contact and familiarisation with people with a mental illness diagnosis have a positive impact. But to make social contact an everyday experience will require some major policy changes. It will mean recognising that just as a diagnosis is only one part of a person's life, so medical treatment is only one part of the support they need - to cope, to recover and to avoid relapse. The other support, by far the largest part, will come from opportunities to enjoy the same range of services, facilities and hospitality within the community as everyone else. People with personal experience of a mental illness diagnosis are currently unheard and unseen in almost all walks of life. Redressing this level of exclusion will need a radical rethink.

Discrimination against people with mental health problems is a civil liberties and human rights issue. Tackling it will mean engaging in some fundamental debates about citizenship and who is, and isn't, included on current social inclusion and neighbourhood renewal agendas. It will also mean shifting the focus from mental illness, defined as the responsibility of mental health services, to mental health, which concerns us all. It is worth noting that no government has ever been taken to task for the impact that its policies have on the mental health of communities. All the major public health scandals concern physical health: BSE, pollution, GM foods. This allows us to avoid addressing some challenging questions about what is needed to build mentally healthy communities.

While local councillors support nimby campaigns, employers promote a "survival of the fittest" working culture, and day centres are seen as the main source of support for people with mental health problems, it is difficult to address the gap between the public's expression of goodwill and what happens in practice. If we stick to the old, known routines of raising awareness, we're in danger of letting the policy makers - in housing, in employment and in the delivery of mainstream services - off the hook.

 Dr Lynne Friedli is chief executive of mentality, a voluntary agency dedicated to mental health promotion

fields.headline: NME pins deputy's badge on Oldham
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The NME has promoted James Oldham to be its new deputy editor, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The NME has promoted James Oldham to be its new deputy editor, replacing John Mulvey, who left last month to go freelance.

Mr Oldham, who joined the weekly music title in 1996, has edited the On section since 1997 and has also edited the NME's Live Reviews section.

webTitle: Freelances force VNU to rethink contracts

fields.headline: Freelances force VNU to rethink contracts
fields.trailText: 8am VNU's business division has been forced to back down over its attempt to rewrite freelances' contracts, writesJessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Computer publisher VNU Business Publications has been forced to back down on new contracts for freelance journalists.

The firm's retreat follows claims that the contracts would seize all online rights and limit writers' opportunities to sell their work on to other titles.

A spokesman admitted that the company was redrafting the contracts after consultation with staff and freelances.

Freelance writers objected to a clause in the contract that classifies all preparatory work done as part of an interview or article as the property of VNU.

They say this would have limited their ability to earn income from different sources.

The contract also banned freelance journalists from accepting any free gifts, which many said potentially included paid-for press trips - a staple of the IT press.

They were also angered by a clause that they claimed would leave them to pick up the bill for any legal action incurred by their stories.

One long-term freelance said: "VNU wants all of the privileges of being an employer without any of the obligations."

Another said that many freelances took the view that the most appropriate response was "to screw up the contracts and throw them back in their faces".

The contract, which has been seen by MediaGuardian.co.uk, stated that changes had to bring VNU's contracts in line with those of Ziff-Davis - the IT publishing firm that VNU acquired earlier this year.

But a VNU spokesman said that the contracts were standard in the industry.

"It's not VNU's intention to take all online rights," he said. "Press trips have not been banned, and if you go on a trip and want to do a story for a newspaper, that's fine. Some of these freelances have interpreted this story wrongly."

And he denied that freelances would be forced to take legal liability for stories, saying: "VNU is simply saying, 'Don't open us up to unnecessary legal challenges'."

webTitle: Leader: The axis swings at Nice

fields.headline: The axis swings
fields.standfirst: It's looking nicer for Nice
fields.trailText: It's looking nicer for Nice
fields.body:
Surprise! The president and the prime minister ate no beef last night, with or without gravy (see the third leader below). As recently as the start of this week conventional wisdom had Tony Blair on a rough ride. The European military force had given the tabloids their issue; the Tories had becoming boringly but effectively monoglot; and the latest British Social Attitudes survey excavated the deep strain of anti-European feeling among Labour's own working-class supporters. But by the time the crab starter was brought to the table at the County Hotel the picture was looking considerably brighter. The Tories are again embroiled in conflict and it is one that goes far deeper than the trivial personality clashes which periodically mar the Blair government: Michael Portillo and William Hague have different views of what kind of party the Tories should be. And the presence in Aycliffe of Jacques Chirac may indicate that the presentation of Nice as Mr Blair's place of shame - his Waterloo, to mix the geography - is off-beam.

We tend to focus, inevitably, on the UK's negotiating position, the number of vetoes to be relinquished and the areas which are to become subject to majority voting. This is important. Gordon Brown looks across at Laurent Fabius in Paris and - snap - sees the money flowing into the coffers. But he notes Mr Fabius is still saying the French budget deficit will grow; French public finances are badly placed to weather a recession. Mr Brown may not need to read the French lessons from the gospel of prudence but he does need to stay on guard against proposals for tax harmonisation. Labour, against the historical odds, is minding a treasure trove; the future looks bright, too, even if recession comes. False moves on the fiscal front are not advisable.

Behind the vetoes lies a profound question: who is to exercise them. Mr Chirac has come to County Durham to lobby Mr Blair over the weighting of votes in the council of ministers. The Germans are going to Nice, as is their right, to request a re-equilibration of population and voting strength. After reunification, German numbers in the European parliament were increased. German contributions to the European budget were likewise adjusted upwards to reflect the new GDP.

But Germany's 10 council votes remained the same as the UK's and Italy's - and France's. Gerhard Schröder goes to the Riviera next week expecting the support of the UK for an act of historical rectification, though that is the sort of phrase the Germans tend to avoid, hesitant as they still are in geo-political conversation. It is a hope on which Mr Blair should play.

It suits the UK that the Franco-German axis is swinging on its hinge. There is a new pluralism in the European air, no longer are the UK's natural allies just the EU's minnows. Next week Mr Blair will have to give in order to take, and the eurosceptics will be ready to pounce on his concessions. But his capacity to strike deals has been enhanced and in the next few days he should burn the phone lines to his colleagues in Madrid, the Hague, Stockholm... and Berlin. Enhanced cooperation, streamlined European governance with a view to enlargement: Nice could be a stage on which a new piece gets played, Mr Blair's Warsaw concerto indeed. The fact the French hold the presidency will make it difficult to prise that looser, more open vision of Europe's future from the smoke-filled rooms and Mr Blair should ensure he gets plenty of sleep in advance of the inevitable late night sessions.

webTitle: Leader: How to save the nation's gravy

fields.headline: The Bisto kid
fields.standfirst: How to save the nation's gravy
fields.trailText: How to save the nation's gravy
fields.body:
There are problems, it seems, with gravy. Too little is being used to enrich and enliven the food on to which it is poured; too much is clogging the nation's drains. These facts have been established by one of those experts who cannot look at a plate of fish and chips without dropping a morsel or two into a handy test tube and jotting down calculations: Dr Len Fisher, an honorary research fellow of Bristol University, and the man who two years ago published a formula for the efficient dunking of biscuits in tea. He estimates the incidence of wasted gravy in Britain at 150,000 gallons a week.

Unwanted gravy has few alternative uses. It is not much help in a crisis. It is valueless, for instance, as a defence against floods, and worthless as an alternative power of propulsion if petrol supplies run low. There is nothing for it but to pour it away. The problem, Dr Fisher believes, is that people eat their meals in the wrong order. Instead of taking a bit from each component in turn, as most of us do, consumers should first consume all the meat and then all the vegetables bar the potatoes. While this process is under way, the gravy will seep steadily into your spud, and the nation's drains will be spared.

Doubts about this recommendation may be strongest in Yorkshire, where his view that Yorkshire puddings - the most successful gravy-absorbers of all - ought to be eaten last will surely be met with contumely. Yorkshire pudding should always be eaten first, on a separate plate, together with gravy. Only when that is done should the beef be served. Others may find the Stalinist sequence of eating which Dr Fisher prescribes objectionable on cultural as well as on culinary grounds. A simpler method for avoiding the waste of gravy might seem to the average eater to be to make rather less of the stuff in the first place. But Dr Fisher says nothing of that; which is hardly surprising when you note that his research was sponsored by Bisto.

fields.headline: The best chocolate scene
fields.standfirst: Small time crooks
fields.trailText: Small time crooks
fields.body:
New York. Petty hustler Ray Winkler (Woody Allen) arrives home carrying an extravagantly wrapped box of chocolates.

"Frenchy!" he yells to his wife. "Frenchy, I'm home?"

A voice is heard from the kitchen.

"Who's that?"

"Who's that? Who's that? It's the Pope. I always wanted to see your apartment. Who do you think it is that comes home every night?"

Frenchy (Tracey Ullman) emerges from the kitchen.

"Hey, I got you some chocolates."

"Chocolates?"

"Yeah, chocolates. You heard of chocolates? These are chocolates. I got you chocolates."

A look of suspicion flashes across Frenchy's face.

"How come?"

"How come? Whaddya mean, how come? Listen, these are from Belgium. They're hand-made by Belgiumites."

"You know what I mean. You're up to something. You get caught hitting on someone?"

"Frenchy, in 25 years of marriage, have I ever hit on anybody but you?"

"Yeah, well, I don't buy it, Ray. You're up to something."

"Aw, Frenchy... OK, you know what?"

Ray hurls the chocolates into the bin.

"Forget it. They're not for you. They're not for you. I got you nothing. Now cook me dinner. And hurry up. Uh, but before you cook dinner, I got something to tell you."

Frenchy's voice rises in triumph.

"What did I tell you? Here it comes!"

See also: Days of Wine and Roses, Life is Sweet, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory

Don't see also: Forrest Gump

Pointless trivia: Woody Allen habitually refuses to watch any of his films once they've been released.
