fields.headline: Cate Blanchett: Life after Elizabeth
fields.standfirst: Cate Blanchett, the luminous star of Elizabeth, tells Libby Brooks about ambition, the Queen and the truth about her 'rivalry' with Gwyneth Paltrow
fields.trailText: Cate Blanchett, the luminous star of Elizabeth, tells Libby Brooks about ambition, the Queen and the truth about her 'rivalry' with Gwyneth Paltrow
fields.body:
And so the conversation turns to chopsticks. "My God!" she shrieks. "Doesn't that upset you? I've got a pair in my bag and when I go to wherever... but if you add up all those paper napkins and all those chopsticks and all those plastic bags from Sainsbury's... it's terrifying!" Cate Blanchett's diamond eyes widen part in horror, part in mirth as she bowls through her environmentalist's tirade, wholly believing in what she says, though not succeeding in taking herself seriously.

Does she always manage to have a spare plastic bag with her? She gestures to the mammalian huddle of wigs at her feet, the remnants of the day's costume fitting. "The milk and bread will go in the bag with the wigs tonight," she announces, all competence. Her voice is both firm and yielding, inviting soft impressions like wet cement. "The bags that my grandma used to have are fantastic, very practical. They look like a wallet, but then you unzip them and pull the bag out. They're like those little rain hats."

Rainmates? "Yes, Rainmates! They're great!" Her face creases with glee, and one senses that a foldaway plastic bag with a Rainmate attached would bring Cate Blanchett extreme joy. She pauses. "It's a terribly intimate question to ask when I don't even know you, but do you have any lip salve?"

She applies. She is delightful to watch. The blonde hair is shorn and modern, her limbs taper like sculpture. Her skin is bright. But she radiates, rather than being radiant. She has none of the princessy confidence of the knowingly perfect. Her beauty is a conversation.

Lips figure prominently in Blanchett's latest release, The Man Who Cried, written and directed by Sally Potter. Arch sensualist Potter has assembled a quartet of voluptuous mouths belonging to Blanchett, Christina Ricci, John Turturro and Johnny Depp. Set in pre-war Paris, the fashion for glossy pillar-box red accentuates the deliciously puffy curve of Blanchett's top lip to the extent that, at times, it appears to be acting by itself. In one scene, Blanchett's character, Lola, observes her lover flirting with another woman across the dinner table. Potter's camera gaze lingers on her lips as they pout, stiffen and sag. It's all the viewer requires to know that a dream is shattering.

Lola is an ambitious Russian dancer, a loquacious, energetic soul who battles the displacement of the age, making compromises to survive and ultimately renegotiating what constitutes survival. "It was great to play someone who interacted with the world so physically. She experienced loss and immediately needed to find something to replace what she'd lost. After playing Susan Traherne, whose brain orbits around memory and abstract concepts, it was great to play someone who was very visceral."

The desperate, disillusioned heroine of David Hare's seminal post-war drama Plenty is clearly a character with deep resonances. The 31-year-old Australian played Traherne last year in Jonathan Kent's 10th anniversary revival of the play for the Almeida Theatre Company. Although initially touted as yet another movie star flouncing through the footlights for a taste of stagecraft credibility, Blanchett has a sturdy theatrical background, as her critically acclaimed performance proved. Raised in Melbourne, she graduated from Australia's National Institute of Dramatic Art in 1992. She worked extensively with Company B, a loose ensemble that included Shine star Geoffrey Rush, and appeared in Caryl Churchill's Top Girls and David Mamet's Oleanna for the Sydney Theatre Company, winning a Sydney Theatre Critics' award for the later role. But perhaps the emotional impact of playing Traherne was augmented by the excessive circumstances of the moment. "It was a very strange confluence of events last year," she muses, "when I just happened to be in the West End at the time that all that Oscars rubbish was going on..." She catches her drift, laughs at it. "Not rubbish, it was fantastic. I probably call it rubbish as a way of dealing with it."

Nominated as best actress, for her portrayal of the title role in Shekhar Kapur's Elizabeth (for which she also won a Golden Globe), she was inevitably pitched against the more fragile, less Australian Gwyneth Paltrow, who scooped the award for her part in Shakespeare in Love. Surely, pined the press, they must loathe one another. "Awful," she drawls. "It becomes a horse race. But thank Christ I'm surrounded by people with amazing senses of humour. And it was great to be doing my work [rehearsing for Plenty]. I literally went for the weekend and came back to the church-hall rehearsal-room atmosphere of the Almeida. It was 'Did you have a good time? Yep? Anyway, so on to page...' That made it much easier to cope with it."

She will not feign disinterest though. "I found the whole thing fascinating. I still do. But somehow all that stuff ends up getting reported like you're participating in it, and I couldn't have participated less. It's undeniably wonderful and of course you undeniably entertain the thought 'what would I do if I won?' But it is in the past now. So many things have happened since, but those things aren't as public. The spectre that haunts me more than the Oscars is having played Susan Traherne."

Perhaps another reason that Traherne remains so vivid for her relates to her forthcoming role as a young resistance fighter in Nazi-occupied France. She is to play the eponymous heroine in Gillian Armstrong's film adaptation of the Sebastian Faulks novel Charlotte Gray. She first read the book as preparation for her role in Plenty, and has worked with Armstrong previously on her adaptation of Peter Carey's Oscar and Lucinda, another of the many happy coincidences that seem to beset Blanchett's career. She tells of "bumping into" Kapur in a bar when he was casting Elizabeth. Her role in The Man Who Cried "felt like an accident", arising via her previous connections with production company Working Title and her former drama teacher's friendship with Sally Potter. One could distrust this, but she's too genuine to elicit cynicism. This woman has no side to her. Which is not to say that she is without complexity, that she does not change her mind, or have secrets. But there is a realness to her, a decency and an engagement with the wide world that is fresh, like the smell of good soil after a downpour.

She is very funny. She has a wide laugh. She is whole-hearted, and appears to have no side to her. She likes chance, the tango, her home Australia. You can imagine that she really enjoys talking about the taste of food. And it must be this firm-footedness that allows her such versatility on stage and screen: the prom queen gaudiness in Pushing Tin, her peachy rectitude in An Ideal Husband, the tremulous gawking in The Talented Mr Ripley.

Anthony Minghella, who directed her in Ripley, once described her as having a "hotline to the heart". He said: "What happens when the camera rolls is a remarkable transformation... the glimpse of soul, tiny flashes of joy and pain, and [she] is apparently incapable of a lie. It's as if she is letting you into her secrets. This is the albino quality, the chalky phosphorescence of her Elizabeth."

Acting, she says, is like telling a dirty story. "People always treat me like I'm being coy or untruthful if I say there's no grand plan, that acting is just an interesting thing that I found myself doing. It's not an end point." Is she ambitious? "What do you mean by that?" she asks sharply. "It's such a dirty word, you know. When people ask that, what they really want is an admission of ruthlessness. I don't think I am ruthless." Perhaps they mean to ask if you're hungry? "Or greedy... I'm hungry but I don't know if I'm greedy. I'm in an environment that tempts the greedy, and, like anybody, of course I have been, I'm not a saint. But you have to be honest about those flaws. You have to remain open to failure. I don't live in a particularly safe way. Of course I don't stand in the middle of the road, but I'm not frightened of pain. I don't want to be in a situation where I'm acting like a studio executive."

But ambition can be about passion too. Is she passionate about her "accidental" career? "I like a challenge, and I find it thrilling to leap into situations that are bigger than me. I suppose that's the accident. It's what you throw away as much as what you choose to hold on to - it's what you say no to." So has she become more self-conscious about those choices, the more success she garners? "People judge you," she says. She smiles, remembering. "Last year, a woman from Ipswich sent me a letter saying how dare I not curtsey to the Queen when she visited the Almeida. I thought 'what is she talking about?', because I had rung the palace and said, 'I've never met the Queen before, what does one do?' They told me it was a very informal meeting - in the past, people had curtsied and people hadn't. So I turned up at the theatre, and suddenly there were Australian television cameras there because the republican debate was going on. I said, 'Do you want to know if I'm a republican, well, yes I am', and obviously that became [she drops her voice to the sandpaper rasp of a republican hoon] the bold Australian who says 'Fuck you!' And all of a sudden I wasn't curtseying to the Queen! I thought 'I had no control over that'." She is, laughing, bemused. "But you move on. That's the strength that comes out of it. Although the couple have been nominally based in London for the past few years, they work flexibly around each other, recently returning to Sydney where Upton was working on a production of Cyrano. "It's constantly evolving. My photo is in the paper more often than his is, but it doesn't mean that my career is prioritised."

And what about wee ones? "I'd like wee ones," she says gently. "There have been a few additions to the family lately, and when you meet someone you want to have wee ones with, it's exciting. But it'll happen when it happens. I'm not taking my temperature, or trying to fit it in around work. I don't think that's a particularly great way to bring children into the world. They'll come when they come."

She has enjoyed perching in London, she says, though she's homesick. She is indulgent of the British version of Australia ("that older sibling thing"), but is currently much exercised by the Howard government's attack on arts funding. She says that she hugely admires Olympic medallist and Aboriginal rights campaigner Cathy Freeman. She is interested in and interesting about all manner of subjects, though she dislikes explaining herself. "I think everyone loves clarity. It's much safer. But I'm incredibly incoherent, so people have to be satisfied with the incomplete sentence." She laughs again. Cate Blanchett, completely.

fields.headline: Small Town Crooks
fields.standfirst: Lightweight and undemanding, Woody Allen's latest would curl up and die without its cracking one-liners, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: What keeps this lightweight, shallow movie going is the succession of cracking one-liners, applied like mega-volt goads, continuously prodding the body of the film and zapping it awake.
fields.body:
It is a function, or perhaps a symptom, of Woody Allen's escapist late style that you can watch Small Time Crooks all the way through and keep forgetting that it's supposed to be set in the present day.

His latest Runyonesque romp looks like it's set in the Manhattan of the 1930s and 1940s; or perhaps more precisely the timeless toytown Manhattan of Woody Allen's imagination. It's the Manhattan of expensive cars pulling up outside fabulous apartment buildings with a long canopy stretching across the sidewalk - and it's a slight jolt when the car is a Lexus rather than a bulbous Buick. Everything about it sits more easily in the Jazz Age.

Allen is Ray, an incompetent criminal married to "Frenchy" (Tracey Ullman), a former exotic dancer. Together, they take the lease on a store a few doors down from a bank so that they can tunnel into it. But the home-baked cookies Frenchy sells in the fake "store" become so wildly successful that this phoney operation becomes more lucrative than any bank-job.

At which point a much less interesting second act is ushered in. The newly wealthy Frenchy tries to better herself with the help of a creepy British art dealer - an excellent performance from Hugh Grant, his best since An Awfully Big Adventure - while Ray yearns for the simple life he has left behind.

And they all behave as if Calvin Coolidge or Herbert Hoover is in the White House. Nothing in it looks contemporary, and it would take just a second to amend the script to place it in the same era as Bullets Over Broadway. Frenchy's giant nationwide cookie franchise, for example, certainly doesn't have a website. She airily hosts a dinner party and tells her guests: "I saw a beautiful painting of fruit... at the Met, or, er, the Whitney, or the Holocaust..." It's one of many big laughs, but something in Tracey Ullman's stagey Guys-and-Dolls accent makes you think for a second: what Holocaust?

All this is part of Allen's new production line of snappy, undemanding plot conceits, drained of both the autobiography and European anxiety of his earlier work and finding a comfortable new home, overtly or not, in the America of the Marx Brothers. (Perhaps not entirely drained of the autobiography: the soundtrack includes Zelda's Theme, composed by his most ferocious critic over the Soon-Yi affair - André Previn.)

The abysmal failure of the plan to tunnel into the bank is actually about modern corporate capitalism being more profitable than any romantic outlaw daring. (Mike Myers had a similar idea with Dr Evil's "Starbucks" operation being more successful and less troublesome than global wickedness.)

What keeps this lightweight, shallow movie going is the succession of cracking one-liners, applied like mega-volt goads, continuously prodding the body of the film and zapping it awake. There are too many to quote here, but Allen surely gives his audience their money's worth with his and Frenchy's furious exchanges as they prepare for the new social whirl Ray dreads. "Escargots? Snails? A snail leaves a trail of scum!" - "Not in France!" Later Frenchy becomes infatuated with the idea of eating truffles: "They're so subtle only pigs can find them."

Woody Allen's own appearance in the film is a curiosity. Playing a character perhaps 30 years too young for him, he demonstrates that all his mannerisms remain eerily the same while he himself gets older. The tics are hard-wired into the script and they will appear in whoever plays the Woody role, as John Cusack showed in Bullets, or, even more notoriously, Kenneth Branagh in Celebrity.

Funny stuff, of course, all of it, except for the new aggression and unpleasantness with which he experimented in Deconstructing Harry. Many a time in this film he threatens Frenchy with an old-fashioned beating ("I oughta slap your head off"), and the effect is jarring and superfluous.

The real success of this middling Allen comedy, and a source of great frustration, is the terrific performance from Elaine May as Frenchy's stupid cousin May. She's brought in to help out at the bakery and Ray eventually finds that he has more in common with her than with Frenchy, with all her airs and graces. May's maladroitness and slowness is achieved with a superb actor's intelligence, and it is a performance that puts Tracey Ullman's hammy TV-sketch-show turn in the shade. But there is nowhere in the script for May to go, so all that energy remains unharnessed.

Small Time Crooks feels like the kind of halfway decent film Allen can make without breaking sweat. Whether he has a big movie left in him is anyone's guess.

fields.headline: No Place to Go
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An agonisingly emotional expression for the unspoken, unacknowledged feelings of anxiety and even epoch-grief that afflicted a generation of Germans in 1989.
fields.body:
The German Film Festival in London strikes a sombre and yet coruscatingly powerful keynote with the UK premiere of Oskar Röhler's No Place to Go (the German title is Die Unberührbare, or The Untouchables). Hannelore Elsner gives a superb performance as Hanna Flanders, a tragic, imperious belle-dame of the intellectual left in late-1980s Germany, living a comfortable life in Munich but failing to find a publisher for her now unfashionable political novels and still affecting to believe in the utopia of the East.

Hanna's world is up-ended with the news of the breach of the Wall. Impelled by a strange appointment with the zeitgeist, Hanna travels to Berlin to find only romantic rejection and contempt from her reading public, who revile her for upholding the political slavery from which they have all broken free.

Rö hler's film finds an agonisingly emotional expression for the unspoken, unacknowledged feelings of anxiety and even epoch-grief that afflicted a generation of Germans in 1989, articulated most clearly by Günter Grass: the heretical belief that maybe reunification was not a good thing.

Röhler's direction and Hagen Bogdanski's stark, black-and-white cinematography recall the paranoid unease of Roman Polanski or early David Lynch, and Hannelore Elsner is wonderful. In her glowering mask of deathly-white make-up and her absurd wig, she is a dark contemporary echo of Klaus Maria Brandauer in Istvan Svabo's Mephisto. It's a magnificent portrayal of a vulnerable, cantankerous, left-wing political reactionary who is still big - it's just that international politics got small.

In her glowering mask of deathly-white make-up and her absurd wig, she is a dark contemporary echo of Klaus Maria Brandauer in Istvan Svabo's Mephisto. It's a magnificent portrayal of a vulnerable, cantankerous, left-wing political reactionary who is still big - it's just that international politics got small.

fields.headline: Urban Legends: Final Cut
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A waste of time, space, celluloid, everything.
fields.body:
A waste of time, space, celluloid, everything... this is the sequel to 1998's sub-Scream campus slasher Urban Legend. A cast of improbably pretty young people, played by improbably pretty young-ish actors, find themselves in film school. One by one they are confronted with the classic "safety or death" choice immortalised in Scary Movie, and one by one get bumped off.

As ever, the film presumes to make loads of smirking self-congratulatory references to scary classics - and, bizarrely, some upmarket nods to Truffaut - but the sheer incompetence and dullness of this non-shocker suggests that director John Ottman has not understood any of them.

fields.headline: Red Planet
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Commercials director Antony Hoffman brings this to the screen with reasonable slickness. But there is an utter refusal to try anything new here.
fields.body:
Once again, it's time for a trip into space in a big balletic space ship. There's a crew of five or so, including a hot babe, floating weightlessly about and slapping peevishly at bleeping control panels, with the traditional cute-but-sinister robot thing on board, characterised by its bloody-minded refusal to open the pod bay doors.

Carrie-Anne Moss and Val Kilmer lead this latest mission to Mars. It's 2050, and due to the environmental rapine of the Planet Earth - an eco-atrocity deplored by each crew member with a solemn frown - they have to colonise that old Red Planet. The crew touch down wearing uniforms bearing the sponsorship logos of Toshiba and Nokia, a cute bit of product placement, and how remarkable that these firms envisage their corporate branding remaining unchanged 50 years into the future.

The pioneers stumble around the desolate wasteland (as in Pitch Black, the Australian outback is the main location) but they find evidence that it is not as uninhabited as they thought. Gulp! The movie cranks through a few permutations of old fantasies, and in keeping with the subliminal America über alles theme, some casual, humourless jibes are flicked at the Russians' tin-pot attempts to land on Mars.

With Brian De Palma's preposterous Mission to Mars, and John Travolta's horrific Battlefield Earth so fresh in our memory, it could be that the bar has been set unnaturally low for this kind of movie. Commercials director Antony Hoffman brings this to the screen with reasonable slickness. But there is an utter refusal to try anything new here. No cliché is left unlaunched, including, incredibly, switching to the android's point of view, and making it a computer screen with X-ray images, temperature readings, and so on.

fields.headline: Judy Berlin
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An intriguing, distinctive piece with an undercurrent of old-fashioned sentimentality.
fields.body:
This is a curious little film I saw at the Edinburgh Film Festival two years ago, written and directed by first-timer Eric Mendelsohn. In some ways, it has a weirdly underground feel. Black-and-white cinematography, uneven sound mix, mike boom often visible in shot.

The chief point of interest is the presence of Edie Falco, now a mega-star thanks to The Sopranos. Here, she displays her versatility by playing a very much younger role as the eponymous Judy, a small-town gal with big dreams of making it in Hollywood, who runs into an old high-school crush, David (Aaron Harnick), who has returned to his home town, bruised by his failure to become a movie director.

Their little suburb is plunged into darkness during a total eclipse, conferring a strange twilight zone aura on everything and making manifest the occluded, suburban nature of their lives. The movie is pleasingly like something Douglas Coupland might have written, with the comic millennial anxiety that seemed so contemporary in 1999. It's an intriguing, distinctive piece with an undercurrent of old-fashioned sentimentality.

fields.headline: La Fidélité
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A bizarre, extended melodrama with its own strange sense of urgency.
fields.body:
Just as Lé os Carax made an uneasy attempt in Pola X to find a modern screen idiom for Melville's Pierre, or the Ambiguities, Andrzej Zulawski here tries to film Madame Lafayette's 17th-century novel The Princess of Cleves, set in a France of the near future.

The result is a bizarre, extended melodrama with its own strange sense of urgency. However, its operatic emotions are never anything other than absurd, and the theme of marital fidelity is entirely lost in the blizzard of commercial and sexual modernity with which Zulawski bombards us.

Sophie Marceau, beautiful as ever, plays Clé lia, a photographer who is always snapping away with her camera at "real life" and naturally transforming it with her passionate, artistic gaze. Words cannot convey how incredibly irritating she is. Anyway, Sophie is hired by bullish media mogul Mac Roi (Michel Subor), to put a bit of class into his tabloid, La Vé rité . So artistic Sophie has to enter the morally squalid world of a tabloid newspaper office, which Zulawski imagines to be all white and brilliantly lit like an art installation but populated by bohemian drunks staggering around screaming.

For some reason, Mac Roi publishes Sophie's blurred pics in some kind of artistic supplement. Meanwhile, Sophie has married the patrician publisher Clè ve (Pascal Greggory) but is tempted by the young photographer Nemo (Guillaume Canet), with a funky barbed-wire tattoo, who appears to be an investigative reporter, shrugging off danger as he blows the lid off child prostitution in Asia and the black market in body parts.

The film shows Andrzej Zulawski to be as innocent as a child about how the mass media works. Mac Roi, who is supposed to be such a crude tabloid merchant, would not be interested in these earnest investigations, which in any case require expensive teams of reporters, not a single hunky guy with a camera and a leather jacket. The fact that every single aspect of the movie's world is so strenuously unreal precludes us from taking it seriously.

Last year at Cannes, the veteran Portuguese director Manoel de Oliveira presented his own modernisation of Madame Lafayette in La Lettre, and that too was a little absurd, but it was carried off more lightly, more simply and with more otherworldly charm than Zulawski's cumbersome epic.

fields.headline: The Grinch
fields.trailText:
Peter Bradshaw: The Grinch, he hates Christmas - but a Blonde Little Girl

Brings the Grinch to his Senses: it Just made me Hurl.
fields.body:
Every Who down in Who-Ville liked Christmas a lot,

But the Grinch who lived just North of Who-Ville did not!

He's played by Jim Carrey, and Cross as can Be,

And Cute in a Suit of Green Latex is he,

He's Grouchy and Grumpy but Funny you see,

And millions of Dollars he's Paid for his Fee.

Dr Seuss Wrote the Book Where the Grinch Did Appear,

It was Huge in the States, Not so Much over Here.

The Cat in the Hat and, well, All of That Stuff,

Americans really just Can't get Enough.

The Grinch, he hates Christmas - but a Blonde Little Girl

Brings the Grinch to his Senses: it Just made me Hurl.

The Little girl's Sweet, an Adorable Lassie

Like JonBenet Ramsey but Not Quite as Sassy.

The Grinch is redeemed 'cos the Kid is so Kind

Oscar Wilde's Little Prince can Go Kiss His Behind

Ron Howard directs and got Plenty of Loot

(That's the Happy Days man, who's now Bald as a Coot)

Sir Anthony Hopkins, he Does the Narration

Mr Hopkins...I mean...he's Deserted our Nation,

The Incessant Rhyming is really the Pits,

And After A While it just Gets on Your Nerves.

fields.headline: A £12bn win for widows
fields.standfirst: Labour was right to concede
fields.trailText: Labour was right to concede
fields.body:
It has rightly been described as the worst case of public administration since the second world war. For 10 years after the 1986 act that halved the payments to widows or widowers of their partner's state earnings related pensions scheme (Serps), social security staff continued to suggest that surviving spouses would still receive a full pension. Even people who telephoned to check their entitlement were not told of the change that was due to start in April of this year. The Tory bungle - which the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, had the grace to own up to this week - has been condemned by the national audit office, the government ombudsman, the public accounts committee and, most recent of all, the public administration committee. It was this committee, with its report published last week - coupled with the threat of a European Court action by Age Concern - that seems finally to have persuaded the government that its original compensation scheme was totally inadequate.

The government was right to bow to such pressure. The losses which widows and widowers were facing were considerable - an average of £25-a-week but with some people losing more than £100. Ministers had already postponed the start of the scheme until October, 2002. But a proposed compensation scheme, which placed an implicit onus on claimants to show they had been misled was, in the words of the public administration committee, "an invitation to fraud". They rightly warned that one administrative disaster was in danger of being compounded by a second. It was going to be impossible to identify who had been misled. Ministers had promised to write to all 20m contributors, but they did not have the correct addresses of 8m .

Labour's new compensation scheme announced this week has been welcomed by all parties. Sensibly, all people retiring before October 2002, will now be able to pass on their full Serps pension to a surviving spouse. Beyond that, the 1986 cut will be phased in over 10 years. This gives fair and proper notice of the pending change. One of the many defects of the original Conservative cut was the lack of transitional arrangements. These changes will cost about £12bn over the next 50 years. But the 1986 cuts were always too draconian. What this week's package does for Labour's support among pensioners, remains to be seen.

fields.trailText: America's most stylish essayist passes judgment on God, Mammon and the land of the brave
fields.body:
The morning one of the Valley's new firms sprang its IPO, the company's 40-year-old CEO instantly became worth $9m. Four and a half hours later, he took his Ferrari for a spin and did just that. The car went through a guardrail and he was killed. The Valley took it as the dark side of the Force, but others saw it otherwise. That there was still a God.

Internet gurus tell us that the computer is a brain and that if we get a sufficient number of them, billions, operating all over the world in a single seamless Web, we will converge on a superbrain that overarches petty nationalism and racial competition. But let me assure you that all the internet does is speed up information and partially eliminate chores. All else is Digibabble. If you don't believe me, tell me why SAT scores are falling?

The answer may be found among the new neuroscientists. We are what we are. Our brains are hot-wired, a genetically predetermined series of electromagnetic switches. There is no such things as consciousness, guilt or freewill. This is not a popular line of enquiry, and even as I write the evolutionary apologists are fighting a revisionist battle for our souls. I predict that as all the accepted 21st-century mantras slip back into the primordial ooze, a new theory will emerge. It will feel solid. And it will be named God.

Which brings me nicely to me. I feel a little uncomfortable including my magnificent 1965 pastiche of the New Yorker, because today it might not seem quite so remarkable as it was then. But let me assure you that its brilliance has stood the test of time and that I have emerged as the only writer with the genius to give America the literature it deserves. Take my last novel, A Man in Full. Eleven years in the writing, I grant you, but the public and the critics adored it. I mention this only because others have mentioned it, not out of self-regard.

And who should be the only dissenters? Norman Mailer, John Irving and John Updike, the three writers who have done the most in recent years to traduce us with their bumbling musings. There will, and there must be a saviour from their myopia.

God bless America and God bless me. Me, me, me, God, me, me, God, me.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: America's most stylish essayist passes judgment on God, Mammon and the land of the brave

fields.headline: New evidence in Damilola murder
fields.standfirst:
Witness saw boy held in headlock near attack scene

More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: A potentially vital witness has told police hunting the killers of Damilola Taylor that he saw a young boy being held in a headlock by three youths close to the spot where the 10-year-old bled to death on Monday.
fields.body:
A potentially vital witness has told police hunting the killers of Damilola Taylor that he saw a young boy being held in a headlock by three youths close to the spot where the 10-year-old bled to death on Monday.

The man came forward yesterday to tell police he had seen an incident as he walked down a street near the North Peckham estate in south London. He had taken no notice because he had assumed the boys were "larking around".

His account chimes with the evidence of a passerby who found Damilola collapsed in a stairwell on the estate, bleeding heavily from a stab wound to his left leg.

As he tended to Damilola he spotted three youths wearing hoods running from the scene.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt, who is in charge of the inquiry, said details provided by the new witness were "significant", although the approximate timing of the sighting - 4pm - was 45 minutes before the attack.

Det Supt Dillnutt insisted yesterday he did not have a list of potential suspects and that his team was still trying to piece together Damilola's last movements from fragments of information provided by his schoolfriends and hundreds of callers to the incident room.

He revealed that a cctv camera had filmed Damilola leaving Peckham library at 4.30pm following an after-school computer class. He was walking with a boy and a girl, who appear to be his age. The boy was carrying a black Reebok rucksack with a white logo. Both seemed to be wearing a dark school uniform.

"I appeal for that boy and that girl to come forward. Please tell us if you were with Damilola - it is vitally important."

Detectives were also examining a list of names written by Damilola and left in his locker at Oliver Goldsmith primary school. One theory is that the note refers to pupils he had accused of bullying and taunting him.

Two kitchen knives and a bloodstained broken bottle found within 200 metres of where the attack took place have been sent to the forensic science service for analysis.

Damilola was walking home along Blakes Road, Peckham, when he was stabbed. His femoral artery was severed.

He staggered 100 metres and died within five minutes walk of the flat where his mother, Gloria, was waiting for him.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday went to Oliver Goldsmith school to urge parents to cooperate with the police.

"We know young people and some adults and friends know exactly who killed Damilola Taylor. And what is necessary for relatives of Damilola is for these people to recognise their responsibility to this community and to Damilola's family and to provide information to the police."

The Conservative leader, William Hague, said the death of Damilola, four months after leaving Nigeria to live in Britain with his mother, sister and brother, showed there was something "disturbing about our whole society. When a family can live safely in Africa, but find their youngest child brutally murdered on the streets of London, all of us feel a sense of shame and anger."

Meanwhile, Scotland Yard revealed yesterday that street robbery by children as young as 10 was a new and growing phenomenon in the capital.

webTitle: Court allows Saudi dissident's extradition to US

fields.headline: Court allows Arab's extradition to US
fields.trailText: A Saudi dissident allegedly linked to Osama bin Laden, the man most wanted by the US, should be extradited there to face charges of conspiracy to murder, the high court ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
A Saudi dissident allegedly linked to Osama bin Laden, the man most wanted by the US, should be extradited there to face charges of conspiracy to murder, the high court ruled yesterday.

Khalid al Fawwaz, who has been living in Britain since 1994, is accused by the FBI of conspiring with Bin Laden to murder American citizens abroad. The US authorities allege that Bin Laden was responsible for the bombings of the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 in which 224 people died.

They say Al Fawwaz conspired with Bin Laden and others between 1993 and 1998 to bomb and murder US citizens. Targets allegedly included US officials and soldiers in the Middle East and Africa, and those working with UN peacekeeping missions.

webTitle: On the Wembley way to a fiasco

fields.headline: On the Wembley way to a fiasco
fields.standfirst:
New national stadium is costly, lacks funding - and has yet to be started
New Wembley in trouble as banks back off
fields.trailText: As recently as October 7, English football and Wembley stadium seemed ready to march, hand in hand, towards a glorious destiny. A couple of hours before Kevin Keegan's team emerged from the famous tunnel to face Germany in a World Cup qualifying match, the chief executive of Wembley National Stadium plc rose to his feet in the press lounge and started to outline the bright future that was about to begin.
fields.body:
As recently as October 7, English football and Wembley stadium seemed ready to march, hand in hand, towards a glorious destiny. A couple of hours before Kevin Keegan's team emerged from the famous tunnel to face Germany in a World Cup qualifying match, the chief executive of Wembley National Stadium plc rose to his feet in the press lounge and started to outline the bright future that was about to begin.

Illustrating his talk with architects' drawings, Bob Stubbs described not just the rebuilt sports arena in north London, with its soaring 350ft high Norman Foster arch and its 150 premium-priced VIP boxes, but the 200-bedroom hotel, the rentable office space, and the lavish facilities for conferences and banquets built into the design. The demolition men would move in to prepare the way, he said, virtually as soon as the valedictory celebrations for the old twin-towered stadium were over.

What Mr Stubbs did not know was that the bulldozers would go for the team before they attacked the stadium. England lost the match, and Kevin Keegan resigned. Yesterday the timetable in the official Wembley website was still giving November 2000 as the date for the start of demolition of the original stadium, based on a structure built in 1923. But apart from the pitch itself, which has been torn up, and some of the fixtures and fittings, which were sold off in a televised auction earlier this month, the scene of England's World Cup triumph of 1966 remains virtually untouched, while the deadline for raising £450m of backing from City banks is postponed again.

Building a national stadium to replace the decaying Wembley edifice should have been a reasonably straightforward affair. The Stade de France, Cardiff's Millennium Stadium and Sydney's Stadium Australia were all completed in time to host prestige events, each built at less than half Wembley's projected cost. And since the owners of the new Wembley are the Football Association, the governing body of a sport so prosperous that it pays teenage players salaries of tens of thousands of pounds a week, the apparent difficulty in raising the cash might seem even more mystifying.

But rebuilding Wembley was never straightforward. First mooted in the early 1990s, it was originally planned as a joint project between Sport England, which administers National Lottery funds, and Wembley plc, the private company that owned and operated the stadium. When the two bodies could not agree terms, a different plan emerged under which the FA would buy the stadium from its former owners and, having created a new wholly owned subsidiary company called Wembley National Stadium plc, would collaborate with Sport England to build a venue suitable for the grandest sporting events, with bids for the 2006 World Cup and the 2012 Olympic Games in mind.

When the new company came into being, chaired by Ken Bates, an FA council member and the chairman of Chelsea football club, it used its lottery grant of £120m to pay Wembley plc £103m for the buildings and the land. The transfer of ownership was confirmed in March 1999, and four months later the new company unveiled the initial design, a joint project by Lord Foster, one of Britain's leading architects, with HOK+Lobb, a partnership formed by the recent merger between a Kansas City company responsible for more than 50 stadiums in the US and a Brisbane company that worked on Huddersfield Town's McAlpine stadium and Bolton Wanderers' Reebok stadium, as well as Stadium Australia.

The plans bore the imprint of Mr Bates's thinking in their inclusion of a hotel and office space, and of the high proportion of seats - 14,000 of a total of 90,000 - devoted to VIPs and corporate hospitality clients. This reflected the philosophy behind the Chelsea Village development at Stamford Bridge, where the football ground is surrounded by facilities intended to generate extra revenue from the site. On the basis of these additional features, the new Wembley company announced a projected annual profit of around £30m, compared with the most recent figure of £8.8m for the old stadium.

In December last year a row broke out over the omission from the final plans of a running track, which had been part of the written agreement between the plc and Sport England. The terms under which the lottery money was granted ensured that the stadium would be able to stage major track and field events, meaning that the new Wembley would be the natural home for the 2003 world athletics championships, which had already been awarded to Britain, and would form the core element of a bid for the Olympic Games.

While Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and Kate Hoey, the sports minister, belatedly tried to insist on the reinstatement of a track, it emerged that the FA had threatened to withdraw from the entire project if it were not given total control over the stadium's configuration. The argument rumbled on, and in the end Mr Bates agreed to forgo £20m of the lottery funding in exchange for the right to exclude athletics. The £20m, it was said, would be diverted to the building of an arena dedicated to athletics, at Picketts Lock in north London, with a capacity of 20,000, barely enough for the world championships and less than a third of the size required to back up an Olympic bid.

There were also lengthy arguments about a payment to Brent council in recognition of the extra work required to bring roads and other public facilities into line with the new Wembley stadium. Brent wanted £30m. Mr Bates offered £1m. Eventually they compromised on £17m. But the highways agency raised objections to the degree of congestion created by the new stadium, based on the number of events the stadium would hold. An amendment to the deal was eventually agreed, limiting Wembley to 30 sporting events and 12 concerts a year.

The company had also run into unexpected difficulties in attracting bids for the building contract. Two months ago Construction News magazine reported that although several British companies, including Taylor Woodrow, McAlpine, Mowlem and HBG, had examined the project, none had submitted a bid. One senior manager of a company which declined to bid described Wembley National Stadium as "the client from hell". Among British companies, only Bovis had tendered, in partnership with an Australian company called Multiplex. When that joint deal collapsed, or was "unilaterally terminated", in WNS's words, the contract was awarded to Multiplex, which has been building Chelsea's new west stand for Mr Bates.

This week news of the latest dispute emerged, this time over the stadium's car park. Required for use by Griffiths McGee, the winners of the £10m demolition contract, it has been leased back to the old owners, allegedly due to a mistake by WNS's legal team. A high court judge is expected to rule before Christmas.

The scale of the project has drawn criticism from those who think that a national stadium should be no more nor less than that. It has been suggested this week that there are influential figures within the FA who believe that the new Wembley should never have attempted to emulate the style of Mr Bates's Chelsea, with its four-star hotel, 54 flats, nine restaurants and a nightclub. It may be, too, that the fiasco of the Millennium Dome has curbed British financiers' appetite for big projects. But the biggest hindrance of all may have been the FA's humiliating failure to win the right to host the 2006 World Cup, which would have provided the project with a guaranteed future success against which to raise funds.

"You could build a Cardiff or a Twickenham," Mr Stubbs said, "but this country deserves better than that. Any fool could build a Cardiff or a Twickenham." Those England fans still unconvinced by WNS's plans, and looking at the potential lengthening of the period in which their team are forced to play their home matches in club stadiums around the country, might just have settled for the fool's choice.

webTitle: What kind of Europe do they want?

fields.headline: What kind of Europe do they want?
fields.standfirst:
The view from Berlin, Paris and Stockholm
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
Germany
The Germans have spent more than a decade electing governments passionately committed to the European ideal, but they have shown only guarded enthusiasm for EU enlargement which member states will wrangle over in Nice.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson, Jon Henley and Andrew Osborn
fields.body:
Germany
The Germans have spent more than a decade electing governments passionately committed to the European ideal, but they have shown only guarded enthusiasm for EU enlargement which member states will wrangle over in Nice.

Polls suggest that a slim majority of Germans are in favour of increasing the size of the EU, but are divided over whether the project will bring any positive advantages. A recent survey in Die Woche newspaper showed a 52% majority in favour of EU enlargement. But 41% said they thought the inclusion of eastern European countries would bring disadvantages. Only 39% thought the project would benefit Germany while 11% were undecided.

In the aftermath of German reunification, former chancellor Helmut Kohl used the phrase "German unity and European unity are two sides of the same coin" to allay French and British fears of a new German superstate emerging in Europe. Gerhard Schroder's coalition government has moved the German goalposts on Europe only slightly. His foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, is committed to an eventual European Federation ruled by a government in Brussels with an elected European president.

According to the newspaper poll, the Germans are divided equally with 46% in favour and 46% against. However Mr Schroder has accused Brussels of "burning up" German money and is now at loggerheads with the French over his demand for an increase in Germany's EU voting weight to reflect its population of 82m. (TP)

France
Despite the fact that France holds the current EU presidency, no senior French politician has made a major speech on Europe since Jacques Chirac's lofty but vague address to the Bundestag in Berlin last June.

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has - like the rest of his government - managed to avoid outlining what kind of Europe France would like ever since he was elected more than three years ago. This is partly because each has already begun his campaign for the 2002 presidential elections, and is worried that any boldly pro-European initiative on the international stage will be used against them domestically. But it is also because neither man is passionately pro-European.

They would be happy with an EU that offered more social guarantees than the lowest-common-denominator, free trade bloc they suspect Britain wants, but certainly not with the United States of Europe that they suspect is Germany's aim. While for differing reasons they cannot afford to say it, France's leaders would be satisfied with something very close to Mr Blair's vision of an almost ad hoc cooperation of sovereign governments - itself a vision very similar to Charles de Gaulle's "Europe des patries". (JH)

Sweden
Sweden has decidedly mixed feelings about the EU and its future direction. Polls show at least half the population would be happy to withdraw from the union altogether, while two in every three Swedes are against Stockholm adopting the single currency any time soon.

Aware that they are a relatively minor player in the EU, the Swedes will do their utmost to ensure that small and medium-sized countries do not lose out when it comes to the reweighting of votes. This is likely to be one of the great faultlines of the talks with the smaller countries such as Sweden, Belgium and Luxembourg pitted against the big four of France, Germany, Britain and Italy.

Swedes are keen for the EU to assume more authority in environmental policy and also fret about corruption and fraud in Brussels. They want a greener, more efficient EU which tackles serious issues such as employment policy but which does not legislate in every single area of their lives. The one area where they are particularly loath to surrender power to Brussels is taxation - because they like paying high taxes for high-quality public services.

When asked whether Sweden wants a Europe of nation states or a federal European superstate diplomats usually respond "something inbetween". (AB)

webTitle: Gulf uranium warning failed to reach troops

fields.headline: Gulf uranium warning failed to reach troops
fields.standfirst: Veterans angry as MoD admits finding 'lost' safety message
fields.trailText: Veterans angry as MoD admits finding 'lost' safety message
fields.body:
Thousands of soldiers were placed at risk from the effects of depleted uranium, the substance linked to Gulf war syndrome, after a safety notice failed to reach troops in Saudi Arabia during the 1991 conflict.

A breakdown in communications meant that the notice from the Ministry of Defence in London never found its way to soldiers attached to tanks armed with ammunition containing the fatal substance, the government said last night.

In a written parliamentary reply, the defence minister, John Spellar, said officials had uncovered a message which was sent from the MoD to 1 Armoured Division in Saudi Arabia on 25 February 1991 about the dangers posed by the substance. A second message, advising on how to avoid breathing in depleted uranium dust, never reached its destination.

Mr Spellar's admission is an embarrassment to the MoD, which is fighting claims by Gulf war veterans that they were poisoned by depleted uranium during the war.

Veterans reacted angrily last night to the MoD statement. Shaun Rusling, of the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association, said he did not believe safety messages were ever sent to the Gulf.

"I think the MoD statement is untrue and is designed to cover up their failure to issue any warnings," he said. "This is very disturbing. I would like to see their documentation as we can prove the MoD was fully aware of the dangers and yet did nothing to advise troops."

The MoD statement came as new figures showed nearly 300 Gulf war veterans have died in the last three years. In a parliamentary reply, Mr Spellar said 278 Gulf war veterans have died since 1995. None of the dead has been officially confirmed as a victim of Gulf war syndrome. Fifty committed suicide.

Stephen Childs, 47, who died of liver and pancreas cancer on Saturday, was the most recent Gulf war soldier to die. His doctor believes exposure to depleted uranium while he recovered damaged vehicles caused his illness.

The MoD said last night that it regretted that its safety notice failed to reach troops. But a spokesman insisted that there was no proof that soldiers fell ill as a result of depleted uranium, which is used to strengthen the tips of shells.

The spokesman said that the substance only posed a risk to Iraqi troops when it vapourised after piercing armour. "We do not believe it is a problem for British veterans, but we have offered them tests. This has not been accepted."

The veterans' campaign received a boost earlier this year after tests were carried out on the body of Terry Riordon, a Canadian military policeman who died after suffering Gulf war syndrome. They found substances linked to depleted uranium in his bone tissue.

webTitle: Europhobic hysteria does Britain no favours

fields.headline: Europhobic hysteria does Britain no favours
fields.standfirst:
Commissioner Chris Patten explains why Tony Blair faces a unique negotiating handicap at the Nice summit

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Commissioner Chris Patten explains why Tony Blair faces a unique negotiating handicap at the Nice summit
fields.body:
European Union leaders will take a "hard pounding" before agreeing a new treaty at next week's Nice summit, Chris Patten, the external relations commissioner, warned last night. On a day that Romano Prodi, the commission president, predicted only a 50-50 chance of success, the former Conservative party chairman insisted it was vital to reach agreement to allow the EU to enlarge and complete the unification of Europe.

Mr Patten, who came to Brussels last year after his governorship of Hong Kong and work on Northern Ireland policing, is a key member of Mr Prodi's 20-strong team. But he remains sharply focused on the tortured relationship between Britain and the EU. Tony Blair, he insisted, is not alone, with his Nice "red lines" on tax, social security, defence and borders, where he refuses to move to qualified majority voting (QMV). "Everyone goes with their own agenda. Everyone has something they'll be battling for. "The prime minister, unlike me, is elected, and the prime minister or any head of a government in the EU has to be able to carry public opinion. But public opinion is whipped up into hysteria by parts of the media."

But Mr Blair faces a unique difficulty, the commissioner argues. "No other prime minister has to cope with the assumption that in any negotiation a government is either beleaguered or selling out to foreigners. It's lunatic." As Mr Patten sees it, the prime minister is placed at a negotiating disadvantage by a domestic debate in which "some people seek to argue that any agreement is the next best thing to treachery. "The truth is, in the last few years we've got most of the changes and most of the advances we wanted out of the EU. If only we could confront these issues with a bit more self confidence we would get one hell of a lot further." Nice, which marks the end of France's six-month EU presidency, has to tackle three tough issues left over from the 1997 Amsterdam summit: the voting weights of member states, the size of the commission, and the vetoes.

Without agreement on these changes, paralysis is likely to set in when 12 candidate countries from Poland to Malta start joining the current 15 members over the next few years, altering the politics and economics of the union beyond recognition. "Nice's purpose is to make the process of enlargement, which is an imperative objective for all of us, easier than it would otherwise be," said Mr Patten. Mr Patten said he was reluctant to snipe at the media but was still fuming yesterday over a BBC radio report on Wednesday saying that a well known plan to simplify existing EU treaties was in fact a sinister blueprint for a new constitution.

And last week he waded into the row over the EU rapid reaction force, which he said was another example of the distorted British domestic debate about Europe.

"To suggest that everything about Europe is rotten, all part of a continental conspiracy to diminish Britain's sovereignty - to erode the White Cliffs - that is no way of conducting the discussion."

Controversially, but only after Nice is out of the way, he stresses, he wants a wider debate about where the EU is heading, a subject launched with high drama earlier this year by the federalist German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer. "For a long time now the conventional argument has been that the European enterprise is an exciting journey and we don't know where we're going, but it will be terrific fun once we get there. I don't think that is politically acceptable any more. The concept of ever closer union is consistently referred to by the anti-Europeans - which is usually a fairer description than the Eurosceptics - as an escalator to that hoary old myth, the superstate.

"We should have an argument about how we can deal with that. I see no reason at all why we shouldn't write into the treaty the notion that ever closer political union does not necessarily mean ever dwindling nation states. "We have to make clear that the union does not involve subsuming nation states, but that it consists of them."

"We need to define once and for all what is done at the European level and what at the national level. We have banged on about subsidiarity for years. Now I think there is a real argument for making it a reality."

Showing a readiness to join the debate about the advantages of the single currency, Mr Patten accepts that Mr Blair would like to keep this most divisive of issues well under wraps. But he does not believe that is possible - or desirable.

"Politicians can't simply close down debates and the debate is going to take place whether or not they like it. The government would plainly like not to talk about the euro until after the election. Without getting into detailed arguments about timing, there are broad principles which should be enunciated and argued about.

"You can argue that the time isn't right for us to take the decision. But I don't think you can argue that if you stay out of the eurozone indefinitely it won't have an effect on us. "Of course there are economic tests but the big tests are going to be political. I think when it comes to the crunch that people are not going to vote on Gordon Brown's famous tests. If they get their chance in a referendum people are going to be voting about other matters." "The debate about the euro has barely been joined, and it has to be part of a bigger debate. I have perfectly civilised discussions with Francis Maude [the shadow foreign secretary] and Michael Ancram [the Tory party chairman] and I'm not going to take part in the British political debate on these things, for the time being.

The Conservative party will fight the next election on a very different set of assumptions about Europe than have prevailed for the past 40 years. Well, good luck!"

webTitle: Miss World  Beauty queen inspired by Mother Teresa

fields.headline: Miss World  Beauty queen inspired by Mother Teresa
fields.trailText: Miss India was last night crowned Miss World at the Millennium Dome, in London, and in the best traditions of the 50-year-old pageant Priyanka Chopra, 18, pledged to use her success to help others.
fields.body:
Miss India was last night crowned Miss World at the Millennium Dome, in London, and in the best traditions of the 50-year-old pageant Priyanka Chopra, 18, pledged to use her success to help others.

"I will use this as a platform to influence people's thoughts and actions," she said as she collected the coveted crown and a cheque for £70,000 from last year's winner, Yukta Mookhey, also from India.

Ms Chopra, the bookies' pre-pageant favourite, who covets a career as a clinical psychologist, went on to cite Mother Teresa as the greatest influence on her life so far.

"I admire her from the bottom of my heart for being so passionate and kind ... giving up her life to put smiles on people's faces," said Ms Chopra, India's fifth Miss World. In second place was Giorgia Palmas, 18, from Italy.

Despite entries from all the home countries none of the British contestants managed to make the semi-finals last night.

Last night's ceremony, hosted by the talk show host Jerry Springer, featured video footage of the swimwear discipline recorded two weeks ago in the Maldives, a more glamorous location, according to the organisers, than Greenwich.

Around 200 people from the National Union of Students' women's campaign brandished placards and yelled slogans to disrupt the competition.

Press Association

fields.headline: The language of Bistro diplomacy
fields.standfirst:
Blair and Chirac share a pint and a lamb chop

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Jacques Chirac could have been forgiven for wishing that he was tucked up in bed in the sumptuous surroundings of the Elyse Palace last night as he dined in a pub in the prime minister's constituency. His brief foray to the north of England was the French president's third stop of the day in a whirlwind tour of European capitals ahead of next week's EU summit in Nice.
fields.body:
Jacques Chirac could have been forgiven for wishing that he was tucked up in bed in the sumptuous surroundings of the Elyse Palace last night as he dined in a pub in the prime minister's constituency. His brief foray to the north of England was the French president's third stop of the day in a whirlwind tour of European capitals ahead of next week's EU summit in Nice.

As the holder of the six-month presidency of the EU, Mr Chirac performed the delicate task of hearing the gripes of fellow European leaders who are digging in ahead of the most important summit since the negotiations which led up to the Maastricht treaty. Mr Chirac kicked off his day in Lisbon, before moving on to meet the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, in Dublin. By early evening he was flying into Teesside airport for dinner with Tony Blair at the smart County Bistro pub restaurant in the prime minister's Sedgefield constituency. Mr Blair set out his stall when he told Mr Chirac that Britain has a series of "red lines" on Europe that he will never cross.

Speaking ahead of their dinner, Mr Blair said he would make it clear next week that Britain will retain its national veto in six key areas, including tax and social security. The national veto is one of the most sensitive areas of European reform. The prime minister said that Britain was prepared to abandon its veto in certain areas, in favour of qualified majority voting, to allow the enlargement of the union. Mr Chirac replied that France also had a red line which he would never cross, on French services and culture.

Over a meal of shoulder of Northumbrian lamb, the two leaders spoke in friendly terms of their "common purpose" towards EU reform. Mr Blair outlined his thinking when he said that Europe must not lose sight of the importance of expanding the EU to the east. "I would like to emphasise that the purpose of the summit is to prepare us for enlargement of the EU," he said. "It is that process of enlargement, taking in the countries who want to join the EU, that is so important in the future."

Mr Chirac said that Europe faced "complex negotiations" at the summit. But he said that Britain and France were agreed on the broad principles for Nice. "With our British friends we share the same ambitions and the same goals and the same vision and that is what we are going to debate this evening in a friendly and peaceful manner." The two leaders later agreed to try to work together with the Americans to get the climate change talks back on track after the ignominious collapse of the negotiations last Saturday. Contacts are likely to be made with Washington over the weekend.

The greatest competition over dinner in the village of Aycliffe came not over Europe but over the French language. The prime minister, who prides himself on the French that he learnt as a Paris barman in his student days, insisted on addressing his guest in French. Mr Chirac, a graduate of the elite ENA college in Paris who has impeccable English, was equally determined to demonstrate his command of the prime minister's tongue. Mr Chirac was on his way home last night after an "enjoyable evening". The president, who appreciates fine cuisine, just smiled when asked about the meal.

Downing Street had, however, gone to great lengths to impress its guest. The County has been transformed into a trendy middle-England eatery by a pupil of Raymond Blanc, offering the kind of food - confit of pork, crispy duck, seafood stew - which would drive some villagers to the local chippy. "We asked the chef for a menu with good British ingredients," said Downing Street. That included dressed crab (£4.95), Northumbrian lamb and trimmings (£13.45), and British cheeses (£4.95) with a pudding thrown in for a fiver.

webTitle: Tube bidder lauds private sector role

fields.headline: Tube bidder lauds private sector role
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: One of the central figures involved in bidding for London Underground's controversial public-private partnership contracts yesterday said the public does not appreciate the benefits brought to the railways by the private sector.
fields.body:
One of the central figures involved in bidding for London Underground's controversial public-private partnership contracts yesterday said the public does not appreciate the benefits brought to the railways by the private sector.

Mike Jeffries, chief executive of property and engineering support services group WS Atkins, which holds a 20% stake in the Metronet consortium bidding for the first two LU contracts, said he had felt "some sympathy" for Railtrack recently and dismissed London mayor Ken Livingstone's public finance proposals for the tube out of of hand.

"Of course the public sector can borrow money at better rates than the private sector," he said, referring to Mr Livingstone's plans to raise £4bn through bond issues. "But it is demonstrable that the public sector can't spend it as effectively or efficiently as the private sector and that more than compensates for the difference."

Mr Jeffries suggested that the media had skewed perception of the public sector's safety record in the wake of tragedies at Southall, Paddingdon and Hatfield. "Last week we heard reports that 5,000 people died because of cross-infection in the national health service largely because people failed to wash their hands before and after procedures," he said. "It did not get top billing on Radio 4, yet it is more than all the people killed on the roads last year."

Mr Jeffries had been referring to a report by the Commons public accounts committee that found 100 patients a week died from infections picked up in hospitals.

"There is a lot of political noise when it's safety and the private sector and less so when it is the public sector," he said.

Echoing controversial remarks made by former Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett, Mr Jeffries said that there could never be such a thing as a failsafe railway and that the balance between safety and performance was overly cautious.

"I must say there is now too much emphasis put on safety at the expense of the travelling public," he said. "There will always be a friction line between performance and safety but the balance is not right."

If Metronet wins either of the two bids, covering seven lines it could be working with the mayor's transport team as soon as April. Mr Jeffries would not comment on Metronet's relations with Mr Livingstone.

Mr Jeffries was speaking as Atkins posted pre-tax profits for the six months to the end of September of £12.3m, down from £14.4m the previous year. Underlying profits were up £1.7m to £18.5m on sales of £314.3, compared with £224.9 for the same period the previous year. Shares closed down 51.5p at 865p.

fields.headline: Record £2m fine on RBS
fields.trailText: Royal Scottish Assurance, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland group, was yesterday fined a record £2m for a catalogue of failings involving mainly endowment mortgages, and is set to pay out a further £50m in compensation to 30,000 people who have lost out.
fields.body:
Royal Scottish Assurance, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland group, was yesterday fined a record £2m for a catalogue of failings involving mainly endowment mortgages, and is set to pay out a further £50m in compensation to 30,000 people who have lost out.

The fine - the joint largest imposed by a British financial regulator - was for "serious deficiencies" in the company's endowment mortgages, "serious and widespread compliance failings" and a string of problems relating to its review of personal pension mis-selling cases.

One of the most serious incidents involved the Edinburgh-based company wrongly calculating the premiums endowment customers had to pay then failing to tell the truth as to why some policies might not generate enough cash to repay the home loan.

Stung by recent criticism that it is not doing enough to tackle the crisis, the financial services authority said the action it had taken "demonstrates our full commitment to secure a fair deal for mortgage endowment holders".

Millions of people with policies are worried they may not generate sufficient money to pay off the mortgage. But the FSA last month angered consumer groups by deciding against a full-scale review.

The Royal Scottish Assurance failings do not involve mis-selling. They primarily concern serious mistakes made in calculating the premiums for its "flexible mortgage plan" endowment policy. The premiums were set too low, which meant the policies would not repay the mortgage on the basis of the company's investment growth assumptions, said the FSA.

Around 30,000 policies sold between October 1990 and December 1994 were affected.

The firm "materially misrepresented the facts" when it wrote to 300 customers to suggest they increase their premiums. "This letter misleadingly explained the increase was necessary because of reductions in projected rates of return. In reality, the main reason was to address the shortfall that would arise as a result of the firm's undisclosed policy pricing errors," said the FSA.

It added that the firm hadaside £50m for compensation to those affected.

In a statement Royal Scottish Assurance apologised for the "wholly unacceptable" failings - but attempted to lay much of the blame on fellow Edinburgh insurer Scottish Equitable, which teamed up with Royal Bank of Scotland to launch Royal Scottish Assurance in 1990 and quit the joint venture three years ago.

Royal Scottish Assurance launched a court action against Scottish Equitable last year and said it is seeking to recover all the losses and costs incurred. Investment bank Morgan Grenfell was also fined £2m - by Imro in April 1997 - for mismanagement.

fields.headline: Mills to join Britt Allcroft
fields.standfirst: New driver for Thomas, new home for Harry
fields.trailText: The owners of Thomas the Tank Engine yesterday turned to transport expert Adam Mills in an attempt to put its flagging share price back on track.
fields.body:
The owners of Thomas the Tank Engine yesterday turned to transport expert Adam Mills in an attempt to put its flagging share price back on track.

Children's television specialists Britt Allcroft said Mr Mills, a former deputy chief executive of the National Express coach group, would replace Roger Llewellyn as non-executive chairman on January 1.

The announcement, made at Britt's annual meeting, also saw shareholders approve a change in the group's name to Gullane Entertainment.

Mr Mills' first task as controller will be to push Britt's share price back to the highs of earlier in the year.

The stock now trades at 515p, down 5p yesterday, around half of the 12-month high it reached while in takeover talks with rival HIT Entertainment. An all-share offer thought to be around 950p a share was eventually rejected by the Britt board.

Trading remained in line with expectations and growth in the crucial US business continued to be strong, the company said.

Mr LLewellyn is stepping down three months after the eponymous vice-chairman, Britt Allcroft, left the board in order to pursue other interests in Hollywood.

Ms Allcroft and Mr Llewellyn are understood to have been strongly opposed to HIT's takeover attempt, and some industry observers believe the management shake-up could eventually see a deal resurrected.

HIT, which reported strong trading yesterday, has said it has no interest in resurrecting a deal. Chief executive Peter Orton is concentrating on building the presence of HIT's two key characters, Bob the Builder and Angellina Ballerina, in the US.

"The prospects for the company have never been better, and [we] believe our existing brands and our ongoing development slate will enable the company to grow into one of the leading pre-school studios," he said.

fields.trailText: In our leader, Gore is right to fight, page 23, November 28, we said, "Absurdly, Mr Gore or Mr Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney (if he is well enough), could cast a deciding vote in the Senate if the electoral college returns are disputed and, perhaps, deliberately manipulated for partisan reasons."
fields.body:
In our leader, Gore is right to fight, page 23, November 28, we said, "Absurdly, Mr Gore or Mr Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney (if he is well enough), could cast a deciding vote in the Senate if the electoral college returns are disputed and, perhaps, deliberately manipulated for partisan reasons."

In fact, the Constitution says that, if there is no result from the electoral college, the House of Representatives chooses a president and the Senate chooses the vice president. If the Senate is split 50-50 (as it now is) the casting vote goes to the current vice president (Gore, not Cheney). So Gore could end up casting the vote that makes Joseph Lieberman vice president. The Senate has no say in choosing the president.

 On page 30, Finance, yesterday, we gave conflicting closing prices for Wolverhampton & Dudley. In a report at the top of the page we said the shares ended weaker at 430p. In the London prices table, below, we gave the real figure saying they closed up 2.5p at 435p.

 In our obituary of Sir Malcolm Bradbury, page 24, November 28, we said he took over the chairmanship of the British Council's contemporary writing seminar in 1976. That was wrong. We should have said in 1979.

webTitle: Analysis: Poor relations and European Union enlargement

fields.headline: Poor relations
fields.standfirst:
In the next two waves of European Union enlargement, the relative poverty of central and eastern Europe will bring drastic changes

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: In the next two waves of European Union enlargement, the relative poverty of central and eastern Europe will bring drastic changes
fields.body:
The European Union has long wanted to create a single "social space" and a declared aim of the social charter incorporated into the Maastricht treaty is that Europe's social dimension be given the same importance as economics and markets. The Lisbon summit agreed earlier this year on new strategic goals for the next decade and among them was greater social cohesion.

But how does this social dimension relate to enlargement? Ten of the countries wanting to join the European Union - preparing for enlargement is supposed to be the main point of next week's Nice summit - are in central and eastern Europe. The others are Malta and Cyprus, which are both small and relatively prosperous. Turkey's application is not progressing because of human rights abuses.

For the applicants from the east, the EU represents prosperity; membership is assumed to bestow it. Yet it may be the consequences of enlargement for poverty across Europe that are going to be most dramatic.

Officially, poverty is defined as getting by on half the average per capita consumption level. The population of the 10 eastern European candidates comes to just over 25% of the EU total but their combined GDP is only one-tenth the EU's. Consumption per head in the EU, expressed in euros, ranges from 9,277 in Greece to 15,325 in Luxembourg. In the candidates the range is from 3,305 in Bulgaria to 7,850 in Slovenia. Average consumption level is just over two-fifths that of the EU.

In terms of inequality, there is not a marked difference in inequality within the individual EU states and the candidates. The poorest tenth of the population has between 2.5% and 4.4% of all income in the EU whereas in the candidates the range is slightly wider from 2.2% to 5.1%.

At present about 17% of the EU's population is poor, ranging from 9.4% in Denmark to 33.3% in Portugal. Most of the poor are concentrated, not surprisingly, in the larger nations; over two-thirds of Europe's poor live in France, the UK, Spain and Germany.

The extent of poverty in the candidate countries is shown in the chart. It is far higher than for existing EU members: it ranges from 30% in Slovenia to 92% in Latvia. Among the candidates in the likely first round of enlargement the average is 69% and among the second-round countries 83%. Full enlargement would almost double the proportion of people living in poverty from 17% to 30% and that poverty would be heavily concentrated - 55% - in the 10 candidate countries. The total number of people living in poverty would more than double.

One of the presumed benefits of enlargement for the eastern European nations is that their growth would be accelerated. We simulated the consequences of all the candidates growing by 2% per annum faster than existing EU members for two decades. Such growth would cut poverty but one-third of the population in the first-round countries and half in the second-round countries would still be below the poverty standard after 20 years.

These disparities raise a question about how far countries would converge in an enlarged EU. From the perspective of "social space", the extent and distribution of poverty is critical. Will the candidates ever catch up? Getting to the EU average by 2015 would require sustained levels of growth in the front-running states of between 5% and 9% every year - rates which are far in excess of any achieved over a sustained period by any European nation ever. Even if growth were sustained at 2% a year faster in the candidates - a remarkable achievement in itself - poverty would still be twice as prevalent in the first-round applicants and three times as prevalent in the second-round counties as in the EU.

The extent and distribution of poverty affects other policies. The EU cohesion and structural funds have the goal of reducing inequality. If these funds were to be redistributed according to the extent of poverty (which is not at present the only criterion) then countries such as Greece, Portugal, Spain and the Irish Republic could lose most of what they now receive.

The largest chunk of EU spending is on agriculture. It claims a far larger share of output and employment in the candidates. If the common agricultural policy (CAP) were to be extended to an enlarged EU on the present basis the cost would be enormous. There would be huge losses for farmers in Germany, France and Britain. Yet if means were found of excluding new entrants from CAP this would reduce their chances of catching up and result in yet higher levels of poverty in the candidates. What is clear is that poverty in the candidates will have massive implications for existing EU programmes.

One of the effects of joining the EU ought to be free movement of workers. Thus far the extent of migration within the EU has been quite small. It, too, will be affected by the distribution and extent of poverty - there could be very substantial levels of migration east to west, with major political and social consequences. These too have, thus far, been given little attention.

Decisions about enlarging the EU will not and should not be decided only on the basis of concerns about poverty. But they are important: how the EU develops will affect the lives of hundreds of million of people and the most vulnerable of them are those who are victims of poverty.

David Piachaud is professor of social policy at the London School of Economics d.piachaud@lse.ac.uk
