webTitle: Ministers plan crackdown on yob culture

fields.headline: Ministers plan crackdown on yob culture
fields.standfirst:
Queen's speech Focus on public disorder as Parliament debates around 20 bills in a session likely to be shortened by calling of election

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is planning a drive against anti-social behaviour, including late night drunkenness, benefit fraud and hit and run drivers as the centrepiece of the Queen's speech next week.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is planning a drive against anti-social behaviour, including late night drunkenness, benefit fraud and hit and run drivers as the centrepiece of the Queen's speech next week.

The fight to end public disorder is intended to shore up Labour appeal with middle England in the run-up to the election, and will be matched by a commitment to pour extra cash into public services.

Ministers expect to table around 20 bills for a parliamentary session that may last less than 16 weeks and will be dominated by speculation about the election date.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, will be at the centre of the legislative action with measures designed to attack yob culture. It will be his second round of major public order legislation since the crime and disorder act in 1998. Critics claim the attack on youth crime contained in the 1998 act, such anti-social behaviour orders or parenting orders have yet to be fully tested.

The key measure will be fixed penalty fines for drunkenness recoverable in the magistrates courts. The plans first unveiled in August include tougher proof of identity and age rules. The policy suffered an inauspicious launch when Tony Blair said he was backing plans for the police to frogmarch drunks to cash machines for on the spot fines.

The police will also have powers to seize bottles, glasses and cans. In addition local councils would have strengthened powers to ban drinking in some public places. Tougher action would be taken against publicans that repeatedly flouted laws.

40% of violent crime is alcohol related, two thirds of violent crime in city centres occur at weekends with one third happening in the vicinity of licenced premises. The bill may also include measures to prosecute hit and run drivers, an issue on which there has been intense backbench pressure.

In addition, the Home Office will put forward new legislation regulating the private security industry and bouncers. Mr Straw will also table a separate bill on the confiscation of criminal assets, a measure trailed in a lengthy cabinet office report.

The Home Office will neutrally steer the fox hunting bill ensuring government time for the measure and promising to ensure MPs are given a free vote on three options ranging from self-supervision, regulation and an outright ban.

Mr Straw will also reintroduce the mode of trial bill restricting the right to trial by jury in confined cases. The bill has twice been rejected in the Lords. The Foreign Office and Department of Trade and Industry have lost their battle for arms export control legislation. Instead the Foreign Office will champion its human rights agenda by tabling a bill ratifying the treaty setting up an international criminal court. The FO may also need to pilot a bill ratifying the NIce Treaty on European Union reform.

The cabinet office has won time for a bill speeding up deregulation, a move that might calm tensions between government and the CBI.

Alistair Darling, the social security security, will pilot measures to combat fraud. Mr Darling will legislate to withdraw benefits - but not retirement benefits - from anyone twice found guilty of benefit fraud. They would be given only limited hardship payments for a fixed period.

He termed the policy yesterday as "two strikes and you are out" adding: "If you are convicted of benefit fraud once that might be described as unfortunate, but if you are convicted twice that suggests the person needs to be reminded their rights have to be matched by obligations to society."

The bill will also gives the DSS and Inland Revenue wide powers to cross check information with other organisations including banks, utility firms and insurance compopanies. They could only seek the information if there was a prima facie case of fraud to investigate. A new offence will make it possible for magistrates to try cases of evasion of even relatively small amounts of income tax.

The investigators should be given powers to make routine "reverse searches" of the telephone directory. This would help them to follow up advertisements for goods and services which give a contact number but no personal details.

The Department of Education is offering only one major bill, the special educational needs bill designed to open up schools and ensure children, including the disabled get equal access to schools.

The giant Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions has hogged the legislative timetable for the past two years and will only be presenting a modest measure on leasehold reform.

webTitle: Emergency team to hasten rail recovery

fields.headline: Emergency team to hasten rail recovery
fields.standfirst:
Speed restrictions to be eased in wake of Railtrack 'panic'

More about transport
fields.trailText: The government last night set up an emergency team to supervise the rapid restoration of rail services under ministerial guidance.
fields.body:
The government last night set up an emergency team to supervise the rapid restoration of rail services under ministerial guidance.

The rail recovery action group, which will meet for the first time today, will include figures from Railtrack, the shadow strategic rail authority, the train operating companies and passengers.

It will be chaired by the transport minister, Lord Macdonald. The meeting will coincide with Railtrack's expected announcement of a gradual easing of speed restrictions that have crippled the rail network since the fatal accident at Hatfield in October.

The implication is that, with no replica of the Hatfield defective rail yet found, ministers suspect that Railtrack panicked and failed to make a realistic and balanced assessment of the risk to travellers.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday had his first full meeting with Steve Marshall, the new chief executive of Railtrack, to dispel the "media myths" that he had tried to block his appointment.

An aide said: "We never made any comment about his appointment. The best thing that can happen is we all pull together to get the railways back to normal as quickly as possible."

Downing Street officials deny that they have interfered excessively in the management of the system since the spate of accidents, but they imply that they have been tougher in private than they felt they should be in public.

While conceding the extra problems had been caused by bad weather and engineering difficulties, Tony Blair and Mr Prescott want a reliable emergency service operating in time for the pre-Christmas rush. No firm dates are being given.

Railtrack yesterday warned passengers not to expect an immediate radical change in the 550 speed restrictions which are paralysing the net work. A number of the 20mph limits will be doubled and 40mph restrictions lifted to 60mph.

The health and safety executive said later it had agreed with Railtrack on lifting some restrictions, but the company had agreed to report any further incidents of gauge corner cracking - the main cause of the Hatfield crash - immediately. It could not say how many restrictions would be lifted.

A skeleton rail service of four direct trains during the rush hour is starting today between Northampton and London, following the freight derailment this week. The train company, Silverlink, said it hoped to improve the service next week.

Airlines yesterday reported big increases in domestic travellers in recent weeks. Many intercity trains are half empty because travellers fear they will not reach their destinations in time.

Commuters will soon be boarding carriages which were involved in the Paddington and Southall rail crashes. Survivors from both accidents are horrified at the decision by First Great Western. Keith Stiles, from west Reading, who received severe burns in the Paddington crash, said: "The operating company should withdraw them from service or use them for safety exercises. It would be a step forward in giving the company credibility."

Mike Caroll, managing director of First Great Western, said the carriages had suffered very minor damage, but had been thoroughly tested and passed fit. "They are not back in use at this point but we need to use our stock," he said.

Railtrack is cracking down on unqualified workers by improved policing of staff coming on site. The magazine Construction News reported yesterday that smartcards were to be introduced for clocking on and to certify identity.

Contractors say Railtrack has been failing to meet its own rules to protect the industry from unqualified workers.

webTitle: Children on poor estates use crime to gain 'street cred'

fields.headline: Children on poor estates use crime to gain 'street cred'
fields.standfirst:
Related special report

Policing crime
fields.trailText: A new breed of young criminals, many as young as 10, are committing street robberies because they believe it will give them credibility and status in neighbourhoods they regard as "lawless", Scotland Yard said yesterday.
fields.body:
A new breed of young criminals, many as young as 10, are committing street robberies because they believe it will give them credibility and status in neighbourhoods they regard as "lawless", Scotland Yard said yesterday.

Sir John Stevens, commissioner of the Metropolitan police, said a recent rise in robberies around London reflected "a new phenomenon" - playground bullies taking their intimidation and menace outside school.

Many of the offenders targeted pupils they knew and put pressure on the victims not to come forward for fear of reprisals.

Although the Met recognises little research has been done in this field, it believes there is enough anecdotal evidence from officers on the beat, as well as worrying statistics from selected boroughs, to conclude a trend is emerging.

Sir John's remarks yesterday had particular resonance because the killers of Damilola Taylor, the 10-year-old who bled to death in a south London council estate stairwell on Monday, are thought to be from his age group.

Describing Damilola's death as "shocking and tragic", the commissioner said 40 officers were now working on the case full time and every back-up support was being offered.

Referring to recent figures from the west London borough of Hounslow, Sir John said 70% of street robberies were committed by youths un der the age of 17. He said 72% of the victims were also under 17, and 40% of the offenders had never been in trouble with the police before, and were surprised they had been arrested.

Commander Tim Godwin said some of the teenagers spoke of earning £300 a week from street crime. They stole pocket money, mobile phones, credit cards and Pokemon cards, he said. In one case a boy told officers how he stole money to give to his parents.

But cash was not the sole or most important motive of those involved. Street crimes were often committed as a rite of passage by youths who were under pressure from their peers, Mr Godwin said.

Sir John said: "What we are witnessing is a new breed of criminal. What started off in the playground is now moving on into the streets."

It was, he said, a new phenomenon.

Although the Met recognises little research has been done in this field, it believes there is enough anecdotal evidence from officers on the beat, as well as worrying statistics from selected boroughs, to conclude a trend is emerging. Sir John's remarks yesterday had particular resonance because the killers of Damilola Taylor, the 10-year-old who bled to death in a south London council estate stairwell on Monday, are thought to be from his age group. Describing Damilola's death as "shocking and tragic", the commissioner said 40 officers were now working on the case full time and every back-up support was being offered. Referring to recent figures from the west London borough of Hounslow, Sir John said 70% of street robberies were committed by youths un der the age of 17. He said 72% of the victims were also under 17, and 40% of the offenders had never been in trouble with the police before, and were surprised they had been arrested. Commander Tim Godwin said some of the teenagers spoke of earning £300 a week from street crime. They stole pocket money, mobile phones, credit cards and Pokemon cards, he said. In one case a boy told officers how he stole money to give to his parents. But cash was not the sole or most important motive of those involved. Street crimes were often committed as a rite of passage by youths who were under pressure from their peers, Mr Godwin said. Sir John said: "What we are witnessing is a new breed of criminal. What started off in the playground is now moving on into the streets." It was, he said, a new phenomenon.

webTitle: Comment:  Damilola's attackers were not born thugs

fields.headline: Pity the killers
fields.standfirst:
Damilola's attackers were not born thugs. Children with mental health problems need help

Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Damilola's attackers were not born thugs. Children with mental health problems need help
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor's dreadful, pointless death is the stuff of every parent's nightmare. A child killed with a knife and, it is assumed, by a child or young person, one of the boy's peers in what may well have been a final act of bullying that went too far.

In the face of Gloria Taylor's distress at having her beautiful child so mercilessly taken, at the knowledge that she had complained to his school that he was being bullied, there is public outrage, a desire to show we care, that we share her fury at whoever committed this bad, bad act.

The trouble is that this increasingly familiar way of making ourselves feel better, manifest in the oceans of media stories about hooligans and thugs, actually distances us from understanding that young people who commit such dreadful acts are not born thugs and hooligans. They become that way because their mental health needs are bypassed until they become a dangerous, dreadful, driving force.

The mental health problems of children in Britain are something we don't dwell on. Kids with hyperactivity, with emotional chaos bubbling inside, with a despair so deep they will do anything to keep it at bay, kids who act out their disturbance in ways that are at best unappealing at worst lethal don't capture the imagination.

We like mental health problems to come in the form of Shakespeare's fools or simple-minded lunatics amusing us with their harmless antics. This is blind folly for those kids whose problems may, to us, seem a private menace for their families or a failure of parenting, but who very often have mental health problems and need help early if they are not to turn mad and bad. When I sat on the Mental Health Foundation's steering committee into children's mental health, preparing the report Bright Futures, it was calculated that at any one time 20% of children and adolescents are experiencing psychological problems. It is very likely Damilola's killers are among them, as was the psychotic cellmate who killed Zahid Mubarek in Feltham.

When these children become thugs, commit dreadful acts and are vilified, we lock them up. We concluded in Bright Futures that "the demonisation enables troubled and troublesome children to be portrayed as the preserve of the mental health professionals or the criminal justice system not the concern of society as a whole".

This point was emphasised this week with the publication of a Prison Reform Trust report showing that out of a sample of 592 young people aged 16-20 in prison, 95% were assessed as having one or more mental disorders. Some had as many as five. Ten per cent had functional psychosis and up to 67% suffered from anxiety and depression. One-third of young women and 20% of young men had attempted suicide before being sent to prison.

These mental health problems are not a product of prison, although prison is the last place equipped to treat the psychological problems of our fragile and vulnerable young, as the statistics for suicide and self-harm bear witness.

We might well have felt sympathy for them if we'd heard their stories, so often ones of deprivation and poverty, before they committed their mad, bad acts, before they were driven to an urgent quest to escape the bad feelings inside themselves by acting them out on someone else.

The bullying that Damilola endured is one of the commonest and most urgent signs we should heed. In the past few years it has been identified as a serious problem - not just swaggering playground machismo but a merciless quest for power and control by those who all too often feel powerless. According to Young Voice, the charity set up to report the views and experiences of our young, 37% of teenage boys say they have been subjected to physical violence from bullies. Young Voice makes the important point that "bullying is a vital indicator of the health of the community".

Our prosperous capitalist society enables many of us to protect and nurture our children. But there is remarkably little interest in encouraging the government, which to its credit is doing more than its predecessors, to prioritise children's mental health problems in schools with special needs help and educational psychologists, or in funding some of the imaginative and constructive organisations offering practical help, psychological support, and early intervention for those children and young people who need it.

Our powerful media, with all the opportunities it has to help us take some moral responsibility for growing violence and criminality, revels in headlines that separate thugs from nice middle England. This is far more comfortable than accepting responsibility for children who are spiralling out of control, who we wouldn't much want sharing our kids' Playstations and teatime treats.

We should recognise our responsibility, albeit distanced, for Damilola's death. If we want to protect children like him, we need a comprehensive and dynamic range of initiatives to spot, intervene and help when children show signs of mental distress. Those of us fortunate enough to have the time and energy to battle for these things must do so.

webTitle: Portillo fails to sway doubters about his political future

fields.headline: Unsure Portillo fails to sway doubters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo last night struggled to shrug off speculation about his political future in response to growing concern among Conservative MPs that he may leave the front bench if he fails to take Gordon Brown's job at the next election.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo last night struggled to shrug off speculation about his political future in response to growing concern among Conservative MPs that he may leave the front bench if he fails to take Gordon Brown's job at the next election.

In a series of radio and TV interviews, after private talks with Willliam Hague, the shadow chancellor insisted that he remains "passionate about politics" and that his future lies in politics - albeit in a subordinate role.

"I may not think I want to be leader of the Conservative party, but I certainly want to be chancellor of the exchequer," he said at one point. "I think that is absolutely the most likely thing, that I never will be (leader) ..." he said later.

Pressed on his lack of ambition for the top job in a week that Labour increased its opinion poll to 15% Mr Portillo smiled, but cryptically added: "It just does not suit me personally." The cumulative effect was that many MPs and observers found his tentative tone unpersuasive as Parliament rose for a brief recess before next week's Queen's speech. Far from shutting down the rumour mill it left the impression that the former tough guy of the Tory right has either lost his nerve or metamorphosed into an unlikely Hamlet who is reportedly bored and uncertain about his long-term commitment to what may be years of opposition.

"My ambition is to be chancellor of the exchequer, and between now and the election to carry the fight against the Labour party, to make sure that people realise that this (Mr Brown) is the chancellor of the exchequer who gave 75p to the pensioners, gave us the most expensive petrol in Europe, and intends to abolish the pound," Mr Portillo said in his round of interviews with the BBC, ITN and Sky.

Asked whether there might still be anything embarrassing about his private life yet to emerge in the Fleet Street tabloids, Mr Portillo replied: "Heavens no." Not all his colleagues are so sure.

fields.headline: Return of the tired men
fields.standfirst:
An old guard of businessmen will follow Bush into power

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A lot of tired men are about to creep back into power in America. "President" Bush is a local Texas boy; for the big picture he relies on his father's people, in economics as much as in foreign policy.
fields.body:
A lot of tired men are about to creep back into power in America. "President" Bush is a local Texas boy; for the big picture he relies on his father's people, in economics as much as in foreign policy. I met quite a few of these yesterday's men (almost all males) when they were out of office in the 1990s, passing the years of idleness at policy conferences on the virtues of private enterprise. They are an unimpressive lot.

They didn't get the new e-economy, neither how it worked nor what its dangers were. When the rich in America were raking money in and the markets booming, Dad's people continued to harp on the need for tax cuts to stimulate investment. When the treasury secretary, Robert Rubin, began to pay down the national debt (with the help of Dad's one distinguished appointee to office, Alan Greenspan), they cried foul; Democrats are supposed to be reckless spenders.

That businessmen, or business-minded people, are efficient and hard-headed in government is an outdated illusion. Compare Gordon Brown to the Conservative chancellors who came before him. He is infinitely more prudent and cunning - and tight-fisted, doling out goodies on social services only after the money had piled up in the Treasury kitty. You might not like the delay (I don't), but you understand it; a finance minister is meant to keep order rather than, like Norman Lamont, cry "I am in pain!" and reel from every economic blow.

Brown's American counterpart, Robert Rubin, was every bit as prudent and tight-fisted - and as clever. Unlike his Republican predecessors, who frequently lost control of the business cycle while steadily piling up a huge national debt, Rubin had no single economic policy; he had lots of policies, for whatever the moment required. There were several moments in the last administration when the economy faced a downturn; Rubin helped prevent them by adroit fiscal manoeuvring.

Why do conservative businessmen make bad politicians? Why, when they gain power, do they suddenly seem to lose their grasp of reality, clinging to simple nostrums like "Cut taxes!", bewildered by how to spend public money?

I kept going to policy seminars with Republican-era businessmen because they were something of an enigma. Get them talking about how to sell soap or insurance and suddenly the years fell away, they were full of energy and interesting ideas; I've the same sense of energy listening to aged doyens of the CBI in Britain. But speak the words "public" or "social" and the metal shutters of the mind come clattering down, shutters on which the graffiti "free market" and "lower taxes" have been sprayed.

The shuttered mind simply refuses to accept the positive side of the public economy. It cannot, in particular, accept the welfare state as a more efficient way to do the public's business, in medicine, transport, and housing, than ways based on selling soap. In the Reagan-Bush years, whenever these businessmen-politicians were confronted by unpalatable facts, they engaged in denial - or, in one egregious instance, tried to pretty-up unemployment figures by changing how the Department of Labour did its sums.

Blinded by their own belief in the superiority of business, guided by simplistic cliches, public servants drawn from the private realm tend to be bad servants of the public. Yet with a wave of the fairy's electoral wand in Florida, Dad's tired men will become the global economy's new masters. Their reappearance is particularly chilling because global capitalism looks set for another hard landing.

The big boom of the 1990s was largely fuelled by the technological revolution and a worldwide demand for consumer goods. Technology is now in a post-revolutionary phase and consumer demand is no longer pent up. In the States, both inflation and labour costs are rising. The bond markets have become credit averse and the stock markets are down, particularly the new-economy Nasdaq market. It is not a pretty picture, but it needn't spell disaster. The landing needs to be managed. For that, however, you need good managers. And good managers, in office, need to believe in government.

British friends assure me that Thatcherism is dead - though at 10 Downing Street there seem surviving signs of it, if not at No 11. But the fact that the British and American economies have become so interlocked is the real issue. During the big boom, British investment poured into America, as it did from the Netherlands and Germany; conversely, American management flowed into Europe.

The return of these blind, tired men to Washington is therefore no foreign spectacle. As diplomats, they aim to "coddle" Europe less; but in their own country, as businessmen in government, their incompetence will soon enough become our problem.

Richard Sennett is professor of sociology at the LSE

R.Sennett@lse.ac.uk

webTitle: Papers reveal outrage at World Cup 'fix'

fields.headline: Papers reveal outrage at World Cup 'fix'
fields.trailText: England's 1966 World Cup triumph nearly proved a diplomatic disaster as the belief that the tournament was an "Anglo-German fix" provoked anti-British demonstrations across Latin America, according to confidential Foreign Office files released yesterday.
fields.body:
England's 1966 World Cup triumph nearly proved a diplomatic disaster as the belief that the tournament was an "Anglo-German fix" provoked anti-British demonstrations across Latin America, according to confidential Foreign Office files released yesterday.

The FO became alarmed that Britain's "fair play" image abroad could be seriously damaged after the Wembley victory led to howls of outrage from defeated countries around the world.

Nowhere were the protests louder than in Latin America where it was widely believed that England had only won because referees had been "fixed" by Sir Stanley Rous, the English president of Fifa, the world football body.

The president of the Brazilian football federation, Joao Havelange, said match officials had been "hand picked political referees" who had received "financial advantage".

In England's bad tempered quarter final, the Argentinian captain was sent off by a German referee. In the same round, Uruguay were beaten by West Germany after two of their players were sent off by an English referee. The results sparked anger across Latin America and press claims of an Anglo-German conspiracy.

The FO files released at the public record office show that an anonymous caller had threatened to blow up the British embassy in Mexico City. In Montevideo, the Uruguayan capital, an angry mob surrounded the ambassador's residence then pulled the doorbell out of its socket and abused the servants.

John Shakespeare, the first secretary at the British embassy in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, dismissed Mr Havelange's allegations, saying he was simply looking for a scapegoat for the Brazilian team's disappointing performance. "I will not weary you with a complete account of his ravings," he told London. "You may consider that such behaviour is unworthy of a leading personality - and you would be right - but this is Latin America."

But AB Blackman, an information officer at the Montevideo embassy, was more anxious. He cabled London voicing concern about damage to Britain's reputation: "It would be comforting to say that the only moral of this is, never let a South American team lose a football game. But the net result has been to raise doubts in many normally friendly people as to whether traditional British fair play really exists."

In Italy at least one newspaper reported that the South American teams had been eliminated because "the Germans were likely to bring more sterling to Wembley".

The Foreign Office cabled all the British embassies in Latin America, Italy, Spain and Portugal, urging them to remain calm: "We have now come to the conclusion that the wisest course is to just to sit tight and let the storm blow itself out.

"The origins of the campaign are almost entirely emotional and we feel that any attempt on our part to weigh in on the argument will tend to prolong it and make matters worse."

webTitle: MPs want Blair meeting after Chinook row

fields.headline: MPs want Blair meeting after Chinook row
fields.trailText: A cross-party group of MPs and peers last night was seeking an urgent meeting with Tony Blair in the wake of a damning Commons report on the way the Ministry of Defence handled the inquiry into the Chinook helicopter crash which claimed 29 lives.
fields.body:
A cross-party group of MPs and peers last night was seeking an urgent meeting with Tony Blair in the wake of a damning Commons report on the way the Ministry of Defence handled the inquiry into the Chinook helicopter crash which claimed 29 lives.

The Commons public accounts committee yesterday described the ruling by two air marshals who blamed the pilots for the crash as "unsustainable". David Davis, the committee's Conservative chairman, called it a "a major miscarriage of natural justice".

The RAF Chinook crashed on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994 with the loss of all four crew and 25 intelligence officers from Northern Ireland on board.

The committee pointed to a series of problems with the Chinook's computer system, accused the MoD of "unwarrantable arrogance", and described its aircraft testing procedures as "incredible".

Furious at the manner in which Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, immediately dismissed the report the Mull of Kintrye Group said it was now up to the prime minister to set the verdict aside. The issue was now a "matter of public interest and honour", it said.

Mr Hoon described the report as "superficial", said it contained no new evidence, and compared it with an earlier report by the Commons defence committee. Yet the defence committee, which heard evidence only from MoD officials, made clear its 1998 report was not about the causes of the crash.

The public accounts committee, in its more thorough report, had access to internal MoD documents and independent experts.

"To dismiss its report as 'superficial' is a prime example of the 'unwarrantable arrogance' of which the MoD stands accused," Lord Chalfont, chairman of the group and a former Labour defence minister said last night.

"It is not a question of finding new evidence now," said Sir Malcolm Rifkind, defence secretary at the time of the crash. "It is that the evidence which has become available over the last three or four years itself demonstrates that it is unfair and unsound to rely on this previous verdict".

Susan Phoenix, whose husband Ian, a Royal Ulster Constabulary counter-terrorism expert, died in the crash said the MoD was simply betraying arrogance in refusing to clear the reputations of the pilots.

Downing Street last night referred to Mr Hooon's comments but added that Mr Blair would consider a request for a meeting with the Mull group.
fields.bodyText: A cross-party group of MPs and peers last night was seeking an urgent meeting with Tony Blair in the wake of a damning Commons report on the way the Ministry of Defence handled the inquiry into the Chinook helicopter crash which claimed 29 lives. The Commons public accounts committee yesterday described the ruling by two air marshals who blamed the pilots for the crash as "unsustainable". David Davis, the committee's Conservative chairman, called it a "a major miscarriage of natural justice". The RAF Chinook crashed on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994 with the loss of all four crew and 25 intelligence officers from Northern Ireland on board. The committee pointed to a series of problems with the Chinook's computer system, accused the MoD of "unwarrantable arrogance", and described its aircraft testing procedures as "incredible". Furious at the manner in which Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, immediately dismissed the report the Mull of Kintrye Group said it was now up to the prime minister to set the verdict aside. The issue was now a "matter of public interest and honour", it said. Mr Hoon described the report as "superficial", said it contained no new evidence, and compared it with an earlier report by the Commons defence committee. Yet the defence committee, which heard evidence only from MoD officials, made clear its 1998 report was not about the causes of the crash. The public accounts committee, in its more thorough report, had access to internal MoD documents and independent experts. "To dismiss its report as 'superficial' is a prime example of the 'unwarrantable arrogance' of which the MoD stands accused," Lord Chalfont, chairman of the group and a former Labour defence minister said last night. "It is not a question of finding new evidence now," said Sir Malcolm Rifkind, defence secretary at the time of the crash. "It is that the evidence which has become available over the last three or four years itself demonstrates that it is unfair and unsound to rely on this previous verdict". Susan Phoenix, whose husband Ian, a Royal Ulster Constabulary counter-terrorism expert, died in the crash said the MoD was simply betraying arrogance in refusing to clear the reputations of the pilots. Downing Street last night referred to Mr Hooon's comments but added that Mr Blair would consider a request for a meeting with the Mull group.

webTitle: Now you can download your cash

fields.headline: Now you can download your cash
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A service allowing people to email money around the world is being introduced next month by a British company.
fields.body:
A service allowing people to email money around the world is being introduced next month by a British company.

Earthport, a provider of internet payment systems, has chosen Hong Kong to begin the service, which will be targeted particularly at the region's large contingent of immigrant workers who wish to send money to family and friends at home.

It will allow people to send "e-wallets" of money which the recipient can use to shop online, put into their bank account or send on to someone else. The company will charge the sender a fee of 20p.

Earthport, which is based in London, has linked up with a yet to be named partner in Hong Kong on the venture, which goes live on January 15. The company plans to extend the service to other locations, including Britain.

The Ofex-traded Earthport is also piloting a scheme allowing people to buy items from vending machines via a mobile phone. The technology is being tested in Finland and involves individuals sending a text message stating they would like to buy, in the test instance, a can of soft drink.

Earthport debits the person's e-wallet with the cost and notifies the company that the drink has been paid for, which then tells the machine to release the item, said Graham Newall, Earthport chief executive. The technology could be adapted for parking meters and petrol pumps.

webTitle: QXL raises £30m but staff must go

fields.headline: QXL raises £30m but staff must go
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: QXL.com, the online auction firm, yesterday claimed it had secured its financial future by completing a £30m fundraising round - but admitted it could still cut nearly a quarter of its 400 staff within six months.
fields.body:
QXL.com, the online auction firm, yesterday claimed it had secured its financial future by completing a £30m fundraising round - but admitted it could still cut nearly a quarter of its 400 staff within six months.

The statement yesterday failed to impress a stock market that has savaged the QXL share price since the summer - despite chief executive Jim Rose's comment that his company is continuing to talk to strategic partners about possible equity investments.

The shares fell a further 30% to an all-time low of 17p as technology shares across the board came under renewed pressure. Earlier in the year QXL shares traded as high as 800p, valuing the company at more than £2bn; now it is worth about £75m.

"There will be head count reductions from within the companies we have acquired," Mr Rose said. "There is duplication in some areas, and as we migrate their business models towards the QXL model there will likely be head count reductions in areas such as merchandising, technology and inventory. It's natural after acquisitions. You'll probably see the head count come down to the low to the mid-300s over the next two quarters."

Mr Rose said the redundancies were part of an effort to reduce costs and move towards profitability earlier than planned. Financing arranged by investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston meant QXL now had £80m cash, which should be enough to see it through to profit in 2003.

Analysts said dealers had been unnerved by the widening second quarter losses that QXL had announced at the same time of the fundraising.

Mr Rose was disappointed by the market's response, saying that financing issues had been addressed and expenses had been reduced by a third since the previous quarter.

"It's frustrating because we have exceeded all our business projections and are still in a high growth market," he said.

In the three months to September 30, turnover climbed to £5.9m from £1.8m the previous quarter. Losses spiralled from £15.5m to £67.7m, largely owing to an accounting charge relating to the acquisition of German rival Ricardo.de.

"It's a decent quarter but not outstanding," said Peter Misek, e-commerce analyst at Chase H&Q. "They haven't blown away anyone's expectations."

An increasing number of analysts doubt whether QXL can survive as an independent. They believe US-based Ebay is winning the race to dominate the European online auction market and fear that QXL's management team will find its time consumed by integrating a series of acquisitions rather than building the business.

A new chief operating officer has been recruited to smooth the process. Mr Rose is about to embark on a charm offensive in the City aimed at improving QXL sentiment among investors and analysts.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Zero Gravity | Foreign Bodies
fields.body:
In an enterprise which sounds ripe for a Turner Prize, Emma Jane Kirby experiences the joys of Zero Gravity (11.0am, Radio 4) at Star City in Moscow. An organisation called Arts Catalyst took a group of dancers and acrobats on specially arranged parabolic flights, where the plane climbs and descends steeply to give passengers 30-second bouts of weightlessness. Apparently it allows them to achieve higher than normal levels of emotional release.

On World Aids Day Foreign Bodies (2.15pm, Radio 4) offers three dramatised insights into the fate of sufferers in different parts of the world. Kulsoom, wife of a Pakistani taxi driver, is more terrified of her family's reaction than of her illness when she is diagnosed as HIV positive. In Kenya, young Amadi watches helplessly as his mother declines into poverty and death, leaving her children without support. In Holland, Erik can only survive on a daily cocktail of dozens of pills. Salutary, if gloomy listening.

webTitle: Journey interrupts optimistic train of thought

fields.headline: Journey interrupts optimistic train of thought
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences on the troubled railways
fields.trailText: Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences on the troubled railways
fields.body:
It is a strange thing that however tedious the previous day's travel has been, each new journey brings a new optimism; a feeling that today it will be OK. The previous evening had been good; good, that is, if you disregard those travelling to Bradford Forster Square who were left in the furthest reaches of the cattle pen queuing system waiting for a train which had long since been cancelled. Good, except for those travelling to Harrogate; whose elusive driver seemed less keen to travel than they were. Good for someone, surely?

The optimism of a new day was brought down on boarding the 06:53. The first thing you notice on using most trains is that they appear to have two heater settings - one non-existent and one of nuclear reactor-like ferocity. Today they selected the higher setting.

It was however reassuring to note that it was still cooler than a few mornings ago when I witnessed the conductor, obscured by billowing smoke, tackling what appeared to be a small fire under the guard's van.

On inquiry I discovered this is a common side-effect of driving a train for 20 miles with the handbrake on.

Another obstacle on the old slam door trains that operate on the Wharfedale line, is usually finding a seat that is not soaking wet from rain that regularly pours in through ill-fitting doors and windows and is not soiled by the remains of someone's half-eaten hamburger from the night before.

Once, moved to complain in writing to Northern Spirit about the daily state of these trains, I received a reply, which although apparently unconcerned by my likening their vehicle to a mobile skip, did offer apologies for their tardy response which they explained was due to "an unprecedented backlog of correspondence".

Strange, that.

Email your rail horror stories to the Guardian: home@theguardian.com

fields.headline: At this price?  Logica
fields.trailText: Investors in Logica, the computer services company, have a problem. Although it is a sound technology company - founded in 1969 and quoted since 1983 - at last night's closing price of £14.01 the shares look overvalued. Yesterday's trading update did little to solve the dilemma.
fields.body:
Investors in Logica, the computer services company, have a problem. Although it is a sound technology company - founded in 1969 and quoted since 1983 - at last night's closing price of £14.01 the shares look overvalued. Yesterday's trading update did little to solve the dilemma.

Based on the facts presented, it looks as if the company is headed for an eighth consecutive year of record profits and sales.

Despite a weak performance from its European operations, which were affected by the strength of the euro, Logica expects at the half-year stage to report good organic growth and a further improvement in margins.

Once again the secret of Logica's success is mobile telecoms software: it is a world leader in the systems behind short text messages. Here growth remains strong and margins are rising.

The other main driver, its operations in the UK, are also in good health. This should be reassuring for investors concerned that the company is too reliant on mobile telephony.

Unlike so many of its peers, Logica has cleared up its policy on revenue recognition. Sales will be recognised only on delivery of a product to the client, where there is no service element. This again is prudent in climate where investors are concentrating on quality of earnings.

But the question remains: is there value in Logica at its current price?

After the problems at Sema, Logica is the quality play in the European IT services sector. As house broker UBS Warburg notes, Logica offers the most secure earnings projections and best momentum of any of the major companies.

However, these are torrid times for tech stocks and Logica is going to have to do a lot to justify a rating of 85 times historic earnings. Most analysts do not expect to upgrade their forecasts following this statement. Hold on if you think the Nasdaq will recover; if not cash in. Buyers should be wary for now.

webTitle: City workers cut the ties - for now

fields.headline: City workers cut the ties - for now
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Many retailers see the dress down trend as more than a fad. Others remain sceptical
fields.trailText: It began as "dress down Fridays" and swiftly expanded into complete weeks of smart casual dressing in corporate Britain. The workplace fashion revolution has left some big names in the clothing industry looking rumpled while others have moved smartly with the times.
fields.body:
It began as "dress down Fridays" and swiftly expanded into complete weeks of smart casual dressing in corporate Britain. The workplace fashion revolution has left some big names in the clothing industry looking rumpled while others have moved smartly with the times.

Austin Reed and Moss Bros, which built their reputations on formal dressing, have moved in to this market. The trendy Ted Baker chain has followed their lead. New store groups are being set up to help the sartorially challenged put together aworking wardrobe which offers more than chinos and check shirts.

The Gap store at Canary Wharf is even offering special deals to the many firms in the neighbourhood, giving them plastic discount cards for staff to present when they come along to be outfitted in the new mode.

Meagre share

Other retail chains are suffering. In April, Arcadia announced it was closing its Principles for Men stores, partly because the garb it sold was deemed too formal for market conditions.

Sally Bain, a senior retail analyst at Verdict, says that in Britain 33% of men's outerwear sales in 1995 were for formal clothing, and 64 % casual. Only 3% of sales were classed as smart casual clothes.

By last year a meagre 28% of sales were formal wear and 14% casual. But 58% of market was in the "smart casual" sector. "The rise of smart casual has taken from both formal and casual sales, and now accounts for £1bn of sales in the UK," Ms Bain says.

Undoubtedly, much of this swing has been down to the demise of denim, but the style overhaul has also been driven by more relaxed office environments.

A few years ago Sir Richard Branson made a mark with his woolly jumper approach to power dressing. Then along came the dot.com entrepreneurs who would not be seen dead in a suit. Even the chief executive of Marks & Spencer ditched his tie in the months before he was ousted from his job.

Dedicated outlet

"This is part of a big trend. There has been a blurring between life at work and at home. It started with taking work home, emailing and shopping over the internet," says Martin Hayward, director of consumer consultancy at the Henley Centre.

Austin Reed, home on the mall to many an aspiring executive, introduced the Reed Label of formal sportswear. Michael Tiffin of Austin Reed says that offset the decline in the company's suit sales.

Reed Label has been so successful that the company plans to open its first dedicated outlet for the range next year.

Marks & Spencer, which accounts for one in four men's suits sold in Britain, has heeded the change. Last month it introduced the Autograph range of menswear designed by Timothy Everest.

Carol Richardson of M&S - which has a dress down policy for its own staff - insists the group has not experienced a significant decline in suit sales but reckons men are now wearing them in a less formal fashion. "Men are dressing them down,wearing suits with knitwear rather than shirts and ties."

Ray Kelvin, founder of the Ted Baker fashion group, is a walking advertisement for the slightly trendy smart casual clothes he now sells in his specialist Ted's The Business outlets. His newest outlet is in Canary Wharf and his target market, too, is the highly paid bankers and analysts of London's docklands. "We're trying to provide a service for City workers who need help with dressing down."

Pablo Slough, director of the internet company Dooyoo.com, believes the dress down culture represents a better, more flexible attitude to working life and that more traditional companies have been forced to "adapt for what a whole generation wanted".

But the cool new office look is not universally welcomed - and some style gurus are already predicting a return to formality. "I think suits or formal wear make one feel more professional in one's approach and behaviour," says Helen Turnbull, the human relations director at law firm Olswang, which experimented with a dress down August but has no plans for a rerun.

Ms Bain reckons there is room for formal and casual business dress.

"There has been a fundamental sea change and this is not a blip. But suits aren't going to go away, and some style magazines are already beginning to herald the return of the suit."

fields.headline: Vodafone mirrors decline
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Professional punters who play in London's biggest stocks will take the information they need to make a turn from almost anywhere.
fields.body:
Professional punters who play in London's biggest stocks will take the information they need to make a turn from almost anywhere.

Take Vodafone . As Britain's biggest, and in stock market terms most important company, its every move is watched by an army of dedicated City analysts.

A rough guess puts the number of Vodafone watchers in the Square Mile at around 25, and as far as anyone knows there is only one house - stockbroking minnow Charles Stanley - that has a "sell" rating on the stock. So if a trader wants to get an edge in Vodafone they need to look outside the City, and a few of the more educated players were doing precisely that yesterday.

It all started mid-morning as word spread that Sanford C Bernstein, the US asset manager, had issued a bearish note on Vodafone. Indeed, Bernstein had published a note giving Vodafone a "sell" recommendation and a down side target price of just 195p.

In the note Bernstein said that while Vodafone clearly had the best assets and management team in the industry, competition would hit Vodafone more than investors expected, and more than the stock price reflected.

This was enough to convince a few punters to go short in the hope that once leading institutions got hold of the note they, too, would sell - and for a while the scheme met with some success. Vodafone shares fell back to 236p, but rallied in the afternoon to close 4.75p lower at 241.25p.

In fact the performance of Vodafone reflected that of the wider market. The morning part of the session was spent in deep in negative territory - at one point the FTSE 100 reached 6,070 points - as London digested the latest overnight profits warnings from PC maker Gateway and chip maker Altera Corp on the other side of the Atlantic.

But just after lunch things started to turn as traders quite irrationally looked forward to the opening on Wall Street. In the event both the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones Industrial Average opened lower but this only served to entice buyers back into the market.

Dealers pointed out that every time the FTSE gets near 6,000 points buyers emerge on the grounds that the market looks reasonably attractive. Nonetheless it was hardly anything to get excited about. Most of the buying interest came from institutions pulling out of the technology sector and reinvesting their cash in safer places, such as the banking, pharmaceutical and retail sectors. But it was enough to help blue chips out of a difficult situation and the FTSE 100 index closed down 22.7 points at 6,142.2.

Things were not as bright in the tech world, where the FTSE Techmark 100 lost 70.36 points to 2,467.75.

Bookham shed 102p to 879p, Baltimore was off 28p at 290p and Sema closed the day 19p lower at 289p.

Computer services group CMG , up 32p to 880p, managed to buck the trend after a last-minute scramble for stock ahead of its inclusion in the MSCI Europe Standard Indices today. The same factor dealers said was behind the rise in intellectual property group BTG , 110p better at £13.05, and Pace Mirco , off just 10p at 500p.

One company heading out of the MSCI is heating and boiler products group Hepworth , down 6.5p to 253.5p, but word has it that a 300p a share bid is on the way. Even the sceptics concede there might be something in this tale. Last month Hepworth said it was in talks that could lead to a takeover by an industry rival.

One takeover tale firmly discounted concerned computer games group Eidos . Although the stock performed well, up 13p to 203p, dealers reported "quality institutional buying" following presentations by Eidos management on Wednesday. According to informed sources a leading house is preparing a bullish note on the company that is likely to carry a 300p target price.

The morning part of the session was spent in deep in negative territory - at one point the FTSE 100 reached 6,070 points - as London digested the latest overnight profits warnings from PC maker Gateway and chip maker Altera Corp on the other side of the Atlantic. But just after lunch things started to turn as traders quite irrationally looked forward to the opening on Wall Street. In the event both the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones Industrial Average opened lower but this only served to entice buyers back into the market. Dealers pointed out that every time the FTSE gets near 6,000 points buyers emerge on the grounds that the market looks reasonably attractive. Nonetheless it was hardly anything to get excited about. Most of the buying interest came from institutions pulling out of the technology sector and reinvesting their cash in safer places, such as the banking, pharmaceutical and retail sectors. But it was enough to help blue chips out of a difficult situation and the FTSE 100 index closed down 22.7 points at 6,142.2. Things were not as bright in the tech world, where the FTSE Techmark 100 lost 70.36 points to 2,467.75. Bookham shed 102p to 879p, Baltimore was off 28p at 290p and Sema closed the day 19p lower at 289p. Computer services group CMG , up 32p to 880p, managed to buck the trend after a last-minute scramble for stock ahead of its inclusion in the MSCI Europe Standard Indices today. The same factor dealers said was behind the rise in intellectual property group BTG , 110p better at £13.05, and Pace Mirco , off just 10p at 500p. One company heading out of the MSCI is heating and boiler products group Hepworth , down 6.5p to 253.5p, but word has it that a 300p a share bid is on the way. Even the sceptics concede there might be something in this tale. Last month Hepworth said it was in talks that could lead to a takeover by an industry rival. One takeover tale firmly discounted concerned computer games group Eidos . Although the stock performed well, up 13p to 203p, dealers reported "quality institutional buying" following presentations by Eidos management on Wednesday. According to informed sources a leading house is preparing a bullish note on the company that is likely to carry a 300p target price.

fields.headline: 'It's not just a horse thing'
fields.standfirst: In the 60s you could buy a George Stubbs painting for £500. Yesterday one fetched £2.7m.  Jonathan Jones tells how an artist once derided as an animal painter became one of the megastars of British art thanks to an American tycoon, a Derby winner and a contender for the Turner prize
fields.trailText: In the 60s you could buy a George Stubbs painting for £500. Yesterday one fetched £2.7m. Jonathan Jones tells how an artist once derided as an animal painter became one of the megastars of British art thanks to an American tycoon, a Derby winner and a contender for the Turner prize
fields.body:
You can still see descendants of the horses painted in the 18th century by George Stubbs at studs in Newmarket and around the world. You can even see the skeleton of one of his most famous equine subjects, the racehorse Eclipse - whose bloodline to this day is one of the most highly regarded in horseracing - at the National Racehorsing Museum. But even in this world with its emphasis on blood, inheritance and continuity, there is something extraordinary about the way a horse painter who died in 1806 and whose paintings were long regarded as decoration for billiard rooms in stately homes has established himself as one of the greatest ever British artists.

Yesterday a Stubbs was sold at auction at Sotheby's for an astonishing £2,753,500. The picture of a dappled-grey racehorse has always been recognised as a Stubbs, but pulses started to race after cleaning revealed an inscription identifying the horse as Euston, which was owned by his patron William Wildman. It is the third-highest sum ever paid for a Stubbs - the highest, undisclosed sum was paid a couple of years ago by the National Gallery for his masterpiece Whistlejacket. It offers confirmation that Stubbs (1724-1806) is up there with Turner, Constable and Gainsborough in the elite of British painting.

The story of how Stubbs rose from minor specialist artist to auction house megastar involves an American millionaire, a Derby winner, and a contender for the Turner prize. It is a tale of horse flesh and art history, the turf and the auction room. It is a drama you can read in the figures kept by the Art Sales Index on Stubbs's prices from the 60s to today.

Back in the 60s you could buy a Stubbs oil painting for a four-figure sum, or less: in 1960 a painting entitled Rainbow-Grey Hunter Standing on Banks of Wooded Stream fetched £500. It was in the 70s that the stakes were raised, but even in 1977 a Pointer in a Wooded Landscape sold for £3,000 at Christie's. Then in the 80s the market turned upside down. All prices for art rose and have continued to rise, but still the Stubbs renaissance was exceptional. In 1987 came the first seven-figure sum, when his Baron de Robeck Riding a Bay Cob sold at Sotheby's in New York for £1,349, 694.

What changed? "It's a relatively recent rise to fame," says Stephen Deuchar, director of Tate Britain. "If you look back even to the 60s, Stubbs wasn't considered to be so important. The turning point was Basil Taylor's biography in 1971. He was the first person to look at sporting and animal art in a serious way." But he did more than champion Stubbs in print. "He acted as an advisor to Paul Mellon."

The name Paul Mellon has become inseparable from that of George Stubbs. Born in Pittsburgh in 1907, heir to the millionaire businessman and politician Andrew W Mellon, Paul Mellon - who died last year - dedicated his life to the arts and was the first president of the National Gallery in Washington, DC. He was a passionate anglophile, a charitable giver, and his monument is the Yale Centre for British Art in New Haven, Connecticut - after Tate Britain the foremost collection of British art in the world.

But he was something else, too. He was one of the world's great connoisseurs of horse flesh. Mellon described himself in his autobiography, Reflec tions in a Silver Spoon, as "an amateur in all phases of my life . . . an amateur scholar, an amateur horseman," but his record as an art collector and horse breeder suggests otherwise. "In addition to owning Stubbs's greatest paintings," says artist and horse-racing fan Mark Wallinger, "Paul Mellon also owned Mill Reef, who won the Derby and the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe and the Coronation Cup - he was one of the greatest horses ever."

Stubbs's collectors are generally a breed apart; they are people who like horses as well as art. "A friend of mine who owns a Stubbs is also a great aficionado of flat racing and gambling," says Christopher Woodward, director of the Holburne Museum in Bath. But it was Mellon who became the first serious collector of Stubbs to value him as a great artist rather than a sporting specialist. In 1984 the first-ever major exhibition of Stubbs was organised by Judy Egerton, another of Mellon's close advisers, at the Tate Gallery. Robert Hughes hailed it as manifesting "the feeling, now spreading in England, that Stubbs is to be ranked with Turner and Constable in English painting."

It helps that this recognition has been, if anything, stronger in America, still the centre of the art market. Mellon's bequests mean that the fullest collection of Stubbs in the world is at Yale. Meanwhile, in this country the National Gallery has acquired Whistlejacket, which ever since it went on loan to the museum in 1996 has been one of the most popular paintings in the gallery. Painted lifesize and with no fields, clouds or trainer in the background, his eyes bulging with animal energy, his flanks pulsing, rearing up in empty space, Whistlejacket dominates his world and exerts a powerful imaginative grip on ours. Just what is it about Stubbs that has made him so contemporary and exciting to modern eyes?

It's not just a horse thing. It's an art thing. You only have to look at Whistlejacket to feel transfixed and perturbed in a rare way, and it's not just in this painting that the world of Stubbs feels odd, even surreal. It's not that he is simply comparable to Turner or Constable, but that in many ways he looks more modern than either. The way his horses are isolated from the world and just stand there in space, isolated animal souls, makes you think of Magritte's painting This is Not a Pipe with its cutting adrift of objects.

Perhaps it is also the obsessive quality of this art that fascinates us, the fact that Stubbs dedicated himself totally to one kind of subject, as if nothing else existed. He was so serious about animals that he dissected horses to understand their anatomy, and the detail of the horse's physical structure laid bare in his Anatomy of the Horse (1766) is the most perfect ever recorded in art. He was commissioned by aristocrats to paint horses; he also painted monkeys, cheetahs, a lion attacking a horse, and at the edge of the action, holding a bridle or sitting in the saddle, he was obliged to paint people.

His adoration of the tranquility, courage and beauty of the horse makes you think of the Houyhnhnms, the wise horses Gulliver meets after all the grotesque humanoids he encounters in Swift's Gulliver's Travels. Perhaps it is the British worship of animals that makes us love Stubbs.

Yet his vision of the world is cold, cruel, as if he was looking at things almost too clearly. Stubbs is the only 18th-century artist to have had a sniff of the Turner prize. In 1995 Wallinger was shortlisted for a series of works focusing on the world of horse racing. Wallinger's most explicit tribute to Stubbs is a series of paintings of horses under the title Race, Class, Sex, which appeared in his Turner show and are now owned by Charles Saatchi. These are paintings of racehorses in a stud at Newmarket, and their connection to Stubbs, reveals Wallinger, is not just one of style. As well as being painted in the manner of Stubbs, three of the horses he painted are directly descended from one of Stubbs's subjects.

"I painted four racehorses down in Sheikh Mohammed's stud in Newmarket. Three of them, Darley Arabian, Byerley Turk and Godolphin, had a direct bloodline back to Eclipse, the greatest horse that Stubbs painted. That is still the greatest bloodline in racing."

It's a strange bloodline that leads from the aristocrats who commissioned Stubbs to record their horses in the 18th century to the Turner prize. Some of the greatest Stubbs paintings are still owned by the families that commissioned them, and still hang in country houses where horses, hunting and gun dogs are around to provide context.

The Grosvenor Hunt, exhibited at Christie's this year and still owned by the Grosvenor family in Cheshire, depicts gentlemen watching from their horses as a pack of black-and- white hounds bring down a stag in a stream under a tree in front of a grey sky. It's a chilling, unforgettable painting as the hunt just sit there and watch, their horses rebelling slightly, as the animal is torn to pieces. We look on, transfixed; wild horses couldn't drag us away.

fields.headline: It's make-your-mind-up time
fields.standfirst: Venables must decide where to spend his Saturdays: on ITV or with Robson at the Riverside
fields.trailText: What's it going to be Terry? Man of the moment Venables must decide where to spend his Saturdays: on ITV or with Robson at the Riverside
fields.body:
Terry Venables was yesterday asked to make a "lifestyle choice" and decide whether he will spend his Saturday nights with Des Lynam or Bryan Robson next season.

With no answer forthcoming on Middlesbrough's attempt to lure the former England coach to Teesside, both the club and ITV put Venables under intense pressure to make a final decision.

Privately, the 57-year-old Venables has in principle accepted the struggling Premiership club's offer of a £1.5m, 18-month contract to replace Robson as first-team manager. Given Venables' record, however, the Boro chairman Steve Gibson will not be holding his breath.

Meanwhile, ITV is reluctantly preparing to lose its most high-profile pundit for the network's expanded football coverage next season. With the Boro post demanding full-time commitment, it would scupper ITV's plans to feature Venables alongside Lynam on the new Match of the Day-style highlights programme to be broadcast at 8pm on Saturdays.

The network is willing to let Venables manage Boro and make midweek appearances on its Champions League programmes - as he did while manager of Crystal Palace in 1998 - until his television contract expires in the summer.

As Robson took training yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's trip to West Ham, club officials stressed it was "business as usual".

"There is nothing fresh to report today regarding the negotiations with Terry Venables," said Robson. "There is nothing more we can tell the fans at the moment. When there is something concrete we can say, we will say it."

Venables' hesitation is in contrast to his reaction when he was linked with the post of England coach after the resignation of Kevin Keegan in October. No mention was made of business or media commitments which might preclude him from taking the post and, at the time, he declared he was "starving" to tackle a high-profile job in management. "If you were asking me if I've lost the bite for it, I would say no," he said. "I could live without being directly involved. But I want to be in and around it because I care about it."

Gibson is believed to have promised Venables substantial transfer funds to steer the side, who have not had a Premiership win since September, away from the bottom three.

Middlesbrough may have lost confidence in Robson but Gibson is reluctant to dismiss him, even hoping that he may return to the position he has held since 1994 once Venables' contract expires.

The future of the coaching staff, Viv Anderson and Gordon McQueen, is unclear with Venables believed to be keen on bringing his former backroom staff at Portsmouth and Crystal Palace, Terry Fenwick, Ted Buxton and Dave Butler, to the Riverside.

The uncertainty will not help the morale of Middlesbrough's players. "We know as much as anyone else out there," said the midfielder Robbie Mustoe.

"We're just reading the papers and trying to find out what's happening like everyone else. We're getting no information whatsoever from within the club. It is frustrating for us at a difficult time."

Robson disagreed: "It's not a difficult situation for the players at all. There's been a lot of speculation about Terry Venables but it should not affect them.

"The lads are professional enough; they get paid to play football. It doesn't matter who is taking the coaching sessions, they just get on with their job and enjoy their football. They have not had an interrupted build-up to the game.

"I don't know whether the lads are reading all the speculation in the newspapers or not, but the approach has been fine. It is up to them to concentrate on their job in hand, which is preparing for the game at the weekend, mentally as well as physically."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Painted into a corner
fields.standfirst:
The Tories' hopeless response to the triumph of the new deal on jobs shows how dire their plight really is

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories' hopeless response to the triumph of the new deal on jobs shows how dire their plight really is
fields.body:
Rhetorical trumpets sounded and drums beat inside Downing Street yesterday as the prime minister and his generals assembled to celebrate an important victory. The flagship manifesto promise - 250,000 long-term unemployed young people into jobs - has been more than met, under budget and ahead of time. "Rejoice!" David Blunkett said, denouncing the "nothing works" cynics.

In truth, it wasn't much of a news story. It has been obvious for well over a year that the new deal was working very well, a modest but solid success. Independent audits from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research showed that 164,000 young people who had been unemployed more than six months had all found jobs at least six months sooner than they would have done without help: the rest might have gone straight into jobs anyway. It cost an average £4,000 per job and at that price the scheme just about pays for itself in saved benefits.

At the height of the 1980s slump, half a million young people had no prospect of work - a lost generation, many of whom never recovered. Now there are only 37,000 long-term young unemployed left and the number is falling fast. Yesterday wasn't news - but imagine if the new deal had failed or if it had cost a great deal more per job. The dome would have paled into insignificance as an emblem of New Labour disaster. That's the trouble for governments - targets achieved, goals met, promises kept are dull. So yesterday ITN didn't mention the new deal result at all; the BBC gave it 10 seconds. Only failures are fun.

In human terms, the new deal has lifted up thousands of young people: to be out of work with nothing to do for six months is a long time for a drifting 18-year-old. The magic ingredient is the personal adviser, a job now hotly competed for, with its satisfying results. The weary, depleted, old Employment Service has sprung into new life. Ninety per cent of new deal clients talk in glowing terms about their personal advisers, who see them right through even when they are in work. Some telephone their advisers at night for help.

Most have never had an adult personally assigned to them before. One adviser swapped clothes with his client so he could send him off to an interview respectably dressed. He wore the boy's jeans and Man U T-shirt for the day; the boy got the job. If doubters want a taste of some real good this government has done, a session sitting in on new deal interviews is heart-warming stuff.

But then come the stark reality checks: a dead boy in north Peckham is a shocking reminder of the wastelands still to be rescued, how many people, how difficult it is to change places left to fester for the past 20 years. Government spending so far has only nibbled round the edges; there is more to come, but little yet.

The full force of what it really means to inherit a society where one in every three children is born poor is starting to sink in with Labour. Even the big increases in benefits for children don't fix all this quickly. Even if schools get better, many of these children will still end up at 18 with the new deal as their last resort. As years go by, these will increasingly be the hardest cases, for whom all else has failed. The later they are found, the larger the sums that need to be spent on treatment, counselling, intensive education, whatever it takes to get them on to their feet and into society.

The new deal was allocated £2.6bn over four years. It has spent only £1bn, so there is money that should now be spent on high-intensity programmes for the toughest cases, old and young. It is cheaper than waiting for them to end up in prisons or mental hospitals. A target of getting 70% of single parents into work will be hard to hit while there are still very few affordable nurseries. Above all, to reach full employment the chancellor has to abandon one great ideological barricade and spend money where he swore he never would - on job creation in the most blighted areas where no amount of training magics up non-existent work.

Nonetheless, hitting that new deal target is an important emblem of Labour success - and the starting pistol for the election campaign. It is also a stake through the heart of the Tory party. Yesterday they struggled to find anything coherent to say about it and their response is a revealing dry run for the plight they will find themselves in next May. Wherever they turn, they skewer themselves.

Yesterday they tossed out a fog of mendacious figures, all desperate stuff. They claimed the new deal cost £5.2bn instead of £1bn. They claimed Labour inherited only half the target number when it came to power - conveniently leaving out the 14,000 more coming on to the books every month. "The new deal is a spin operation. It claims credit for finding people jobs they would have found anyway." Why? Because the economy is so strong, but how can the Tories admit that?

They promise to scrap the programme, privatising it with bonuses for every job new contractors find. It will cost, they claim, £1,000 less per job. Where will that cut fall? On education and training - the high-value part of the new deal. Never mind that many of these young people are illiterate and innumerate, private employment agencies will bundle them into jobs anyway. "Employers don't want all this waste on training," said the Tory spokesperson. Nor workers who can read and write? No.

Michael Portillo is said to be tired of the game; he wants out. Maybe he's a sleeping crocodile but it wouldn't be surprising if he really has had enough. Who could blame him for not facing another arid four years of opposition? Trying to oppose the new deal epitomises their problem. It is virtually impossible to oppose most of Labour's major programmes for schools, the NHS or the poor except with lies and the odd ideological privatisation devised for the sake of it. Rarely can politics have seemed more pointless than inside the Tory party now. The sterile search for anything different to say must be deathly toil. Never mind what works, all that matters is contriving something plausible to say. Forget honesty, oppose everything. If Portillo wants to get a life instead, why not?

Seeking clear blue water, Hague has landed the Tories on a desert island alone with their own ageing clan, tax-cutting, social-programme-slashing, 1950s-moralising, Europhobic, mad little Englanders. webTitle: 70 minutes that will make US history

fields.headline: 70 minutes that will make US history
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The seven men and two women who patrol the frontier between American law and politics will sit down in Washington today to hear a legal case that could propel the US presidential election dispute further into the constitutional unknown - or that could stop it dead in its tracks.
fields.body:
The seven men and two women who patrol the frontier between American law and politics will sit down in Washington today to hear a legal case that could propel the US presidential election dispute further into the constitutional unknown - or that could stop it dead in its tracks.

Not since the Watergate scandal of the 1970s have the nine members of the US supreme court been so firmly in a presidential minefield.

Back then, by ordering Richard Nixon to hand over his White House tapes, the court made a ruling which eventually drove the president to resign. Now, 26 years later, it may again make history by in effect deciding who will become the 43rd US president.

The issue in Bush v Palm Beach County Canvassing Board is legally narrow but politically vast. At 10am, George W Bush's lawyers will have 35 minutes to say why Florida's supreme court overstepped the constitution on November 21 by permitting manual recounts of the November 7 poll.

Al Gore's lawyers will have 35 minutes to argue why the Florida court was within its rights. At that point, the judges will adjourn to ponder their decision. A decision seems likely early next week.

If the judges reaffirm the Florida supreme court's decision, Mr Gore's efforts to have all the votes counted can continue. If they override the Florida decision, however, the counts are over and Mr Bush is home and dry - unless one of the Florida courts separately overturns the election.

The history of the US supreme court is the history of the balance between the constitution and the states' rights to make their own laws.

Mr Bush's team says that the Florida decision breaches a section of the US code of 1887 which stipulates that controversies about the appointment of members of the electoral college must be made according to "laws enacted prior to" the election. The Florida court also violated the separation of powers between courts and the legislature in article 2 of the US constitution, it argues.

Mr Gore's team says that the Bush case "flatly misreads" the law. The Florida court's ruling, it argues, was in "a state-law case that, despite its importance, does not belong in federal court". In modern time, Democrats have traditionally fought against states' rights in such battles, but not this time.

The nine judges often divide on liberal versus conservative lines, but today's case will be difficult to call in advance because of the states' rights issue. Traditionally, the chief justice, William Rehnquist, heads the conservatives, with Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas. A more liberal block frequently includes John Stevens, David Souter, Ruth Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer. Anthony Kennedy and Sandra O'Connor tend to hold the balance.

Mr Bush's case will be put by Washington lawyer Theodore Olson, who acted for Los Angeles police officers in the 1991 Rodney King beating case. Mr Olson is a close friend of the former special prosecutor Kenneth Starr, and is married to Barbara Olson, author of a fanatically hostile 1999 biography of Hillary Clinton.

Mr Gore's lawyer is the Harvard University constitutional law expert Professor Laurence Tribe. He played a key role in the successful 1987 Democratic effort to block Ronald Reagan's nomination of a conservative judge, Robert Bork, to the court.
