fields.headline: No: 1773
fields.standfirst: The 3am team
fields.trailText: The 3am team
fields.body:
Real names:
Jessica Callan, Polly Graham and Eva Simpson.

Appearance:
Daily, grinning a little smugly, atop the Mirror's showbiz column, 3am, alongside a logo incorporating a devil's tail. Because these girls are wicked!

Exactly how wicked?
Very wicked indeed. The trio have revolutionised tabloid showbiz gossip, eschewing photos of themselves hugging celebrity "friends" in favour of infuriating said celebs with lurid details of their nasal activities in nightclub toilets.

And why 3am?
Because that's how devilishly - nay, satanically - late the gossipmongering minxes stay out at their glitzy bashes. Oh, and because Mirror editor Piers Morgan couldn't find a big name to replace his star columnist Matthew Wright.

So there's nothing in the rumour that it stands for "three awful mingers"?
Tittle-tattle, possibly initiated by Noel Gallagher, who told a Wembley concert they were "uglier than 15 Matthew Wrights put together" (a claim disproved by a 3am phone poll). Or maybe Liam Gallagher, who - displaying his characteristic instinct for le mot juste - called them "fucking ugly" and pressed home his point by attacking one of them in a hotel.

They must be awfully distraught by all this hostility.
Hardly. The mock fallout/reconciliation leitmotif (to quote Liam) is an endless source of copy - as with this week's exclusive toilet-based interview with Spice Girl Mel C. The feisty threesome were, they said, "powdering our noses" in the loo at a Madonna concert when the singer - who had previously called them "fucking sluts" - spilled the beans about her depression and various other issues of national importance.

What a coincidence that they happened to be in the toilet at precisely that moment!
Mmm, yes.

Typical 3am story type one - insufficient evidence to satisfy the Mirror's libel lawyers:
"Which livewire TV presenter runs a lucrative sideline selling nasal stimulants to senior executives?"

Typical 3am story type 2 - not libellous, but mind-explodingly dull:
"Dane Bowers [spotted] buying a Yaku plant and some cushions with his mum in Ikea in Croydon."

fields.headline: Civil rights marchers 'fired at from both sides'
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday inquiry

Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Civilian witnesses to the Bloody Sunday civil rights march in 1972 yesterday described their panic as they were trapped in the heart of the Bogside area of Derry when, without warning, army fire came at them from the front and rear.
fields.body:
Civilian witnesses to the Bloody Sunday civil rights march in 1972 yesterday described their panic as they were trapped in the heart of the Bogside area of Derry when, without warning, army fire came at them from the front and rear.

"It sounded like judgment day," said Eunan O'Donnell, a 28-year-old teacher at the time, who recalled the shouts of armed soldiers leaping out of Saracen armoured cars as "battle cries".

He told the Bloody Sunday inquiry: "It looked like they were obviously on the attack. Nobody believed the army were firing live rounds. I'm sure the people were as amazed as me."

Mr O'Donnell was in Rossville Street, where six of the day's 13 fatalities took place.

At about the same time as the Saracens arrived from the north, half a dozen shots came from the south-east, probably from Derry's city walls, Mr O'Donnell said. As hundreds of people threw themselves to the ground and began to scramble away, crouching, crawling and screaming, he came across a youth lying on the ground with his face covered in blood.

"I think the bullet had entered on one side and left on the other. He had a large hole in one cheek and a smaller one in the other," Mr O'Donnell said. Gory pictures were taken on the day of the shot youth, Michael Quinn, who survived his injuries.

Minutes before concentrated fire broke out, Mr O'Donnell said he heard what may turn out to be the first shots fired by the army. At that stage the march of up to 20,000 people had been largely peaceful, but a few dozen youths had started throwing stones at army barricades and the soldiers had responded with CS gas and rubber bullets.

"The next thing we heard were two high velocity shots from an elevated position." He thought they came from an army observation post on top of the Embassy Ballroom.

Another teacher, Kathleen Turner, told the inquiry that the shots had come from the Presbyterian church. With tears streaming from her eyes because of the gas, she saw a young man raise his arms in a V shape. Men rushed to help him as he fell. Damien Donaghy had been shot in the thigh. He, too, survived.

Mrs Turner started running through the rubble of the Bogside wastelands, in the same direction as Mr O'Donnell.

"I saw Saracens turning into Rossville Street and screeching to halts. The soldiers were shooting live ammunition.

"I have this vivid memory of one soldier kneeling on one knee with his rifle pointing down Rossville Street." It was like a picture on an army recruitment brochure, she said.

Mrs Turner also heard shots that appeared to come from the city walls.

"I recall being trapped. I just fled." She crawled away with her sister and took shelter behind a garden wall.

Afterwards, she said, she felt "sheer outrage". "The sense of injustice is still there."

webTitle: Flooded areas face shortages next year

fields.headline: Flooded areas face shortages next year
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Britain's worst flooded areas could next summer be faced with water shortages because of leaky pipes and rising demand from new homes and factories, parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, reveals today.
fields.body:
Britain's worst flooded areas could next summer be faced with water shortages because of leaky pipes and rising demand from new homes and factories, parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, reveals today.

The report highlights Thames Water, Welsh Water, Wessex Water, South East Water, Essex and Suffolk Water and South Staffordshire Water as areas where home-owners could face shortages because the margin between supply and demand is inadequate.

South East Water serves East Sussex and parts of Surrey which last month were inundated. It covers the town of Uckfield and the villages of Barcombe and Alfriston which were flooded after rivers burst their banks.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, whose area includes many homes served by South East Water, said yesterday: "It would be absurd if people who have spent the winter mopping up from floods should be facing hosepipe bans this summer. People will be furious if they have got to put up with this next."

A spokeswoman for South East Water said the company had stepped up its activity to plug more leaking pipes. "In the last four months we believe we have cut leaks by more than any other company in Britain. We have also set up a leakage control centre at our reservoir in Barcombe. Until we have studied the report in detail we cannot comment further."

The report praises Ofwat, the water regulator, for laying down a tough programme to repair leaking pipes - which in 1995 averaged one in three of those supplying homes and in dustry. This figure has dropped to 22% of all pipes, but is still equivalent to 3m cubic metres a day - nearly half the average flow rate of the River Thames through London.

The report reveals that a third of the water companies are saying it is uneconomic to repair the rest of their systems. Eight have told the NAO they do not believe it can be justified economically to continue plugging leaking pipes. They are Bournemouth and West Hampshire Water, Three Valleys Water, Tendering Hundred Water, South Staffordshire Water, Hartlepool Water, Southern Water, South West Water and Anglian Water.

Thames Water is also disputing Ofwat's demands that it reduce the number of leaking pipes on the grounds that such targets are "premature".

The auditors say that they believe the margin between supply and demand is too narrow for the seven worst affected companies to do nothing about it.

It warns: "To maintain a safe margin between water supply and demand, the companies that serve these areas need to avoid wasting water through excessive leakage and to manage customer demand by promoting the efficient use of water."

David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said today: "People served by Thames Water should be especially alarmed. In their region water resources are classified as tight and leakage, at 27%, is still unacceptably high."

The auditors say that Ofwat has to do more to decide how many more leaks should be plugged and what would be the most effective way of persuading customers to use less water.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Three hanged in Japan
fields.body:
Three hanged in Japan

Japan hanged three convicted murderers yesterday, bring to 39 the total of executions since 1993, when Tokyo began using the death penalty again after a three-year gap.

The justice ministry did not disclose the names of those hanged, but Japanese media identified them as a man, 52, convicted of serial murder and robbery, a 57-year-old found guilty of killing his ex-wife and her family and a 55-year-old murderer.

Reuters, Tokyo

Marines hurt in Bosnia blast

Two US Marines injured in an explosion in Bosnia were in stable condition in a hospital in Germany yesterday, officials said.

Chief Warrant Officer Robert Hayworth, 41, and Gunnery Sergeant Richard O'Connell, 38, were hurt on Tuesday at Camp Bedrock near Tuzla, the army said. A third Marine has been released from hospital.

The men are part of an explosive ordnance disposal team.

AP, Tuzla

German train crash injures 32

A local passenger train in southern Germany hit the back of a stationary freight train yesterday, injuring 32 people, five of them seriously, officials said.

One passenger had to be freed by firefighters after the collision at Herbrechtingen, about 100 miles east of Munich.

AP, Stuttgart

$1m for capture of 'mob boss'

The FBI has increased to $1m (£703,000) the reward for information leading to the capture of the alleged mob boss James "Whitey" Bulger, who has been on the run for five years.

Prosecutors say that from the late 1970s, Bulger, 71, helped control the Winter Hill Gang, which generated money through extortion, loan sharking, bookmaking and drug sales. He is accused of involvement in 18 killings.

AP, Boston

Creamed Kohl keeps his cool

Former German chancellor Helmut Kohl was hit in the face by a cream cake during a book signing session in Berlin yesterday. Police detained a suspect.

A spokesman for the bookshop said: "The chancellor reacted calmly, wiped the cake remains from his face and kept on autographing."

AP, Berlin

webTitle: Jakarta's threats fail to crush hopes of Papuan separatists

fields.headline: Jakarta's threats fail to crush hopes of Papuan separatists
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian government yesterday raised the stakes in its campaign against the growing separatist movement in the province of Irian Jaya as its people prepare for the 39th anniversary today of a unilateral declaration of independence.
fields.body:
The Indonesian government yesterday raised the stakes in its campaign against the growing separatist movement in the province of Irian Jaya as its people prepare for the 39th anniversary today of a unilateral declaration of independence.

Ministers in Jakarta threatened treason charges against anyone raising the Papuan flag - the Morning Star - or repeating the 1961 declaration of independence of West Papua, as Indonesia's easternmost province is called by its people, and thousands of heavily-armed riot police and soldiers paraded through Irian Jaya's towns threatening to shoot troublemakers.

The police also charged two leading members of the separatist movement's coordinating committee, the Papuan Presidium, with subversion.

"We cannot tolerate people demanding a separate state," said Brigadier General Sylvanus Wenas, the province's police chief. "They know it is against the law as I have told them so myself and so we have to act. But we will treat them fairly as we would our own brothers."

The presidium's chairman, Theys Eluay, its secretary-general Thaha Hamid, and a presidium member, Don Flassy, were arrested on Wednesday. All insist they have done nothing more than articulate the desires of most Papuans.

Indonesia took over the territory from Holland in 1962 after promising a vote on self-determination. The referendum, which did not take place until 1969, was limited to 1,024 tribal chiefs, and has always been regarded as rigged.

Since then there have been numerous military operations to crush the fledgling separatist movement in Indonesia's most resource-rich region. After taking heart from East Timor's successful struggle for independence, the West Papuan separatists began to make significant progress.

In May, the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, allowed them to fly the Morning Star, said he would recommend changing the province's name from Irian Jaya to Papua, promised autonomy and said that Jakarta would help pay for a Papuan people's congress.

But the army, the nationalist vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, and parliament blocked the changes.

Last month the security forces started hauling down flags, parliament has refused to ratify the name change, the implementation of autonomy has been postponed until next May at the earliest and the congress has been declared subversive.

Indonesia's chief security minister, Bambang Susilo Yudhoyono, insisted that the government would stop any attempts to break away from Jakarta but would continue to use a legal approach for as long as possible. "If it becomes necessary, we will not be afraid to use repressive measures."

However, there is mounting evidence that the government is already using force in many parts of the province to intimidate the separatists, who commands widespread support.

Several battalions of special forces were deployed in recent months and thousands more reinforcements have arrived in the last few weeks. Earlier this year British-made Hawk jets were used to "buzz" towns in the rugged mountainous interior until the tactic attracted too much bad publicity.

"The authorities use the police in the towns but soldiers are deployed in the remote districts," said Julien Warringmo, a member of a student body that is monitoring the activities of both sides. "People are certainly being blocked from travelling freely. They are not being allowed to gather for any sort of meeting."

Islamic groups, similar to those responsible for much of the violence in the sectarian conflict in Indonesian's Molucca islands, are now operating in predominantly Christian Irian Jaya. "They are working as drivers and vegetable sellers," Mr Warringmo said. "We fear it will only be a matter of time before they start provoking unrest as they have done in the Moluccas."

It is difficult to verify these claims as most journalists are banned from travelling beyond the provincial capital, Jayapura. Yesterday vehicles entering towns were searched and anyone carrying weapons or failing to show proper papers was arrested.

The crackdown appears to be working to a degree. Most members of the Papuan Presidium are encouraging their supporters not to do anything on the anniversary that might provoke a military backlash.

"It seems that the military is just looking for an excuse to crush us," said Obed Komba, a presidium member. "So we are asking people just to go to their churches and pray for the future of our land. We do not want huge rallies that might get out of hand or be used by provocateurs to stir up trouble."

It remains to be seen whether his call will be heeded, particularly by the young. "We have to stand up for what we believe in," Mattias Miaga, a student activist, said. "Indonesia has given us nothing and taken everything for the last 30 years. Now is the time to really start fighting back."

webTitle: African leaders criticise Mugabe for farm seizures

fields.headline: African leaders criticise Mugabe for farm seizures
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, was sharply reprimanded yesterday for his violent land seizures by two of Africa's most powerful leaders, the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, and the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, was sharply reprimanded yesterday for his violent land seizures by two of Africa's most powerful leaders, the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, and the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo.

The two travelled to Harare in a last ditch effort to persuade Mr Mugabe to uphold the rule of law and make his land redistribution acceptable to the international community. But, following an unprecedented two and a half hours of talks, Mr Obasanjo made it clear that they had failed to make a breakthrough.

"What I think the Zimbabwean government should do is to strictly follow the law that is already in place for the resolution of the land problem," Mr Obasanjo said as Mr Mugabe sat to the side with pursed lips and downcast eyes.

It is a rare occasion when two African leaders publicly criticise a fellow head of state. Mr Mugabe did not speak at the conference.

Mr Obasanjo said the handling of Zimbabwe's land redistribution was important to the entire southern African region. "The issue of land reform in Zimbabwe is an issue that is not only current but it affects almost everybody's life in this country and the lives of others beyond this country," he said. "We do know that there is a law that stipulates what needs to be done and how it should be done so that this problem can be resolved."

Mr Mugabe's "fast track" land seizures have broken his own Land Acquisition Act that was passed by parliament in early November.

He has repeatedly assured international leaders that he is following legal procedures but his promises have been starkly contradicted by the numerous violent incidents in which white-owned farms have been overrun by veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule, often armed, and other supporters of Mr Mugabe.

Five white farmers have been killed this year and scores more attacked. Thousands of black farm workers have also been beaten.

Mr Mugabe has blatantly flouted orders from Zimbabwe's supreme court and high court to stop the illegal invasions. Instead, he and his cabinet have attacked the country's top judges as racists.

Mr Obasanjo implicitly acknowledged that Mr Mugabe had not agreed to change his policies and that it was not currently possible to have fruitful negotiations with the international community to raise funds for land reform.

The Nigerian leader offered his services as a mediator once Mr Mugabe is closer to the position of potential donors, specifically Britain. "It takes two to tango," he said. "When the British and Zimbabweans say 'yes, you can continue to mediate', we are available to act as mediators."

A special envoy of the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, was also in Harare yesterday with a package of financial assistance for land reform that will be made available only if Mr Mugabe stops his land resettlement.

Virtually everyone, including international donors and Zimbabwe's white farmers, agree that thorough land reform is needed to redress the historic injustices in which white British settlers seized vast tracts of African land without paying compensation.

But all international parties agree that Mr Mugabe must follow the laws of his own country in acquiring the land and carry out the reform in a way that will improve the lives of the resettled farmers.

Mr Mugabe has pursued his land seizures because he is convinced it is his best chance to keep a grip on support among rural blacks. He is already reviled by urban blacks who largely support the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

But Mr Mugabe's government badly needs cash, as it cannot pay for imports of adequate supplies of fuel or electricity. He may well agree to international demands so that he can receive assistance, but he will find it very difficult to reverse the land confiscations he has put in motion.

Mr Mbeki at first refrained from publicly criticising Mr Mugabe's policies, but as Zimbabwe's farms descended into lawlessness, the contagion of instability infected South Africa, bringing about a dramatic drop in the value of its currency, the rand.

webTitle: Spurs chief resolves libel action against newspaper

fields.headline: Spurs chief resolves libel action against newspaper
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur Football Club and its executive chairman, Sir Alan Sugar, yesterday resolved their high court libel action against a Sunday newspaper.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur Football Club and its executive chairman, Sir Alan Sugar, yesterday resolved their high court libel action against a Sunday newspaper.

A jury was waiting to be sworn in to hear the case in London when the two sides announced their decision before Mr Justice Gray that the action should be "stayed".

The soccer club and Sir Alan were suing News Group Newspapers over an article in the News of the World in August 1998 which referred to critical comments about the running of the club made by ex-Spurs and England player Alan Mullery.

The club's barrister, Richard Rampton QC, said the respondents had undertaken that they would not publish or repeat statements that the club or Sir Alan had treated player Gary Mabbutt "meanly or disloyally", or that Sir Alan or the board gave false or bogus reasons for their failure to acquire top players in the run-up to the 1998-99 season.

A statement yesterday said that Sir Alan and the club were satisfied that the News of the World had agreed to publish an apology in their next issue and had agreed to pay £80,000.

The newspaper said the sum represented a contribution to costs and that there was no payment of damages.

webTitle: End in sight for infertility treatment lottery

fields.headline: End in sight for infertility treatment lottery
fields.standfirst: Hospitals warn cancer funding will suffer after minister's pledge
fields.trailText: The government pledged yesterday to end some of the unfairness surrounding access to fertility treatment, which for years has been available on the NHS to couples in some areas of the UK, but denied to those who live elsewhere.
fields.body:
The government pledged yesterday to end some of the unfairness surrounding access to fertility treatment, which for years has been available on the NHS to couples in some areas of the UK, but denied to those who live elsewhere.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, announced that he will issue guidelines to ensure equal access to the treatment for all who need it, regardless of where they live. His announcement, long awaited by doctors and pressure groups, met with delight, but there were warnings that it could inflate many times the NHS bill for infertility treatment at the expense of illnesses such as cancer and heart disease.

"Infertility causes distress to thousands of couples. Unfortunately NHS fertility services vary massively around the country. Some health authorities pay for it, some do not," said Mr Milburn. "That postcode lottery has to end now.

"It was right for the NHS to first target cancer, coronary heart disease and mental health in the modernisation programme. However, now the NHS has record funding secured - in the five years to 2004 it will rise by a third in real terms - it is time to tackle infertility."

Mr Milburn has asked the national institute for clinical excellence - set up to end inequities such as these, as well as to decide what drugs and treatments are cost-effective for the NHS - to review guidelines drawn up by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

A survey published yesterday revealed that some health authorities spent £500,000 a year on fertility treatments while others spend nothing. About 43,700 couples seek infertility treatment each year and 12,000 couples get it, either on the NHS or privately, where prices average at £3,000 an attempt. The chances of success are not high - around 14%-18% - and many couples get into financial difficulties in their desperate attempts to have a child. The success rate falls sharply as women get older and some NHS clinics exclude women over 35.

Rationalising fertility treatment around the country could cost the NHS tens of millions of pounds. Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, which represents hospital trusts and health authorities, said they had not paid for fertility treatment in the past because they could not afford it.

"It is not because they think it is bad treatment or doesn't work. It is because it is unaffordable," he told BBC radio. "If they are going to make it affordable, they are going to have to take some of the government's money which is being pumped into the NHS and spend it on infertility treatment, which of course means it won't be available for other pressing government priorities like coronary heart disease, cancer and mental health."

A spokesman for the health policy body the King's Fund agreed. "If health authorities are being asked to spend more than they are currently spending, other things are going to have to lose out."

The fertility expert Lord Winston said he thought there might be savings to offset the increased costs. "A great deal of money is lost and pain caused by inappropriate treatment being given and drugs being given in the wrong situations, and IVF not being offered to people who it should be offered to," he told the BBC.

Clare Brown, executive director of the infertility support network Child, said: "Patients have waited years for infertility treatment to be given the recognition it deserves as an illness, the treatment of which should be funded by the NHS."

A spokesman for Issue, the infertility support group, said: "This comes at a particularly good time. Christmas is devastating for infertile couples who desperately want a baby."

webTitle: The crippling cost of failed IVF attempts

fields.headline: The crippling cost of failed IVF attempts
fields.trailText: Beverley Verney could not imagine a life without children. She worked as the nanny of a little boy and had always wanted her own. For years, she had tried to get pregnant. Then in 1992 she found out that she would never be able to conceive naturally. Her fallopian tubes were blocked and the damage was too bad for an operation to clear them.
fields.body:
Beverley Verney could not imagine a life without children. She worked as the nanny of a little boy and had always wanted her own. For years, she had tried to get pregnant. Then in 1992 she found out that she would never be able to conceive naturally. Her fallopian tubes were blocked and the damage was too bad for an operation to clear them.

There was no choice for her or her partner Dean. They would have to undergo fertility treatment. But it was clear from the start that it was going to cost them a lot - and not just in emotional trauma. "The GP told us the waiting list for NHS treatment was phenomenal and probably not worth going on."

The couple, who live in Nottingham, were faced with finding about £2,500 for each IVF attempt at a private clinic. Few are successful first time. Beverley and Dean took out a loan and in June 1993, the treatment began. It was unsuccessful. "They told us you have a chance of about 24% or less, but I still convinced myself it would work," she said. "I was devastated when it didn't, but immediately began looking for a way to find more money."

The clinic advised a break before the next attempt. The couple arranged their wedding, even though the uncertainties over fertility treatment "took the shine off it". They borrowed money for the wedding - and a bit more for the second attempt.

The second attempt took place in August 1994. It failed. "You are informed by phone whether it has worked." said Beverley. "That is general. But when you are paying all that money, you at least expect someone to comfort you."

She and Dean were distressed and ever deeper in debt. It became too much, and they split up. "I pushed my husband away and went back to my mum's. But we realised we wanted children of our own and we would have to be strong. We took out money for a third attempt."

Beverley was unhappy with the clinic, so they changed to one recommended by a friend. She felt the new consultant was more positive. "He said: 'I'm going to get you pregnant.' Him being so positive made me feel much stronger."

The treatment began in September 1997 and was successful. Beverley was told she was carrying triplets, but at 20 weeks, one baby died in the womb. The couple were sad, but decided it was meant to be. She gave birth to twin girls, Tara and Rosie, nine weeks prematurely. The twins, now two and a half, are thriving.

Beverley and Dean were delighted, but had a huge debt, which she puts at £18,000. While she was still pregnant, they sold their home to pay it off and went to live with Dean's parents two months before the twins were born. Eventually the council housed the family in a two-bedroom flat. Two years later, with both working, they managed to buy another house, but she felt she was losing out through not seeing enough of her babies. Now Dean is doing two jobs so she can spend time with the children she desperately wanted.

Money is still tight. She understands that the NHS cannot pay for all fertility treatment, "but just one attempt would have helped".

fields.headline: Roderic Barrett
fields.standfirst: Humanity's slender hopes shine through his formal paintings
fields.trailText: Roderic Barrett, who has died aged 80, was a painter of great emotional, as well as formal, power, of rich symbolic suggestiveness and, above all, of deep humanity.
fields.body:
Roderic Barrett, who has died aged 80, was a painter of great emotional, as well as formal, power, of rich symbolic suggestiveness and, above all, of deep humanity.

He was born into a radical, non-conformist family; his father, a conscientous objector, had been jailed during the first world war. The death of his mother, when Roderic was only 10, almost certainly contributed to his later melancholic predisposition.

His talent for drawing was recognised at St Christopher's school, Letchworth, along with his keen sportsmanship, and when he was 15, his father took him for interview at the Central School of Art and Design in London. Although formally too young to be considered, Barrett was accepted on the strength of his portfolio. He studied there until 1940, in particular wood engraving under John Farleigh, who considered him the best engraver he had seen.

During the second world war, Roderic was also a conscientious objector, although unlike his father, he was exempted from active service. After the war, with his wife, Lorna Blackmore, whom he had married in 1943, he set up home outside Colchester, and supported his family with teaching appointments in London, first as a part-time instructor at the Central School (1947-68), then as tutor at the Royal Academy Schools at Burlington House (1968-96).

From early on, he was involved with the Colchester Arts Society, along with John and Paul Nash. In 1982, he succeeded Cedric Morris as its president, a position he held until his death with dedication and pride.

Fundamentally resistant to, and suspicious of, the "isms" of modern and post-modern art since the 1960s, Roderic pursued his own way. Having changed from engravings to oils, he retained the mastery and precision of drawing associated with the former. His large-scale painting, often "six-footers" like traditional history pieces, are dominated by human figures of a generic nature - children, the old, the oppressed, the naked, clowns, but also oppressors, hypocrites and charlatans.

Seemingly normal objects, such as chairs, tables, buckets and candles, take on symbolic meanings, suggestions of myths, the subconscious, or of nightmares. What shines through the appearance of a domestic scene are the fears and anxieties, the slender hopes and the melancholia of the human condition.

Roderic would never talk about the "meaning" of his works, only about their formal composition. That was of paramount importance, yet the formality clearly helped to give structure to, and make bearable, a deeply disturbing view of mankind.

Roderic was an outspoken defender of what he called "authentic" art; he was not concerned with the shock of the new, but with getting it right. In this sense, too, he was a deeply moral artist, to whom consistency, hard work and honesty were important.

His honesty made him a perceptive, and sometimes sharp, critic of his own work, as well as of that of others. Given half a chance, he would rework earlier compositions, sometimes several times. Despite occasional battles with depression, he was a man of great charm and grace, a warm friend, and a living encouragement to others.

Since showing at the Beaux Arts gallery, London, in 1954, he exhibited regularly, culminating in a show at the European parliament gallery, Strasbourg (1995), a retrospective at the Barbican and firstsite, Colchester (1996), and an 80th-birthday celebration at Chappel galleries, near Colchester, earlier this year. From 1993-98, he was a trustee of the Colchester and District Visual Arts Trust; and, in 1997, was awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Essex.

He is survived by his wife and three children, Jonathan, Kristin and Mark.

fields.headline: Alexander Schindler
fields.standfirst: Reform rabbi advancing progressive policies for American Jews
fields.trailText: Whether he was visiting famine victims in Korea, or highlighting the decay of America's inner cities, Rabbi Alexander Schindler, who has died aged 75, expressed a distinctly universalistic vision of a Judaism rooted in social activism.
fields.body:
Whether he was visiting famine victims in Korea, or highlighting the decay of America's inner cities, Rabbi Alexander Schindler, who has died aged 75, expressed a distinctly universalistic vision of a Judaism rooted in social activism. Between 1973 and 1996, the German-born rabbi represented more than a million US Reform Jews, as president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations (UAHC).

Schindler was also the first Reform figure to chair the broader Jewish community's umbrella group, the Conference of Presidents, from 1976 to 1978. During this crucial period, he played a pivotal role in facilitating peace between Israel and Egypt, another cause dear to his heart. Indeed, just three days before he died, Schindler castigated "Jewish zealots" for attempting to destroy the ailing Middle East peace process.

Not everyone shared his political predilections. Nor did every Jew, including several Reform co-religionists, relish his theological innovations. In response to the dramatic decline in American Jewish observance and identification, Schindler welcomed intermarried couples into his synagogues, and encouraged the ordination of women rabbis. In 1978, he overturned a 500-year-old Jewish prohibition against proselytising, by launching an outreach programme targeting "unchurched" gentiles.

He also advocated gay and lesbian rights, and, earlier this year, persuaded north American Reform rabbis to endorse the principle of same gender marriage. Even more potentially divisive, at least to Orthodox Jews, was his 1983 acceptance of patrilineal descent as an authentic basis for Jewish identity; in halacha, or traditional law, Jewishness derives solely from the mother's line.

Schindler never apologised for bypassing halacha. He believed Judaism's essence lay in its message of social justice, as voiced by the prophets. He saw the Torah as a human creation, albeit inspired by divine will. Consequently, he argued, biblical laws were not immutable, but should change with the times.

Behind Schindler's avuncular and self-effacing exterior lay a truly courageous soul. Born in Munich, he was just seven when his mother whisked him out of a Germany rapidly falling under Hitler's spell. Eventually, the family were reunited in Switzerland, finally arriving in America in 1938. Alexander later earned the Purple Heart and Bronze Star during combat duty as a US Army ski-trooper in Europe.

His religious path really began after he witnessed the horrors of Dachau. On returning to the City of New York College, he switched from engineering to social sciences, went on to the Hebrew Union College, and was ordained as a rabbi in 1953. He served as an inspirational minister in Worcester, Massachusetts, for six years.

In 1963, Schindler became education director at UAHC, and its vice-president four years later. As president, in 1977 he set up ARZA, the first significant zionist body in Reform history. He later established a religious action centre in Jerusalem to campaign for Israel's marginalised, non-Orthodox minority.

For all Schindler's achievements, however, rank-and-file parishioners most vividly recall his warmth, compassion and capacity to make every individual feel important. Ideological foes seldom became personal enemies.

The classic instance was his bizarre friendship with the late Israeli premier, Menachem Begin. Schindler favoured the eradication of nuclear weaponry, had opposed the Vietnam war, and backed affirmative action for African-Americans. Begin, by contrast, was a rightwing former terrorist and a proponent of the expansionist doctrine of "greater Israel". Yet the liberal rabbi convinced American Jews to take the Likud leader's call for peace at face value. He encouraged and advised Begin during the momentous Camp David talks in 1978. Although the pair later clashed publicly over Israel's conduct in Lebanon, they remained intimate confidants until Begin's death in 1992.

In a verbally flat-footed age, Rabbi Schindler's oratory was legendary. Love of language was a trait he probably inherited from his father, a Yiddish poet and songwriter. From his practical mother, he acquired a preternatural ability to get things done, despite his chronic unpunctuality.

Latterly, he was a link to American Jewry's largely European past, a connection he maintained even after his retirement, as vice-president of the World Jewish Congress and president of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture. Most of all, Rabbi Schindler believed that because "man is created in the image of God", every human life is sacred.

He is survived by his wife, Rhea, two sons, three daughters and nine grandchildren.

fields.headline: Sir Cyril Clarke
fields.standfirst: His pioneering research into genetics among the old, and blood disorders in the young, changed the course of 20th-century medicine
fields.trailText: His pioneering research into genetics among the old, and blood disorders in the young, changed the course of 20th-century medicine
fields.body:
The death of Sir Cyril Clarke, at the age of 93, marks the end of the era of great medical all-rounders. His career as a clinician ranged through life insurance practice, medical specialist in the navy, consultant physician, professor of medicine at Liverpool University, and, finally, president of the Royal College of Physicians.

His research contributions spanned his classical work on mimicry in swallow-tailed butterflies to his inquiry into longevity based on tracing the lifestyles of centenarians who had received congratulatory messages from the Queen. He was one of the first in this country to appreciate that medical genetics, far from being a discipline which focuses on rare and esoteric diseases, has a major role to play across every aspect of day-to-day clinical practice. This led him to establish the Nuffield unit for medical genetics in Liverpool, which became a stable for many in this new field.

Clarke's most important contribution to medicine, however, and one that reflects his flair and willingness to chance his arm in problems which were often outside his field of expertise, was his inspiring leadership of the Liverpool team that discovered how to prevent rhesus haem- olytic disease of the newborn, one of the major advances in preventative medicine of the last half century. This work typified his unwillingness to be deterred by the gloomy prognostications of experts, who often said his thinking was way off the mark, and his instinctive gift for what Sir Peter Medawar called "the art of the possible".

The son of Astley Vavasour Clarke, a physician at Leicester Royal infirmary (and one of the first to use X-rays in this country), Cyril was educated at Oundle school, Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, and Guy's hospital medical school. After three years in life insurance practice, which allowed him time to indulge his passion for sailing, he served throughout the war as a medical officer in the navy, ending his service by writing one of his first papers, on the neurological complications of malnutrition that he observed in British prisoners-of-war in Hong Kong.

He then moved to Liverpool, where he became consultant physician at the David Lewis northern hospital. Despite busy hospital and private practices he, together with his long-time friend and collaborator PM Sheppard, began a series of classical experiments on the genetics of swallow-tailed butterflies, work which later stimulated his interest in medical genetics.

The success of his team of young, clinical research workers left less time for his clinical practice. He was appointed reader in medicine at the University of Liverpool, and, in 1963, became professor of medicine, a post he held until 1972. He founded the Nuffield unit of medical genetics, which he directed from 1963 to 1972. That year, he was elected president of the Royal College of Physicians, a post he held with great distinction and flair until 1977.

From 1977 to 1983, Clarke was director of the college's medical services study group, and, from 1983 to 1988, director of its research unit. Among many other activities, he served as president of the Royal Entomological Society and, much to his delight, president of the British Mule Society. He spent his later retirement in Liverpool, continuing his work on the genetics of butterflies, and in a characteristically broad range of medical research.

Cyril was a caring, if slightly eccentric, clinician, very much of the old school, who believed in minimal intervention. His advice to new staff on the use of drugs came, he claimed, straight from one of his teachers at Guy's, who, as he got older, had restricted his personal pharmacopoeia to morphia and sodium bicarbonate, and was not too liberal with the bicarbonate.

As professor of medicine, Clarke led his department with a light touch, preferring to let bright youngsters go their own way, but always around if they needed support. His remarkable flair and enthusiasm, and his ability to sniff out talent and to pick research areas of importance, was undoubtedly the major factor which led to the wonderful achievement of the rhesus team, and to the success of the Liverpool department as a major influence on the development of medical genetics.

As a person, Cyril was a complex mixture; alongside the lifelong schoolboy, constantly bubbling with enthusiasm and new ideas, he could also appear distant and sometimes difficult to approach, a reflection of his innate shyness. But he was warm and extremely loyal to his staff, and supported them throughout their careers, usually behind the scenes.

In 1935, Clarke married Frieda, or Feo, as she was always known, who became an integral part of his work and other activities, ranging from crewing for him on his annual small-boat racing - not a relaxing pastime as Cyril had been an Olympic trialist and hated losing - to breeding swallow-tailed butterflies in captivity. It was a remarkable partnership and he never fully recovered from her death in 1998. They are survived by three sons.

Cyril's work was widely recognised. He was elected a fellow of the Royal Society, and received many national and international awards. At the age of 88 years, still busy at his research, he wrote that he would very much like to know why butterflies have an XX chromosone complement in males and XY in females, yet the latter live much longer than the tempestuous XX males. "God moves in a mysterious way," he concluded.

webTitle: Site of industrial blight joins icons of world heritage

fields.headline: Site of industrial blight joins icons of world heritage
fields.trailText: Pealing church bells in Blaenavon yesterday morning announced the startling news: the south Wales town and its industry-scarred hills have been declared a world heritage site, joining the Taj Mahal and the pyramids.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Pealing church bells in Blaenavon yesterday morning announced the startling news: the south Wales town and its industry-scarred hills have been declared a world heritage site, joining the Taj Mahal and the pyramids.

The blighted landscape, pocked with mineshafts, tunnels, foundries, furnaces, chimneys and great rusting lumps of abandoned machinery, was regarded as an eyesore for most of the 20th century, and by the end as a painful reminder of thousands of lost jobs in the coal mines and iron works. But the earth holds a unique record of the development of the industrial revolution.

Early yesterday morning the news flashed by satellite from the Unesco meeting in Cairns, Australia, to the Working Men's Institute in the town: the UN committee had voted to add Blaenavon to the list of the world's most important sites, to be cherished and protected.

In the Corner Cafe customers greeted the news with delight, incredulity, and some cynicism. The town's population of 6,000 is half that of a century ago, and the main street has dozens of boarded up shops. Blaenavon remains an employment blackspot.

The leader of Torfaen county borough council, Brian Smith, said: "The history of the town is made up of stories of agony and hardship suffered by the workers. This award is a fitting tribute to all of them."

Blaenavon Ironworks opened in 1789 with three steam operated blast furnaces fed by the unlimited supply of local coal. It was one of the largest ironworks in the world, but the industry spread rapidly. The 8km by 6km world monument site holds remains of railways, canals, the town itself, the preserved ironworks and the pit mining m'useum, where some of the last working miners in Wales guide tourists through the maze of shafts.

The tunnel through the top of the mountain was once, at just under three kilometres, the longest in the world. It has been blocked by rockfalls, but was used in 1963 by villagers cut off by snow to get to the town.

At Cadw (Welsh Historic Monuments), Peter Wakelin, an inspector of ancient monuments whose work was crucial to the bid, described the valley as "a relic landscape". He said: "People keep making the comparison with the Taj Mahal, but aesthetic value is not the only criterion. In terms of historical importance Blaenavon is unquestionably far more important than the Taj Mahal."

webTitle: Fox gets down to business as Mexico dreams of change

fields.headline: Fox gets down to business as Mexico dreams of change
fields.trailText: Seventy-one years of one-party rule in Mexico ends today with the inauguration of President Vicente Fox, setting the clock ticking on his promises to eradicate pervasive corruption, reduce rampant poverty and attack widespread petty and organised crime.
fields.body:
Seventy-one years of one-party rule in Mexico ends today with the inauguration of President Vicente Fox, setting the clock ticking on his promises to eradicate pervasive corruption, reduce rampant poverty and attack widespread petty and organised crime.

It is a tough task and a potential time-bomb for the 6ft 5in former businessman who defeated the entrenched Institutional Revolutionary party by convincing Mexicans they could, and should, expect more than the old system provided.

"If we can wait 70 years to get rid of the PRI, we can hold on for a bit more," said Mercedes Leon, a domestic servant struggling with debt after having a secure steel door added to her slum home and who still dreams of installing plumbing. "I have faith things will get better. They have to."

Not that the high expectations seem to daunt Mr Fox, who is - having spent three years persuading voters to put their hopes in him and five months in the limbo-like transition period after winning the election - clearly eager to take office and get back on the campaign trail.

"The task of the president should be to inspire, which is why I am going to be a president who is always in the street, always outside with the citizens," he said after announcing his first cabinet. "That's why I have chosen such a professional team so that they can take care of the office work."

The Jesuit-educated former Coca-Cola executive's cabinet reeks of a dry business ethos reflecting his conviction that Mexico's salvation will come through efficient management and creative marketing.

"The next government will be a government of total quality that will produce results," the country's new leader said, promising a battery of quantitative indicators to chart progress in job creation, poverty reduction, corruption eradication and more.

webTitle: Scientists hope world's rarest macaw is not an ex-parrot

fields.headline: Have you seen this bird?
fields.standfirst: Scientists hope world's rarest macaw is not an ex-parrot
fields.trailText: The rarest bird in the world has disappeared from its perch in the north-east of Brazil, putting the future of its species in jeopardy.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The rarest bird in the world has disappeared from its perch in the north-east of Brazil, putting the future of its species in jeopardy.

The Spix's macaw was last seen 56 days ago by a team of biologists who have spent ten years tracking its daily movements. The vivid blue parrot is the last of its species living in the wild and has become an international cause celebre for conservationists.

The Brazilian Institute for the Environment is launching a search of the region near Curaça, 1,300 miles north of Rio de Janeiro, in an operation that has more in common with a police dragnet.

Three groups, made up of researchers and local people, will track through miles of the semi-arid scrubland where the bird lives, handing out leaflets with photographs and interviewing everyone they pass. It is believed that a villager believes he spotted the bird a month ago.

Yara de Melo Barros, the coordinator of the Permanent Committee for the Recovery of the Spix's macaw, said: "It is important to find the macaw because it is the only one of the species that has knowledge about living in the wild. This knowledge is fundamental if we are ever to reintroduce others that have been raised in captivity,"

During the dry season it is usual for the bird to leave the tree it lives in for most the year. However, it has never been away for such a long time before.

The academic infrastructure based around the parrot has the ultimate purpose of creating a community of Spix's macaws in the wild. Currently there are about 60 of the species in zoos and private aviaries around the world, mostly on other continents.

Experiments over the last few years showed that the lone Spix's, a male, has the capacity to rear young. He formed a partnership with the more common Illiger's macaw and the couple raised baby Illiger's from eggs that were sneaked into the couple's nest.

Next year, they plan to import five Spix's from the Philippines and introduce them into the wild with the hope they will procreate with the Brazilian male.

Maria Iolita Bampy, of the Brazilian Instutute for the Environment, said the team was working on the theory that he was not gone for good but parrots are monogamous and part of the worry stems from the fact that the Spix's partner, the Illiger's macaw, has already returned to the tree they have shared for several years.

"We hope that he has just found another girlfriend," Ms Bampy said.

webTitle: Auction rouses Greek passions for 'our Maria'

fields.headline: Auction rouses Greek passions for 'our Maria'
fields.trailText: At an auction this weekend at Drouot-Montaigne in Paris more than 2,000 of Maria Callas' possessions will go under the hammer. But the sale has caused an outcry in Greece
fields.body:
"She was a symbol fired into the very psyche of the opera-goer. She drove her audiences wild. She blazed through the skies and was burned out very early. But what years those were!" So wrote the New York Times critic Harold Schonberg in 1977 after the death at 53 of Maria Callas, one of the 20th century's operatic greats.

Twenty three years later, the fascination with the fiery diva lives on. Her recordings are more popular than ever; biographies are still appearing, Callas fans go misty-eyed evoking memories of her performances. And many dream of possessing something that the diva once owned, touched or wore - anything that makes the Maria myth more tangible.

Now they have their chance.

At an auction this weekend at Drouot-Montaigne in Paris more than 2,000 of the singer's possessions, including jewellery, paintings, furs and haute couture dresses, photo albums, letters, and sheet music, will go under the hammer.

But the sale, entitled Maria Callas, Souvenirs of a Legend, has caused an outcry in Greece, with many claiming the auction cheapens the memory of the woman they call "our Maria" and regard as Greek, even though she was born in America to Greek immigrant parents. However, others see it as another lost opportunity to reclaim part of the country's lost cultural heritage -an example of what is known as Elgin Marbles syndrome.

Callas fans in Greece bemoan the fact that the singer, the most influential diva of her era, remains largely unhonoured in her homeland.

The controversy around the auction has prompted Dimitris Avramopoulos, the mayor of Athens, to dispatch an emissary to Paris with a bulging wallet. His brief is to buy as many of the 400 lots as he can. Mr Avramopoulos has said Athens will create a museum to house the memorabilia in time for the 2004 Olympics.

Cultural icon

"For us Maria Callas was a symbol, a cultural icon," the mayor said. "She was born in New York but she was an Athenian in her soul. She gave a glorious continuity to the theatrical tradition, which was born in Athens, and which Maria Callas took a stage further. So for us to honour her as a city is not just sentimental, or an act of reverence, it's a cultural duty."

The singer's death triggered a bitter bat tle over her effects, which were eventually divided between her estranged husband, Giovanni Battista Meneghini, and her mother, Evangelia Kalogeropoulou.

Collection sold

On Meneghini's death in 1981, most of his collection was left to his housekeeper, who sold it to an Italian, Mario Tamassi. Callas's sister Jackie inherited her mother's collection, and then sold it to Callas biographer Nicolas Petsalis-Diomidis.

Frédéric Chambre, partner in Calmels-Chambre-Cohen, the auction house organising the sale, convinced the collectors to part with their treasures after they had turned down other approaches, which they deemed "too commercial".

One of the star items is an 18th century miniature of the Holy Family by the Italian painter Giandomenico Cignaroli. This was one of Callas's most prized possessions; she kept it in a red velvet case and took it with her everywhere she sang.

There is also an emerald green chinchilla evening coat, made for her by Puccini's granddaughter. A poignant photograph shows Callas, in the coat, posed between her husband Meneghini and her lover, the shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis.

But among the photographs and the haute couture , there are also petticoats, a girdle, two bras, and a blue corset - to the disgust of many Greeks.

"The legacy of Maria should be her art, not her lingerie," the film director Michael Cacoyannis, a friend of Callas, said.

Mr Avramopoulos vowed that Athens would not be bidding for such items - though some have urged the city to buy them if only to destroy them. "We will consider bidding only for what we would view as appropriate for a museum," he said. "We don't want her personal stuff."

webTitle: Rats take larger bites of Big Apple

fields.headline: Rats take larger bites of Big Apple
fields.trailText: Everything but crime is rising in the city that likes to think of itself as the capital of the world: tourism, employment, housing costs, congestion, self-regard - and rats.
fields.body:
Everything but crime is rising in the city that likes to think of itself as the capital of the world: tourism, employment, housing costs, congestion, self-regard - and rats.

This last index of both prosperity and poverty is now an Official Problem, with a deputy mayor appointed as rat tsar, $600,000 (£420,000) set aside for public education about rats, legislation proposed and a rat conference held at Columbia University in Manhattan.

About 250 academics, health officials, politicians and administrators at the conference heard a rallying cry from Randy Dupree, a rat expert. "Twenty years ago this city had a concerted effort to fight rats," he said. "That stopped and now we've seen a burgeoning of the rodent population. What we need is everyone to join in a war on rats."

But good intentions are not enough, said biologist Bruce Colvin, with the city's rats living longer, breeding faster and eating better all the time while growing resistant to poisons.

"If you're chasing critters up and down alleyways, you're missing the point," he said. "You have to change the environment. You provide the food, they do the sex. That's the formula."

Some estimates put the rat population at 8m - an exaggeration, says Mr Colvin - against an official human count of 7.3m, which does not include an illegal immigrant population of perhaps 2m.

Both groups are served by about 17,000 restaurants, most of them proud of their contribution to what the city believes is the highest-quality and most diverse cuisine on the planet.

They prefer not to dwell on one element that is of particular interest to Mr Colvin. "For rats, grease is a high-protein food source," said the biologist. "It allows them to kick up their sex drive. You know the rest."

Deputy mayor Joseph Lhota, who heads the campaign to persuade people to take greater care of their rubbish, said that this year the city had carried out 30,000 inspections, 51,000 exterminations and cleaned up 5,000 open spaces.

His boss, New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani, has had to contend with demonstrators on the steps of city hall chanting: "One rat, two rats, three rats, four; everywhere I look there's more and more," and "Fumigation is a right, not just for the rich and white."

And it was left to Mr Giuliani to reassert New York's pre-eminence in this field, as in all others. "We make unprecedented efforts to kill rats," he said. "We kill more of them than any place else. We probably lead the country in rat-killing."

webTitle: Australian PM told to say sorry for stolen generation

fields.headline: Australian PM told to say sorry for stolen generation
fields.standfirst: Senate increases pressure on Howard over post-war policy that tore aboriginal children from their families
fields.trailText: Australia's prime minister, John Howard, came under renewed pressure yesterday to apologise to aborigines for the way children were forcibly removed from their families by state welfare services after the second world war and brought up in children's institutions and white foster homes.
fields.body:
Australia's prime minister, John Howard, came under renewed pressure yesterday to apologise to aborigines for the way children were forcibly removed from their families by state welfare services after the second world war and brought up in children's institutions and white foster homes.

A report by an influential senate committee called on Mr Howard to apologise in parliament, and recommended the creation of a reparations tribunal to deal with aborigines' compensation claims for the "stolen generation".

But the government rejected the need for a tribunal. Its member on the senate committee, Helen Coonan, claimed that a landmark court case, which recently found against two aborigines, had "established pretty well conclusively that there was no wholesale policy of removal".

Aiden Ridgeway, an aborigine Democratic party senator, said: "It's misleading for the government to suggest that two [failed] claims lead to a conclusion that there wasn't a widespread policy in place that led to the forcible removal of children."

Mr Ridgeway said a reparations tribunal would be a cheaper solution to solving aboriginal grievances than for the government to continue to contest them in the courts.

In August, a federal judge cited lack of evidence in dismissing compensation claims by Lorna Cubillo and Peter Gunner, who were taken from their families almost 60 years ago. But the judge said his ruling did not refute the existence of a stolen generation.

The UN's human rights committee criticised Mr Howard's government in July for failing to compensate properly aborigines who had been forcibly removed from their families.

The National Sorry Day Committee said that Mr Howard's refusal to apologise was exacerbating the breach between the government and the aboriginal community.

"It hurts all of us that the pain continues, and as each month goes by there's more damage to our people," said the Sorry Day Committee's co-chair, Audrey Kinnear. "Some of our people haven't even been able to find their families, and they haven't been able to have access to counselling."

However, in a sign that the political tide could be turning against Mr Howard, Peter Costello, the federal treasurer who is widely tipped to succeed him as leader of the Liberal party, agreed to join a reconciliation march in Melbourne on Sunday.

Mr Howard excused himself from joining the parade, saying that he was committed to attending an annual Liberal party supporters' function on the day. But at least three other members of his government, including the aboriginal affairs and health ministers, will join the march.

The Melbourne march comes at the end of a 10-year process of reconciliation, which has frequently been frustrated by the government. Judges, politicians and activists have sought to get Mr Howard to agree to a programme reconciling the white population with the 400,000 aborigines. A key symbolic part of this is an apologetic acknowledgement of the bloody and often hidden history of discrimination by the settlers against the indigenous minority.

The life expectancy of aborigines continues to be almost 20 years less than that of the white population. Many indigenous Australians in remote rural communities are poverty-stricken, and also suffer from higher than average rates of problem drinking, unemployment and imprisonment.

webTitle: LineOne goes on sale as owners find it doesn't fit

fields.headline: LineOne goes on sale as owners find it doesn't fit
fields.trailText: The widely anticipated consolidation of Europe's leading internet service providers took another step yesterday when the joint owners of LineOne confirmed that a buyer was being sought for the portal.
fields.body:
The widely anticipated consolidation of Europe's leading internet service providers took another step yesterday when the joint owners of LineOne confirmed that a buyer was being sought for the portal.

BT's Openworld division and United News & Media said the 50:50 joint venture "no longer fits with either company's plans", and that a new owner was being sought.

Investment bank Merrill Lynch has sent out information to potential buyers; LineOne is said to have been valued at around £340m.

Analysts believe LineOne - which has 1.4m registered users - is likely to be swallowed up by a leading European player seeking to increase its presence in the UK.

Germany's T-Online, Spain's Terra Network, Italy's Tiscali and the UK's own Freeserve, which is in merger talks with France's Wanadoo, are seen as potential suitors.

Analysts have long predicted that the dominant internet service providers in each domestic market would eventually swallow up smaller competitors. Tiscali is in the process of taking over World Online of Holland, while Terra has already bought its American competitor, Lycos.

The sale of LineOne fits with United News & Media's stated intention of exiting consumer publishing activities after the sale of the Express Newspapers group. It plans to concentrate on business-focused internet activities.

BT, meanwhile, is seeking to sell its non-core assets to reduce a debt load of up to £30bn, and has already said that the parent company will be split into four divisions.

The valuation being placed upon LineOne is indicative of the declining stock market fortunes of the UK's internet companies. Earlier this year, LineOne shareholders were talking privately about floating the business for between £1bn and £1.5bn.

However, a fall in value of internet service providers led by Freeserve has led to wrangling among the shareholders and management instability. In the past six months alone, LineOne has lost two chief executives as Ajay Chowdhury and then his successor, Andy Harwood, quit the firm.

LineOne courted controversy in July when it decided to withdraw its unmetered net access service shortly after finding it was not viable.

BT, meanwhile, is seeking to sell its non-core assets to reduce a debt load of up to £30bn, and has already said that the parent company will be split into four divisions. The valuation being placed upon LineOne is indicative of the declining stock market fortunes of the UK's internet companies. Earlier this year, LineOne shareholders were talking privately about floating the business for between £1bn and £1.5bn. However, a fall in value of internet service providers led by Freeserve has led to wrangling among the shareholders and management instability. In the past six months alone, LineOne has lost two chief executives as Ajay Chowdhury and then his successor, Andy Harwood, quit the firm. LineOne courted controversy in July when it decided to withdraw its unmetered net access service shortly after finding it was not viable.

webTitle: NTT pays £7bn for AT&T wireless stake

fields.headline: Ambitious in America
fields.standfirst: NTT pays £7bn for AT&T wireless stake
fields.trailText: Japanese mobile phone firm NTT DoCoMo yesterday gained a foothold in the world's largest telecoms market by paying $9.8bn (£7bn) for a 16% stake in US group AT&T Wireless.
fields.body:
Japanese mobile phone firm NTT DoCoMo yesterday gained a foothold in the world's largest telecoms market by paying $9.8bn (£7bn) for a 16% stake in US group AT&T Wireless.

The Japanese group has bought minority stakes in several companies around the world in order to encourage the adoption of its technology as a global standard. Keiji Tachikawa, DoCoMo's chief executive, said yesterday: "We have completed our expansion in the US and Europe."

Analysts welcomed the deal. Linda Mutschler, wireless analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the new ownership structure was good for AT&T Wireless - the US's third largest mobile phone business - as it gave it access to the next generation of high-speed technology and extra capital.

The wireless company, which is to be spun out of parent AT&T next year, is expected to use its $6.2bn share of the deal to win more domestic licences.

AT&T, the group's parent company, is to use the $3.6bn it will receive to pay down a $62bn debt burden. AT&T Wireless expects to be among the first in north America to use the new global standard, UMTS, or universal mobile telecommunications system.

DoCoMo has 50 times more wireless customers than AT&T. NTT will pay about $24 a share for its stake, according to Merrill Lynch.

fields.headline: Study confirms polling flaws
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Canadian psychologists who tested Palm Beach county's double-column "butterfly" ballot on 116 volunteers found that 20% of them voted for the wrong candidate, compared with no errors among voters who used a traditional single column ballot,  writes Tim Radford.
fields.body:
Canadian psychologists who tested Palm Beach county's double-column "butterfly" ballot on 116 volunteers found that 20% of them voted for the wrong candidate, compared with no errors among voters who used a traditional single column ballot, writes Tim Radford.

"It didn't take a rocket scientist to do this study," said Robert Sinclair, who reports on the test in Edmonton, Alberta, in Nature magazine next week. "Why didn't somebody do this before the election? You wouldn't have had this fiasco."

More than 462,000 presidential votes were cast in Palm Beach. A 20% error rate would add up to more than 90,000 votes. Hundreds of US voters claimed they voted for rightwinger Pat Buchanan when they meant to vote for Al Gore.

fields.headline: Water profits suffer Ofwat's bite
fields.trailText: United Utilities and Pennon, the owners of two of Britain's big privatised water companies, yesterday said the regulatory regime of Ofwat was adding unnecessary costs to their business. UU, the multi-utility that owns North West Water, said the capital markets had not accepted the regulator's view that water was a low risk industry.
fields.body:
United Utilities and Pennon, the owners of two of Britain's big privatised water companies, yesterday said the regulatory regime of Ofwat was adding unnecessary costs to their business. UU, the multi-utility that owns North West Water, said the capital markets had not accepted the regulator's view that water was a low risk industry.

John Roberts, the chief executive, said that in practice the debt market regarded the industry as high risk because of the danger of regulatory intervention. Companies were raising funds for 30-year projects, but the capital markets were worried about the impact of the next regulatory price review in four years' time.

Ken Harvey, the chairman of Pennon, which owns South West Water, said the price regime was preventing the company from raising money to develop Viridor, the non-regulated side of its business.

"Because of the effect of the regulatory regime we do not now have the financial capabilities to grow Viridor through acquisition," he said.

The interim results of UU and Pennon show the impact of price cuts imposed by Sir Ian Byatt, director general of Ofwat, in his last price review before stepping down in July.

UU said first-half pre-tax profits fell £64.7m to £168.5m. It has, however, booked a £191.2m exceptional profit from the sale of its energy supply business but the group has been forced to postpone the flotation of its Norweb Telecom business. Shares ended 15.5p down at 709p while Pennon closed 50p down at 697.5p.

Measures to control leakage since the 1995 drought have resulted in the saving of 1.8m cubic metres of water a day, enough to supply the daily needs of 12m people, head of the National Audit Office Sir John Bourn told MPs.

webTitle: BP chief and Glaxo win high praise

fields.headline: BP chief and Glaxo win high praise
fields.standfirst: Business leaders pick their winners
fields.trailText: The business community has named GlaxoSmithKline as Britain's most admired company even though the merger creating the pharmceutical giant has yet to be completed.
fields.body:
The business community has named GlaxoSmithKline as Britain's most admired company even though the merger creating the pharmceutical giant has yet to be completed.

The runner-up was BP - whose chief executive, Sir John Browne, was named the country's most admired business leader for the second consecutive year.

It will be a comfort to Sir John, who in company with other oil company leaders, was widely criticised for allowing forecourts to run dry during the recent protest against high fuel prices.

BP has been undergoing a period of radical change during the past few years.

It has swallowed two US oil companies, Amoco and Arco, and relaunched itself as an environmentally friendly energy business. It has abandoned its long standing shield logo on favour of a symbolically more friendly green, yellow and white flower.

Sir John, however, has yet to prove to the environmental lobby that BP has truly changed its culture. Record first-half profits of $5.5bn (£3.8bn), up from $1.9bn, did nothing to allay fears that the new BP was the old hard-edged money making machine in a different guise.

The most admired awards, organised by the magazine Management Today in association with eLoyalty, give business leaders the opportunity to judge their peers.

The BP boss won more votes as top business leader than the two other short-listed candidates put together. They were Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, the international mobile phone group, and Gerry Robinson, boss of Granada Compass.

That was not the only bad news for Mr Robinson. To his chagrin, new entrant Manchester United toppled his company from its place as the most admired company in the leisure and hotel sector. Mr Robinson has overseen a string of deals in recent years, culminating in the merger between Granada and Compass to create a huge catering and hotels group.

While the BP, Vodafone and Granada Compass bosses lorded it over their peers last year's nominees, Sir Richard Branson, Sir Brian Pitman and Sir Geoff Mulcahy, all failed to make it to the short list.

GlaxoSmithKline, the result of the yet to be completed merger between Glaxo Welcome and SmithKline Beecham, ended Tesco's three year reign as the country's most admired company.

Last year the two pharmaceutical groups were runners-up to Tesco.

The travails at BT and Marks & Spencer are reflected in their poor showing in the most admired company table.

BT, in 93rd place, was 53 places lower than PizzaExpress, while M&S could only make the 206th slot.

Land Securities, the property group, emerged as the British company most admired for its financial soundness, beating GlaxoSmithKline and Shell Transport & Trading in second and third place.

Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, which in effect put itself up for sale after regulatory price changes undermined its profits, was rated 239 in the financial soundness league.

Its new American owner, Western Power Distribution, has already run into problems, but of the legal sort. The high court ruled that its plan to award the contract to run its Welsh Water subsidiary to United Utilities breached European commission procurement legislation which required the contract to be put out to tender.

GlaxoSmithKline topped the list of companies with value as a long-term investment.

Manchester United came in 11th, two places behind Vodafone and ahead of all the big clearing banks.

webTitle: Ballots and black burgers add to drama in Florida

fields.headline: Ballots and black burgers add to drama in Florida
fields.standfirst:
Convoy of votes sets off as presidential battle rages on
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: With television news helicopters fluttering in its wake, the convoy bearing 462,000 ballots from Palm Beach set off yesterday morning, accompanied by sheriff's officers, for its eight-hour drive into Tallahassee and the history books.
fields.body:
With television news helicopters fluttering in its wake, the convoy bearing 462,000 ballots from Palm Beach set off yesterday morning, accompanied by sheriff's officers, for its eight-hour drive into Tallahassee and the history books.

To the US media, this was a repeat of the police pursuit of OJ Simpson even though the crimes being alleged by both sides this time are bloodless - so far. All that was needed to prolong this saga was for Cuban-Americans to hijack the van and ignite the votes.

Anyone familiar with the novels of Floridian writer Carl Hiassen, which are packed with dodgy politicians and dark deeds in the alligator state, will be familiar with the scene and some of the characters who have emerged in Florida in the last three weeks.

Here are the latest ingredients in this cross between a political thriller, a morality tale and a soap opera:

 Ballots from Palm Beach and Miami-Dade, which number more than 1m in total, are due to arrive in Tallahassee by 5pm today. Circuit judge N Sanders Sauls had ordered that the ballots should be taken to the state capital so that they are instantly available if he orders a recount.

The Gore team had asked for only 14,000 disputed ballots - the subject of a legal action that starts tomorrow - but the Bush camp asked for them all, a strategy which the Democrats say is mischievous and designed to delay and confuse.

 In another action involving absentee ballots in Seminole county, the Bush team attempted to remove Nikki Clark, the judge hearing this case, on the grounds that her attempts to become an appeal court judge had twice been rebuffed by governor Jeb Bush, brother of George W. They failed.

 State Republican politicians continued to move yesterday to set up a special session that would give Florida's 25 electoral college votes to Mr Bush, regardless of what the courts decide.

Andrew's, around the corner from the supreme court, has been one of the chief watering-holes for lawyers, journalists and commentators in Tallahassee over the last few weeks. It offers a "Jeb Burger" for lunch, which it describes as a "blackened" burger served with mushrooms and cheese.

Mr Bush said yesterday that he would be ready to sign a bill that would make his brother president, adding: "I think people expect governors to say 'yea' or 'nay'." Such action, say his Democrat opponents, would indeed create a blackened Jeb Bush and they suggest they would have him for lunch if he went ahead.

For the Gore camp, the lead character now in Tallahassee is undoubtedly David Boies, the lawyer who successfully took on Microsoft on behalf of the government. He has taken over the front-man role from the former secretary of state Warren Christopher and presents the reasonable face of the team in contrast to the more combative front men for the Bush camp, the other former secretary of state, James Baker, and the would-be vice-president, Dick Cheney.

After the failed attempts to remove her, Judge Nikki Clark, 49, has now emerged as another lead character in the drama. A registered Democrat, she must decide whether to exclude from the count absentee ballots in Seminole county that were legitimised by Republicans who added missing voter identification numbers. This is seen as the case that could just change the result. If Judge Clark excludes the votes, Mr Gore would be in the lead - until the inevitable appeal.

Not that the Seminole case is the only one arousing fresh attention. The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People has announced plans to sue Florida over voting irregularities that prevented many black residents from casting their votes.

So a governor with a burger named after him, a couple of feisty judges, a smart lawyer, a convoy and the whiff of racism. All that remains is a final twist in the plot.
