webTitle: Bravado and fear over death of a neighbour

fields.headline: Bravado and fear over death of a neighbour
fields.standfirst:
Young people regularly carry knives and many will not go out alone - welcome to the estate that was home to Damilola Taylor

More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: "It's hard growing up here," said 15-year-old Spencer Seed. "You don't know when people are going to come up behind you. Peckham's got so bad."
fields.body:
"It's hard growing up here," said 15-year-old Spencer Seed. "You don't know when people are going to come up behind you. Peckham's got so bad."

Spencer and his 13-year-old sister, Cheryl, had just been to see the stairwell in which Damilola Taylor died - a place that has become a shrine of flowers, cards and soft toys.

The pair lived "just over there", they said, pointing across concrete gallerys and landings, past the bulldozers that are tearing apart some of the old buildings. They did not like the new part of the estate much either and now the murder had made things worse.

Spencer was robbed in February by children his own age as he came out of a chip shop."I had just spent £10 and they stole all my food," he said. "There was three of them and I was on my own."

The pair said children regularly carried weapons in Peckham. Spencer said: "I've had a knife put on me three times here. I know lots of people round here who carry knives."

Cheryl felt scared unless she is with one of her brothers. Fingering a chunky gold necklace, she said: "If I went out on my own my jewellery would get nicked off of me and so would my mobile phone."

Spencer said it was easier for Cheryl because she had her brothers for protection. He did not have anybody and he was keen to stress that he did not carry a knife. "If they can't fight with their own hands they shouldn't carry weapons."

Like most other children on the estate, Cheryl and Spencer have been talking about the murder and picking up rumours. Spencer said: "I heard two boys talking about it and how they know the person who killed the boy."

In the window of the heavily-shuttered shop just one landing above where Damilola died, a sign reads: "Only two children/youths at a time."

The shopkeeper said he could not cope with more. "They are just nasty kids. They come and steal things and pinch things from the till and shoplift."

Damilola must have passed here in the seconds before his death, he must have turned the corners in this rat-run of almost 20 miles of deck landings. He would have run past the workers using heavy machinery to remove concrete amid clouds of dust, he may have glimpsed the piles of rubbish. He could have caught the strong smell of urine in these corridors.

Downstairs are yellow signs appealing for witnesses to the murder but in spite of all the talk very few people have anything to say. Sade Bikini passes the signs as she comes up the rank stairs that lead to the scene of the child's death. A 16-year-old pupil at Alwyn girls' school, she was sure that those of her friends fuelling the rumour mill knew nothing about what really happened.

She was also adamant that North Peckham estate was getting a bad press. She did not fear its dark corners, she said. The estate was not as bad as everyone made out.

"Some of this gang stuff people are coming out with is rubbish," she said. "The Peckham Boys don't hang around here. It's not that violent and I don't feel threatened."

Dressed in school uniform and in high spirits, six girls waited for a bus on Rye Lane. Latita, 16, said she did not like to go out alone. Her mother laughed at her when she asked to be accompanied from her home to the bus stop. "The only way to feel safe is to go out with my friends. We won't get touched if we stick together."

Further up the road, outside Warwick Park school two boys watched children pour out of the building. Both had been excluded from their Camberwell secondary schools. Rashshi, 14, said a project for pupils who had been in trouble at school, the Boyhood to Manhood Foundation, had helped him cope with his anger.

"It's racism that has made me angry, especially from the teachers. If a teacher sees me scuffling with a white kid, then I'm always the bad guy."

His 15-year-old friend said Damilola's murder had stirred up fears about gangs. "Black kids get accused of being in gangs, but often all we're doing is playing in a group. If it's black kids, we're a gang. If it's white kids, they're just playing football," he explains.

"Gangs have existed for a long time. But that's because groups of people from the same area hang out. There's no parks, no community centre to keep us off the streets."

fields.headline: Law review tackles board pay-offs
fields.standfirst: Directors' contracts to be limited to one year under DTI proposals
fields.trailText: Directors would be prohibited from having service contracts lasting more than a year under plans for reform of company law published yesterday.
fields.body:
Directors would be prohibited from having service contracts lasting more than a year under plans for reform of company law published yesterday.

But they could be given protection from activists such as the animal rights campaigners who targeted Huntingdon Life Sciences. The review suggests directors' home addresses should be kept private and that shareholder registers should be available only for legitimate company purposes.

The report, commissioned by the Department of Trade and Industry, accepts the principle that shareholders should be able to know where their directors live but says that harassment of their families by activists is unacceptable.

The proposals are the latest from a fundamental review of Britain's Victorian legal framework, ordered by Margaret Beckett when she was trade and industry secretary in 1998. Yesterday's report is the last consultation document before a final report is published in the spring. That is to be the basis for a white paper and legislation in the next parliament.

The report sets out a drastic simplification of the law for smaller companies to make it easier to set up and run small businesses.

The contentious issue of boardroom pay is the subject of a separate study within the DTI. But this report does call for an end to excessive pay-offs, achieved by legislating for the one-year maximum contract period which was proposed by the Cadbury committee in 1992.

Relatively few companies have reduced contracts to one year, although most have come down to two years. The longer the contract period, the bigger the pay-off a director can expect when fired.

Under yesterday's proposals directors would be allowed an initial three-year contract but after that would be limited to one year unless the annual meeting approved a longer period of tenure.

On the issue of directors' responsibilities, the review panel rejected arguments to incor porate social and environmental matters.

John Parkinson, professor of law at Bristol University, said yesterday it would not be practicable for directors to have divided duties so their responsibilities under law would be to shareholders only. "These are ethical or political matters which are not appropriate for the courts."

But he argued that the plan for an operating and financial review would bring transparency on social and environmental as well as financial matters. Companies will not be required to include social and environmental issues in the OFR, however. Directors will decide whether they are "material" to the company.

webTitle: Scotia resubmits cancer drug to FDA

fields.headline: Scotia resubmits cancer drug to FDA
fields.trailText: The anti-cancer treatment drug Foscan, which was rejected by US regulators in September, is to be resubmitted by its developer Scotia for approval along with results from additional patient trials.
fields.body:
The anti-cancer treatment drug Foscan, which was rejected by US regulators in September, is to be resubmitted by its developer Scotia for approval along with results from additional patient trials.

Scotia, one of Britain's biggest biotechnology firms, said yesterday it would submit the amended application to the US food and drug administration with data from 83 patient trials in order to satisfy the regulator about the efficacy of the drug.

Scotia shares dropped more than 80% on news of the initial rejection by the FDA but were up yesterday by 39.7% to 22p after the resubmission was announced.

Rob Dow, chief executive of Scotia said: "Delays are commonplace in pharmaceuticals. We all try to avoid them but we have also come to expect them. Approval can be a complex interactive process these days."

The delay has put back development of Foscan by about 12 months and left Scotia, which only has funding to take it through to March, with a cash flow crisis. Dr Dow said the company would consider all options, including selling out to a competitor, in the race to raise funds.

The FDA decision on Foscan, which has cost £25m-£30m to develop over two years, is expected by September. Analysts estimate the drug could generate between £50m and £250m in sales for Scotia.

webTitle: Harvey Nichols may let surfers go on splurges

fields.headline: Harvey Nichols may let surfers go on splurges
fields.trailText: The therapy shopping trips to Harvey Nichols, as practised by Ab Fab's Patsy and Edina, may soon be a thing of the past.
fields.body:
The therapy shopping trips to Harvey Nichols, as practised by Ab Fab's Patsy and Edina, may soon be a thing of the past.

The upmarket department store is considering whether to expand the scope of its planned information website in order to handle transactions.

Recent research indicated that a transactional site would not generate sufficient sales to make a profit. But the board is still considering the issue.

The company yesterday reported a 10% rise in first-half pre-tax profits to £6.7m, but said like for like sales had slowed during the first eight weeks of the second half.

The chairman, Dickson Poon, said the recent volatile trading was partly explained by the fuel blockades which put off potential shoppers, the floods and persistent adverse weather conditions.

The group's e-commerce initiatives were on target and the informational website would be operational next month.

The company plans to open stores in Edinburgh and Manchester in 2002 and 2003. At present it operates in Knightsbridge and Leeds.

Its first overseas licensed store, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, opened in May. Directors said no clear trading pattern had yet emerged.

fields.headline: Terrified settlers beat hasty retreat
fields.standfirst:
Israelis lured into living in West Bank and Gaza are fleeing under threat of Palestinian violence
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: It was the commuting that got to Yossi Warshenbrot: a white-knuckle ride along a lonely stretch of road, squinting at the hilltops for possible attackers. It ground him down, until finally he left his snug home on the West Bank for a rented flat near Tel Aviv.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Migdalim, West Bank
fields.body:
It was the commuting that got to Yossi Warshenbrot: a white-knuckle ride along a lonely stretch of road, squinting at the hilltops for possible attackers. It ground him down, until finally he left his snug home on the West Bank for a rented flat near Tel Aviv.

"Do you have any idea what it is like to drive with an Uzi by your right hand, and a pistol in your left?" he says. "It's not a good feeling."

Mr Warshenbrot, his wife Rikki and their two small children are joining the exodus of Jewish settlers from the West Bank and Gaza that has been prompted by two months of Palestinian insurrection.

From the lonely outposts that dot the stony hilltops of the West Bank, the settlers have watched an intensifying struggle for control of the roads turn them into prisoners in the Israeli equivalent of a suburban dream home.

"I was shot at, my neighbour's car was shot at until it looked like something from the mafia - full of bullet holes," Mr Warshenbrot says. "Just a miracle saved him."

Drive-by shootings, and stoning of passing vehicles on the settler bypass roads, was certainly not what Mr Warshenbrot, a marketing executive in a hi-tech firm, had in mind three years ago when he moved his family from the big city to Migdalim.

The secular settlement, population 40 Jewish families, is set on a hilltop overlooking four Palestinian villages. Mr Warshenbrot paid about £30,000 for his starter home with a garden. He sniffs at what that would have bought him inside Israel's borders.

Dmitri Geffen owns a grander, two-storey house on the other side of Migdalim. He has a wide terrace with a glorious view of desert hills rolling down to the Jordan river, which is decorated with ship's bells and anchors from his seafaring past.

"Everybody is afraid," says Mr Geffen, who is now a security officer who patrols the settlement with a pistol on his hip. "Nobody wants shooting or stone-throwing."

He argues that successive Israeli governments have put the non-ideological settlers in an impossible situation, offering economic inducements to move to the West Bank and Gaza even while negotiating with the Palestinians to hand back the territories occupied by Israel since 1967. The result, he says, is total confusion, and the uncertainty is harrowing.

"We came here without force, and I hope we will leave here without force, not from the government of Israel or from the Palestinians," he says. "If our government tells us to leave, we will certainly leave."

Outsiders - including Israelis - generally brand all of the 200,000 Jewish settlers dangerous extremists who believe that God wanted the West Bank and Gaza to be the exclusive preserve of the Jews forever.

Palestinians call the red-roofed outposts "the thorn in our throat", breaking their would-be state into disjointed blobs on a map; Israeli liberals say they stand in the way of a negotiated peace.

But a survey in May 1999 by the Peace Now movement found that 53% of West Bank settlers had moved to the occupied territories for "non-ideological" reasons: cheap housing, great views, and income tax rebates. Nearly 34% were also prepared to evacuate in return for reasonable compensation.

Peace Now believes the last two months have driven those numbers up further still. A poll for the Yediot Ahronoth newspaper suggests 10% of the West Bank settlers are planning their escape.

Ami Katz, a peace activist from the small, religious settlement of Metzed, south of Jerusalem, explains: "First, it's because of the security situation, which is growing harder every day, with the shooting and throwing rocks. Second, people see that in any negotiations some settlements will be given back. They are going to have to leave the place anyway, so why stay around to be the last person to turn out the lights?"

But after being encouraged by successive Israeli governments to move to the West Bank and Gaza, the departing settlers do not want to leave empty-handed.

Mr Warshenbrot is already totting up his demand for compensation. His housing costs have doubled this month; in addition to the £400 mortgage payment on his house in Migdalim, he has had to shell out an advance on a flat in the Tel Aviv area, where the rent is also £400.

In the short term, he wants the government to pay for his move. In the long run, he expects the state to buy him a new house, somewhere inside Israel's borders.

"What do I buy with $40,000? Nothing. Why did I put my life on the line? Also nothing. So I think the government should give us a solution where I can buy an alternative, or move to an equal situation," he says.

Other families moved first, and then thought about the payout.

Efrat Artzi and her husband, Eyal, left a £70,000 house in the settlement of Hermesh, which lies just seven four miles kilometres outside Israel's borders, to move back home to the Hod HaSharon kibbutz - where the prime minister, Ehud Barak, was raised - on November 2, a day after her windscreen was shattered, spewing glass over her 18-month-old daughter. "When will I go home? Not until I feel I can drive on the roads with my daughter," she says.

Despite the temporary dislocation, the Warshenbrots and the Artzis are relatively lucky. They have somewhere to go. Most cannot afford to leave.

"I have a sister in Petah Tikva. I can go there for two weeks or so, but after that she is going to say: 'Hey, what is this, are you going to settle in my house too?' " Mr Geffen says.

Unless Israeli politicians can first agree among themselves on how much land to transfer to Palestinian control, and then reach a settlement with Yasser Arafat that at last will define the borders of Israel, and the new state, he is trapped.

"Somebody has to tell me: 'This is your house, fight for it, or you have to leave in two years,' then I will know," he adds. "Somebody has to tell me, officially: 'This is not yours'." he says.

"Now it is Barak, in two or three months, it could be Ariel Sharon, and he might say 'No mister, you can stay here for ever'. I have to know."

fields.headline: Reacting at leisure
fields.trailText: Now that the British army's armoured cars are to have their speed restricted (Army puts 30mph limit on Warriors, November 30), presumably the EU Rapid Reaction Force will have to be re-named.
fields.body:
Now that the British army's armoured cars are to have their speed restricted (Army puts 30mph limit on Warriors, November 30), presumably the EU Rapid Reaction Force will have to be re-named.
Terry Hyde
Edinburgh

 Congratulations on naming and shaming Dr Len Fisher for suggesting Yorkshire puddings and potatoes should be eaten last (Physics finds plug for great gravy drain, November 30). As all right-thinking people know, Yorkshire puddings are eaten as a separate course before the meat and potatoes.
Donald S Gill
Earley, Berks
dong@easicom.com

 The real irony about spell-checkers (Letters, November 30) is that they check spelling, not spells.
Dr KJ Vines
Plymouth
KVines@plymouth.ac.uk

 I am 85 years old and still greatly enjoy having a go at the Guardian Quick Crossword. Today I had finished it by 12 noon, but I must say this was most unusual. I was greatly chuffed. I wonder how many other 85-year-olds share my enthusiasm?
Margaret R Kewell
Teignmouth, Devon

 What the C of E won't be passing on to parishes when it invites them to erect mobile phone masts on church steeples (Money for spire hire is heaven sent, November 30), is this: the deal includes ugly cabins containing equipment cooled by noisy fans, usually erected over graves, as planned in my historic parish.
Jackie Lloyd
Dunchurch, Warwickshire

fields.headline: Patten fury at Tory euro 'hysteria'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is hamstrung by "hysterical" Conservative and media hostility to the EU as he faces next week's landmark Nice summit, where agreement is vital to ensure that former communist countries can join, Chris Patten warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is hamstrung by "hysterical" Conservative and media hostility to the EU as he faces next week's landmark Nice summit, where agreement is vital to ensure that former communist countries can join, Chris Patten warned yesterday.

Speaking in Brussels, the EU's external relations commissioner and former Conservative party chairman launched a fierce counter-attack against Eurosceptics who were really "anti-Europeans" limiting the government's room for manoeuvre.

He conceded that Mr Blair had to sell any deal to a hostile public, but signalled a clear difference with the prime minister by saying there was a case for dropping the national veto on indirect taxation - one of the government's "red lines" for the summit.

"As we come towards Nice the whole thing is debated in this frenzied atmosphere of a superstate just around the corner," a combative Mr Patten said in an interview with the Guardian.

"Anyone who knows anything about what is happening in Europe knows that this is unutterable bilge. The French are never going to be Massachusetts, the Germans are never going to be Iowa. We're never going to be California, and not just because of the climate."

Mr Blair, who was meeting the summit chairman, French president Jacques Chirac, in his Sedgefield constituency last night, has insisted he will not shift to majority voting on tax or social security matters.

Diplomats say he can count on the support of Ireland, Luxembourg and probably Sweden over tax, but could be isolated on social security, linked to the free movement of people in the single market.

All 15 EU members except Italy and Belgium have objections to removing the veto in some area. Mr Patten also predicted that the government would not succeed in stifling debate about the single currency until after the next elections and should enunciate "broad principles" beyond the five economic tests set out by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

He said he enjoyed "civilised discussions" with the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, the chief spokesman for the "superstate by stealth" argument that dominates Conservative policy on the EU.

But he added: "People say of course we can be hostile to Britain joining the euro but positive about Europe. But they never are positive about Europe. And the debate is more and more about the little green men who live under the bed."

Mr Patten said he sympathised with recent outbursts against the Eurosceptics. The prime minister was obliged to hit back, "as John Major had to".

"We can't go on getting the best for Britain without tackling these hysterical criticisms head on. They don't actually have the bottle to say, 'Okay, we think Britain should be out of the EU'. But that's implicit."

Earlier, Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, voiced the widely held fear that Nice may repeat the 1997 summit failure in Amsterdam to grasp the nettle of voting reform.

He put the chances of success in Nice at no more than 50-50, warning that on "the real hot potato" of more majority voting, member states were deadlocked.

But diplomats said Mr Prodi was deliberately lowering expectations of an outcome which will almost certainly be disappointing for the commission, but will probably include the minimal institutional changes needed for enlargement to proceed.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, also sounded a cautionary note on the likelihood of substantial reform at Nice.

He predicted that most of the proposals for specific moves towards majority voting would fail because "one country or other objects to pretty well all that is currently on the presidency's shopping list".

The government has signalled readiness to move to majority voting on as many as 25 areas out of a total of 50 tabled by the French EU presidency up for consideration.

But despite Eurosceptic claims that this represents a huge shift away from national sovereignty, majority voting already decides the vast bulk of EU policies: only about 73 treaty articles out of a total of 700 retain the right of national veto. More than 85% of EU decisions are taken by qualified majority each year, including single market issues, trade policy and agriculture.

webTitle: Letter: Shahid Malik's right to reply

fields.headline: Right to reply
fields.trailText: Irrespective of accuracy, I suppose it's an honour of sorts for a humble "Burnley boy" to be mentioned four times in as many weeks in Matthew Norman's Diary - truly, I am not worthy.
fields.body:
Irrespective of accuracy, I suppose it's an honour of sorts for a humble "Burnley boy" to be mentioned four times in as many weeks in Matthew Norman's Diary - truly, I am not worthy.

Norman has finally admitted that Tribune is the source of his pieces. What a shame he hasn't questioned why his source has written some 17 pieces over five months. The reason is simply because 33,000 Labour party members voted me onto Labour's NEC, and kicked off Tribune's editor, Mark Seddon.

As a long-standing Guardian reader and admirer of Norman's writing (non-Diary pieces), what I find most disturbing is that he has become an unwitting tool for a disgruntled political hack with an axe to grind. It is no coincidence that nominations for next year's NEC are due shortly. Surely we've a right to expect much more from the Guardian?

Oh, and if Norman doubts my snooker prowess - any time, any place.
Shahid Malik
London
fields.bodyText: Irrespective of accuracy, I suppose it's an honour of sorts for a humble "Burnley boy" to be mentioned four times in as many weeks in Matthew Norman's Diary - truly, I am not worthy. Norman has finally admitted that Tribune is the source of his pieces. What a shame he hasn't questioned why his source has written some 17 pieces over five months. The reason is simply because 33,000 Labour party members voted me onto Labour's NEC, and kicked off Tribune's editor, Mark Seddon. As a long-standing Guardian reader and admirer of Norman's writing (non-Diary pieces), what I find most disturbing is that he has become an unwitting tool for a disgruntled political hack with an axe to grind. It is no coincidence that nominations for next year's NEC are due shortly. Surely we've a right to expect much more from the Guardian? fields.headline: Aids: unhealthy profits
fields.trailText: Your report (Aids: South Africa's new apartheid, November 30) fails to mention that when the South African government tried to change the law to allow importing or local production of cheaper versions of Aids drugs, it received trade threats from the US and the EU, and law suits from the big drug companies.
fields.body:
Your report (Aids: South Africa's new apartheid, November 30) fails to mention that when the South African government tried to change the law to allow importing or local production of cheaper versions of Aids drugs, it received trade threats from the US and the EU, and law suits from the big drug companies.

Even as the G8 prepares to meet next week to draw up a global action plan to tackle the disease, our trade minister, Richard Caborn, has told ACTSA that such policies are "not the answer" as it might "undermine the willingness of the pharmaceutical industry to play a constructive role".

The one-off, country-by-country deals (often with strings attached) offered by the drug companies are gestures to divert attention from any threats to their patents and profits; South Africa and other countries in the region are quite right to be wary of them.
Ben Jackson
Director, Action for Southern Africa
ben.jackson@actsa.org

 Am I the only white, gay, affluent, European, HIV positive male to find Sarah Boseley's article (Aids is back in town, November 30) offensive? A positive diagnosis to HIV is a terrible blow to the citizen of any country, irrespective of their racial heritage or income. It is terribly unjust to suggest that one individual suffers more than other. Indeed how does Ms Boseley quantify suffering? We're all just trying to survive.
Matt Corrall
London

fields.headline: Barak's peace plan rejected
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, launched his re-election campaign yesterday, unveiling a cautious peace plan aimed at appeasing rightwing critics.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, launched his re-election campaign yesterday, unveiling a cautious peace plan aimed at appeasing rightwing critics.

For a man who claimed last July to have offered the Palestinians more than any other Israeli leader - 90% of the West Bank, and a foothold in Jerusalem - his offer yesterday was paltry. It stretched only as far as transferring another 10% of the West Bank to a Palestinian state.

His interim arrangement also proposes annexing an unknown number of Jewish settlements, and freezing the question of the right of return for refugees.

The plan has yet to be formally presented to the Palestinians, but they were swift to reject it yesterday. "This is another trick that we have been suffering for the last seven years," said Marwan Kanafi, a spokesman for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

 One Palestinian teenager was shot dead near Bethlehem yesterday. Three others were wounded.

webTitle: Contrite GM firm pledges to turn over a new leaf

fields.headline: Contrite GM firm pledges to turn over a new leaf
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Five years ago, Monsanto planned to flood the world with GM crops and reap the profits. Now the world's leading biotech company has admitted that it has been arrogant, blind and insensitive and has formally pledged to be "honourable, ethical and open" in all its future actions
fields.body:
Five years ago, Monsanto planned to flood the world with GM crops and reap the profits. Three years ago it received a bloody nose in Europe and had to apologise to the British for misunderstanding their hostility.

Now, in a feast of humble pie, the world's leading biotech company has admitted to the world that it has been arrogant, blind and insensitive and has formally pledged to be "honourable, ethical and open" in all its future actions.

The new Monsanto, said the corporation's president and chief executive Hendrik Verfaillie, is now outwardly very different to the one which promised to be part of the solution to world hunger and environmental problems only five years ago.

Instead of trumpeting "faith, hope and prosperity", the genetically modified line is now that biotechnology is a way to improve human health and that Monsanto is contrite, listening and leading world business into an ethical age.

"Even our friends told us we could be arrogant and insensitive," said Mr Verfaillie of the company, which has merged with the pharmaceutical giants Pharmacia and Upjohn.

"We were blinded by our enthusiasm," he told a Washington audience this week. "We missed the fact that this technology raises major issues for people - of ethics, of choice, of trust, even of democracy and globalisation. When we tried to explain the benefits, the science and the safety, we did not understand that our tone - our very approach - was arrogant."

Mr Verfaillie said he believed biotechnology was now "at a watershed" and that society everywhere had changed.

"The shift that started 40 years ago is approaching maturity," he said. "It is a movement from a 'trust me' society to a 'show me' society. We don't trust government - and thus government rulemaking and regulation is suspect. We don't trust companies - or the new technologies they introduce into the marketplace. We were still in the 'trust me' mode when the expectation was 'show me'."

From now on, he said, the new Monsanto would be ethical and to prove it it had published a five-point pledge of new commitments which were, he said, unprecedented in the biotechnology industry.

"We commit to respecting the religious, cultural and ethical concerns of people," said Mr Verfaillie. "[Monsanto] will not sell grain products until they have been approved for consumption by both humans and animals; nor will [Monsanto] use genes taken from animal or human sources in our agricultural products intended for food or feed, or sell foods in which known allergens have been introduced." And he promised not to pursue technologies that resulted in sterile, or so-called terminator, seeds.

The company has been criticised for imposing GM farming on poor countries. No longer. The new Monsanto will, according to its chief, "bring the knowledge and advantages of all forms of agriculture to resource-poor farmers in the developing world to help improve food security and protect the environment".

To those who accuse Monsanto of having consistently evaded government regulations, he promised to work legally, probably a first in corporate history.

In response to critics who have alleged the company is secretive about sharing its research, he said it would now publish all scientific data and data summaries on product safety.

Yesterday the company's many critics around the world were congratulating it on its pledges but were mostly hoping it would pledge to go away.

"Sweet isn't it," said a Friends of the Earth spokesman. "Here's a company with its back to the wall and its technology going down the tube. We welcome its pledges but it must face up to the fact that people do not want its food."

"We have read the commitments," said an Indian anti-GM activist who has been marching with many thousands of small farmers against Monsanto and other giant companies. "They are very fine. But a tiger is not a pussy cat. If it has large whiskers it is probably still a tiger with a plan to gobble you up even faster."

Monsanto, said its chief, had set up "a dedicated team to facilitate its pledges and share its GM technology with public institutions, charities and industry round the world".

Yesterday the Guardian asked the Monsanto HQ switchboard to be put through to one of the team. The call was met with an answering machine.

fields.headline: Fresh start school to close
fields.standfirst:
Government faces uphill battle to salvage controversial scheme for failing institutions

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will today attempt to shore up its flagship scheme for turning around failing schools, as a "fresh start" comprehensive announces it is to close.
fields.body:
The government will today attempt to shore up its flagship scheme for turning around failing schools, as a "fresh start" comprehensive announces it is to close.

The scheme, under which poor-performing schools in England and Wales are relaunched under a new name with extra cash, has been dogged by controversy, including the resignation of four "superheads".

But today the policy will hit a new low when the pupils and parents of Telegraph Hill, in Lewisham, south London, relaunched in September last year, will be told that the local education authority is abandoning efforts to keep it going.

Formerly known as Hatcham Wood, its headteacher, Mike Davies, quit last term and only 3% of its GCSE candidates achieved five good passes. This put it in the four worst schools in England and Wales.

The school is the first of 25 fresh start secondary and primary schools, nine of which joined the scheme this September, that are set to close.

The National Union of Teachers last night demanded an apology from the council for imposing fresh start on the school against the wishes of staff.

Today Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, will put pressure on local authorities to close schools that have been subject to "special measures" for two years or more, rather than resort to fresh start.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, believes councils were given too much leeway to create fresh start schools and has ordered his officials to get the programme under control.

Ms Morris will say: "The government will not support proposals for fresh start schools in future where there is not a good chance of success. Fresh start ... is to be reserved only for the very hardest cases where closure is not an option.

"In each case there would be very clear targets and government support will be dependent on there being a real prospect of recovery. Normally a school should close if it consistently fails to raise standards for local pupils. Fresh start is about raising standards in the most challenging circumstances and it cannot be used to avoid local difficulties for schools that should close."

Ms Morris will say the government's approach for turning around failure "is clearly working in most schools". She will say that 600 have been "turned around" since Labour took office and 122 have been closed.

Telegraph Hill, in one of the poorest parts of the borough, has had major discipline problems, with some teachers complaining it had become impossible to run lessons. This year it had the 11th worst truancy rate in the country.

Martin Powell-Davies, the Lewisham secretary of the NUT, said last night: "Fresh start doesn't work. I think the council want the whole thing to go away now. I just hope they admit they are responsible."

About a dozen of the Hatcham Wood staff, mostly junior teachers, were kept on at Telegraph Hill, and the school had an experimental curriculum.

One teacher, who did not want to be named, said the school had opened without computers, photocopiers or a telephone system. Only 620 pupils had stayed at the school instead of the planned 750. The teacher said the school had no maths teachers last year and only one science teacher this year.

Governors were told of Lewisham's decision last night. Althea Efunshile, director for lifelong learning and culture at Lewisham council, told the Guardian: "There is a meeting at the school this evening. Until I have had the chance to talk to pupils and parents at the school tomorrow morning it is not fair to speculate about the future of the school."

fields.headline: Marchioness victims had hands severed
fields.standfirst: Families tell inquiry of distress at 'chaotic' identification process
fields.trailText: Families tell inquiry of distress at 'chaotic' identification process
fields.body:
Families of the people who died in the Marchioness accident told of their horror at discovering that their relatives' hands had been severed to allow fingerprinting as the inquiry into the identification of victims opened in London yesterday.

Relatives at the hearing, a subsidiary of the main public inquiry into the events in which 51 people drowned, told of chaos as they tried to find out what had happened to their loved ones in the aftermath of the accident on the Thames on August 20 1989, when the dredger Bowbelle collided with the cruise boat full of revellers.

Many were refused the opportunity to see victims and none knew hands had been severed until two years ago. All complained of a lack of information and support, and in some cases of basic mistakes. One black family were given a white body when they tried to reclaim their son for burial.

Eleven years after the accident, the relatives hope the inquiry at Westminster Central Hall will determine why things went so wrong and improve identification processes in future. Opening the hearing, which follows a formal inquiry into the causes of the accident, the chairman, Lord Justice Clarke said the removal of the hands had caused "profound shock and distress".

Friends and relatives had provided descriptions of victims and their clothing. But the coroners' office, police and a pathologist decided that visual identification of bodies recovered from the Thames would be too distressing. They decided fingerprinting should be used to double-check identities even where dental records were available and that hands could be removed if it was otherwise impossible to take fingerprints.

In total, 25 victims had their hands removed. Their families were told they could not see bodies before burial or cremation because their deterioration would be too upsetting.

Sally Smith, who subsequently saw photographs of her daughter's body, told the hearing: "I have no doubt I could have identified her.

"I was quite expecting she might have lost a limb in the accident, but she hadn't, and to think she then had her hands severed - I was so devastated and I think that was worse than actually knowing about the disaster."

Despite the fingerprinting, her daughter was identified with the details Ms Smith had provided at the opening of her inquest. Jane's father, Peter Bourke, tried to see his daughter's body after the postmortem but was told her coffin could not be opened.

"I was shown into a room with a wooden box which I didn't want to look at or talk to, so after a few moments I left," he told the hearing.

Survivor Annette Russell, who lost several friends in the accident, said the process had been chaotic. "There was a continual lack of facts and communication," she said. "Everything was just hideous ... it was quite shambolic."

Judy Wellington, whose son, Simon, had his hands removed, said the family was initially given the body of a white man although Simon was of Caribbean origin.

Lord Clarke said his role was to find out what had happened and make recommendations, but insisted that he would not allow a "witch-hunt", a reference to the Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman's, reluctance to appear.

Dr Knapman took charge of the identification process, although he was on holiday for some of the relevant period. He initially refused to attend the hearing and could not be compelled because it is a non-statutory inquiry. He had supplied written evidence already.

Dr Knapman's counsel, Roger Eastman, yesterday told Lord Clarke that his client would attend, but might decline to answer certain questions. Eileen Dallaglio, who lost her 19-year-old daughter Francesca in the accident, said outside the court: "We have only ever shown Dr Knapman and his staff great respect...but we look for change. Never again should any family be treated in this way.

"Anyone who holds public office - and that includes the coroner and the coroner's officers - has a duty to come to the inquiry and give a full account of their actions."

The police officers involved in identification continue to refuse to attend.

"What are they frightened of?" asked Angela Bensamenn, whose son Dean Palmer died. "We are normal people wanting answers to questions we have asked for 11 years."

webTitle: Football manager 'hid secret of child abuse'

fields.headline: Football manager 'hid secret of child abuse'
fields.standfirst: Accused said to have preyed on boys during spell as residential carer
fields.trailText: A former manager of Southampton Football Club, David Jones, physically and sexually abused boys at a special school then hid the "dark secret" behind the respectability of his sporting career, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A former manager of Southampton Football Club, David Jones, physically and sexually abused boys at a special school then hid the "dark secret" behind the respectability of his sporting career, a court heard yesterday.

Jones, 44, of Chilworth near Southampton, denied 14 charges of abusing four boys aged between 10 and 17.

The abuse was said to have been committed between January 1986 and May 1990 while he worked as a carer at a residential school for children with emotional and behavioural difficulties.

Jones had applied for the job after a knee injury forced him to retire from professional football. He had played for Everton, Coventry City and Preston North End. He faces 10 charges of indecent assault, three of assault causing actual bodily harm, which included punching and kicking a child, and one of buggery.

David Aubrey QC, prosecuting, told the jury at Liverpool crown court: "It will become clear that the defendant abused three boys in his care for his own sexual gratification. They were all young and vulnerable at the time. None of them complained while they were at the school."

He said the boys thought if they complained no one in authority would believe them.

The regime at the residential school allegedly lent itself to exploitation and gave Jones "the opportunity to perpetrate acts on vulnerable young boys in his care and the opportunity to carry out his own sexual perversions upon them", Mr Aubrey added.

He said Jones, who began work at the school at the age of 29 caring for children in residential units, took advantage of opportunities that arose, or ensured that opportunities to abuse the targeted boys did arise.

The jury heard that Jones, who is married with four children, was a "man of hitherto impeccable character and a professional sportsman of some distinction".

At the time of his arrest on June 15 last year he was man ager of the Premiership club Southampton and had previously managed Stockport County. Mr Aubrey said Jones hid a dark secret and was "hiding behind respectability".

The jury heard that all four alleged victims had pursued lives of crime since leaving the school. Some had been in custodial institutions. Two were still serving jail sentences.

The first witness, the subject of six of the sexual abuse charges, has since changed his name by deed poll and part undergone a sex change.

The witness, known as Miss A, told the court she was admitted to the Merseyside school as a boy aged 10. She said Jones used to "toy fight" with her in the accommodation block, like a brother and sister would do.

"I always used to seem to end up with my arms behind my back and he would always touch me with his groin area," she said. This happened on a regular basis.

Miss A, who is serving a 42-month sentence for arson, said Jones had sexually abused her in the bathroom of a residential unit. She was having a bath in a locked cubicle when Jones entered.

"He said something about how I was always a good lad and I always did what I was told. He said it would be a shame to spoil it all. Then he unzipped his trousers."

Jones told her not to tell and she kept quiet, fearing school privileges would stop, she said.

She recalled a second encounter with Jones while she was washing a member of staff's car outside the school. "He said he was going to make me into a proper lad because I used to get called names a lot and I just wanted it to stop," she said. Jones then sexually assaulted her.

Asked by Mr Aubrey why she had never told anyone of the assaults, she replied: "I was terrified of him because he was so powerful and everyone knew he was a footballer."

Henry Globe QC, defending, said that as a child Miss A had been described by an educational psychologist and careworkers as manipulative, over-demanding and living in a fantasy world, often telling lies.

The trial continues.

They were all young and vulnerable at the time. None of them complained while they were at the school." He said the boys thought if they complained no one in authority would believe them. The regime at the residential school allegedly lent itself to exploitation and gave Jones "the opportunity to perpetrate acts on vulnerable young boys in his care and the opportunity to carry out his own sexual perversions upon them", Mr Aubrey added. He said Jones, who began work at the school at the age of 29 caring for children in residential units, took advantage of opportunities that arose, or ensured that opportunities to abuse the targeted boys did arise. The jury heard that Jones, who is married with four children, was a "man of hitherto impeccable character and a professional sportsman of some distinction". At the time of his arrest on June 15 last year he was man ager of the Premiership club Southampton and had previously managed Stockport County. Mr Aubrey said Jones hid a dark secret and was "hiding behind respectability". The jury heard that all four alleged victims had pursued lives of crime since leaving the school. Some had been in custodial institutions. Two were still serving jail sentences. The first witness, the subject of six of the sexual abuse charges, has since changed his name by deed poll and part undergone a sex change. The witness, known as Miss A, told the court she was admitted to the Merseyside school as a boy aged 10. She said Jones used to "toy fight" with her in the accommodation block, like a brother and sister would do. "I always used to seem to end up with my arms behind my back and he would always touch me with his groin area," she said. This happened on a regular basis. Miss A, who is serving a 42-month sentence for arson, said Jones had sexually abused her in the bathroom of a residential unit. She was having a bath in a locked cubicle when Jones entered. "He said something about how I was always a good lad and I always did what I was told. He said it would be a shame to spoil it all. Then he unzipped his trousers." Jones told her not to tell and she kept quiet, fearing school privileges would stop, she said. She recalled a second encounter with Jones while she was washing a member of staff's car outside the school. "He said he was going to make me into a proper lad because I used to get called names a lot and I just wanted it to stop," she said. Jones then sexually assaulted her. Asked by Mr Aubrey why she had never told anyone of the assaults, she replied: "I was terrified of him because he was so powerful and everyone knew he was a footballer." Henry Globe QC, defending, said that as a child Miss A had been described by an educational psychologist and careworkers as manipulative, over-demanding and living in a fantasy world, often telling lies. The trial continues.

fields.headline: Same old story
fields.standfirst: A new survey suggests that mature audiences feel alienated by the way they're portrayed on TV. Don't hip young programme-makers realise that children of the 60s might still have a spark of life in them? By  Katharine Whitehorn
fields.trailText: A new survey suggests that mature audiences feel alienated by the way they're portrayed on TV. Don't hip young programme-makers realise that children of the 60s might still have a spark of life in them?
fields.body:
If you accuse the bright young sparks in TV or ad agencies of being behind the times, they think you're accusing them of still liking Duran Duran or wearing the wrong sort of scarf (so last year). What's really out of date is their notion of what older people look like, do, talk about and want to see on TV, and the only surprising thing about the current fuss is that it's apparently taken a survey commissioned by the ITC and Age Concern to make them even dimly aware of it. For the over-50s are truly fed up with the way they are shown - or not shown - on television.

We know, of course, that TV people rate themselves on how they impress other TV people, most of whom are under 40 or feel the need to pretend they are. (Jane Root, new controller of BBC2, and herself 43, is quoted as saying that all people think they're under 40, which is nonsense.) But the ads that support these programmes, you'd have thought, would be more concerned with the sheer marketing idiocy of aiming everything at the young - the young who, in any case, are much more likely to be out or bonking in front of the box than actually watching it.

There are, after all, 19 million over-50s, who will outnumber the others in a few years' time, and already spend £145 billion a year. Half of them, maybe, are the penniless pensioners who appear on the news every single time "pensions" are mentioned, but the other half - with mortgages paid, children (with luck) off their hands - are free to spend money - more so than they've ever been - and they're not spending it on Ovaltine and corn plasters.

I wouldn't be unkind enough to suggest that the programme-makers simply can't count, but I can't understand why, whenever they want to show the over-50s, they usually show the over-80s, preferably in an old folks' home or crouching over a single-bar fire in their mouldering bedroom slippers? Nobody make programmes for 10-year-olds on the assumption they're the same as 40-year-olds, after all, but it's the same age gap in either case.

Why does the word "grandmother" instantly throw up a white-haired old thing who's either going goofy or rotting up her descendants' lives, instead of the harried, working, busy factotums that actually do the job - the ones who are running charities, starting pressure groups, gardening, working, and looking after their grandchildren half the time (one consequence of family break-up)? Or going on holidays - and no, I don't just mean cruises. I mean mountaineering expeditions, dog-sledding with Eskimos, camel trekking across the Australian outback - just three well-subscribed senior holidays.

I am, I should maybe say, currently Agony Aunt for Saga magazine for the over-50s. People hearing this usually laugh till their gums bleed and then ask if I get questions about Zimmer frames and false-teeth fixative. When I mention the man who, at her request, wears his lover's nightdress when he goes to visit her (should he wear it in front of her sister?), or the ones who don't know how to handle the surges of desire brought on by aromatherapy, or the 70-year-old woman asking about reliable computer courses - she must have heard that the biggest users of email in the States are grans and grandchildren - they are amazed. Why? Because they haven't noticed - and TV hasn't helped them notice - that today's over-50s aren't like the parents and grandparents they remember. These are the kids of the swinging 60s, and they're not about to take up knitting and the inglenook.

The people who are complaining most, according to the Age Concern survey, are the people in their 50s and 60s, most of whom don't want special golden-oldie programmes - they are mainstream, they just want to be let off things aimed only at the young. They are possibly bored with programmes that are entirely full of violence and swearing ("If there's not a fuck or a fight in the first 10 minutes, I'm not interested," as one producer put it), or programmes aimed at the notional "younger viewer" who is thought to want everything jazzed up, jokey, instant - who wouldn't watch a first-class programme like Local Hero, it says here, without Adam Hart-Davis wearing that foul pink bicycle helmet, or switch on to anything unless the girl seems to be having an orgasm as she announces a programme about global warming or the NHS.

Older women feel especially poorly treated by TV. They are mostly allowed on the box only if they're guyed up like Clarissa Dickson-Wright on her silly scooter, or preceded, like Victor Meldrew's wife, by 200-year-old tortoises and the grim little dirge of One Foot In The Grave. There are exceptions - there was Hetty Wainwright, we get occasional bouts of Claire Rayner, there are grown-up dramas like Sins and Middlemarch; but the idea of showing, say, a senior female presenter with her white hair superbly blow-dried like Michael Aspel would be unthinkable.

All right, we all like to think that we're a bit younger than we are, but not ludicrously so, and certainly we prefer handsome to plain people. But those in their 60s, according to the survey, are choosier than their elders. They watch more television than they did - at the moment, but this may not continue. And how will TV fare if half its audience drops away?

webTitle: Millionaire winner in plea for hard-up toffs

fields.headline: Millionaire winner in plea for hard-up toffs
fields.trailText: As pleas of poverty go, it was not the most auspiciously timed. Judith Keppel, who last week won  £1m on the gameshow Who Wants to be Millionaire?, has urged penniless aristocrats to use the TV quiz show as a comeback vehicle.
fields.body:
As pleas of poverty go, it was not the most auspiciously timed. Judith Keppel, who last week won £1m on the gameshow Who Wants to be Millionaire?, has urged penniless aristocrats to use the TV quiz show as a comeback vehicle.

"I think toffs ought to line up in rows and sign on and fight back a bit," she told the Spectator.

Ms Keppel's win after correctly identifying Henry II as Eleanor of Aquitaine's husband was received in some quarters with a disapproving eye on her £500,000 house in west London and direct bloodline to Edward VII's mistress.

"What they don't seem to realise," she said, "is that you can have toff relations, but equally you can have not very much money. My particular bit of the family are not rich. My grandfather sold our family house in Norfolk after the war because they thought that way of life was over."

Ms Keppel's grandfather was the ninth earl of Albemarle. Her win on the television quiz show was not rags to riches, it was argued, but rich to richer. Ms Keppel, however, dismissed the snide coverage as part of a wider movement to undermine the aristocracy.

"It's the last throw, really," she said. "They are stamping on us now. There's no power base, no House of Lords."

She put paid to speculation that her win was a fix designed to beat the BBC's One Foot in the Grave. "I don't see how it could have been a fix," she said. "There was a man locked in the room who sent the questions to Chris Tarrant on his computer, and he was there throughout the recording."

Ms Keppel said she viewed the gameshow as a "frightfully good opportunity to make some money".

"I realised that if you were lucky with the questions and didn't get asked too many pop stars and footballers, you could win a great deal of money."

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Remember that ill-fated edition of BBC1's Panorama about reality TV? You know, the one that was broadcast earlier this month, initially dismissed as a joke by the channel's new boss Lorraine Heggessey because it was fronted by Mariella Frostrup - arguably not a presenter with "serious journalistic credentials". It was also a ratings flop, pulling in just under three million viewers as Panorama filled its new Sunday evening slot, compared to the four-and-a-half million tuning in to the last Monday evening showing.

Well, it seems the show narrowly missed an even more farcical end - being injuncted by the BBC's own supplier of reality TV programming.

The BBC decided it should cover its own reality show, Castaway, to balance any slagging-off of C4's Big Brother. But Lion TV, makers of Castaway, have what they call an "ongoing position" with former Crusoe team member Ron Copsey. Ron, you'll recall, is the pullovered one who kept threatening to leave the remote Hebridean island - and then did. What Lion's "ongoing position" means is that it reserves the right to take legal action against our Ron if he breaks the terms of his TV contract. Slagging off reality TV, particularly the Castaway project, would seem to be a pretty serious breach of contract.

But disaster was averted when Lion's legal advice concluded that both Lion and Ron could take part in the doomed Panorama. The show went ahead, although after all that bother what was obviously intended as a "populist" piece of current affairs TV didn't turn out to be very popular at all. BBC director of television Mark Thompson even admitted at an industry dinner that the reason so few people watched it was because it wasn't the kind of subject matter that interests Panorama viewers.

Lion director Jeremy Mills is now as dismissive of the programme as Heggessey was. He'll only say: "I was most mortified that they asked me such a long drawn-out question that I had time to take two sips of tea on camera before I could answer. And the mug didn't have a Lion TV logo on it."

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Sometimes with politics it is the vignettes that shed most light. On Wednesday, leftwing MP Alan Simpson was collecting signatures for an early day motion to mark Tony Benn's 50 years in parliament.
fields.body:
 Sometimes with politics it is the vignettes that shed most light. On Wednesday, leftwing MP Alan Simpson was collecting signatures for an early day motion to mark Tony Benn's 50 years in parliament.

By convention, ministers seldom sign EDMs, so Alan got permission from chief whip Ann Taylor, on the grounds that the motion was so uncontroversial, before approaching Nick Raynsford in the lobby. The housing minister scrutinised it with great care and had his pen poised to sign when junior whip Mike Hall intervened. "Are you sure you've got permission for ministers to sign, Alan?" he bellowed. At this, even though Ann Taylor herself was standing nearby, Nick scuttled away like a petrified crab.

Alan remonstrated with him, and in the ensuing confusion all other ministers present slunk away, loath to stake their careers on so hazardous an undertaking as passing on good wishes to a great parliamentarian soon to retire. I know we've said it before, but what a bleedin' party it is.

 A more curious encounter on Wednesday involved Peter Hain, the Foreign Office's most zealous fan of the poisonous sanctions against Iraq whose efforts to supplant Robin Cook, rumour has it, are becoming embarrassingly transparent. So when Cookie's PPS Ken Purchase was seen chatting animatedly in a corridor to George Galloway, Peter's chief persecutor over Iraq, the inference was obvious. After doing no more to check Peter's rampant ambition than rebuking him for ticking off the governments of Zimbabwe ("uncivilised") and France ("pretty contemptible" for sending aid to Iraq), could it be that Cookie may be prepared to fight dirty at last?

 Hats off to the Mirror for a front-page exclusive about the BBC printing leaflets teaching staff how to use new turnstiles at White City. How much funnier this story seems now than on November 3 when it appeared here. Mirror editor Piers Morgan refuses to pay us a penny because, he says, "that will guarantee a huge moral dilemma next time. DILEMMA: Do I stick this in the column to amuse a few twats in Islington, or do I make £1,000 flogging it on the quiet to Piers?"

 When Richard Desmond promised to "spend what it takes" to save the Express, the sneerers laughed. Well, they're not laughing now. Not only has the porn baron cancelled all courier accounts (staff now send secretaries to collect urgent items in taxis), he has also decided to pack an extra 40 people on to an already crowded editorial floor. The office shared by Peter Oborne, newly recruited Carol Sarler, her fellow columnist John Diamond and a so-called rival diarist has already been requisitioned, the quartet being given two desks to share in the outer office.

 The first extract from Mr Desmond's Best of Forum, our inaugural Magazine of the Month, is postponed. My so-called rival Alan Rusbridger has quoted from Best of Asian Babes in his New Statesman diary, and I'd hate to be accused of plagiarism. That extract will now appear on on Tuesday, when the antidote to Mr Desmond's hard-core porn will be the giblet section of my mother's recipe for chicken soup - something Mr Desmond, a patron of Jewish Care according to today's Jewish Chronicle, might enjoy.

 Bad luck to my friend Sir Alan Sugar, who settled his libel writ with the News of the World yesterday for a proportion of his (or Spurs') legal costs. Alan's forays into the world of libel are always fun to behold, so let's hope this latest reverse isn't too great a discouragement.

 Commiserations also to comic actor David Spade whose personal assistant attacked him in Beverly Hills yesterday with a gun. Mr Spade, who is recovering from the shock, is best known as a star of the NBC sitcom Just Shoot Me.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: How can I stop myself bursting into tears during disputes at work?
fields.trailText: How can I stop myself bursting into tears during disputes at work?
fields.body:
I have a problem with which many women and, I suspect, very few men, will empathise. I am a university lecturer and am normally quite assertive and able to hold my corner in disputes. However, occasionally during an argument, I find myself on the verge of tears with associated wobbly voice, runny nose and watery eyes. It is difficult for me to specify which sort of row brings this on but I think it usually involves a personal criticism of me or a feeling that I am being treated unfairly. In a professional environment, the effect of this tearfulness leaves me embarrassed and unable to pursue the argument. I can only imagine how the other party feels - anything from embarrassment to feeling manipulated or even contempt. Is there anybody who has mastered this problem? Is there anything I can do to prevent it - therapy, role play, conditioning, shock treatment or whatever?

It's their sadistic streak

There is a sadistic streak within academic life, maybe as a result of the public school background of many of the key players. I remember being bullied at a job interview for a lecturing post at which my doctoral work was unfairly trashed and I still dream of revenge. I see no reason why the ordinary cut and thrust (note the language) of academic debate should not happen in a respectful climate. However, it sounds like you might need better survival skills. There is nothing wrong in getting good professional help. A counsellor would help - get advice from your institution's student counselling service. Is there any relevant staff training available at your institution? Do you have a mentor? And remember it is the quality of your work with your students that truly matters.
William West, Manchester

Think before you react

You say that the feelings which upset you and prevent you from pursuing an appropriate argument seem to be associated with a sense of being criticised or unfairly treated. It may well be that it is this interpretation that is the cause of your difficulties.

My own work suggests that a good way of getting out of the recurring pattern you describe is to cast doubt on your "I'm being personally criticised/unfairly treated" interpretation by practising thinking "perhaps I'm not being criticised or unfairly treated". This can free you to deal with it in either of two ways: firstly by putting your initial interpretation "on hold" (after all, your interpretation could be wrong!). This will enable you to take what is being said at face value, as information to be explored with the other person, eg, "When you said X, did you mean... ?" And secondly by checking publicly with the other person whether your initial interpretation was correct, as follows: "I felt criticised when you said X... did you mean it that way?/I feel unfairly treated because (give reasons)... do you see it that way?" This will enable you to respond to what the other person really thinks.

Your feelings can now be turned from an embarrassment to an asset. They can be used as a signal to yourself to move into the new routine.

My experience is that it takes persistent practice to learn to question one's "automatic" interpretations and to use negative feelings to signal the need to do so. However, these are techniques one can practice in any situation in which negative feelings play a part. I have found that they offer a very practical way of escaping from disabling patterns such as those you describe.
Sue Clark, Birmingham

It's OK to cry

I am a university professor and my solution to weeping at work has been to redefine the problem as part of the new-style workplace. In the old-style workplace, when things got stressful, people were likely to shout and swear, insult each other and generally become angry in ways which left a legacy of distrust and dislike. How much less destructive it is if stress can be expressed in tears. I always try to make it clear that the tears are not a sign of weakness and indecision - if anything, they represent a determination to see the issue through. Name and address withheld

Picture them naked

I used to often suffer from the same problem in my career as a PA in the city. I had very low self-esteem and as a graduate with much less experience than my colleagues I felt insecure in my role. Counselling helped increase my self-esteem and gain a sense of perspective which taught me that I was a worthy person and there are matters far more important in the world than, in my case, investment banking. Change in 15 minutes

The problem is one experienced by many women and also men - it's just that men don't show their response in the same way. When I am working as a life coach with a client, they will often describe an unwanted response very similar to yours. The good news is, there is a simple procedure, that usually takes about 15 minutes or so, that will change your response in that situation for ever.

We store our experiences as memories, and often a response will pop up that our brain has linked to a (usually fairly early) experience when we were say five, six or seven. Many of those of us in the development business use techniques originating from neurolinguistic programming (an awful mouthful for really useful study of how we process and store our experiences). We will work with the client to access the earlier memory/ies, and add inner resources to change the experience - and hence the memory when it pops up again.

Keep your chin up

I used to suffer from the same embarrassing tendency to cry when I experienced an unexpectedly hostile response. Then I undertook some training in transactional analysis (I am a social worker) and the trainer explained my problem as a childhood response which was intruding into my adult psyche. In TA speak, I was reacting "in my child" instead of "in my adult". For all of us, our child self is only just beneath the surface. Of course, the person who provoked the reaction is usually also "in their child".

Also, a hypnotherapist advised my daughter to look up at the ceiling, instead of down at the floor, when you feel the tears coming. This stops the tears and gives others the impression you are thinking.

Next week

About a year and a half ago I asked my partner whether she was having an affair with an old friend of hers. She said that she wasn't, but that they were wanting to see more of each other, including weekends away and developing a physical relationship. This has now happened.

I love my partner, to whom I am married and have three children and don't want to simply split up. Together we went through the 70s, feminism and being critical of the nuclear family. Dealing with jealousy and emotional insecurity has been very painful for me. I feel I'm the only person in this boat. I don't want to find another partner as a "balancing act" but find being in this open-ended marriage very difficult. Telling my partner simply to leave is something I do not wish to do; mainly because I love her and because I have a difficult relationship with our eldest daughter. I would like to hear from other people in similar situations or with similar experiences. How can I cope with this?

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Star Trek: Insurrection | Roseanna's Grave | Mulholland Falls | Wild Things
fields.body:
Star Trek: Insurrection

(Jonathan Frakes, 1998)

9.25am, 6pm, Sky Premier

After the dark pleasures of First Contact, this ninth outing for the bold Trekkers seems a little tame. On a planet of eternal youth, Captain Picard is forced to disobey Federation rules in order to save the peace-loving Ba'kus from ethnic cleansing. The thin plot barely makes warp-factor two, but with all its special effects, it's an enjoyable voyage.

Roseanna's Grave

(Paul Weiland, 1997)

8pm, FilmFour

Charming tale of an apparently doomed love. Jean Reno is Marcello, husband of Mercedes Ruehl's Roseanna, who's suffering from a fatal heart condition. Her one wish is to be buried in the village cemetery, and there's only one space left, so Marcello must work wonders keeping the old and ailing villagers alive in order to reserve the spot. But there's a dark secret at the centre of this captivating romantic comedy.

Mulholland Falls

(Lee Tamahori, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

Chinatown production designer Richard Sylbert recreates a simi lar ambience here, but there the similarities end. New Zealander Tamahori, who directed the bruising, brilliant Once Were Warriors, has a tremendous cast for this tale of an elite bunch of cops investigating murder and mystery at an atomic power plant in 40s LA. Nick Nolte, Chazz Palminteri, Michael Madsen, Chris Penn, John Malkovich and Melanie Griffith are all on board, but the plot plods and there's none of Chinatown's wit to lighten things up

Wild Things

(John McNaughton, 1998)

11.45pm, Sky MovieMax

Denise (Starship Troopers, The World is Not Enough) Richards and Neve (Scream) Campbell are young women to be wary of, as Matt Dillon's likeable teacher discovers to his cost. They're both alleging rape, and although a cop played by the ubiquitous Kevin Bacon suspects a plot, only ramshackle lawyer Bill Murray stands in between Dillon and a long spell in prison in McNaughton's extremely sly, dark and devious comedy.

webTitle: What the Aristoc ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Aristoc ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Aristoc ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
We open on a beautiful, brightly lit apartment occupied by a young Italian couple who have obviously fallen out. We can see the man but only catch arty glimpses of the woman's legs, and each time she speaks her face is clumsily obscured by subtitles. "Something's wrong Paolo," she says in Italian. "Is it us?" he replies. "No, it's these stupid subtitles. Why aren't mine at the bottom? No one can see my face." Paolo replies, deadpan, "That's because you're wearing Aristoc Slimline System tights. The compression knitting gently massages your skin, for a slimming-looking bum and thighs..." The spot ends with the woman swivelling round in a chair to look towards the camera, a packshot of the tights cruelly superimposed over her features.

The jargon:
Evidently hosiery has become a "commodity" buy, with around 71 per cent of tights purchased being own-label. So this cinema ad is to get punters to reassess the quality Aristoc brand in a witty way, as well as to promote the company's new cellulite-zapping Slimline System range.

Personality:
You're a young, self-confident woman, dubbed by ad agency Miles Calcraft a "cheerful realist" - ie, you don't have the perfect body and you know you don't, but you're quite happy about making the best of what you have.

Financial status:
These fancy new tights cost around £4.50 a pair, which might be pricier than the own-label variety, but then those don't come with "compression knitting and encapsulated sea minerals".

Telling lifestyle detail:
You're fashion-conscious, you go to the cinema, you like evenings out with your female pals, and you scoff at patronising Liz Hurley-style female- targeted ads that are all hearts and flowers and puppy dogs. You like a good laugh, basically.

Other relevant data:
The duo in the commercial are speaking the real Italian equivalent of the English subtitles. The ad was filmed in a listed 30s building in Gerard's Cross.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.body:
Just out of Tetbury, on the eastern side across Wiltshire Bridge, lies Folly Farm. Once part of the Estcourt Estate, and more recently run as a dairy farm milking a herd of 120 cattle, the old farm, at the heart of which lies a great tithe barn, is now a 64-bed wedding and conference centre. Much of the estate, through which we've walked on summer hikes back from Shipton Moyne, seems now devoted to serious equine pursuits.

I pass Folly Farm regularly, often on a bike ride to Crudwell or beyond, and have always thought the two splendid pigs in the roadside paddock were a pair of Gloucester Old Spots. Closer examination reveals this to be a delusion. Although marked like Old Spots, they are in fact long-haired pigs - returning migrants from New Zealand.

Julian, the proprietor, explained their provenance - descendants of the livestock carried on wooden-walled naval vessels through the centuries of sail, turned loose and naturalised in the Antipodes; now back in the UK two centuries later. They are grazing pigs, as opposed to rooting pigs, which is the normal habit of all pig breeds native to these isles.

But they also enjoy the windfall apples of late summer and autumn with the same appetite and enthusiasm that I recall our sheep did at the same stage of the year. "They can smell like a cider factory if you're downwind of them," observed their owner. Which is another feature replicated by our flock, who would tuck into a trough of quartered cooking apples with little thought for the internal consequences of fermentation in the complicated digestive arrangements that are necessary to derive nourishment from grass.

Steve Bell is on holiday
