fields.headline: Great balls of fire
fields.trailText: Horizon | Close and True | EastEnders
fields.body:
Those of us who were planning to be in London for New Year's Eve are still smarting with disappointment over the cancelled fireworks. Be patient, though. If we can just wait another three billion years, we're promised the best firework display of all time - the biggest, and certainly the last. For this is the date set by cosmologists in last night's Horizon (BBC2) for the collision of our galaxy with its neighbour, Andromeda. The resulting explosion was the subject of some whizz-bang graphics, all swirling colours and great balls of fire, just in case we couldn't imagine what the end of the world might look like. The graphics software must have gone into meltdown by the time they'd finished the show - after all, when you're making a programme primarily about supermassive black holes, swirling clouds of white-hot gas and events three billion years in the future, there isn't much real footage you can show. Occasionally we saw a smudgy computer print-out or a scientific talking head; needless to say, after one too many ponytails, it was relief to get back to the all those rave graphics.

At the heart of every universe, including our own, lurks a big, hungry black hole, just waiting to suck us all back into oblivion. And if this wasn't alarming enough, Horizon bombarded us with the kind of facts that almost begin to make one feel insignificant. The sun is just one of billions of stars in our galaxy, and our galaxy is just one of hundreds of billions of other galaxies. To bludgeon us further into submission, there was a portentous voice-over and, believe it or not, the Star Trek theme in its full orchestral magnificence. It's difficult to find the right way to present something as abstract and mind-boggling as cosmology on television, but melodrama may not be the best way to go. More appealing was a ghoulish American scientist who, having gazed into his crystal ball, announced that one day, far, far in the future, the atmosphere will evaporate, the seas will boil dry and "the earth will be toast". He seemed delighted.

All of this brought a certain amount of perspective to the rest of the night's viewing, and made it hard to care too much whether or not John Close (Robson Green) managed to make a go of his ailing law firm in ITV's Close and True . Who cares whether fat, miserable misfit Eric is wrongfully imprisoned? Or whether John can't pay the electricity bills? They too are toast. However, it's impossible to watch any Robson Green vehicle without succumbing to the man's charms by the first ad break, and so before long one almost began to care about wronged Eric and chilly John. Green looked like proper husband material in a suit and glasses, and managed to get through the entire episode without taking his shirt off - is this a first?

Newcastle, as depicted in this show, is a simple moral universe where working-class Geordies are good and middle-class southerners are bad. There seemed to be no exception to this rule, which ought to make the lawyer's job a much easier one. We were unsurprised to learn that a young woman who was about to perjure herself and put Eric away for life came from Somerset. Smarmy barrister Heart was also a drawling southern ponce, or, as Eric put it in a rare burst of articulacy, a "devious toffee-nosed git".

The only thing that trumps northerness in the currency of TV dramas these days is Irishness, so we wait with some excitement for John Close's first client from the Emerald Isle.

Back in the land of devious toffee-nosed gits, Sonia faced the aftermath of handing baby Chloe over to social services. One by one her accusers came home to confront her - Jamie, hotfoot from Southend, had a tentative rapprochement on the couch, while Robbie, in a blur of tears and snot, laid about him in frustrated parental affection.

This was the climax of another cracking week in EastEnders (BBC1), with the drama nicely offset by the delicious spectacle of Ian Beale and Nick Cotton having a stand-off in Bridge Street. The episode closed on a downbeat note. Robbie and Sonia sat on the bed, the baby gone, all passion spent. "Jacksons against the world," said Sonia. "We just never seem to win, though."

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | Just out | On the menu | Food on the net
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Lettonie , 35 Kelston Road, Bath, Somerset BA1 3QH. Tel: 01225 446676

There are no lengths to which the Guzzler will not go in search of a bargain, even if it means taking in a double Michelin-starred restaurant. But as Lettonie is prepared to show such daring - a two-course autumn menu for £15 (although, with extras, that could swell) - then so must we. Housed in a Georgian pile, it has a proper (without being stuffy) dining room, with proper waiting staff and a proper complement of appetisers and extras. A "fish and chips" starter came with pert plaice chunks and impossibly thin crisped potato, and an impeccable tartare sauce. Skirt of beef was pink to the core.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Take 5 , 1 Grove Street, Bath, Somerset BA2 6PJ. Tel: 01225 425888

Not formal, not stuffy and not half bad. One visit coincided with a special of hot roast pork, stuffing and apple sauce in a granary bap. And special is exactly what it was: who would have thought crackling could taste so fine in a sandwich? Plenty of other gourmet sandwiches in that vein. Small, raffish interior. There is hardly enough room to queue inside, so take a wander to the river and wonder at the weir.

Just out

M&S king prawn linguini

King prawns with thin ribbons of pasta in a sauce of white wine, tomato and chilli.

Flavour:
Good, clean flavours with a strong whiff of unheralded garlic; prawns there for texture rather than flavour but, then, aren't they always?

Decent stuff, and as trouble-free as could be. Don't even have to add parmesan (never with fish pasta). Couldn't fault the generosity of the quantity of prawns (which tend to hide underneath the linguini, at the bottom of the plastic tray). Could have done with a touch more chilli, and a squeeze of lemon juice woke up the contents no end.

Price:
£4.99 for 600g.

On the menu

Avruga

Are we talking about a foot condition here?
Over my dead bunyions.

So what is it then?
What are they, you mean.

Well, what are they, then?
They are fish eggs.

Caviar?
Of a kind.

Which kind?
The herring kind.

How can I tell if my caviar comes from the supreme sturgeon or the humble herring?
The eggs are smaller, for a start, and dark grey to jet black. And they don't taste a million dollars. Or cost it, either.

How much?
£4.90 per 55g jar.

As against?
£95 per 55g for Sevruga.

Who loves it?
The Spaniards who produce it, and it's all the rage, apparently, among French chefs.

fields.headline: After Damilola, the post-mortem
fields.trailText: Jack Straw talks of a "walk on by" culture, and the need for society to shoulder some of the responsibility for the crimes of this latest lost generation. This is both insulting to those who live in areas such as Peckham, and blind to the fundamentals of the crisis facing our inner cities, and the teenage kids living in them.
fields.body:
Jack Straw talks of a "walk on by" culture (Boy's death spurs attacks on 'culture of thuggery', November 30), and the need for society to shoulder some of the responsibility for the crimes of this latest lost generation. This is both insulting to those who live in areas such as Peckham, and blind to the fundamentals of the crisis facing our inner cities, and the teenage kids living in them.

The Metropolitan police can neither recruit nor retain good officers, and our inner-city schools are staffed by desperate teachers lacking the resources to cater for the special needs of teenage kids surrounded by drug abuse, gangs and poverty. Fear is the reason Damilola Taylor wasn't helped. Lack of confidence in the law is why the police are not called.

The investment in urban regeneration is obviously a positive step, but the government needs to listen to those working on the ground, and direct resources to providing caring human contact for a generation of disenfranchised kids who don't care about themselves, let alone anyone else.
Jonathan Hawkins
London
jonathan@pumpkin.uk.com

 Earlier this year two older boys viciously assaulted my 11-year-old son near our home. His nose was broken, he was knocked unconscious and left bleeding on a main road. Dozens of cars drove past. Eventually he was helped up by a passer-by, who left him to walk home alone.

The police refused to take a statement from my son, to put up witness boards or to investigate this attack properly. The head of the local robbery squad told me that this was because "there was nothing unusual about the incident, it was a schoolboy scuffle".

In our neighbourhood the police seem incapable of seeing black and white boys in working-class areas as anything other than trouble. Their witness board in Peckham even describes Damilola Taylor as a "young man", not as the 10-year-old child that he was.

Jack Straw and David Blunkett need to wake up. Simplistic rhetoric about "walk on by culture", curfews and tagging is cheap. They would do well to look at their own part in the demonisation of children in inner-city areas and to consider the impact of their pronouncements on police and public attitudes.
Alison Higgs
London

 I am afraid your leader misses the point. Bullying is the issue that needs to be addressed, outside school as well as inside - and not only in deprived areas. My eight-year-old son goes to a posh, private school, a couple of miles from Damilola Taylor's school. Since September, my son, a white, middle-class, physically fit child, has been bullied at school. Like Damilola, he has come home asking me what "gay" means.

The school may enforce an anti-bullying policy, but it cannot prevent what goes on outside the gates, especially on the way to and from school. Parents should be made to feel responsible and give a good example. Children should understand that there is nothing to be ashamed of - or potentially dangerous - in reporting anti-social behaviour. The ritual initiation that Damilola's headteacher refers to ("bullying, name calling, every newcomer gets it") is demeaning and should be stamped on.
Name and address supplied

 Damilola's murder cannot be separated from the insecurity and destruction wrought by five years of the biggest single regeneration budget project in the country. Politicians persist in giving money to urban regeneration programmes that are about buildings more than the people who live in an area.

The Peckham Partnership SRB programme will spend at least £260m over seven years, £207m of that on housing. Of the £12m devoted to education, only two projects are non-school based. One is the Peckham library, the other a sports/youth centre for 14 to 23-year-olds.

The SRB project demolished nine community spaces; four new ones have been built, only one of which is easily available for general community use. One community centre has been improved and remains available; it is constantly booked.

There was a community in Peckham but it has been torn apart in the interest of long-term improvement. Yes, it will be a better place to live in the end, but if that takes 10 to 15 years to achieve, and a community takes longer to rebuild than a house, how many children will have been lost?
Pascale Vassie
London
Pascalev@aol.com

 Your leader is right to say that we shouldn't jump to conclusions as a result of one tragedy in Peckham. The neighbourhood has one of the most active regeneration programmes in Britain, tackling poor housing conditions, jobs and crime.

Improving the quality of life in areas like Peckham is a steady grind over a period of years, in which confidence in the area is gradually restored. It can be done, as success stories in equally difficult areas have shown.

Peckham has already suffered a major setback. It certainly doesn't need either the media or politicians condemning those who are actively building a new future for and with its residents.
John Perry
Director of policy, Chartered Institute of Housing
john.perry@cih.org

• This column was amended on 14 January 2015 to remove personal details at the individual's request.

webTitle: A reformed paedophile's plea on behalf of children

fields.headline: A reformed paedophile's plea on behalf of children
fields.standfirst: We must campaign for the resources to offer every sexually damaged individual the  possibility of cure. Only then will all our children be safe
fields.trailText: We must campaign for the resources to offer every sexually damaged individual the possibility of cure. Only then will all our children be safe
fields.body:
Nick Davies' horrifying revelations about the international sex trade in young boys highlight a paradoxical three-sided reality (When sex abuse can lead to murder, November 27). First, attempts by the police and legal system to tackle child abuse are weak and under-resourced. Second, a terrifying pogrom is whipped up against "paedophiles" by the rightwing press. Finally, the curative resources available to treat paedophiles and other sexually distressed people are dreadfully inadequate.

Yet there is a sickening pseudo-rationality behind these contradictions. The protection of powerless children is consistently under-resourced by a governing class whose overwhelming concern is to contain public spending, whilst the mass scapegoating of "paedophiles" serves to revive wider sexual victimisations (of gays and other "perverts") whose political function we have begun to forget with the growing sexual tolerance of recent decades. At the level of public policy, neglect of children and the pogrom against paedophiles are but opposite sides of the same reality: divide and rule.

We need policies which combine toughened repression of child abuse with a massive increase in curative resources directed at those suffering the dreadful burden of a paedophile sexuality.

For your timely report misses out part of the story. There are thousands of paedophiles who have never committed child abuse, and who control their damaged impulses, living lives of fear and self-loathing, unable to access therapeutic resources, despairing of the possibilities of a normal life, yet determined to repress their own deviant sexuality and stop the cycle of sexual damage.

Our language is itself damaged. It is not "paedophiles", per se, who commit crimes against children; it is sexual abusers. This is no nit-picking irrelevance. My own terror of discovery and despair of the possibilities of cure, as a non-abusing paedophile 30 years ago, lost me many vital years, before I was referred to an NHS facility which helped me to reach a normal sexual identity. I do not want any sexually damaged child to grow up to the despair that I suffered.
Name and address supplied

 Nick Davies' concentration on policy and performance statistics seems at odds with the recent prosecution of Gary Glitter and allegations against Jonathan King. The subtext of his articles contain the unasked question: was the reluctance of senior police to investigate fully because of a fear of discovering tendrils leading to respected pillars of the community, people in positions of power or trust, or even members of the police force or judiciary?

As a victim myself, I feel that the robbing of children of their innocence is one of the most pressing issues society should address.
Mark
London

• This article was amended on 22 February 2010 to anonymise the name of the second letter writer, at his request, to help differentiate between his comment and the headline reference to a reformed paedophile.

webTitle: Profile: Roberto Rossellini: sexual adventurer and master film-maker

fields.headline: The Love Pirate
fields.standfirst: Tom Dewe Mathews  on Roberto Rossellini: gambler, sexual adventurer and master film-maker
fields.trailText: Tom Dewe Mathews on Roberto Rossellini: gambler, sexual adventurer and master film-maker
fields.body:
In March 1953, after visiting Ingrid Bergman in Rome, the English author Rebecca West wrote to the Swedish movie star: "You may love your husband very much, but you should face the fact that he has no talent. You have great talent and a great personality, and it is absurd that for the sake of your private emotions you should allow these gifts to be wasted. You will think me an odious woman. But when your husband has made two more films for you, you will remember this letter."

Actually, West was mistaken on more than one count. The Italian director Roberto Rossellini would in fact make only one more feature film with his wife Ingrid Bergman - Journey to Italy - and that would bomb at the box office a year later. Yet now, 47 years later, Martin Scorsese says that Rossellini's 1953 film is "genuinely great" and "one of the most honest portraits of a marriage ever put on film".

So who is right? West was convinced that Rossellini was, "in fact, a cameraman who has worked his way up on a ladder of sheets and blankets." There is some truth in this. While he was never a cameraman, Rossellini was a gambler; a user of people who relied upon scams and unpaid debts to make his films; a sexual adventurer who dumped Bergman when his films failed and straitened circumstances forced her to leave Italy and return to Hollywood; an escape artist who, when he was quizzed by a lover about how he managed to manoeuvre himself between so many marriages, affairs and divorces, replied, "I always keep a window open."

But the "man who knows nothing," as West put it, is also acknowledged as the father of Italian neo-realism, the director who introduced naturalism into world cinema in 1946 with his revolutionary film, Rome, Open City. Then, three years later, Rossellini again tried to change the way we look at films. This time - largely in his films made with Ingrid Bergman, such as Stromboli or Journey to Italy - his aim was to encourage the audience to understand and engage with his actors through an exploration with them of their surroundings on screen. This was in opposition to the more conventional Hollywood method of identifying with the characters on the screen. With Rossellini's way, he claimed, one watches "with one's own eyes".

Maybe Rossellini was expecting too much from his audience, by demanding that they discover his films at the same time as his characters. Anyway, for whatever reason, audiences didn't bite, and all four of his films with Bergman flopped. He was forced to retire from the screen for the next four years until 1958.

This interlude, however, replenished him. "Few film-makers at this stage of their lives or careers were as adventurous or ambitious," notes Scorsese in the preface to a new book, Roberto Rossellini: Magician of the Real. Scorsese adds, "Rossellini's goal was nothing less than to educate the entire world." The method he chose was TV, which he regarded as an overlooked "educational tool" for mass audiences and the means he applied was biopics or "film histories" of cultural heroes from Socrates, Christ and St Augustine through to Pascal, Alberti and Karl Marx, in a proposed film that was cut short by Rossellini's death from a heart attack in 1977.

Rossellini's son Renzo, who collaborated with this father on many of his "historical" films, currently lives in Los Angeles. In halting English he explains his father's approach. "It was impossible to make studio films in Italy towards the end of the war. There was no technical structure, so you had to invent some other way to create the film, to find the light, to find the camera, the film stock - everything."

The solution for Rossellini Sr - who started setting up a film about the Nazi occupation of Rome barely a month after the Germans fled the city in June 1944 - was to become a street hustler. Constantly on the move, Rossellini sold his furniture, begged and borrowed for cameras, and stole his light by running cables from a nearby betting shop to the offices of the US army newspaper Stars and Stripes, with the "friendly complicity" of someone who worked there. With no studios available, he was forced to shoot on the street, using real people in real settings rather than professionals against fake backdrops; and from this moment on, that would be the key to his films - in his words, he would be "leaving things to their authenticity". The way Open City was made immediately reverberated around the world. Suddenly everybody wanted to shoot on location. As Jean-Luc Godard confirmed a decade later: "All roads lead to Rome, Open City."

At the time, however, Rossellini's acclaim did not last long. Indeed, abuse was soon raining down on the innovative director from all sides - first from Italian communists, who were outraged by the ending of Rossellini's first film with Ingrid Bergman, where, as an estranged wife married to a "primitive" fisherman in Stromboli, she shouts in desperation, "God, my God, help me!" That, according to the Italian Communist party, was not the way to react to working-class poverty.

Meanwhile, the rest of Italy despised the director for forsaking their favourite actress, Anna Magnani, the star of Rome, Open City, for Ingrid Bergman. Then, after he and Bergman began their affair in 1949, the Americans started in on "the love pirate", denouncing him - in the words of Edwin Johnson, a Colorado senator of Swedish ancestry - as "a narcotics addict, a Nazi collaborator and black market operator". And as if all that wasn't enough, neither was Bergman particularly happy with her director.

David Forgacs, who has recently written a monograph on Open City for the BFI Classics series, says, "After she split up with Rossellini, Bergman used to regale audiences in America with how difficult it was for her, a professional actress trained in Sweden and Hollywood, to work with the non-professionals Rossellini used in his films.

"When they were making Stromboli," reveals Forgacs, "Rossellini would tie bits of string to the toes of the [real] fishermen and tug them when it was their turn to speak to Bergman. Otherwise they didn't know when to come in. Quite often you get these pauses as though somebody is holding up a cue card. You can almost see the joins in the movie."

With Rossellini, however, there was always a distinctive method underlying any apparent madness. The same year he made Journey to Italy, Rossellini attacked the idea of pre-planned scripts in the style of Hitchcock. That was all right in Hollywood where films were made "purely for entertainment". For "realistic" films, he insisted, inspiration and spontaneity were what mattered. "An author writes a sentence or page, then crosses it out. A painter uses a red, then paints it out with a green. Why shouldn't I be able to cross things out too, to remake and replace film? This is why I don't think you can have a fixed script. If I thought you could, I'd think of myself as a scriptwriter. But I'm not a scriptwriter. I make films."

Yet, in all kinds of other ways, Rossellini is the most fashionable director in world cinema. Certainly, he is one of the most influential. Truffaut's 1959 film, The 400 Blows, which kicked off the French new wave, is a homage to Rossellini's third neo-realist movie, Germany Year Zero; Federico Fellini, who started out as an assistant director to Rossellini, realised that with "the maestro" you could "make a film with the same freedom, the same lightness of spirit with which you might draw or write," while Martin Scorsese reveals that, "The Rise to Power of Louis XIV, which is as close as Rossellini ever got to the gangster genre, was definitely on my mind when I was making Goodfellas."

Closer to home, his son Renzo, who has become a producer in his own right says, "I looked to him like a master. He taught me everything." But maybe his qualities as both a father and a film-maker are summed up best by Renzo's half-sister, Isabella Rossellini, when she said, "As a little child, I thought he was God. Then, as I got older, I had to come down a little bit and say he was a genius."

A season of Rossellini's history films is at Tate Modern from December 1 to 10, and a one-day symposium on Rossellini will take place at the Tate Modern on December 9 (details: 020 7887 8008). Roberto Rossellini: Magician of the Real (BFI, £14.99) is published in December.

Anyway, for whatever reason, audiences didn't bite, and all four of his films with Bergman flopped. He was forced to retire from the screen for the next four years until 1958. This interlude, however, replenished him. "Few film-makers at this stage of their lives or careers were as adventurous or ambitious," notes Scorsese in the preface to a new book, Roberto Rossellini: Magician of the Real. Scorsese adds, "Rossellini's goal was nothing less than to educate the entire world." The method he chose was TV, which he regarded as an overlooked "educational tool" for mass audiences and the means he applied was biopics or "film histories" of cultural heroes from Socrates, Christ and St Augustine through to Pascal, Alberti and Karl Marx, in a proposed film that was cut short by Rossellini's death from a heart attack in 1977. Rossellini's son Renzo, who collaborated with this father on many of his "historical" films, currently lives in Los Angeles. In halting English he explains his father's approach. "It was impossible to make studio films in Italy towards the end of the war. There was no technical structure, so you had to invent some other way to create the film, to find the light, to find the camera, the film stock - everything." The solution for Rossellini Sr - who started setting up a film about the Nazi occupation of Rome barely a month after the Germans fled the city in June 1944 - was to become a street hustler. Constantly on the move, Rossellini sold his furniture, begged and borrowed for cameras, and stole his light by running cables from a nearby betting shop to the offices of the US army newspaper Stars and Stripes, with the "friendly complicity" of someone who worked there. With no studios available, he was forced to shoot on the street, using real people in real settings rather than professionals against fake backdrops; and from this moment on, that would be the key to his films - in his words, he would be "leaving things to their authenticity". The way Open City was made immediately reverberated around the world. Suddenly everybody wanted to shoot on location. As Jean-Luc Godard confirmed a decade later: "All roads lead to Rome, Open City." At the time, however, Rossellini's acclaim did not last long. Indeed, abuse was soon raining down on the innovative director from all sides - first from Italian communists, who were outraged by the ending of Rossellini's first film with Ingrid Bergman, where, as an estranged wife married to a "primitive" fisherman in Stromboli, she shouts in desperation, "God, my God, help me!" That, according to the Italian Communist party, was not the way to react to working-class poverty. Meanwhile, the rest of Italy despised the director for forsaking their favourite actress, Anna Magnani, the star of Rome, Open City, for Ingrid Bergman. Then, after he and Bergman began their affair in 1949, the Americans started in on "the love pirate", denouncing him - in the words of Edwin Johnson, a Colorado senator of Swedish ancestry - as "a narcotics addict, a Nazi collaborator and black market operator". And as if all that wasn't enough, neither was Bergman particularly happy with her director. With Rossellini, however, there was always a distinctive method underlying any apparent madness. The same year he made Journey to Italy, Rossellini attacked the idea of pre-planned scripts in the style of Hitchcock. That was all right in Hollywood where films were made "purely for entertainment". For "realistic" films, he insisted, inspiration and spontaneity were what mattered. "An author writes a sentence or page, then crosses it out. A painter uses a red, then paints it out with a green. Why shouldn't I be able to cross things out too, to remake and replace film? This is why I don't think you can have a fixed script. If I thought you could, I'd think of myself as a scriptwriter. But I'm not a scriptwriter. I make films." Yet, in all kinds of other ways, Rossellini is the most fashionable director in world cinema. Certainly, he is one of the most influential. Closer to home, his son Renzo, who has become a producer in his own right says, "I looked to him like a master. He taught me everything." But maybe his qualities as both a father and a film-maker are summed up best by Renzo's half-sister, Isabella Rossellini, when she said, "As a little child, I thought he was God. Then, as I got older, I had to come down a little bit and say he was a genius."  The Roberto Rossellini season runs from December 2-16 at London's NFT (tickets: 020 7928 3232). A season of Rossellini's history films is at Tate Modern from December 1 to 10, and a one-day symposium on Rossellini will take place at the Tate Modern on December 9 (details: 020 7887 8008). webTitle: Jonathan Glazer: The man who spent a million pounds in 100 seconds

fields.headline: The man who spent a million pounds in 100 seconds
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glazer's TV ads for Guinness are the most expensive ever. And now he's made his first feature film - a brutal gangster movie with Ray Winstone.  Leslie Felperin  asked for details
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glazer's TV ads for Guinness are the most expensive ever. And now he's made his first feature film - a brutal gangster movie with Ray Winstone. Leslie Felperin asked for details
fields.body:
Leslie Felperin: You made TV trailers before commercials. What did you learn from that?

Jonathan Glazer: I didn't want to go into film trailers at all. I had just been pounding the streets after I left poly for close to a year, not really getting very much opportunity. Then I was offered a job cutting film trailers. This involved sitting in a dark basement round a monitor and people would give you really shocking pieces of work - then you'd write a voiceover and cut it down and try and make a two-minute trailer out of it.

Did it help you learn how to come to grips with narrative and how to hone it down into a really short form?

Yes, they did want to give the emphasis of a story. Occasionally you would get ones that had absolutely no story to them, nothing. So we always had this one line that we would start with: "Once in a while along comes a film that is beyond your wildest imagination" - and then you would have just two minutes of shot with a bit of music.

But there are disciplines involved. Obviously. Historically in cinema there are some great film-makers who come from edit suites, from seeing how things cut together and how the significance of a scene or sequence can be changed depending on how you edit it.

How did you make the transition into directing commercials?

The company I was working for occasionally asked us to create little graphics or things like that between trailers, and then I remember trying to convince them to let us shoot little interesting things instead. I just lived for that, really. I cut trailers knowing that a few weeks later I would have a fantastic opportunity to shoot four seconds of film. That was worth getting out of bed for.

And then I started getting a bit more confidence and I went to see a commercials producer. I showed him my stuff and he obviously didn't rate very much of it. But the advice he gave me was to go and try to shoot something I absolutely believed in. And when you witness all the work that's out there, you think - how can I compete? And of course you can compete simply with ideas. It took me a while to learn that.

What was that first personal film?

It was a little short called Mad. I saw it the other day. It's pretty dreadful, looking back on it. It was a two-minute piece and it was very simple. I got it made with an actor that I knew, with friends as crew, and put it together on a Sunday. I did what everybody has to do, where you are directing your film and making the sandwiches and everything else just to try and cut through. It was an odd little thing about some dementia or something. Not too cheerful.

What was your first commercial assignment then?

I met a producer who asked me to do a corporate video for a caravan park in Northampton. This businessman was selling caravans to OAPs: basically persuading them to use their nest egg and come and live in this community. He wanted me to make it look like Barbados - it looked like a muddy field. So that was my first experience of manipulation. But the first actual advert I got was for Kodak. Which I sort of felt was a good thing to do at the time.

Do you feel more a sense of liberty when you're making a pop video, compared to commercials?

Yes, I would say so. Again it depends. If you're making a music video for a boy band, you know, or a manufactured sort of product band, then the record company is going to be all over the director. It's would be the equivalent of making, say, a Persil commercial - where they're saying, you know, light the packet from this angle, because our demographic tells us that if you light it from side or top or whatever, then we will sell. But I think at the other end of it, the best way to do it is with a great band who have got no commercial pressures at all and you can go and mess about with a digital video camera and do something extraordinary. It's the most liberating experience I've ever had. Because it is just you and the artist.

Your surfer commercial for Guinness has been voted the favourite of all time. Where did the concept originate?

It originated with the advertising agency. They came to me with a concept. They'd just won the account for Guinness, which is, I suppose in advertising terms, a famous account. Guinness like doing unusual work, so it's a good one to work on. I remember we had a casting thing that said nobody in this commercial can be under the age of 25 or over the age of 35. And we ended up casting somebody who was 62 as the lead. You have to sort of sneak around the back and cast people who you know are right. And pretend that they're 35 years old. You have to play those little games to get the people you want. And slowly, slowly, they begin to trust you.

Obviously the music is very important. Was that there at the beginning?

We were looking for a track for it, and we found one we liked because it was percussive and simple. We also found a BBC2 recording from about 1956 of Richard Burton reading Under Milk Wood. And the serendipity of the sound track on the images was incredible. And then, unfortunately, the client said nobody will get it. But you've got Dylan Thomas, Richard Burton and Guinness - I mean, it doesn't get any better than that. And he didn't see it, you know? So we kind of wrote our own version of Moby Dick. But I still mourn the loss of that one because that was an amazing find.

I heard you spent ages looking for the right character.

Yes, casting is the key, it's the most critical thing. If the casting is wrong, everything else is irrelevant. Everything around the actor, whether it's the set or the sky or the car or whatever it is, will look like crutches. They'll look like they're trying to support something. It's like a house on quicksand.

I'll chase the right guy. I mean in the Swimmer [Guinness] ad, there's a guy in there who I chased around a harbour in Italy. The day before the shoot, I still hadn't cast. We saw this guy walking around the harbour with his friends - and there was the man we'd been looking for for months. He was a fisherman and we said you've simply got to do this thing. I said to him, you'll save my life if you do this - you have to do it.

There seems to be a real significant climate change at the moment - a crossover between commercials directors and feature film directors.

I think, at best, music videos and commercials can reinvigorate cinema to an extent. Steven Spielberg is using shutter angles that he would never have used had he not seen them in Air commercials. Gladiator and those big movies are using a sort of photographic style of hyper-realism which is very much coming from commercials - not even the most creative end of commercials. I think it is all merging. It is important to look at them as you're graduating from one thing to another.

Working on commercials, you have to make some compromises. Is there the same problem in feature films - you have to deal with compromises with the audience or people lending the money?

Well, making the film was the hardest situation I have been in, certainly. A good one, you know, but very difficult, a lot of new lessons to learn. I'm used to having people around that I really want to work with, that I know and trust as well - you know that your back will be covered. On a feature it's different: the mentality is different, you can't know everybody, you can't have your crew around you in the way you are used to.

What about in terms of story?

I purposely chose something that is very character-led, and not visual, something that is very minimalistic and just based around three central characters, very dialogue-intensive. A lot of the stuff I have been sent has been visual and technique-orientated, but these two writers Louis Mellis and David Scinto are very special, I think, and they write in a way which just intoxicated me. But in terms of budget, my first feature is two and half Guinness ads. The first one, the Surfer, was a million pounds, which is obscene. The cinema version was a 100 seconds long.

Ten thousand per second.

Something like that.

Can you explain how you came to do Sexy Beast?

The film is very simply about a man who lives in Spain who is a retired bank robber and someone comes over to ask him back to London to do a job. No great shakes as a storyline at all. But it's a funny, black sort of character drama with Ben Kingsley and Ray Winstone and Ian McShane.

And for me it was an important first step, because I thought I needed to learn how to work with actors. Louis and David are two theatre writers who have written a number of things, but the only thing that they had before that was made into a film was Gangster No 1.

The writers actually found me, rather than me dig them out. We had a conversation about Gangster No 1 long before Sexy Beast, but the whole process unfortunately spun out of our control, and we ended up leaving the project. It has since been made, as you know.

Was it nice to be given the chance to work with really big names, and to see how much collaboration comes out of just getting them to produce for you on camera?

Absolutely. I have never worked with actors like that before. I found it a very different ball game. The film is really a duel between the Ray Winstone and Ben Kingsley characters which goes on for probably two thirds of the running time. And they needed to understand those rhythms completely for me to have anything to shoot, because if they started improvising within a scene and went away from the script for a second, the scene would somehow fall to bits. All the brutality, all the tension, everything came from the words, and I was really just trying to construct an atmosphere around that. One line of dialogue and eight close-ups, it was that sort of discipline for me. I didn't want the camera to be anything other than architectural.

Did you have a long rehearsal period to get those rhythms just right?

I had nothing. Unfortunately, Ben Kingsley came two weeks late off a film he was shooting in Los Angeles. I got out of the car, the first day of my first film, and they said: "Ben is not here, we are not going to shoot what you thought you were going to shoot." So everything was re-scheduled, there was pressure to recast - it was a very difficult first couple of weeks. The actors hadn't even met one another, but in a sense it kind of worked because Ben Kingsley comes into the film like an alien, like a kind of pollutant. Thankfully, though, they had learned their lines.

 This is an edited extract of the Jonathan Glazer event, part of the onedotzero...reprise at the ICA, for which Guardian Unlimited is a media partner.

fields.headline: Adoption law reform is urgent
fields.standfirst: Felicity Collier of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering calls on the government to  introduce adoption reform legislation in next week's Queen's speech
fields.trailText: Felicity Collier of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering calls on the government to introduce adoption reform legislation in next week's Queen's speech
fields.body:
Adoption has become a major policy issue over the last year, both for the government and the opposition. Successive reports about the failure of the state to ensure the safety of the children it looks after, compounded by information about the very poor prospects for adults who have been in care, have provided a catalyst for change. But what are the problems facing policy makers?

A key challenge to social workers and to courts is how and when to make the decision to sever children legally from their birth family. It is obviously difficult to tell a deeply disadvantaged and failing parent that there will be no more effort to return their child to their care. Some 58% of birth parents contest the adoption of their children in court, and many of the lengthy delays experienced by children in care before they are adopted result from drawn out proceedings.

Ironically, we also know that approximately 16% of children whose birth parents had their rights terminated in court are still without legal parents two years later. There are no families out there for many of these children. The creation of these state orphans will surely be ruled as an abuse of the "right to family life" under the Human Rights Act.

We hear too often about adoptive parents struggling to cope with the challenging behaviour of children who have been traumatised by their early separations and abuse, as well as delays in decisions about their future. Adopters asking for the help and support which can prevent the disruption of their new family are not always given priority because of the lack of a statutory duty on hard pressed local authorities.

Much of this is well understood by government - the prime minister's Cabinet Office report sets out an impressive agenda for change. But the key to achieving this change has to be new adoption legislation. Most care workers agree it is necessary and long overdue; the Adoption Act is outdated and responsible for some of the dilemmas outlined above. We are approaching a general election and awaiting the Queen's speech.

The irony is that we have been here before. In 1996 the previous Government published a draft adoption bill for consultation which would have made a real difference. BAAF and others lobbied for it to be included in the November Queen's speech prior to the May 1997 election, but it was left out. The Labour shadow secretary of state for health offered a deal to the Conservatives to smooth its passage if it could be squeezed into the legislative agenda. Nothing happened. I remember Chris Smith in December 1996 saying it was a "bit rich" of the government to blame social workers for failing to provide good enough adoption services when they had failed to bring in the legislation.

Adoption is not a simple issue. Despite general cross-party agreement about much of the content of legislation, it is unlikely to have an easy ride. Too many campaigners on the right see the adoptive family as representing the "ideal" family unit for our society - married, heterosexual and financially secure. Any consideration of single parents and gay and lesbian parents is anathema to their vision. Race is seen by some commentators as a "non-issue". Any preference for placing children with families of a similar ethnic background is viewed as mere political correctness and racially divisive nonsense. Providing adoptive parents with financial support is also questioned by those who still have visions of the adopted child as a "gift" which they believe should be a nil cost to the state.

These conflicts raise their heads in many forms in many debates. Let us hope the government does not allow them to obscure the vital issues for children who could benefit from adoption - and cuts across any further delay by introducing legislation next month.

Too many campaigners on the right see the adoptive family as representing the "ideal" family unit for our society - married, heterosexual and financially secure. Any consideration of single parents and gay and lesbian parents is anathema to their vision. Race is seen by some commentators as a "non-issue". Any preference for placing children with families of a similar ethnic background is viewed as mere political correctness and racially divisive nonsense. Providing adoptive parents with financial support is also questioned by those who still have visions of the adopted child as a "gift" which they believe should be a nil cost to the state. These conflicts raise their heads in many forms in many debates. Let us hope the government does not allow them to obscure the vital issues for children who could benefit from adoption - and cuts across any further delay by introducing legislation next month.

fields.headline: La Donna del Lago
fields.standfirst:
St John's, London
**
fields.trailText:
St John's, London
**
fields.body:
There are some long-haul Rossini operas that should come with the same kind of health advice as cross-Atlantic flights; be sure to wriggle your feet every now and then, as people are not intended to sit still for that length of time. La Donna del Lago, based on Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake, is just such a work. Though popular in London in the years following its composition in 1819, the work wasn't revived until the Camden Festival staged it in 1969, casting in the demanding role of Elena a promising young soprano called Kiri te Kanawa.

Following such a period of neglect, Midsummer Opera's decision to revive La Donna del Lago is in many ways to be applauded. The music may not be Rossini at his very best but at times it's close. There's a beautiful duet for the heroine Elena and her lover Malcolm, who is sung by a mezzo soprano, while the arias, especially those for Elena and for her unwanted suitor Rodrigo, are appealing to the ear and at times breathtaking in the demands they make on the singers. Although Mozart had shown the opera world how to get through a libretto wittily and concisely 30 years earlier, the trend in Rossini's Italy was for staggeringly florid vocal lines, and this composer was not one to fly in the face of fashion.

Yet the length of the piece and the complexity of some of its writing made it ultimately an overambitious choice for this company. The greatest disadvantage was for the orchestra and chorus, a mix of professionals and amateurs. With so very many pages to get through, rehearsal time had been limited. Too often there was poor intonation from the orchestra or a ragged choir entry; too many moments of potentially high drama passed without causing a stir. Conductor David Roblou kept the music unfolding at a good pace but didn't seem able to get as much out of his players as he might have wished.

However, as always in Rossini's operas, the soloists were the focus of attention, and several were impressive. John Upperton threw out Rodrigo's scintillating high Cs with apparent ease, while Katy Bingham-Best gave a creditable performance as Malcolm, despite a tendency for her tone to grow harsh. But it was Emma Dogliani who captivated the audience, her voice warming into Elena's vocal acrobatics as the evening went on. Nobody was quite as communicative as Ivan Garcia, the imposing Douglas; however, with no translation to hand, the details of his lines were lost on those in the audience who didn't speak Italian.

webTitle: Hollywood studios race to show movies over the net

fields.headline: Hollywood studios race to show movies over the net
fields.trailText: As Sony finishes work on a film internet site that should be operational by next year, Disney and 20th Century Fox join forces to create their own site
fields.body:
While UK internet users are still awaiting the arrival of affordable and reliable broadband connections that will make it possible to watch a 10-minute short, let alone a feature length film, US studios are planning to deliver entire feature films straight to consumers on the net.

The Los Angeles Times and the Wall Street Journal both report that Sony is currently working on a movie site that should become operational next year. Disney and 20th Century Fox are jointly working on a separate site, and Paramount may yet become involved in their venture.

Yair Landau, president of Sony Pictures Digital Entertainment, confirmed the studio's plans, telling The Wall Street Journal: "People want to see movies on the internet, and we, along with other studios, plan to give them a chance to do that."

Although the internet has made little or no impact on western audiences' cinema-going and video-watching habits, this development could finally bring the change in attitudes that so many have been predicting. As the LA Times notes, this "could eventually change the economics throughout the movie industry, affecting cinemas, video stores and television networks that rely on current releases."

Sony's system will allow consumers to download an average feature via high-speed telephone or cable lines in about an hour.

fields.headline: Munich Philharmonic/ Levine
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Barbican Hall, London
**
fields.body:
James Levine took over as music director of the Munich Philharmonic at the beginning of the 1999-2000 season. It was a surprising career move by a conductor who, as artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera in New York, already occupied one of the most powerful positions in the musical world, for the Munich Philharmonic would never feature in a list of Europe's leading orchestras. Their appearance together at the Barbican confirmed their status as more of a promotion contender from the Nationwide First Division than a Premier League band in their own right.

Whether Levine will be able to give the orchestra the time needed to ensure that promotion remains to be seen. At present there are some fine features to their playing - especially the characterful wind, very central European in its sound, and the tonal depth of the strings in sustained passages - but also some worrying insecurities, which were revealed in Berg's Three Orchestral Pieces more than the Mozart and Tchaikovsky symphonies that flanked them in the programme.

Levine's Mozart, though, is not to everyone's taste. Using an orchestra with five double basses and 14 first violins, this was a brazenly conservative account of the E Flat Symphony No 39, the kind of interpretative anachronism one thought had collapsed under the weight of its own absurdity years ago. Themes in the first movement were presented with Brahmsian monumentality, the Andante was full of slithery, over-manicured phrasing, the rhythms of the finale galumphed where they should have danced. All perfectly horrid, but at least the concert could only improve from that deeply unpromising start.

It did to a certain extent in the Berg, for Levine inhabits that expressionist world very securely. But the lines were never teased out with the clarity they need, and uncertainties in some of the playing, especially in the final March, took the edge off an internal drama that really should grab the audience by the throat. Only in Tchaikovsky's Pathétique Symphony did the Munich Philharmonic really begin to show their true worth. The sound was often magnificent - rich and gleaming, the woodwind and brass contributions incisive - but there was still something rather stolid about it all: rhythms that remained earthbound, phrases that were sculpted when they should have been sung; not inventive, inspirational music-making at all.

fields.headline: Le Tigre
fields.standfirst:
Garage, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Garage, London
*****
fields.body:
The room is packed with teen girls and young women, all squealing and seething with sexual desire. The object of their giddy affections isn't a ditzy male heart-throb such as Craig David or Robbie Williams, however, but a sharp, opinionated, fervent punk activist called Kathleen Hanna. In the early 1990s, long before the Spice Girls figured out that the words "girl power" could be an effective marketing tool, Hanna was a key player in the empowering riot grrrl movement. Fronting the band Bikini Kill, she scrawled "slut" across her belly and raged against the inequalities behind such a word. If she is calmer these days, it's only in appearance: the anger and conviction that fire her performance with her new band Le Tigre are as fierce and exhilarating as ever.

Joined by guitarist Johanna Fateman (ragged peroxide hair and thrift-store chic) and keyboardist Sadie Benning (absent tonight, and replaced by an androgynous-looking person called JD), Hanna aims to merge politics with pop in a manner that has been scoffed at for decades. Le Tigre's manifesto is encapsulated in Slideshow at Free University: it didn't sound like much on last year's debut album, but live, accompanied by images of protest marches, it's a stimulating piece of work. Over a hypnotic, gloopy groove, a man's voice intones: "We favour the simple expression of the complex thought."

The trio's music is correspondingly basic: a gritty garage-pop assault of scrawling guitar and pogo rhythms, against which gender, race and sexual politics are distilled into shout-along anthems, incomprehensibly but coruscatingly yelped by Hanna, attacking New York mayor Rudy Giuliani in My My Metrocard, the misogyny of film-maker John Cassavetes in What's Yr Take on Cassavetes, and the artists who contribute nothing to social change in The Empty. The results could be glib, but Le Tigre are too passionate, too committed for that to be the case. A new song about racism ends with the trio chanting the numbers from one to 41, the number of times the west African immigrant Amadou Diallo was shot by New York police. It's simple but brutally effective.

"The artists," continues the voice on Slideshow, "wanted [their art] to be something to be involved in." And so Hanna and Fateman introduce each song with spirited rallying cries inspiring their audience to engage in politics, to fight against discrimination, be it on the internet, on the streets, in a joke or in a pop song. In return, the panting young ladies in the front rows take up an incessant chant: "Kathleen, you rock." There's something disappointingly inane about their reaction - they almost deserve the Spice Girls instead. Then again, that might be the most brilliant thing about Le Tigre: they can be political without being po-faced; they can discuss weighty issues and be go-go dancing at the same time. They are serious and playful and the kind of role models every teenage girl needs.

 Le Tigre play the 13th Note, Glasgow (0141-243 2177), tomorrow.

webTitle: Keeping a rein on building cowboys

fields.headline: Keeping a rein on building cowboys
fields.trailText: After the weather and property prices, they're probably one of the nations' favourite topics of conversation, but a new internet company hopes to send cowboy builders galloping off into the sunset.
fields.body:
After the weather and property prices, they're probably one of the nations' favourite topics of conversation, but a new internet company hopes to send cowboy builders galloping off into the sunset.

For a fee ranging between £29.99 and £59.99, consultants at QuoteCheckers will analyse three quotes from builders and will advise, within seven days which provides the best value for money in terms of price and service.

It can also assign a personal consultant who can help draw up any building plans and talk to builders on a client's behalf.

Christian Lamoy, one of the founders of the company explains the rationale: "Homeowners shouldn't let the builder confuse them. With us, you can have someone on your side asking the right questions and getting the right answers. We can even give you help with setting out stage payments or the correct amounts to hold as retention. It's like having a builder in the family."

Alternatively, if a job is relatively small, the company runs a free DIY email service. An emailed query will be replied to within a few hours with answers and advice.

The company says builders rip off one in five homeowners and unless without a builder in the family it can be hard to judge which is the best one to use. Further, says Quotecheckers, one-stop-shop services which get a variety of quotes for you are not always as independent as they seem, and may get payments and perks on the sly from builders they are supposed to select independently.

To avoid such a proble, QuoteCheckers says it won't be recommending builders, just giving an analysis of the quotes already received.

fields.headline: Thunderbirds FAB
fields.standfirst:
Playhouse, London
**
fields.trailText:
Playhouse, London
**
fields.body:
After a nail-biting delay of the kind that International Rescue would surely never countenance, and just when it looked as if the mission might be aborted, Andrew Dawson and Gavin Robertson flew into the West End in another daring attempt to cash in on the current Thunderbirds revival.

The duo's show began almost 20 years as a small-scale Scottish tour of obscure arts centres but quickly became a cult hit, and it has been in and out of the West End since 1989. This revival offers the opportunity to watch at least three generations of small boys, both on the stage and in the audience, enjoying themselves while wearing silly hats.

The evening begins with Space Panorama, a tabletop recreation of the 1969 lunar landing. Robertson provides a commentary that is an enter taining mix of the portentous and the ironic, while Dawson's hands play all the characters as well as rockets, clouds, moon and so on. Dawson's hands would pass an audition for Rada without the rest of him attached, and part of the pleasure of this piece is watching his inventiveness and technical brilliance.

Yet the 25-minute piece, more rewarding when seen in an intimate setting, is clearly only a filler to extend the evening to a standard West End length and allow for a profitable interval that lasts longer than the first half of the performance. Then it is down to the main event. Except that it never feels like a main event. Thunderbirds FAB is an affectionate, good-natured show with really funny moments, but it seems like the sort of thing you'd have caught in an arts centre 20 years ago. That's even allowing for Graham Johnston's nifty, low-key design and Jon Linstrum's clever lighting, which give the show a bit of a gloss.

Otherwise this is basically a comedy of recognition and nostalgia that gets its laughs from Dawson's ability to recreate a marionette walk and the immobile features of Gerry Anderson's original creations, what with Lady Penelope as a guy in drag and Captain Scarlet a drag in red.

It is all enjoyable enough, but who it is really for? The humour is surely too unsophisticated and the send-up too underplayed to really appeal to adults, while the five-year-old fans of the current TV reruns seem to take it deadly seriously and haven't heard of irony. If your hopes of getting Tracy Island for Christmas are doomed, a ticket to this is unlikely to bring solace.

 Booking to January 21. Box office: 020 7316 4747.
